DOC.HEAD: Smithsonian Doesn't Want Bus; Original in a Field
DOC.TEXT: When Ken Kesey regrouped the old Merry Pranksters to drive across the country and maybe donate his psychedelic bus to the Smithsonian Institution, he had another trick up his sleeve. The bus currently on the road isn't the one that drove into the lore of the psychedelic 1960s. It's a newer model incorporating parts of the old and the Smithsonian doesn't want it, institution spokeswoman Madeleine Jacobs said Thursday. Kesey and the Merry Pranksters became heroes when Tom Wolfe chronicled their 1964 trip aboard the bus, named Further, in his ``Electric Kool-Aid Acid Test.'' Kesey was a bright new literary light then from his novels ``One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest'' and ``Sometimes a Great Notion.'' This week, Kesey and some of the old gang boarded a wildly painted bus, also named Further. Kesey said they were headed for the Smithsonian in Washington, D.C., though he wasn't sure he'd give up the bus now since he was having such fun with it. Along the way, he's promoting his new book, ``The Further Inquiry,'' in which the soul of Neal Cassady is put on trial. Cassady was Further's driver, and the inspiration for the driver in author Jack Kerouac's ``On the Road.'' ``The truth is, we had no direct knowledge of his intention to give the bus to (the Smithsonian) other than what we had been reading in the paper,'' Jacobs said from Washington. ``A few years ago, some of our curators talked to some potential fund-raisers about the possibility of purchasing or acquiring the original bus used by Ken Kesey and restoring it. But we were never successful in reaching Mr. Kesey directly. ``The current bus he is using is not even close to the original,'' she added. ``Even if it were, the Smithsonian is not interested in a replica.'' Jacobs said the Smithsonian also was concerned that Kesey was invoking its name without permission. At a stop in Berkeley, Calif., Kesey denied he had tried to pass off the 1947 International school bus as the 1939 original. He said the driver's seat and other parts from the original were put into the newer bus. Back home at his farm in Pleasant Hill, the rusted hulk of the original Further sits in a field. Kesey said he was miffed at the Smithsonian for never contacting him when it was interested in restoring his original bus. ``I thought it was a little presumptuous of them, and it was time they deserved a little pranking,'' he said. As for Smithsonian officials, Jacobs said they could take a joke, but wanted the public to know neither Kesey bus was bound for the museum. ``While we appreciate Mr. Kesey's view, which we think is fun - we need more humor in our lives - we want the general public to know that is not the case.''

DOC.HEAD: Hard Fight for Polish Presidency
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: It's a tough campaign for president, barbed with Polish humor, between the earthy shipyard worker who founded Solidarity and the somber, laconic intellectual he chose as prime minister. What do Poles think of the contest between Lech Walesa and Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki in their first popular vote for the presidency? Some call it Cham vs. Hamlet. Cham, pronounced ``ham,'' is Polish for bumpkin. Others have asked: Will Mazowiecki declare his candidacy before or after the election? Then there's the story of a problem Walesa had when he wanted to reserve a burial site in Jerusalem next to Jesus Christ. He found the cost was $150,000, it goes, and said to his top aide: ``I don't know, Krzysiek. Is it worth it for only three days?'' The duel between Eastern Europe's first non-Communist head of government and the man who gave him the job has rekindled interest in politics after months of hand-wringing by commentators over post-Communist apathy. Nearly all conversations turn sooner or later to the question of which one will occupy Belweder Palace, seat of Polish presidents. A man was even killed in a drunken dispute with his son-in-law over who would be the better president, the state news agency reported. Poland held parliamentary elections in June 1989 that were largely free and democratic local elections in May, but this is the first real contest because Solidarity candidates swept the earlier votes. Surveys indicate the two former Solidarity allies are running about even. Other candidates have ventured into the ring, including Roman Bartoszcze of the Peasant Party and Wlodzimierz Cimoszewicz of the Social Democrats, formerly the Communists, but only Walesa and Mazowiecki are given a real chance. If neither gets 50 percent of the votes Nov. 25, a runoff will be held Dec. 9. Part of the fascination stems from their contrasting styles. Walesa is electric, speaking rapidly, seeming to bob and weave through questions thrown at him from the crowd. Mazowiecki is ``grey on grey'' in the words of one newspaper, shy and ponderous in speech but exuding character and moral authority. Walesa declared early and began an aggressive campaign immediately with meetings at factories, where he is strong, and with academics, Mazowiecki's turf. In the first three weeks of October, Walesa visited nine cities, saw more than 100,000 people and was seen by millions more on television. Local Solidarity chapters organize his Western-style rallies, held outdoors or in large arenas with banners, brass bands and deafening loudspeakers. Mazowiecki made his first campaign appearance Oct. 14, two weeks after Walesa, in the Krakow Philharmonic Hall, which seats only 800 people. Instead of direct questions from the crowd, he took written ones that were rephrased by his campaign spokesman. The prime minister seems hesitant about contact with strangers. Hundreds of people waited outside the hall in Krakow for two hours and Mazowiecki rewarded them with only a few minutes on the balcony, his stilted words of thanks barely audible through a bullhorn. His dedication to his job, evident in his tired, careworn appearance, earns sympathy even from people who say they will vote for Walesa. After becoming prime minister in August 1989, Mazowiecki set a considered, pragmatic course that won respect abroad and gave Poles a sense of security against the sudden shocks of revolutionary change. To many, however, Mazowiecki's government has seemed to drag its feet, allowing former secret police to destroy records and keeping Communist ministers in the government half a year after the party dissolved. In his campaign, Walesa advocates faster change and has been quoted as intending to use a ``sharp axe'' to chop away vestiges of the old system. He and Mazowiecki also appear to disagree about policy toward the Communist leadership. When he took office, the prime minister spoke of drawing a line between present and past, but Walesa has said he wants to ``settle accounts'' with those who have injured Poland or stolen from it. If Walesa becomes president, Mazowiecki says, he will join the opposition. Walesa replies that he already has five other candidates for prime minister. Critics accuse Walesa of currying favor with the mob, promising easy solutions he cannot deliver and becoming a demagogue who could abuse the still-fragile democracy and frighten off Western investors. ``I'll vote for Mazowiecki because, under his presidency, I can sleep peacefully,'' Adam Michnik, a former Walesa adviser, told a rally. ``If someone knocks at my door at 5 in the morning, it can only be the milkman.'' ``Walesa is as suitable to be president as I am to be a radio announcer,'' Michnik, now editor of Gazeta Wyborcza, Poland's leading daily newspaper, said in a recent broadcast. Michnik spoke with his usual stutter. Walesa wished him luck in radio.

DOC.HEAD: Mexico's President Says Happy Economic Days Are Here Again
DOC.TEXT: President Carlos Salinas de Gortari declared Thursday that his reform program has propelled Mexico out of its economic crisis, and he defended his decision to negotiate a free-trade accord with the United States. But his comments, made in a state-of-the-union address, were repeatedly interrupted by shouts of opposition lawmakers. ``We have left fear and weariness behind,'' he told this nation of 81 million people in the nationally broadcast speech. He assured Mexicans their jealously guarded national sovereignty would survive a free trade pact, the economic opening of Mexico's borders, and the privatization of state businesses like banks and telecommunications. ``Today, new channels are open to Mexican nationalism,'' he said. Salinas took office in December 1988 during a protracted financial crsis provoked in part by the worldwide plunge in oil prices six years earlier. ``Today, we have left behind the most serious aspects of the crisis, such as the foreign debt, and we are focusing our attention on growth and justice,'' he said Thursday. The president also stressed stability, one of the proudest boasts of his Institutional Revolutionary Party. The party has governed Mexico for 61 years. ``Mexico has made significant progress. The economy is recovering and has remained stable,'' he said. ``The political system, despite the pressures to which it has been subjected, has maintained internal order and been able to accomplish major tasks.'' Lawmakers from the conservative National Action Party and the center-left Democratic Revolutionary Party interrupted his more than two-hour speech with jeers and shouts ten times. ``Salinas: More Misery and Hunger in the Countryside,'' said a bedsheet-sized banner held aloft by two opposition deputies. The president's comments about his administration's electoral reform provoked one of the loudest outbursts. ``Total repudiation of electoral fraud!'' shouted lawmakers from the Democratic Revolutionary Party, which says the governing party's reforms of election procedure are insufficient to deter vote fraud. The president, however, forged ahead without acknowledging opposition outbursts. He received hearty applause from supporters. Salinas' ambitious economic reforms have been called a Mexican version of Soviet perestroika. The president is opening a protected economy, divesting the state of burdensome industries, trying to lure foreign investors, and hoping to make Mexico a full-fledged competitor in the changing world economy. In his speech, the 42-year-old, Harvard-trained economist said he has eliminated the fiscal deficit, increased social spending, made the tax burden fairer, and reduced the foreign debt from 60 percent of the gross national product to 40 percent.

DOC.HEAD: After Beating Oppression at Home, New Czech Envoy Fights Own Cancer
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: While her country celebrates the end of a half century struggling under dictatorship, Rita Klimova finds herself in a lonely new struggle. Last year's peaceful revolution in Czechoslovakia elevated her from hardship and obscurity to prominence and a challenging new post. As post-Communist Czechoslovakia's first ambassador to Washington, she was to be the voice of a democracy reborn after a long night of Nazi and Stalinist repression. But she had barely settled into her 10-room ambassadorial residence when high fever and what felt like severe flu sent her to a hospital. After weeks of uncertainty and no improvement, she was diagnosed as having leukemia, a cancer of the white blood cells that can be fatal. Some doctors speculated that Klimova had one of the thousands of cases of cancer attributable to radioactive fallout from the 1986 Chernobyl nuclear accident in the Soviet Ukraine. ``Who's to say?'' she said. ``They asked me routinely if I have been exposed to radioactive material and I said no, except for the Chernobyl thing.'' Mrs. Klimova, 58 and a widow, agonized in a July newspaper interview about whether she should return home to avoid saddling her government with huge bills for periodic, prolonged chemotherapy treatments in U.S. hospitals. She said she might stay if she could be fitted ``into someone's research plans.'' The article helped get her admitted as a patient at the oncology center of Baltimore's Johns Hopkins Hospital, she said later. It is one of 21 facilities in the United States for comprehensive cancer therapy. ``I sort of panicked when I found out about leukemia,'' Mrs. Klimova recalled in an interview. To boost her morale she invited her son, a 24-year-old Prague journalist, to visit. They toured the Manhattan neighborhood where she lived with her parents during World War II, perfecting English with a New York accent. The son, Vladimir Mlynar, stayed through her first week of chemotherapy. ``When they actually give you chemotherapy, you feel miserable, and his last words to me after that very trying week, were, `we licked the communists and you've got to lick this,' and then he left,'' she said. Mrs. Klimova spent most of August in the hospital. There, she dealt with her mail and maintained telephone contact with her staff and Capitol Hill seeking support for the most important legislation affecting Czechoslovakia - restoration of U.S. import concessions for goods from friendly countries, known as most-favored-nation treatment. The ambassador estimates the concessions could boost exports to the United States - $82 million in 1989 - by $1.7 million a month. ``For Czechoslovakia,'' she said, ``that's a lot of money.'' Restoration of the concessions had been expected in the spring, after the two countries concluded a trade agreement. But the follow-up authorization got caught in Congress' annual logjam, and it finally was cleared on Oct. 24. Mrs. Klimova was back in the hospital at the time, undergoing a six-week siege of chemotherapy expected to last well into November. She hopes it will be the last interruption to her new job. ``I was lucky to have a foreign minister who is willing to put up with an ambassador who occasionally pulls a disappearing act,'' Mrs. Klimova said. She and the foreign minister, Jiri Dienstbier, go way back. ``She was once my teacher'' at Charles University, he said. But her life changed after the 1968 Warsaw Pact invasion that ended the brief reform period dubbed the ``Prague Spring.'' Mrs. Klimova lost her economics professorship in the post-invasion purge of thousands of reform-minded Czechoslovaks. She worked later as a freelance translator and became active in the Charter 77 dissident movement along with playwright Vaclav Havel, now the Czech president, and Dienstbier. Both men spent time in prison for such activity. Mrs. Klimova became well-known as the English language translator and spokeswoman of Civic Forum, Havel's popular movement, when foreign television crews and journalists crowded into Prague during the 1989 peaceful revolution that ended communist rule. ``Then, all of a sudden, I found myself in the States in such wonderful circumstances until this disease came,'' she said. ``I hope I can get it out of the way, and then really get down to my job as ambassador.''

DOC.HEAD: 7-Year-Old Who Died Trick-or-Treating Suffered Heart Defect
DOC.TEXT: A 7-year-old girl who collapsed while trick-or-treating died of a congenital heart defect, not because of poisoned candy, authorities said. Ariel Katz, 7, collapsed and died while trick-or-treating Wednesday night with friends and two chaperones. Police had said they were checking candy the girl had eaten to see if it was poisoned, and they urged parents to withhold sweets collected in the area where she had been trick-or-treating. But the Los Angeles County coroner attributed the death to an enlarged heart, police Sgt. Bill Brucker said Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Don't Mess With Linda Hooper
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: If there are any male chauvinist pigs still on the prowl, they'd better steer clear of Linda Hooper, the Annie Oakley of the FBI. She looks every inch the all-American woman until she opens her glen plaid jacket to reveal a black, .38-caliber Smith & Wesson five-shot revolver tucked demurely in her skirt waist. It would be just the thing for silencing the jeers of hard hats perched in the sky, or quickly cooling the ardor of subway mashers. But Mrs. Hooper, who is 39 and married to another FBI special agent, says macho men never bother her. Besides, she says, agents never play around with guns. ``We only shoot when our life or someone else's life is in danger,'' says the Orange County, Calif., native who grew up plinking tin cans with her grandfather's .22-caliber squirrel rifle. In her six years with the FBI, Mrs. Hooper has never fired her gun, even while chasing bank robbers, drug pushers, kidnappers and plane hijackers during her first assignment in Portland, Ore. ``But I've been in situations where I've pulled it and pointed it,'' she says, ``and I will use it if I have to.'' A member of an elite club of sharpshooters among the FBI's 982 female agents, Mrs. Hooper is in charge of the indoor shooting range at FBI headquarters. There she demonstrates her firearm skills for the half-million visitors who tramp through the building annually on the most popular guided tour in Washington. Crouching with feet wide apart, Mrs. Hooper shreds the torso of a silhouette target with noisy bursts from such FBI weapons as the Sig Sauer P-226 9mm semiautomatic pistol and the lightweight Heckler & Koch MP-5 fully automatic submachine gun, which can turn a miscreant into mincemeat at 800 rounds per minute. As a sentimental gesture, she occasionally fires a .45-caliber Thompson submachine gun, the notorious ``Tommy gun'' favored by gangsters in the 1920s and 1930s which was retired from the FBI arsenal in 1979. Interviewed next to a glass case containing the straw hat, eyeglasses and cigar found on gangster John Dillinger's body the night he was gunned down in Chicago in 1934, Mrs. Hooper said her sex has helped rather than hindered her work as an FBI agent. ``I like it the way it is because I consider being a woman as my cover,'' she said. Even though male FBI agents outnumber female agents by 10-1, she said, women sometimes can outperform men in dangerous situations. She mentioned the time she tricked a suspected Portland bank robber into opening his apartment door and submitting to quick, visual surveillance without arousing his suspicion. She doubts that a male agent wearing a business suit could have done the same thing. ``When I go up to your door, you'll think I'm selling Avon or Tupperware. You won't think I'm an FBI agent,'' she said. ``When I asked the bank robber if he knew where `Julie' was, he thought I was some dumb broad.'' Even so, being a woman does have its drawbacks. ``I don't like those short women's jackets that are so fashionable these days, because it's hard to carry your gun under them,'' Mrs. Hooper said. And the skirts without belt loops have forced her to use a clip-on holster. Mrs. Hooper is no trigger-happy TV cop but a proud, no-nonsense professional who hopes the visiting school children who watch her firearms display won't get the wrong idea. ``We're not trying to glamorize guns in any way, but they're part of what our job is all about,'' she said. ``I always tell the kids that if they find a gun at a friend's house or on the street, don't touch it. Guns are very dangerous.''

DOC.HEAD: Arab Diplomacy Unlikely To Win Iraqi Pullout
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Soviet proposals for an Arab diplomatic solution to the gulf crisis are unlikely to succeed, but could be the last buffer against war, Arab and Western observers say. ``There is no Arab solution,'' said a well-connected Saudi businessman, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``The time isn't right and the Arabs are too divided. Saddam thinks time is in his favor.'' Foreign ministers from Saudi Arabia, Egypt and Syria met in the Saudi summer capital of Jiddah Wednesday night to discuss Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's proposal for an emergency Arab summit. Few details about the talks filtered out. ``I don't see the Arab solution as being different from the international solution'' by the United Nations, said a Western diplomat in Riyadh, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak, one of the first Arab leaders to align against Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, noted previous Arab summits failed to come up with a workable solution. Saudi newspapers quoted Mubarak as saying the meeting would become ``a summit of insults.'' Cairo's state-owned Al-Ahram newspaper wrote that Gorbachev's proposal serves Saddam's ``strategy of stalling, in the belief that time is on his side.'' After Saddam sent his troops into Kuwait Aug. 2, U.N. resolutions have demanded an unconditional pullout from the oil-rich emirate and imposed an economic embargo on Iraq. There was widespread confusion about Saudi intentions last week when the defense minister, Prince Sultan, referred to previous territorial concessions made by Saudi Arabia in border disputes with his neighbors. Some interpreted his remarks as a hint that Riyadh was willing to compromise over Iraq's demands for a strip of northern Kuwait as well as the two Kuwaiti islands of Warba and Bubiyan. They dominate Iraq's access to the Persian Gulf and have long been coveted by Baghdad. Prince Sultan issued a statement saying he had been misinterpreted. King Fahd stressed Saudi demands for an unconditional Iraqi pullout has not changed. The Soviet Union was Iraq's principal arms supplier during the 8-year war against Iran and the two countries have a friendship treaty. Gorbachev's envoy, Yevgeny Primakov, has traveled to Baghdad twice to meet with Saddam in search of a diplomatic solution. But Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze said the latest mission failed. That did not prevent Gorbachev from hinting in Paris that Iraq may be softening its stand. He warned against rushing toward a military solution, saying the coming days ``might bring some clarification'' of a change in Iraq's position. In one version, reported last month by the Soviet news agency Novosti, Primakov was quoted as saying Iraq might withdraw from most of Kuwait if it could keep the northern strip and the two islands. Saddam has annexed Kuwait and declared it Iraq's 19th province. But he has attached the islands and the northern strip, whose oil wells are an extension of Iraq's Rumailah field, to Iraq's Basra province. Iraq denied it was contemplating making a deal to keep the territories. The Saudis, the United States and the Kuwaiti government-in-exile have rejected any such solution. Adding to the tense mood, Saudi Arabia's pro-government Asharq al-Awsat daily reported the meeting of Arab foreign ministers in Jiddah under the headline ``Gulf Crisis Heats Up.'' The secretary-general of the six-nation Gulf Cooperation Council, Abdullah Bishara of Kuwait, told reporters earlier in the week that war would erupt in the gulf soon unless a diplomatic solution were found. ``We're very close to the last chapter of diplomatic activities,'' he said. ``I think we'll be very close to the chapter of inferno.'' ---= EDITOR'S NOTE: Martin Marris is based in Bahrain and has covered the Middle East for four years.

DOC.HEAD: Cruise, Fox, Sununu Stand Tall on List of Best-Dressed Short Men
DOC.TEXT: Actors Tom Cruise and Michael J. Fox and White House Chief of Staff John Sununu are short in stature but tall on style, said a clothier who put them on his list of the ``10 Best-Dressed Shorter Men in America.'' Bob Stern, the 5-foot-2 president of Short Sizes Inc., said he created the annual list four years ago to ``highlight that short men can dress for success.'' Cruise and Sununu are the tallest short men on the list. Both just reach 5-foot-9, the maximum height for the list. Cruise is a trendsetter who has turned black sunglasses and black silk shirts into a national passion, while Sununu ``never beats around the bush'' in both politics and dress, Stern said. Fox, 5-foot-5, was named to the list for the third consecutive year for ``charmingly combining a tux jacket and shirt with washed jeans and tennis shoes,'' Stern said. Others listed, in ``descending'' order, are novelist Tom Wolfe and the former host of television's ``This Old House,'' Bob Vila, both 5-foot-8; singer Billy Joel, Broadway actor Robert Morse and Cleveland Mayor Michael R. White, 5-foot-7; gymnast and television sports analyst Bart Connor, 5-foot-6; and actor-director Danny DeVito, 5-foot-1.

DOC.HEAD: More Than 1.5 Million People Displaced by Crisis
DOC.TEXT: More than 1.5 million people have been displaced by the Persian Gulf crisis, World Bank officials and other sources say. And hundreds of thousands of workers from the Third World remain in Iraq and Kuwait. The numbers dwarf the approximately 1,000 hostages from the United States, 1,400 from Britain and 3,000 from the Soviet Union. Hundreds of thousands of others are returning to their distant homelands, some as far away as the Philippines and South Korea, said officials at the World Bank, which coordinates aid at its Washington headquarters for the hardest-hit countries. The foreigners were lured to the Middle East by the better wages that Iraq and Kuwait could pay because of income from oil. The largest and most recent group forced from their homes are citizens of Yemen who have been living in Saudi Arabia, some of them for decades. The Saudi government is retaliating against Yemen because of Yemeni sympathy for President Saddam Hussein of Iraq. About 2 million of the 12 million people in Saudi Arabia were Yemeni. The newly united republic of Yemen also has a population of nearly 12 million. The uncertain border between the two countries runs for thousands of miles, much of it through the desolate area called the ``Empty Quarter.'' A report from Yemen estimated the number of Yemenis who have fled across it at 750,000. Arntraud Hartmann, who works on the problem at the World Bank, told a meeting on refugees this week that the number of displaced Yemenis was about 500,000. But she added that it was not known how many more may have to go. About 20,000 a day were reported leaving in early October. Estimates were imprecise in part because large families sometimes travel on one passport. ``We don't handle immediate relief,'' Ms. Hartmann said of the World Bank's role. ``Others do that better. We're concerned with making loans that will create jobs and do other things to ease the impact.'' Refugees need food, housing and jobs and are always an immediate burden. The World Bank is the biggest source of aid to the Third World, lending more than $20 billion last year. Its staff is speeding up loans to the countries badly hit by the gulf crisis and is expected to report in the next few weeks to its 154 member governments. Peter Riddleberger, a bank spokesman, said many countries have been doubly hurt: they have lost the hard cash that their citizens used to send home from Iraq and Kuwait, and they now have to spend their own money and whatever help they can get on finding homes and jobs for them. In addition, countries that import oil must pay the high prices brought on by the crisis. Some have also lost valuable trade because of the United Nations sanctions against Iraq. Egypt is one of the hardest-hit countries. Ms. Hartmann estimated that 380,000 Egyptians have fled Iraq and Kuwait, with perhaps as many more to come. A.S. Abderahman, second secretary at the Egyptian embassy here, said that when the crisis began there were 800,000 to 1 million Egyptians in Iraq, mostly farm workers and manual laborers. Others put the number as high as 1.3 million. ``Iraq needed farm workers and made them welcome,'' Abderahman told the meeting on refugees. ``The Iraqis made some of them Iraqi citizens. Some were drafted and taken prisoner in the war with Iran. Some will want to stay in Iraq.'' An additional 200,000 Egyptians worked in Kuwait and had an estimated $8 billion deposited in Kuwaiti banks, Abderahman said. Others say there were as many as 300,000 Egyptians. Egyptians working in Iraq and Kuwait sent home more than $1.65 billion a year in hard currency, much valued in their country's cash-starved economy. Jordan, Iraq's neighbor, has been hardest hit of all. A country of only 3 million people, it must try to absorb about 220,000 returning citizens. Many are professionals and skilled workers for whom there are no jobs in sight, Ms. Hartmann said. Fran Sullivan of the International Organization for Migration, which works with the United Nations, said India had brought home about 150,000 citizens. Figures reported from Cyprus, a center for news from the Middle East, put the number at 85,000 each from Bangladesh and Sri Lanka.

DOC.HEAD: Naval Quarantine Cuts Aqaba Traffic By 80 Percent
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto DHA1,2; LaserColor DHA101,102 Nov.1.
DOC.TEXT: On an average of three times a day, a hand-picked team of armed U.S. sailors boards merchant ships in the Red Sea that might be trying to break a U.N. embargo to get supplies to Iraq. ``We're the Red Sea Highway Patrol,'' said gunner's mate William ``Bo'' Kitchens, 27, of Lakeland, Fla., a member of Boarding Team Alpha aboard the guided missile cruiser USS Biddle. ``We should put a red and blue light atop the ship with a siren. It's more police work than anything else. We're stopping contraband from reaching its goal,'' Kitchens said after an interdiction this week. The United Nations authorized the naval quarantine to punish Iraq for its Aug. 2 conquest of Kuwait. Nothing but medical supplies are allowed in, and no ships, including tankers carrying Iraq's lifeblood of oil exports, are getting out. Much of the seagoing police work is done in the northern Red Sea, which includes traffic coming south from the Suez Canal and bound for the Jordanian port o Aqaba. The port is a potential opening in the international effort because land routes from there lead across Jordan into Iraq. What was one of the world's busiest shipping lanes just three months ago now has more warships than merchant vessels. ``The shipping volume has been substantially throttled down. There's been an 80 percent reduction in the volume of shipping,'' said Rear Adm. Nick Gee, commander of Red Sea operations by the Maritime Interdiction Force. One of the warships plying the azure blue waters is the Biddle, part of the task force accompanying the aircraft carrier USS Saratoga. ``It's a total roadblock. This is a very effective blockade,'' said Capt. Louis Harlow, the Biddle's skipper. ``Nobody can leak through. Anything that moves, we've got them. The Iraqis have to be hurting.'' A ring of warships is on patrol around the Arabian peninsula, which is bounded by the Red Sea, Arabian Sea and the Persian Gulf. Since the embargo began in August, 3,107 ships have been intercepted, with 310 boarded. Almost all of the boardings have occurred in the Red Sea. Navy officials said 23 cargo ships have been diverted to other ports, including 10 ships bound for Aqaba or other ports because something was suspicious. For example, the Biddle refused passage to one ship carrying potassium nitrate, an ingredient for gunpowder. Others have been turned away because their manifests did not jibewith their cargo. ``A lot of Iraqi ships are at anchor in port. They're not even making the attempt,'' said Cmdr. Mark Merchat, public affairs officer for Navy Central Command. He said that in the gulf itself, traffic to and from Iraq ``is virtually at a standstill.'' In a typical operation, a U.S. warship or other units of the multinational armada enforcing the sanctions will hail a merchant ship and ask its destination or cargo. Anything bound for Aqaba is immediately under suspicion. Other things that draw attention are ship's names that are painted over or ships that are sailing courses that differ from their announced destination. Earlier this week, the Biddle stopped the Greek container ship Zim Venezia, which was headed for Eilat, Israel, right next door to Aqaba. A 20-man boarding team carrying sidearms and shotguns and wearing black flak jackets scurried down a rope ladder onto a 26-foot whale boat for a 1,500-yard trip to the merchant ship. The boarding party, consisting of Navy and U.S. Coast Guard personnel, checked the ship's paperwork and crew before it was allowed to continue. During the mission, a warplane dispatched by the Saratoga buzzed the area. That interdiction lasted about four hours. Some can take 14 hours or longer if cargo is checked. Many are done at night, which makes the operation a bit dicier. ``It kind of gives you an eerie feeling at night, but it doesn't change our job any,'' said Coast Guard Ensign Chris Clark, 32, of Cape Cod, Mass. Clark's last job was working interdictions against drug smugglers in the Caribbean, which he considered a more dangerous assignment than the work he's doing now. ``With drug interdictions, you never know what you're going to run across. There are more unknowns,'' Clark said. ``Out here, we're on guard but we're not overly aggressive. We're firm but polite.'' The Red Sea crew has its share of surprises. One time, a Soviet ship was told to divert, and its captain radioed back: ``I have your boarding party hostage.'' When the boarding team gave him startled glances, the captain quickly replied: ``That's a joke. Just kidding.'' The Navy has nicknamed the Red Sea operation Toto Station, after the line in ``The Wizard of Oz'' when Judy Garland tells her dog, ``Gee, Toto, I don't think we're in Kansas anymore.'' The Suez Canal is dubbed the Yellow Brick Road. Warships refer to sectors with codenames like Emerald City, Wizard, Oz, Wicked Witch and Tin Man.

DOC.HEAD: India's Religious Dispute is 105 Years Old
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The religious dispute that has killed more than 200 people in nine days and threatened to bring down the government has its roots in a 105-year-old court case. In 1885, a Hindu priest filed a lawsuit claiming a small plot of land in the town of Ayodhya was the birthplace of the Lord Rama, the much-revered warrior-god. The priest also claimed that the unpretentious three-domed mosque on the site was built over what had once been a Hindu temple. Sixty-one years later, the court decreed that the site was a mosque and dismissed the priest's claim. The legal snarl was revived in 1949 when an idol of Rama was spirited into the building. The mosque was locked by court order and closed to people of both faiths in an effort to prevent religious strife. In 1986, another court order re-opened the mosque, but only to Hindus. Riots over the decision killed at least 200 people. Around the same time, the fundamentalist World Hindu Council called for the removal of the 460-year-old Babri mosque and the construction of a temple in its place. The group was not particularly well-known at the time, but it gathered increasing support. In 1989, it announced definitive plans for the temple construction and said it would raise $14 million for the project. Religious riots broke out again, this time claiming at least 900 lives. After a year of futile government efforts to halt the campaign, the group said Hindu holy men had deemed Oct. 30, 1990, as an auspicious day to start the construction. Prime Minister V.P. Singh's government vowed to halt the attempt, although this stand cost it the support of the Hindu Bharatiya Janata Party. The desertion relegated the government to a minority in Parliament. Singh faces the possibility of losing a vote of confidence Nov. 7. On Tuesday, thousands of Hindus stormed the mosque. At least seven people died when police opened fire, but many youths broke through security cordons, raced through the narrow, winding lanes leading to the site and planted orange Hindu flags on the domes. Three more bodies were later found in a river and were thought to be victims of Tuesday's violence. What is most worrisome about the outbreak of violence, say newspapers and political commentators, is the widespread support the Hindu campaign has received, which could foreshadow an unending cycle of religious strife. India's 880 million people are 82 percent Hindu and 12 percent Moslem, but the country has been officialy secular since it gained independence in 1947. Hindu-Moslem riots have periodically flared but usually have been sparked by local issues and quickly resolved. ``India is entering a period when all the values it cherishes are in peril,'' The Statesman newspaper editorialized Thursday. ``On the survival of this one mosque may depend the survival of India as we know it.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush's Tough Talk on Iraq Could Boost GOP Candidates
DOC.TEXT: Tough presidential talk about Iraq's Saddam Hussein is dominating the news again to the potential advantage of Republican candidates struggling to recover from tax and budget blues, analysts say. At a campaign-trail news conference in Florida, Bush conceded Thursday that mixing statements on the Persian Gulf with campaign rhetoric was ``a little bit awkward because we are a few days before an election and I want to continue to work for Republican candidates.'' ``It's having a big political impact,'' Democratic pollster Celinda Lake said of the presidential rhetoric. But she also called it ``very high-risk strategy'' for the president. ``What he's tinkering with is the most robust part of his image,'' Lake said. ``If he creates cynicism in the one part of his image that's still very robust ... he's in for a much harder presidency.'' A sign of the kind of trouble Bush could encounter came in this statement from Rep. David Obey, D-Wis., chairman of the House Appropriations subcommittee on foreign operations: ``If the president wants politics to end at the water's edge, he has an obligation to leave events beyond the water's edge out of campaign politics.'' ``The agenda has switched to foreign policy,'' said Democratic pollster Peter Hart. ``He (Bush) has been very effective in moving the agenda at least somewhat off the focus on the budget and off taxes,'' said Lake. ``I think he figured out he could not reshape voters' impressions about taxes ... so that he had to get voters' minds off of that.'' At a briefing on Senate races, Rick Shelby, political director of the National Republican Senatorial Committee, said prospects have become more positive for GOP candidates. ``One of the reasons the environment improved (is) the focus is no longer entirely on the budget,'' said Shelby. For the past week, Democrats exulted as campaign surveys reported growing support for their party from voters who agreed with their contention that Bush and his party were tilting to the rich in the budget negotiations. The argument came to be dubbed ``the fairness issue.'' In state after state, polls found Democratic candidates gaining ground. In some cases, Republicans once thought to be safe suddenly found themselves in very tight races. In others, Republican challengers dropped far behind Democratic incumbents. Hart said he couldn't say if the shift in Bush's focus had boosted the prospects of Republican candidates. But the pollster added that ``there's no longer the sense that they're still losing ground. Whether they've started dramatically to pick up ground is less certain.'' ``What they have to hope for is they get a minor rebound,'' said Kevin Phillips, a Republican political analyst. ``My sense is they've slapped a bottom on the domestic policy hemorrhage.'' The decline that appeared to be sending Republicans toward a major defeat next Tuesday already had begun to slow after the budget agreement was reached and Congress adjourned. Left open was the question of whether a shift of emphasis to foreign policy would alter the overall dynamic of the election and create a national issue that would turn the tie in the Republicans' favor. ``Unless something actually happens (in the Persian Gulf), then all this scene-setting is only marginal, that you're not going to change the dynamic,'' said Phillips. ``I don't think it's necessarily changed the dynamics of the election,'' said Hart. GOP pollster Robert Teeter said he didn't know of any races where the Persian Gulf was ``a particularly important issue. I think it's important to the public impression of the president.'' Lake said that during the budget negotiations, people responded to polls by saying ``this is a bad package, Bush is doing this, Bush is on the side of the rich.'' Now, she said, ``he has very, very effectively moved the focus off himself in terms of taxes.'' She contended the fairness issue remains potent but with slightly diminished momentum.

DOC.HEAD: Once Viewed as Shoo-in, Boschwitz Scrambles to Keep Senate Seat
DOC.TEXT: The upheaval in the Minnesota governor's race has battered Rudy Boschwitz as well, forcing the Republican senator to scramble in a re-election bid once thought to be a sure thing. ``He better bring out the heavy artillery. I think he needs it,'' said Selden Hanson, Minnesota 8th District GOP chairman. ``Three weeks ago I didn't even worry. Now I hope we win. I've got my fingers crossed.'' Boschwitz, seeking a third term, had been considered to have one of the safest senatorial re-election bids this year against Democrat Paul Wellstone, a political science professor at Carleton College. But his fortunes have turned in the 2{ weeks since allegations of skinny-dipping with teen-age girls and adultery rang out against Minnesota's one-time Republican gubernatorial nominee, Jon Grunseth. ``I think it has affected my campaign negatively,'' Boschwitz said Thursday. ``That's an advantage to a newcomer, no doubt about it.'' As Wellstone was gaining attention through a series of catchy TV ads, the Minnesota Republican Party was shaken Oct. 15 by the initial allegations against Grunseth. Boschwitz initially supported Grunseth but later urged his withdrawal. Grunseth bowed out on Sunday. The developments appeared to take their toll on Boschwitz. An independent public opinion poll conducted Oct. 19-21 showed the Boschwitz-Wellstone race a virtual draw, compared with a 15-point Boschwitz lead less than two weeks earlier. Boschwitz returned to Minnesota the day the new poll figures were published, saying, ``I have to get back and campaign.'' ``My own political situation has gotten worse because of the governor's race,'' Boschwitz said while campaigning in Duluth on Tuesday. ``When I wrapped my arms around Grunseth, my poll numbers dropped precipitously.'' Wellstone has repeatedly portrayed himself as David against Goliath because Boschwitz had amassed a campaign war chest of more than $7 million to Wellstone's less than $1 million. He has accused Boschwitz of dodging responsibility for the $3 trillion national debt, lacking compassion for the poor and disadvantaged and compromising the interests of average Minnesotans by accepting campaign donations from big out-of-state businesses. Humorous television ads, which show the bouncy Wellstone talking and walking in fast motion, have made the challenger easy to recognize. And Boschwitz changed his vote on civil rights legislation after Wellstone criticized the initial vote. ``Now look at what the polls show. I'll tell you, I've climbed on top of Goliath's $7 million. I'm looking at him straight in the face,'' Wellstone said at a rally last week. But Wellstone was on the defensive this week after Boschwitz said the challenger's national health care plan would result in the shutdown of the Mayo Clinic and that Wellstone's spending proposals would require a doubling of taxes. The senator also said Wellstone had been arrested for trespassing during protests against the Vietnam war and the farm crisis. And he caused a stir when he called on Wellstone to renounce a plan by a street gang to pass out Democratic campaign literature. Wellstone said he didn't know of the plan. ``He has gone after me and after me and after me for 10 weeks with very, very negative stuff,'' Boschwitz said Thursday. ``So the time had come to take the offensive. Nobody was explaining and defining Paul Wellstone. That's what we wanted to do, so that people understood what he was about and what he was saying.'' And Boschwitz hoped to get a big boost today with President Bush's appearance in Rochester on his behalf. Political science professor Charles Backstrom of the University of Minnesota said that either Boschwitz is running scared or wants his supporters to think he is. ``He wants his supporters to come out and work for him and vote,'' Backstrom said. ``You really want them working their hardest and their best in the last 10 days,'' said D.J. Leary, a longtime Democratic political consultant. Wellstone campaign manager John Blackshaw discounted the notion that Boschwitz was merely pretending to be nervous. ``I think he is legitimately scared. I hesitate to think that he is that arrogant to think he doesn't have any problems in his own Senate race,'' Blackshaw said. Boschwitz ally Vin Weber, a Minnesota Republican congressman, believes the narrowing gap between Boschwitz and Wellstone is part of the national backlash Republicans are feeling over tax increases and Medicare cuts in the federal budget. ``It's not a Boschwitz problem, it's a Republican problem,'' Weber said.

DOC.HEAD: Kuwaiti Documents in Iraqi Hands Said Unlikely to Compromise U.S.
LaserPhoto WX8
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi troops seized scores of documents when they invaded Kuwait, but the papers are unlikely to compromise the United States because of Kuwait's limited intelligence service, officials and private analysts say. ``They obviously got a lot of documents,'' said Ali Al-Sabah, a spokesman for the Kuwait Embassy. ``They have to sift through them and they have the labor to do that.'' Attention focused on Kuwaiti documents Wednesday when Iraqi Ambassador Mohamed Al-Mashat released one he said was taken from files at Kuwait's internal security bureau after the Aug. 2 invasion. But officials said the fact that the documents belonged to Kuwait makes the situation different from 1979, when Iranian revolutionaries seized the U.S. Embassy in Tehran. In that instance, Iranian students pieced together shredded U.S. documents in an effort to gain some insight into official American activities in Iran. Diplomats at the U.S. Embassy in Baghdad are known to have shredded sensitive documents, according to U.S. officials. It is likely that the handful of diplomats trapped at the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait have done the same thing, said Neil Livingstone, an adjunct professor at Georgetown University who is a specialist on terrorism. Livingstone said he doubted the Iraqis have learned much about U.S. intelligence from the Kuwaiti documents. ``This is not the Rolls Royce of intelligence services,'' he said. ``They didn't have wide knowledge of the United States.'' Al-Sabah said the Kuwaiti inelligence service was small and reported to the interior minister. Most Kuwaiti security work involved keeping tabs on foreigners working inside the country. ``We are talking about a little country that doesn't have a lot of assets,'' Livingstone said. A U.S. diplomat familiar with Kuwait agreed. Although the United States and Kuwait were allies, Washington was cautious about sharing secret information with Kuwait because that country also had good relations with the Soviet Union, said the diplomat, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The two countries cooperated in reflagging Kuwaiti tankers during the Iran-Iraq war in 1987, but much of that information would be dated, officials said. Of more concern to the United States is the military hardware that Iraq stole from Kuwait, Livingstone said. ``They got a lot of goodies out of Kuwait,'' he said. There have been unconfirmed reports that Iraq has seized U.S.-made HAWK missiles that were sold to Kuwait. Even so, Livingstone said the United States did not have a large military presence in Kuwait. The memo provided Wednesday by Al-Mashat purports to be from the director general of the state security department to the Kuwaiti interior minister, detailing a meeting the security chief had with CIA Director William Webster on Nov. 14, 1989. In the document, Kuwaiti Brig. Fahd Ahmad Al-Fahd said he and Webster agreed on a number of points. Among them: -``We agreed with the U.S. side that it was important to combat drugs in the country after the CIA narcotics experts informed us that much Kuwaiti capital is being used to promote drug trafficking in Pakistan and Iran, and that the spread of such trafficking will have negative consequences for the future of Kuwait.'' -``We agreed with the American side that it was important to take advantage of the deteriorating economic situation in Iraq in order to put pressure on that country's government to delineate our common border,'' the document said. The CIA said statements contained in the document are fabrications. Ali Al-Sabah, a spokesman for the Kuwaiti embassy, said the document - written in Arabic - appeared to have been altered. But Al-Mashat insisted on the document's authenticity. The document also provided a telephone number said to be Webster's private line. A telephone answering machine with a woman's voice answers the number.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Everyone Appears Rattled
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: President Bush evidently set out this week to rattle Iraq, but he may have wound up rattling everyone - including himself - on whether he is about to go to war against Saddam Hussein. As a result, Bush toned down the rhetoric a little bit Thursday as he came to a news conference equipped with past statements that matched his recent bellicosity. ``Some are saying there is a shift here, a dramatic shift,' Bush said, denying any inconsistency on his part. Indeed, he had called the Iraqi president barbaric in the past. ``I am not trying to sound the tocsin of war,'' he said, easing off slightly. Bush explained he was just trying to get the focus back where it belonged - on Iraq's unacceptable invasion of Kuwait - after some digression over the budget and his dealings with Congress. ``I am not going to discuss what or will not trigger an armed conflict,'' he said. There is no denying, however, that the country is experiencing a siege of war nerves, and it extends to Capitol Hill. House Speaker Thomas Foley and Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell said Tuesday they were worried that a growing number of people feel war is unavoidable. At the very least, Congress wants to exercise what many members perceive to be its constitutional right to decide whether to declare war. But Bush told the leaders Tuesday that while he would continue to seek their advice and support in shaping U.S. policy, they must understand ``that any such commitment must be hedged, given the unpredictable and dynamic circumstances of this crisis.'' Indeed, the rattling rhetoric one day, and the emphasis in seeking a peaceful solution another day, could be calculated to confuse Saddam. If that is Bush's purpose, he obviously cannot admit it. Nor can he explain the shifts of emphasis to the American people without giving his strategy away. And yet, an argument can be made that the president has an obligation to explain to Congress and the American people what would trigger an armed conflict. It's hard to say whether that would provide Baghdad with critical information to help prepare for war, but it probably would enhance Bush's chances of getting support at home once an attack was launched. Explaining why he had taken a hard line of late, Bush said Thursday he wanted the American people to know how strongly he felt about the plight of the nine diplomats and others holding out in the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait and Americans detained in Iraq. Some are being used as human shields at strategic installations to deter U.S. attack. Bush said relatives of the hostages would be discouraged from accepting an Iraqi offer to make holiday visits. And he called the Iraqi invitation ``a canard.'' The emphasis Bush placed on the plight of the hostages and the diplomats could be evidence that he, indeed, is now more inclined to use force and that he has begun to justify a war to the American people. And yet, in late August, the president said the hostages would not affect his policy toward Iraq. That is, he said he would not be deterred from taking military action by threats to the Americans. ``I will not change the policy of the United States (to) pay homage or to give credibility to this brutal move of staking out citizens and a brutal move of holding people against their will,'' he said on Aug. 30. At this point, however, their situation could be the very reason Bush uses force. He said Wednesday he had ``had it'' with Iraq's treatment of the hostages and the diplomats. He accused Iraq of trying to starve out Ambassador Nathaniel Howell and the other besieged Americans at the embassy. ``I must keep this in focus for the American people,'' he said. --- EDITOR'S NOTE: Barry Schweid has reported for AP on U.S. foreign policy since 1973.

DOC.HEAD: Marsalis Family on Stage Together
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Will stand for PMs.
DOC.TEXT: The Marsalis family, the highest profile family in jazz, performed together in public for the first time at a benefit here. The spirit was warm and the music was wonderful. Trumpeter Wynton Marsalis plays a dull-finish trumpet but the notes are bright and shining. He was the relaxed host Wednesday night, introducing tunes with endearing glimpses of family life. Older brother Branford, who leads his own group, played tenor saxophone. Jason, 13, made his New York debut and charmed the audience with his thin look, unaffected manner and drumming. Their father, Ellis, played piano. Delfeayo, trombonist and record producer, wasn't there. Wynton said, ``Mother would say she used to sing. She'd go to the piano and do a terrible rendition of `Embraceable You.' We knew it was time to get the horns out. Paying our respects to our mother who's not here tonight, we'll play `Embraceable You.''' Wynton played it bebop style, but sweet, slow and satisfying. Branford's solo was tuneful and mellow. One of the first tunes that he and Branford played together, Wynton said, was Charlie Parker's ``Air Conditioning.'' ``We haven't played it in a long time. It might be a little rusty.'' It wasn't. Wynton played with his nattily dressed six-man group on the show opener, Duke Ellington's ``Play the Blues and Go.'' In more than two hours without intermission at Alice Tully Hall, the grouping kept changing. ``A tune he taught me when I was in high school,'' is how Wynton introduced himself and his father's subtly swinging ``Big Butter and Egg Man.'' They also played a lovely ``The Very Thought of You,'' Wynton using a furry tone and taking some discreet note-bending chances. ``The only reason we're playing this is my Daddy likes it,'' Wynton said before his group played his composition, ``The Majesty of the Blues,'' which has much piano complexity. An Ellis Marsalis composition, ``Swinging at the Haven,'' featured Ellis, Branford and Jason Marsalis. The concert ended with an encore, ``In the Court of King Oliver,'' by bassist Reginald Veal, drummer Herlin Riley, Ellis and Wynton. Wynton ended it by walking off stage playing each phrase quieter than the one before. The evening was a benefit for Graham-Windham Services to family and children, the Autism Society of America and the Immunohematology Research Foundation which develops therapies for autistic patients. Wynton said, near the end of the concert, ``I have a little brother who's autistic. You know it's a worthy cause.'' At the beginning of the evening he dedicated ``this evening's swing'' to drummer-band leader Art Blakey, who died in October. Wynton said, ``He said, `Music washes the dust of everyday life from your feet.'''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Commander Urges Caution in Attacking Iraq
DOC.TEXT: Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, commander of U.S. forces in the Persian Gulf, said Thursday American troops could destroy Iraq but such action might not be ``in the interest of the long-term balance of power'' in the region. Schwarzkopf, who assumed command of more than 210,000 American troops in Saudi Arabia in August, said war could erupt any time, but he doesn't expect it to. ``President Bush has stated again and again, our argument is not with the Iraqi people, and that (military action) would cause thousands and thousands of innocent casualties.'' In an interview published Friday by The New York Times, Schwarzkopf said he recommended to the Pentagon that combat units in Saudi Arabia be rotated out of the country every six to eight months. He said Iraqi missiles would have only a modest effect on any military action because they are highly inaccurate and because the Iraqis have a relatively small number of rocket launchers. Schwarzkopf played down Iraq's ability to mount chemical warheads on its missiles.

DOC.HEAD: Cuomo: No Presidential Run if State Fiscal Problems Continue
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Mario Cuomo says that if he is re-elected and can't put New York's fiscal house in order, there's no sense in even discussing a possible 1992 presidential bid. ``That's what I have to get done. That's what I ran for,'' Cuomo said Wednesday of his current re-election bid and dealings with New York's sagging economy. ``There's no way you could say, `No, that's not really important. I'll solve the problems from Washington,' and then take off and campaign from coast to coast,'' Cuomo added. ``I couldn't do it and I wouldn't do it.'' And if the state's fiscal problems are under control by the time the 1992 presidential campaign began? ``Then you talk to me,'' he said, leaving open the possibility of a presidential run. Cuomo's comments came as he answered speculation from political analysts that a solid re-election win next week could set the stage for a presidential campaign. National Republican political strategists have said Cuomo's fiscal record in New York would be a major issue if he ran for president. During Cuomo's almost eight years as governor, state spending has grown at more than twice the rate of inflation. In his bid for a third term, Cuomo has come under constant attack from Republicans who claim he's largely responsible for the state's budget woes. They've compared him to Michael Dukakis, Massachusetts' lame-duck governor and unsuccessful 1988 Democratic presidential candidate. The collapse of the ``Massachusetts Miracle'' was in large part responsible for Dukakis' decision not to seek re-election. Cuomo, in turn, has sought to blame Presidents Reagan and Bush and the Republican leadership of the state Senate for New York's continued fiscal problems. ``My sense is that Cuomo will be a candidate (for the presidency),'' Lee Miringoff, head of the Marist College Institute for Public Opinion, said Wednesday. ``He'll be under more pressure than he's ever been under before, the morning after the election,'' said Robert Strauss, a former Democratic national chairman and veteran party power broker. ``He doesn't like that kind of pressure, but he's going to get it whether he likes it or not.'' Cuomo responded by saying that ``if you don't feel it, it's not pressure. Nobody can pressure you to make a decision like that and nobody's going to.'' According to the latest polling, Cuomo is a heavy favorite to win re-election Tuesday to a third, four-year term as governor. His opponents are Republican Pierre Rinfret and Conservative Party candidate Herbert London.

DOC.HEAD: Peru's President Attacks Catholic Church on Birth Control Issue
DOC.TEXT: In his sharpest attack on the Catholic Church, President Alberto Fujimori has accused the church of controlling minds and obstructing freedom by refusing to support a planned birth control program for the poor. ``A sector of the church is restricting the freedom of citizens with its medieval opinions and recalcitrant positions,'' Fujimori said Wednesday. ``It is unethical to manipulate consciences and sow fear and doubt among the population.'' The government ``wants the use of contraceptives to be the free choice of citizens,'' Fujimori told a national mayors' convention in the coastal town of Huaral, 40 miles north of Lima. A planned birth control program was announced last week for this overwhelmingly Catholic nation. If it is not put into effect, Fujimori said, Peru's population of 22 million would reach 30 million by the turn of the century. The program would distribute free condoms and birth control pills to the poor. Eight million people, more than one-third of the population, live in extreme poverty, and families of 10 or more children are not uncommon. Fujimori, a self-professed devout Catholic and political independent who took office July 28, said the government would not make birth control compulsory for anyone but stressed that the population should be informed. He criticized the Catholic Church for not supporting the government's program to encourage people to have only the number of children they can feed. ``There is nothing terrible about not wanting children to eat garbage in the streets,'' Fujimori said. ``The church won't lose any authority by admitting there's something wrong, on the contrary, it will gain.'' The president angered church officials Oct. 23 when he announced plans to launch a birth control program among the poorer sectors. Church leaders are influential among the 95 percent of the population that is Catholic. The government's aim, he said, was to cut the present annual population growth rate from 650,000 to 300,000 by the year 2000. Peru is in the grips of its worst economic crisis in history and a 13-month-old drought that has badly hurt agricultural production. Peru's educational system, which is heavily influenced by the powerful Catholic Church, does not provide sex education in schools. However, contraceptives like the birth control pill are freely available without a prescription in pharmacies. The church, represented by Bishop Ricardo Durand, has echoed the anti-birth control message of Pope John Paul II, who last visited Peru in 1988. ``From the church's point of view, there must responsible paternity,'' Durand said in a radio interview Friday. But he ruled out any means of birth control except for natural methods. ``Let the people's conscience decide,'' he said in a television interview Sunday. ``But they must answer to it up above later on.''

DOC.HEAD: Bitter Words in Race to Choose State's First Black Congressman
DOC.TEXT: Louisiana will elect its first black congressman since Reconstruction in Tuesday's election, following a campaign marred by bitter personal barbs. Marc Morial and state Sen. William Jefferson, both Democrats and both lawyers, want to replace Rep. Lindy Boggs, an extremely popular congresswoman who is retiring after 17 years in the House. Allegations about Jefferson's personal gain from political contacts and Morial's fathering a child out of wedlock have sometimes overshadowed other issues. Jefferson and Morial, the son of New Orleans' first black mayor, were the top vote-getters in the 12-way primary Oct. 6. Jefferson led with 24 percent, while Morial garnered 22 percent. Having virtually split the black vote in the primary, both candidates need white support to win Tuesday. There have been no recent independent polls released, but University of New Orleans political science professor and researcher Susan Howell said white voters appear to be largely undecided. ``It's really up for grabs,'' Howell said of the white vote. Early in his career, Jefferson enjoyed strong support from conservatives and business interests - which could translate into white support at the polls. But that support appeared to diminish as he fought Gov. Buddy Roemer's fiscal programs and other initiatives important to the reform-minded governor. Morial still is virtually an unknown quantity among whites - although his father, the late Mayor Dutch Morial, had a strong coalition of white and black support. Morial, 31, has leveled charges that Jefferson's law practice has benefited from his political contacts. ``My law firm built its practice, not on public contracts, but by serving individuals,'' Morial said at a forum of business leaders. Jefferson, 43, responds by criticizing Morial's lack of experience. ``If you don't do anything in life, you won't get any criticism,'' Jefferson said. ``If you do, you will.'' Jefferson, born to a poor family in northern Louisiana, graduated from Southern University in 1969 and Harvard Law School in 1972. He clerked for a federal judge in the early 1970s, later joining the staff of U.S. Sen. J. Bennett Johnston. He set up a New Orleans law practice in 1976 and was elected to the state Senate in 1979. Jefferson has battled Roemer on several matters, including the governor's call to abolish four state boards that govern higher education in Louisiana and replace them with one board. The plan would do away with predominantly black Southern University's Board of Supervisors. The board opposes the plan. Jefferson is the board's lawyer - a job reportedly worth up to $195,000 annually. Morial calls that a conflict of interest, saying it's only part of a reported $590,000 in public contracts Jefferson has from various public agencies. A graduate of Georgetown University Law Center, Morial established a law practice in 1985. He, too, has at least one public contract, acting as legal counsel for the Orleans Parish Civil Sheriff's Office. That hasn't become a campaign issue. However, the fact that he fathered a child eight years ago while a law student has. The story broke just after the primary election. Jefferson denies having anything to do with the publicity surrounding the matter. The child's mother, an attorney who now is married and lives in Africa, filed suit two days before the primary and later was quoted as saying she never sought or received a penny in child support from Morial. Morial said he has met all financial and moral obligations. Jefferson's campaign plays up the fact that Jefferson has been married for 20 years and that he and his wife have five children. It is not, Jefferson said, an effort to paint Morial as an irresponsible bachelor father. Rather, he said, it is to show that he has empathy with families trying to survive in Louisiana's poor economy. ``My only point in bringing it up is to make sure that the voters out there know that I appreciate their problems,'' Jefferson said during a recent forum before the New Orleans Young Leadership Council. ``I grew up in a family,'' Morial countered, drawing laughter and brief applause from his supporters in the audience.

DOC.HEAD: Backer of Drug Legalization Gets Rude Welcome
DOC.TEXT: Drug legalization advocate Anthony Henman got a rude welcome when he arrived in the United States to attend a conference: 20 hours in custody and three strip searches. A federal arrest warrant for Henman popped up when an immigration officer at New York's John F. Kennedy International Airport punched his name into a computer, said Immigration and Naturalization Service spokesman Farrell Adams. The INS detained the British citizen at 5 p.m. on Oct. 25 and turned him over to the U.S. Marshals Service, Adams said. The trouble was, the warrant wasn't valid. The 1972 indictment stemmed from an accused drug dealer's allegations that Henman had been his supplier, according to attorneys from the American Civil Liberties Union and its New York branch. ``The indictment was later dropped, but the arrest warrant wasn't,'' said Phil Gutis of the ACLU. ``This was the first time Henman has come into the country since then.'' It took until mid-afternoon of Oct. 26 for Assistant U.S. Attorney Ira Belkin in the Eastern District of New York to discover that the indictment had been dismissed in 1981. ``For whatever reason, that information never made its way into the computer,'' Belkin said. ``The warrant, as far as the computer was concerned, was still in there. Basically, it was a mistake. As soon as we figured that out, he was released.'' Henman is the executive secretary of the Brussels-based International Anti-Prohibitionist League. He traveled to the United States to attend a conference organized by the Washington-based Drug Policy Foundation, which advocates drug decriminalization. ``He was held incommunicado for 20 hours - which, unfortunately, isn't that unusual - and he was strip-searched three times,'' said Gutis. ``When he was able to contact a lawyer, he got hold of the New York Civil Liberties Union and they were able to clear up the situation rather quickly.'' Henman's lawyers say they may sue. ``Mr. Henman indicated there were lots of apologies after the fact, but the apologies cannot really undo the profound harm,'' said Donna Lieberman, associate director of the New York Civil Liberties Union. ``The computer ... was dead wrong, and as a result, an innocent person was subjected to deprivation of his liberty in violation of his fundamental rights.''

DOC.HEAD: Budget Has Medicaid Aid for Holocaust Survivors, Other Hidden Items
DOC.TEXT: A Medicaid break for Holocaust survivors, an award named for a member of Congress and a promise by Democratic leaders of billions in new spending for minorities are all tucked into the deficit-reduction bill. The provisions are among numerous obscure items in the budget that are only now coming to light, days after Congress approved the measure and adjourned for the year. Other language provides assistance for Americans fleeing Iraq and Kuwait and money for certain centers to treat patients with Alzheimer's disease or those who may have AIDS. But in a money-saving move, lawmakers decreed that deceased veterans using federal burial benefits no longer would be able to receive free headstones from the government. It is a longstanding Washington tradition for giant measures like the deficit-reduction package to be crammed with items that affect limited numbers of people. In fact, Rep. Curt Weldon, R-Pa., is offering dinner for two at a Capitol Hill restaurant for anyone who brings one to his attention that benefits five or fewer people. He has yet to find one. ``Staff tells me this is the cleanest bill they've seen in recent times,'' Weldon said Wednesday. But the bill - the main part of an effort to slash the federal deficit by $496 billion over the next five years - does contain provisions that benefit specific groups or areas. A report accompanying the bill contains an unusual promise by Democratic congressional leaders to try to increase federal spending for minority group members by at least $8.8 billion over the next three years. The leaders promise an effort to target science and energy research and education initiatives to traditionally black and Hispanic colleges and universities. They say they will try to set up a new federally backed bond program for new construction at the schools, of which there are about 120, mostly in the South. The Democrats also say they will try to increase spending on foreign aid to Africa, housing, urban development, education, health, child care and anti-gang programs in inner cities, welfare, job training and veterans. House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., said Tuesday the language had nothing to do with the hunt Democratic leaders made last week for support for the budget, which the House approved 228-200. ``A number of our members, black and white, felt we wanted to make investments in certain areas,'' he said. But Rep. Alan Wheat, D-Mo., one of 24 House Democrats in the Congressional Black Caucus, said the provision was included after negotiations between black lawmakers and House leaders. Much of it came from the budget the caucus proposed earlier this year, he said. ``Most of us wanted to find a way to support the Democratic leadership'' and vote for the budget, Wheat said Wednesday. Ten of the black caucus' members voted for the bill and 13 voted against it. Walter Fauntroy, the delegate from Washington D.C., has no vote on the House floor. In another section of the bill, Rep. Ted Weiss, D-N.Y., inserted language that allows Holocaust survivors to ignore reparation payments they receive from Germany when it comes to determining Medicaid nursing home benefits. The provision is expected to affect 300 low-income, elderly people who survived Hitler's death camps and who each receive an average of $1,600 annually from the German government. They would no longer have their federal nursing home benefits reduced by the amount of those checks, a provision likely to cost the government about $500,000 per year. Another clause creates the Walter B. Jones Excellence in Coastal Management awards. The prizes of up to $5,000 will be given to individuals, local governments and graduate students for protecting coastal lands. The award is named for Rep. Walter B. Jones, D-N.C., chairman of the House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee. The bill also: -Extends the life of 10 special projects where Medicare money is being used to treat patients with Alzheimer's disease. Only eight of the facilities have been financed so far, in Rochester, N.Y.; Urbana, Ill.; Memphis, Tenn.; Portland, Ore.; Cincinnati, Ohio; Parkersburg, W.Va.; Minneapolis and Miami. -Contains $30 million for Medicare for two new centers - expected by congressional officials to be in New York and San Francisco - to treat people infected with the AIDS virus and pregnant women believed to be at risk of getting the virus. -Allows the government to spend whatever amount is necessary to provide temporary aid to Americans escaping from Iraq and Iraqi-occupied Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Economic Slowdown Reported in All Regions of Country
DOC.TEXT: All regions of the country are reporting either slow growth or an actual decline in economic activity, the Federal Reserve Board says. The bleak assessment in a central bank report known as the ``beige book'' offered a contrast Wednesday with the bit of optimism generated a day earlier by a separate report. The Commerce Department had reported that the economy, as measured by the gross national product, grew a stronger-than-expected 1.8 percent in the July-September quarter. However, the Federal Reserve said a survey of its 12 district banks found that higher oil prices are shaking the confidence of consumers and businesses in much of the country. ``Most districts reported that retailers were generally pessimistic. ... (They) blamed lower consumer confidence brought on by greater uncertainty and higher fuel prices,'' the central bank reported. District Federal Reserve banks said economic activity was holding up relatively well in the Midwest and Northwest, but the Boston district reported, ``Manufacturers are battening down the hatches.'' The report, based on information collected through Oct. 19, was prepared for the Nov. 13 meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, which sets the Fed's monetary policy. In response to enactment of the budget deficit-reduction package, the central bank on Monday lowered a key interest rate, the one charged among banks for overnight loans, by a quarter of a percentage point to 7.75 percent. However, economists believe Fed policymakers will be reluctant to cut the rate again soon for fear of further weakening the value of the dollar or adding to inflation pressures already boosted by higher oil prices. ``The beige book shows ... the process of gradually slipping into a recession, but the tone wasn't urgent enough to cause the Fed to ease policy right away,'' said economist David Jones of Aubrey G. Lanston & Co., a government securities dealer in New York. The survey found pessimism even in relatively strong regions. The San Francisco district, for instance, said 67 percent of the area's business leaders expect a national recession next year. ``Several districts reported that some financial institutions had tightened their lending standards, especially for real estate loans, because of uncertain economic prospects,'' the report said. In a sign of slipping confidence in the banking system, the Philadelphia Federal Reserve bank said institutional investors - pension funds, insurance companies, universities and the like - were less interested in depositing uninsured funds with banks. Most areas reported some fallout from oil prices, which rocketed after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in August. The St. Louis regional bank said fuel prices caused airline layoffs and contributed to the cancellation of expansion plans by a trucking firm. The San Francisco region said one of its respondents reported the addition of a fuel surcharge to shipment costs and the Dallas district said food processors were raising their prices to cover increased transportation costs. On the positive side, the Dallas district said orders for oil field machinery were up. Applications for oil well permits have risen in both Texas and Louisiana, it said. The other bright spot in the report was agriculture. Yields of most crops were expected to be good. The Minneapolis and Kansas City districts reported that higher livestock prices and low feed costs were helping to support farm income.

DOC.HEAD: Farm Production Costs at Eight-Year High
DOC.TEXT: Farm production costs are rising at the fastest clip in eight years because of higher oil prices caused by the Mideast crisis, according to the Agriculture Department. The surge in costs of producing crops and livestock is expected to bite into farmers' income prospects in 1991. New quarterly figures through October showed farm expenses jumped an average of 2.2 percent from July, when such figures were last available. The expense index was up 5.6 percent from October 1989. ``A sharp rise in fuel prices since July contributed most to the largest quarterly index increase since January 1982,'' said a report released Wednesday. The monthly report by the department's Agricultural Statistics Board said prices farmers get for raw products declined 0.7 percent from September to October but still averaged 1.4 percent more than a year ago. ``Decreases in the prices of broilers, milk, corn and apples were partially offset by higher prices for hogs, tomatoes, strawberries and eggs,'' the board said in its preliminary report. Prices of most food and feed grains were down from September, although higher prices were reported for oats, rice and durum wheat. Soybean and sunflower prices declined, while peanut prices increased. ``The October all-hog price increased moderately over September, while the all-cattle price was up slightly,'' the report said. Prices of steers and heifers sold as beef were at a record high for October, the report said. But broiler prices dropped sharply from September, partly due to large supplies and weaker seasonal demand. USDA economists say consumer food prices will rise an average of 5 percent to 7 percent this year, compared with a 5.8 percent gain in 1989, the most since 1981. There has been no official forecast for 1991. The net cash income of farmers in 1990 has been forecast at a record in the range of $59 billion to $63 billion, up about 10 percent from last year. The previous high was $57.2 billion in 1988. Net cash income is the amount nationally that farmers have left from gross cash income in a calendar year after deducting cash expenses. It includes government payments and proceeds from crops grown previously but sold during the year. In another method of agency accounting, which includes changes in inventories, depreciation and other allowances during the year, 1990 net farm income may be in the range of $47 billion to $52 billion, compared with $47 billion last year. The Agriculture Department's first 1991 forecasts for food prices and farm income are scheduled to be released during an annual outlook conference here in late November.
