Based on preliminary figures that could be revised next month, the October price index for all crops was down 1.6 percent from September and averaged 4.7 percent less than a year earlier. The October index for livestock and products was down 1.2 percent from September but still averaged 5.6 percent more than in October 1989. Milk prices, reflecting stepped-up production, dropped 60 cents from September to an October average of $13.60 per 100 pounds. The October price was down $1.20 from a year earlier. The all-fruit price index in October was down 6.4 percent from September and 8.7 percent the October 1989 average. Lower prices for apples, oranges and grapefruit were mostly responsible for the decline from September. The report also said: -Cattle averaged $75.10 per 100 pounds of live weight nationally, up 10 cents from September. A year earlier, cattle averaged $68.70 per hundredweight. Those are averages for all types of cattle sold as beef. -Hogs averaged $56.90 per hundredweight, up from $54.30 in September and $46.60 a year earlier. -Corn, at $2.15 per bushel, was down from $2.32 in September and $2.22 a year earlier. -Wheat prices at the farm, according to preliminary figures, averaged $2.39 per bushel, compared with $2.46 in September and $3.75 in October 1989. -Rice averaged $6.34 per 100 pounds, against $6.25 in September and $7.37 a year earlier. -Soybeans were $5.90 per bushel, compared with $5.99 in September and $5.54 in October 1989. -Upland cotton was reported at 66.9 cents per pound, compared with 65 cents in September and 65.8 cents a year earlier. -Eggs were 73.5 cents per dozen, compared with 68.5 cents in September and 71.6 cents a year earlier. -Milk was $13.60 per hundredweight, against $14.20 in September and $14.80 in October 1989. -Broilers were 29 cents per pound, live weight, compared with 35.2 cents in September and 30.2 cents a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: 472 Rich Americans Paid No Tax in 1988
DOC.TEXT: It's not as easy as it used to be, but it's still possible to make $200,000 a year and avoid paying any federal income tax. In fact, 472 couples and individuals with incomes averaging $447,000 ``zeroed out'' on returns filed in 1988, the Internal Revenue Service says. That was down from 595 who paid no tax the previous year. In a report released Wednesday, the IRS said 557,848 returns showed income of $200,000 or better, making those people among the highest-earning 0.5 percent. In addition to those who paid no tax, 9,300 high-income people paid less than 5 percent while 17,082 paid under 10 percent - about the same as paid by the average $35,000-a-year family. The report, required annually by Congress, said 149 of the 472 used itemized deductions to wipe out their tax liability. Others relied on losses from farm, business and partnership operations. In contrast, only 76 of the well-to-do who paid no taxes reported losses on the sale of investments. Those capital losses averaged only $2,600. The IRS said 273 reported capital gains - profits from investment sales - that averaged more than $384,000. The analysis is based on raw tax returns. IRS audits could result in assessments that would move some of the couples and individuals out of the non-taxpaying category. The report said a special levy, called the alternative minimum tax, made taxpayers out of 3,396 high-income people who otherwise would have gotten off scot-free. This levy, designed to ensure that high earners pay some tax regardless of how many legitimate deductions they have, hit 35,223 people in the over-$200,000 group for a total of $1 billion. However, the alternative tax does not apply in all cases. Because capital gains now are taxed in the same fashion as ordinary income - eliminating capital gains as a tax-avoidance device - the take from the minimum tax was down sharply compared with returns filed in 1987. For that year, the minimum tax produced $4.8 billion from 158.903 high-income filers. Under orders from Congress, the IRS has been reporting the tax situation of upper-income Americans since 1977. In that year, there were 53 returns reporting income of $200,000 or more while paying no taxes. Although the law has been changed several times in an effort to prevent the well-to-do from shielding their income, the figure grew to 613 on returns filed in 1986. Analysts say anti-tax-shelter rules enacted in 1986 will continue to reduce the number. Through the years, the number of tax-free rich people has been only a tiny fraction of the wealthy. The new IRS report showed the 557,848 taxpayers in the $200,000-and-over group paid a total $72.7 billion, an average of $130,276 apiece. Here are some of the income and deduction items reported by the 472 who paid no tax: -381 claimed itemized deductions totaling $161 million, an average $423,000. -179 claimed business losses totaling $22 million while 71 listed business profits of $14 million. -Farm losses of $12 million were reported on 29 returns; only four reported farm profits, totaling $137,000. -Partnership losses of $123 million were shown on 256 untaxed returns. On the other hand, 73 reported partnership profits of $23 million. -436 received interest totaling $95 million. More than half of that was from tax-exempt investments. -322 had dividends, totaling $29 million. -Only 40 reported receiving pension payments, worth under $2 million. -55 had taxable Social Security benefits worth $305,000. -Alimony receipts were reported on only one return; they totaled $8,000. -Deductions for interest paid averaged $135,000; for medical expenses $186,000; for casualty losses, $405,000; for state and local taxes, $33,000; for charitable contributions, $87,000. Nearly 2,700 people with income over $200,000 received unemployment compensation during the year. Two of them paid no tax.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Kenny Rogers, Dolly Parton, Willie Nelson and George Strait are some of the stars in a package of 150,000 cassette tapes being donated by Nashville record companies to U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia. ``As long as they are there, we want to stand by our troops,'' said Ken Harding of New Haven Records, chairman of a committee that organized Operation Desert Song. Also heading for Saudi Arabia will be 500 copies of a two-hour videotape containing messages from recording artists and clips of their music videos. On the videotape, Reba McEntire said, ``Hurry up and come home 'cause we miss you. Thanks for keeping us safe.'' Tammy Wynette said: ``Hang in there until November. I promise I'm coming over to sing to all of you.'' --- NEW YORK (AP) - Dr. George Nichopoulous, Elvis Presley's personal physician for 11 years, discounts the claim of Presley biographer Albert Goldman that the King committed suicide. In his first interview since the King's death in 1977, Nichopoulos said on the syndicated TV program ``A Current Affair'' that Presley's death may have been caused by the pressures of stardom or psychological problems. But he said, ``I don't think Elvis was capable of committing suicide. ... (He) had many opportunities to commit suicide at much more stressful times.'' In 1981, Nichopoulos was acquitted of prescribing excessive amounts of narcotics to Presley and eight other patients. He was accused of prescribing more than 10,000 doses of drugs during the 18 months before Presley's death. The interview will air next week. --- MEMPHIS, Tenn. (AP) - Cybill Shepherd says movie studios are afraid to make a film about racism. ``Prejudice is ever present. It's just uncomfortable. People don't want to recognize it in themselves,'' the ``Moonlighting'' actress said Wednesday while promoting the TV movie ``Memphis,'' which airs next year. The movie is about the kidnapping of the grandson of a wealthy black businessman from Memphis in the 1950s. Ms. Shepherd plays a kidnapper who develops a maternal bond with the child. A Memphis native, Ms. Shepherd is one of the film's producers and helped write the script based on Shelby Foote's novel ``September, September.'' Ms. Shepherd said she began working in 1981 on the screenplay and looked for several years for a studio interested in making the movie, which Turner Network Television recently decided to back. --- APPLE VALLEY, Calif. (AP) - Cowboy star Roy Rogers is the ``terror of the hallways'' and anxious to leave the hospital where he is recovering from heart surgery, his son says. The 78-year-old actor, who appeared in 87 Westerns, probably will be released from St. Mary Desert Hospital this week, Roy ``Dusty'' Rogers Jr. said Wednesday. ``He's the terror of the hallways from what I understand. He's walking from room to room and going as far as he can go,'' he said. Rogers turns 79 on Monday, and the family usually holds one party for him, his wife, Dale Evans, who turned 78 Wednesday, and Dusty, who was 44 on Sunday. ``Dad was saying, `It's mom's birthday, I've got to go out and get her something.' I told him, `There ain't no way you're going to do it this year,''' Roy Jr. said. Rogers underwent a four-hour operation last month in which doctors replaced a weak spot in his aorta with a graft of Dacron. --- MILAN, Italy (AP) - Soccer great Pele celebrated his 50th birthday by playing with Brazil's national team against a group of world all-stars in what he said was possibly his last appearance on a soccer field. Pele, who led Brazil to three World Cup championships in the 1950s and '60s, wore the No. 10 jersey he made famous during the exhibition game Wednesday. Pele surrendered to fatigue and emotion after 40 minutes, during which he made some clean passes, missed a long goal shot and led a fast counterattack in the 2-1 loss. He ended his professional career in 1977 with the now-defunct New York Cosmos. --- CAMBRIDGE, Mass. (AP) - The red carpet has faded for Saudi Prince Turki bin Abdul Aziz. The prince has been stripped of a security detail made up of off-duty police officers from Harvard University. Harvard Vice President Daniel Steiner ordered an end to the guard detail, which reportedly earned officers at least $27,000 a week, to avoid the perception that it compromises routine police work. ``We had tried to be helpful to Prince Turki, and I think it went on longer than either he or we expected,'' Steiner said Tuesday. ``Our mission is providing security for Harvard.'' The prince has paid Harvard and Cambridge police to protect his entourage of 65 bunked in the top two floors of the Charles Hotel since their arrival in August. Turki, the fourth in line to the Saudi throne, at first received a royal welcome. But Cambridge residents have complained that his bodyguards kicked children out of a playground, and two photographers from the Harvard Crimson said they were threatened by royal bodyguards.

DOC.HEAD: Experts Say Gulf War Could Triple Oil Prices
DOC.TEXT: War in the Persian Gulf would send a shock wave through world oil markets aimed directly at the wallets of consumers, petroleum industry officials say. ``The day the war starts, prices will explode,'' John Lichtblau of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation told the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee on Wednesday, and ``there is no limit'' to how high prices could ise. Short of quickly winning a war against Iraq, he added, there is little the United States could do to control prices. Oil prices hovering in the $33 per barrel range could easily triple, said Professor Fariborz Ghadar of George Washington University's business school. ``I would not be surprised if oil prices reached $100 per barrel,'' he said. Translating a crude oil price increase into a higher price at the pump is an inexact science. But some industry experts use a ratio of 12 cents more per gallon for every $5 increase in the price of crude. At $100 per barrel, under that formula, gasoline could rise to nearly $3 per gallon at the pump. The reasons for the sharp price rise, the experts said, would be fear that war would disrupt supply lines, combined with the likelihood that a gulf war would curtail Saudi Arabia's oil-producing capabilities. With oil production already at or near capacity, oil-consuming states could do little beyond release oil reserves onto the market, the witnesses said. Conversely, they said, if Iraqi President Saddam Hussein suddenly ends the crisis by withdrawing his forces from Kuwait, the price of oil could drop just as suddenly to levels below those that preceded the Aug. 2 invasion. ``That range is likely to be reached approximately 48 hours after the crisis is over,'' Lichtblau said. If the stalemate continues, it is likely that oil prices will remain about where they are, the witnesses said, but they could jump quickly with any disruption of a supply system already straining to meet demand. ``This is a very tight market,'' Ghadar said. ``A pipe blowing up in Nigeria, a fire in Venezuela, some other disruption,'' could be enough to spread panic and push prices higher. The witnesses said there was little the United States could do to break up the oil cartel and that meantime, the simple laws of supply and demand would govern the price of oil. Witnesses rejected as unworkable, for example, a suggestion by Sen. Joseph Lieberman, D-Conn., that Saudi Arabia unilaterally lower the price of its crude in exchange for U.S. military support. The market would quickly absorb the cheap Saudi oil and no other countries would be compelled to lower their prices, Lichtblau said. The best the United States could hope for is more money from Saudi Arabia to help pay the cost of Operation Desert Shield, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Embargoed for release 10 a.m. EST; time set by source
Environmental, Consumer Groups Attack Troop Deployment
DOC.TEXT: Nine environmental and consumer groups are launching a campaign to convince Americans that Detroit automakers, not Saddam Hussein, are the reason U.S. troops are in the Middle East. The Coalition for Fuel Efficient Transportation is asking newspapers, television and radio stations to run free commercials with the message that the United States is on the brink of war over oil. ``This is Detroit's war, not the public's war,'' Jeremy Rifkin, president of a group called the Center for Sustainable Transportation, said Wednesday. ``If we begin conserving energy at home, we won't have to risk American lives in the Middle East.'' The coalition will sponsor advertisements in major newspapers, beginning with a $25,000 half-page ad in Friday editions of The New York Times, Rifkin said. It is asking radio and TV stations to run its commercials as public-service announcements, and some already have done so, he said. The campaign is designed to rekindle the battle over automobile fuel efficiency, Rifkin said. It faded in September, when opponents beat back efforts to force a Senate vote on a bill sponsored by Sen. Richard Bryan, D-Nev., to require new cars to average 40 miles per gallon by the turn of the century. The commercials urge Congress and the Bush administration to raise government fuel efficiency standards and boost the federal tax on gas-guzzling automobiles. U.S. oil imports have risen over the past 15 years although fuel efficiency has improved 100 percent, said Tom Hanna, president of the Motor Vehicle Manufacturers Association. ``Casting this business in the Middle East as a failure of U.S. energy policy is a rather mean-spirited interpretation of the president's actions,'' he said. In addition to Rifkin's groups, members of the coalition include the U.S Public Interest Research Group, the American Council for an Energy Efficiency Economy, the Center for Auto Safety, Citizen Action, Environmental Action, the National Toxics Campaign, Public Citizen and the Safe Energy Communications Council.

DOC.HEAD: Report Sees Millions Denied Care as Health Costs Rise
DOC.TEXT: Over the next decade, millions more Americans will be shut out of the health care system unless the federal government acts to prevent a national catastrophe, two social activist groups said. With the nation's health care costs expected to soar from $606 billion this year to $1.5 trillion by the turn of the century, America's quality of life is on the line, said Robert Brandon, vice president of Citizen Action. ``Increasingly, health care is becoming a luxury item that fewer and fewer individuals and families will be able to afford,'' Brandon said. ``The already frayed safety net will be in shreds by the end of the decade.'' A report by Citizen Action and Families USA Foundation, released Wednesday, projected meteoric rises in health care costs that it said would harm American businesses and hurt their competitiveness with foreign companies. Americans, too, would have to spend larger portions of their income on medical care and insurance, the report said. ``We've got to do something to get health care costs under control or health care is going to be unaffordable for millions of Americans,'' said Ron Pollack, executive director of Families USA Foundation. ``Unless the United States takes bold action now to curb health care costs, the explosion of health care costs will mean a declining standard of health care and a declining standard of living,'' he said. The report does not recommend any specific solutions to the problem of rising costs, but at a news conference Pollack said, ``This is a national problem. ... Ultimately we need a national system.'' Pollack and Brandon blamed the rising costs on a variety of factors, including insurance companies' inefficiencies, escalating fees for doctors and hospitals and uncoordinated use of expensive, sophisticated technology. The report, which lists state-by-state health care spending, identified Massachusetts as the largest per-capita spender. There, state and federal governments, residents, employers and other private sources will pay an estimated $3,031 for every man, woman and child in the state this year. The national average is estimated to be $2,425 this year, rising to $5,515 by the year 2000, according to the report. It based the estimates on 1987 Medicare and Medicaid data, changing demographics and a model of how those demographics will change health-care spending within states. The estimates are also based on state spending figures compiled by the Health Care Financing Administration in 1982, the last year the federal agency developed state figures. California was second to Massachusetts in health care spending, at $2,894 per capita, followed by New York, $2,818; Nevada, $2,757; Rhode Island, $2,707; Connecticut, $2,699; and North Dakota, $2,661, according to the report. By the turn of the century, per capita health care spending in these states will be more than $6,000, the report said. The lowest levels of per capita spending were in South Carolina, $1,689; Idaho, $1,726; Mississippi, $1,751; Wyoming, $1,756; and Utah, $1,784. In 10 years, these states will be spending nearly $4,000 per capita, according to the projections. Per capita spending over the 20 years from 1980 to 2000 is expected to grow fastest in Arizona, Alaska, New Mexico, Florida, Maine, North Dakota and Washington state, according to the report. Families USA Foundation is a nonprofit group working on behalf of low- and middle-income senior citizens and their families. Citizen Action is a national grassroots citizens' organization with chapters in 31 states.

DOC.NOTE: EDS: Note contents of last item
DOC.HEAD: Father Opposes Daughter's Candidacy
DOC.TEXT: A man urged voters to reject his daughter's candidacy for the state Assembly. James Nagle, 58, made his feelings known in a seven-page, handwritten letter to suburban newspapers criticizing Cliessa Nagle' pro-choice position on abortion. ``I don't understand how a father can treat his daughter this way,'' his daughter, Ms. Nagle, 31, said Wednesday. Nagle delivered letters to three newspapers in Montgomery County. His daughter, a Democrat, is challenging incumbent Republican state Rep. Robert W. Godshall. Cliessa Nagle says the abortion issue is merely a handy excuse for her father to try to ruin her political career. ``It's a very dysfunctional relationship,'' she said. ``And it's simply an attempt to derail his daughter's campaign in the final days. It's very unfortunate, very disturbing.''
DOC.HEAD: KPTV Poll Shows Roberts Pulling Ahead
DOC.TEXT: Democratic gubernatorial candidate Barbara Roberts has a slight edge over Republican Dave Frohnmayer, according to a new poll. Forty-two percent of the respondents to a statewide telephone survey of 605 voters favored Roberts for governor; 36 percent favored Frohnmayer, said the survey commissioned by KPTV-TV in Portland and conducted Oct. 22-26. The margin of error was four percentage points.
DOC.HEAD: Environmentalists Unveil Eastwood, Danson, Ritter Ads
DOC.TEXT: Actors Clint Eastwood and Ted Danson are appearing in TV ads supporting a ballot proposition to protect forests. Meanwhile, actors John Ritter, Kyle MacLachlan and Michael Ontkean are doing ads on behalf of another ballot proposition favored by growers and food companies. MacLachlan and Ontkean are stars of the ``Twin Peaks'' television show. That proposition is a pesticide initiative designed to weaken support for Proposition 128, the so-called Big Green initiative. Big Green would ban pesticides with cancer-causing ingredients. Eastwood and Danson are supporting the initiative which would authorize the sale of more than $700 million in bonds to buy and preserve old-growth redwood forests. It would also virtually ban clearcutting and impose other logging restrictions.
DOC.HEAD: Goddard Still Leading in Polls
DOC.TEXT: Democratic gubernatorial candidate Terry Goddard continues to lead Republican opponent Fife Symington, according to new polls. A poll published by the Arizona Republic says Goddard received 44 percent in the poll to Symington's 38 percent. Fifteen percent were undecided. The Republic's statewide poll was conducted Thursday through Sunday and 603 registered voters were interviewed. The poll has a margin of error of plus or minus 4 percentage points. Symington trailed by 17 points in a poll in September. In another poll, Goodard had a lead of 47 percent to 36 percent for Symington. The poll by Washington-based Political Media Research Inc. surveyed 812 registered Arizona voters last weekend. The margin of error is plus or minus 3.5 percentage points and was sponsored by Tribune Newspapers, KPNX-TV of Phoenix and KVOA-TV of Tucson.
DOC.HEAD: Battle By Hahns
DOC.TEXT: Lesson for the day: If you get your picture taken with someone, know who the someone is. In the Los Angeles County assessor's race, candidate Kenneth P. Hahn sent out campaign mail showing him posing with two other people named Hahn. All three are smiling for the camera and a line reads ``Kenneth P. Hahn for County Assessor, with Supervisor Kenneth Hahn and City Attorney James Hahn carrying on the tradition of the Hahn name.'' The only problem is that the supervisor and his son the city attorney support Kenneth Hahn's opponent, incumbent John Lynch. The supervisor and city attorney said the picture was taken at a Democratic party gathering and that they didn't know with whom they were posing. ``If somebody is going to be misleading or deceptive, we certainly don't want him to be the county assessor,'' said city attorney Hahn.
DOC.HEAD: Miller Leads Isakson, One Week Before Election
DOC.TEXT: Democrat gubernatorial candidate Zell Miller is maintaining his lead over Republican Johnny Isakson, 54 percent to 36 percent, according to a new poll. Ten percent were undecided in the poll conducted Oct. 24-28 by The Atlanta Journal-Constitution. It was based on interviews with 691 likely voters. The margin of error is 4 percentage points. A poll released by the newspaper Sept. 29 found Miller with 54 percent and Isakson with 33 percent.
DOC.HEAD: Sex Education Measure Provides Fodder in State Race
DOC.TEXT: The campaign in a General Assembly race is sounding more like a sermon filled with hellfire and brimstone. The Democratic incumbent, state Rep. Lynn Taborsak, is under attack for proposing legislation earlier this year encouraging young people to masturbate to avoid sexually transmitted diseases and unwanted pregnancies. ``The Bible says cast your seed into the belly of a whore rather than onto the ground,'' Republican candidate Alex Nahas said recently, referring to the character Onan in the book of Genesis whose name has become synonymous with masturbation. ``It violates every religious principle in the Bible,'' said Nahas, who believes sex education should be reserved for the home. Taborsak's measure, which was circulated in the House but never formally introduced or debated, called on young people to practice masturbation until they are ready for marriage. Taborsak says she only introduced the measure to derail a Republican amendment requiring that students be taught abstinence from premarital sex as the ``expected norm.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Expected To Sign Bill on TV Violence
DOC.TEXT: Legislation giving the television industry a three-year antitrust exemption to adopt voluntary guidelines on violence in programming is awaiting President Bush's signature. The House and Senate included the provision in a bill on the federal judiciary passed during the waning hours of the 101st Congress. Bush is expected to sign the measure, according to an aide to Sen. Paul Simon. The Illinois Democrat, who has been trying to get such legislation passed since 1985, has cited studies that show by age 16, the average American child has seen 200,000 acts of violence on television, including 33,000 murders. Simon said the bill could help ``scale back the atmosphere of violence'' on television. The American Civil Liberties Union has attacked the bill as being a ``Trojan Horse'' that could lead to censorship of TV programming. But Simon and the bill's House author, Rep. Dan Glickman, D-Kan., said the bill merely gives the TV industry an easy way to lower the level of violence without losing audiences to more-violent competitors and without violating antitrust laws. ``Each network is reluctant to take unilateral steps to reduce violent programming for fear of slipping in the ratings,'' Glickman said. ``The bill in no way attempts to dictate programming policy.'' Simon's bill had passed the Senate and House in previous sessions, but never had gotten to the president's desk.

DOC.HEAD: Accused Terrorist Turned Over to Israel
DOC.TEXT:
The State Department says it has turned Mahmoud Atta over to Israeli authorities to face terrorism charges. Atta, who also uses the name Mahmoud El-Abed Ahmad, was placed in Israeli custody and immediately taken out of the United States, spokesman Adam Shub said Wednesday. The imminence of the transfer and threats from a terrorist group to act if it were carried out prompted the department to issue an unusual alert last Friday warning that terrorists might be panning an attack on passenger ships in the eastern Mediterranean Sea. The department said then it had ``specific and credible'' information about such an attack that ``may be undertaken at any time.'' Wednesday evening, Shub said he had nothing to add to the alert. Atta, 37 and a U.S. citizen, has been accused of taking part in the 1986 machine gun attack on a bus carrying Jewish settlers in the occupied West Bank. The driver was killed and a passenger wounded. He was arrested in the United States three years ago. On Aug. 31, the Supreme Court rejected his last appeal in a court battle to avoid extradition. The Abu Nidal Organization, a terrorist group of which Atta was a member, has threatened ``to attack U.S. interests'' if Atta were extradited, the department said.
---
DOC.HEAD: `White House Connection' Gets 10 Years on Cocaine Sale Conviction
DOC.TEXT:
A high school senior accused of selling the crack cocaine President Bush used as a prop in an anti-drug speech was sentenced to 10 years in prison for his conviction of three counts of selling cocaine. Keith Jackson, 19, was arrested last September after being lured by Drug Enforcement Administration agents to Lafayette Square, across the street from the White House. The DEA set up the alleged drug sale in Lafayette Square to dramatize how easy it is to buy drugs in the nation's capital. Two juries deadlocked on that charge, once in December 1989 and again last January. But the January jury convicted Jackson of three counts of distributing drugs in other locations before the Lafayette Square sale, including a count of selling crack within 1,000 feet of a school. That crime carries an automatic 10-year sentence. The same jury acquitted Jackson of using a telephone to further a narcotics deal. U.S. District Judge Stanley Sporkin on Wednesday told Jackson, who had no prior criminal record, that he regretted having to impose the sentence of 10 years without parole. He urged Jackson to ask Bush for a commutation. ``He used you, in the sense of making a big drug speech. But he's a decent man, a man of great compassion. Maybe he can find a way to reduce at least some of that sentence,'' said Sporkin, the former CIA general counsel appointed to the bench by President Reagan in 1986. ``You have to realize, you are on the road to getting into very, very serious trouble. I think you're a nice young man and you have a future. But I do believe you were out of control for a period of time,'' Sporkin said. Jackson's lawyer, Charles Stow III, said because of his client's publicity from the Bush speech, the authorities made an example of him.
---
DOC.HEAD: Device Capable Of Detecting Plastic Explosives Goes Into Service
DOC.TEXT: A device said to be capable of detecting the kind of plastic explosive that destroyed Pan Am flight 103 is now being used at Dulles International Airport near Washington. James B. Busey, administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration, said Wednesday that the Thermal Neutron Analysis or TNA device represents a ``significant improvement in performance'' over earlier generations of detection technology. ``The machine has the capability of detecting the explosives that we think were present on Pan Am 103,'' the airliner destroyed over Scotland two years ago, Busey said. The Dulles detector put in service Wednesday is the fourth to be installed at international airports in an FAA program to test capabilities and build an enhanced anti-terrorist security system at airports worldwide. Other TNA units are at John F. Kennedy International Airport in New York, the Miami international airport nd Gatwick Airport near London. Busey said tentative plans call for similar explosive devices to be installed at airports in Frankfurt, Germany and at the Baltimore-Washington airport in Maryland. Adaption of the TNA device, the only technology now believed able to detect plastic explosives of the kind that brought down Pan Am 103, coincides with a report from the National Academy of Sciences concluding that the FAA is essentially on the right track.

DOC.HEAD: Racial Fears Stirred By Plan to Bring Subway to the Suburbs
DOC.TEXT: Atlanta's rapid transit system is beckoning to booming suburban Gwinnett County, but some voters there want to derail the expansion because of fears that blacks from the city will stream out on buses and trains. Others say they simply don't want to pay for it. Gwinnett County voters decide Nov. 6 whether to bring the Metropolitan Atlanta Rapid Transit Authority into the county in exchange for a 1 percent sales tax. County Commissioner W.J. Dodd said his constituents oppose the idea, and he predicted it would fail. ``One of the worst fears is bringing people out of Atlanta, the minorities,'' he said. Dodd refused to say where he stands on the expansion. Blacks and other minorities make up only 6.4 percent of Gwinnett's 355,000 residents. Blacks make up 66 percent of Atlanta's 425,000 people. Voters in the northeastern Atlanta suburb rejected mass transit service in 1971. That same year, Fulton and DeKalb counties - which make up Atlanta - became the first in the nation to pay voluntarily for a mass transit system. The sales tax they approved has not kept pace with MARTA's expenses, though. The system in July raised bus and train fares 15 cents to $1 rather than cut service. MARTA, the South's first mass transit system, now transports 280,000 bus riders and 220,000 rail passengers daily. The rail line stretches in four directions from downtown Atlanta to Fulton and DeKalb suburbs and to Hartsfield Atlanta International Airport. Residents of Gwinnett County, whose population has quintupled since 1971, depend on their cars - 311,000 of them. Traffic is bumper-to-bumper from Gwinnett into downtown Atlanta most weekdays. MARTA officials estimate mass transit could take 25,000 cars off the county's roads, and ridership in Gwinnett could reach 60,000 by the year 2010. Opponents argue that the masses would finance the expansion but that only businesses trying to attract low-wage workers would benefit. The plan's foes have taken their campaign to grocery stores and malls, handing out Ban MARTA stickers. Supporters of the plan have put up signs on Interstate 85 into Gwinnett County that read, ``Gwinnett's Future is Riding on MARTA.'' Radio spots tout the benefits of public transportation. ``Some people have said they oppose MARTA because they are concerned about crime and a decrease in their property values,'' said Richard Myrick, a Gwinnett businessman leading the expansion effort. Myrick and others are trying to assure residents that public transportation won't ruin their neighborhoods. If voters approve, MARTA will spend $681 million to extend a rail line 10.8 miles toward Gwinnett Place Mall in Duluth. The line would be completed by 1998. Gwinnett County residents would pay a 1 percent sales tax until the year 2032 and a 1.5 percent sales tax for the next eight years until the contract expired in 2040. The current sales tax in Gwinnett County is 5 percent. A Gwinnett Daily News poll last month found that 60 percent of voters surveyed opposed the sales tax. Twenty-six percent of the 500 voters said they would foot the bill; the remainder were undecided. The newspaper gave no margin of error for the poll. Anna Roupe said she would vote against the expansion. ``The people of Gwinnett County can't afford it,'' she said. ``As far as I'm concerned, for me, it's my pocketbook. There is no other issue.'' Joe Lupton of Snellville said there is another issue for county residents: crime. ``I would hasten to say they fear for their lives,'' he said. Gwinnett County Commission Chairman Lillian Webb, the only commissioner who has voiced support for the expansion, lamented that many people see it as a racial issue. ``Some of them have said, ``We don't want those people out here.' It upsets me. The other races, other ethnic groups contribute to our cultural diversity,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Examples of Changes in College Entrance Exam
With PM-SAT Changes, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are examples of changes in the Scholastic Aptitude Test, announced by the College Board on Wednesday. The new test will be known as SAT-I; an expanded version of an optional test now offered with the SAT will be called SAT-II.
DOC.HEAD: VERBAL SECTION
DOC.TEXT: Current SAT: 85 questions, 60 minutes. SAT-I: 75 to 85 verbal questions, 75 to 90 minutes. The new test will have longer reading comprehension passages. At least half the verbal section will be devoted to critical reading.
DOC.HEAD: MATH SECTION
DOC.TEXT: Current SAT: 60 questions, 60 minutes. SAT-I: 55 to 60 questions, 60 to 75 minutes. The new test will include questions that require students to produce their own answers instead of picking an answer from multiple choices. Such questions will make up about 20 percent of the math section. Sample: Martin and Alice buy newspapers for 20 cents each and sell them for 25 cents each. If, at the end of one week, Martin made a profit of $12.60 and Alice made a profit of $18.75, how many more papers did Alice sell than Martin? (Answer: 123.)

Essay questions will be included. Sample: Consider carefully the following quotation and the assignment following it. Then, plan and write your essay as directed. ``People seldom stand up for what they truly believe; instead they merely go along with the popular view.'' Assignment: Do you agree or disagree with this statement? Write an essay in which you support your opinion with specific examples from history, contemporary affairs, literature or personal observation.

DOC.HEAD: South Bronx Clinic Fighting to Preserve Abortion Counseling
DOC.TEXT: Eighteen-year-old Rita Roundtree says she wants information about abortion if the pregnancy test she took this week turns out positive. But the Planned Parenthood clinic in her blighted South Bronx neighborhood won't be able to provide such information - either for or against abortion - if a federal ban on such counseling is upheld by the U.S. Supreme Court. The clinic's medical director, Dr. Irving Rust, is leading a battle to overturn the regulation, which was enacted under the Reagan administration in 1988 but has not been enforced pending court appeals. On Tuesday, the Supreme Court heard arguments in the case, in which Rust, Planned Parenthood, and the city and state are challenging the law. A decision is expected in July. A federal judge in New York City and a federal appeals court panel upheld the regulation, but other federal courts around the country have ruled it an unconstitutional infringement on free speech. The law bans abortion counseling at health clinics that receive federal funds. Twenty-seven percent of the South Bronx clinic's funds - about $450,000 a year - come from the government. If the law is upheld, said Jeannine Michael, the clinic's director, Ms. Roundtree could neither be counseled for or against abortion. ``You may have a woman come in and say, `I'm here for an abortion,' and you don't accept that on face value,'' she said. ``You may find out ... that in fact she has been coerced into having an abortion that she doesn't want.'' If she is pregnant, Ms. Roundtree said, she wants advice about getting an abortion. ``To me, by having a baby, would have me get behind,'' said the young woman, who is looking for a job. Another patient, 19-year-old Sharice Jackson, said the clinic plays a crucial role in the well-being of South Bronx residents. ``Without this place, I don't think my generation would have any other place to go, because, with the way things are going with teen-age pregnancies, you need a place that you can go to get options to know what you can do,'' she said. The clinic is in one of the country's poorest communities. Its acres of abandoned and vandalized buildings have become a symbol of urban decay. Most of its residents are black or Hispanic. Eighty percent of the students entering the ninth grade in the South Bronx don't graduate. For many of the 6,000 women and teen-agers who visit the clinic each year it is their only source for a full range of medical services, including routine gynecological care, prenatal care, abortion, abortion counseling, AIDS testing and baby care. ``(We have been) particularly involved in trying to make sure that our clients get as much good care as would a woman .. getting private, expensive medical care,'' Rust said. The ban on abortion counseling would put an end to that, he said. He added that many women whose pregnancies threaten their lives need to know about the option of abortion. ``I get a lot of women who come in with serious medical problems - anemia, diabetes, high blood pressure,'' he said. ``Sometimes they come in with emotional problems and a lot of genetic problems.''

DOC.HEAD: Jew Stabbed By Arab As Violence Continues
DOC.TEXT: An Arab stabbed a Jewish man several times in the chest in a Tel Aviv suburb on Thursday in a continuing wave of violence that began with last's month Temple Mount killings. The 48-year-old Israeli Jew was on his way work when he was stabbed near his home in Rishon Lezion, said district police spokesman Eli Maimon. He was hospitalized and listed in satisfactory condition. Israel army radio said extra police were deployed at nearby major junctions to search for the assailant and prevent revenge attacks by Israelis on Arabs. The attack apparently was the latest in a spate of revenge attacks set off by the police response to an Oct. 8 Palestinian riot on the Temple Mount in Jerusalem. Twenty Palestinians were killed in police gunfire. Since then, attacks by both Arabs and Israelis have left six people dead and more than 10 wounded. After last week's revenge attacks, Defense Minister Moshe Arens closed off the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip for four days, barring Palestinians from entering Israel. On Monday, Arens announced tougher restrictions for Palestinians entering Israel from the occupied lands, saying he would ban all those with records of crime or nationalist political activity.

DOC.HEAD: College Board Changes SAT, But Not Enough for Critics
With PM-SAT Samples
LaserPhoto BX11 of Oct. 31
DOC.TEXT: In a few years, college-bound students will have to give their own answers to some Scholastic Aptitude Test math problems instead of picking from multiple choices. But they'll be able to use a calculator. Those are among changes announced Wednesday by the College Board, sponsor of the SAT, the most widely used college entrance exam in the nation. The revisions - the most drastic in the test's 64-year history - also include more emphasis on reading comprehension. The revised SAT, called SAT-I, will be introduced in 1994, board President Donald M. Stewart said. In addition, an optional test, known as the SAT-II, will be phased in starting next year and will include an essay section. Critics who have charged that the test is culturally biased and a poor judge of students' ability said the changes don't go far enough. ``It's polish. It's adding new tailfins to the Edsel,'' says Bob Schaeffer, public education director at FairTest, a Cambridge, Mass.-based group critical of the SAT. ``The SAT should be optional and it should be comprehensively overhauled to address its problems.'' Stewart said the revisions were aimed in part at reducing students' reliance on test coaches. The changes will increase the SAT's ``educational relevance and quality for all college-bound students,'' he said. He denied the changes were prompted by charges that the SAT is biased, particularly against women and minorities. ``Nothing could be further from the truth,'' Stewart said at the board's annual meeting in Boston. ``The SAT has been in almost continual evolution. It has never been set in concrete.'' Gregg Driben, national director of pre-college programs for Stanley Kaplan Educational Center Ltd., which prepares students for standardized tests, said professional coaches still will play an important role. The old SAT had 85 verbal and 60 math questions. SAT-I will have 75 to 85 verbal and 55 to 60 math questions. The new math questions requiring students to produce an answer on their own will make up about 20 percent of the math section. Sarah Stockwell, FairTest's university tests coordinator, said letting test-takers use calculators ``is going to make worse an already existing income bias'' because low-income students may not have access to a calculator. Observers had predicted the essay would be included in the main SAT. But Gregory Anrig, president of the Educational Testing Service of Princeton, N.J., which administers the test, said field trials showed an essay would make the exam too long. The SAT first was given to 8,040 students in 1926. Now about 1 million college-bound students take it every year. The 2{-hour exam currently consists of two multiple-choice sections that test verbal and math skills. Each section is worth 800 points, for a perfect score of 1,600. FairTest and other critics have claimed that the SAT tends to cover subjects that male and affluent test-takers are more likely to be familiar with, such as sports and finance. Whites as a group have outperformed minority students, and males have fared better than females. In 1988 the National Organization for Women filed a lawsuit that forced the New York State Education Department to stop using the SAT exclusively to award state merit scholarships. The department now uses high school grades as well. While College Board officials have steadfastly denied bias allegations, a panel of educators the board appointed to evaluate SAT revisions said the charges ``frequently stem from deep-seated concerns that call for a thoughtful remedy or response.''

DOC.HEAD: Maine Caribou Restoration Effort Ends
LaserPhoto AU1 of Oct. 31
DOC.TEXT: An effort to restore caribou to the wilds of Maine has been pronounced a failure after predators killed many of the ungainly reindeer. The Maine Caribou Project Inc. announced Wednesday that it is abandoning its 4-year-old effort. Project officials said they doubt they can raise the money needed to transplant enough caribou to create a self-sustaining herd. Of the 32 caribou released in Maine, 25 are confirmed dead - 12 killed by bears and coyotes. The rest are unaccounted for, but biologists believe only two or three are alive, and they apparently have lost the radio collars used to keep track of them. Four caribou calves also were born in the wild. Two died of unknown causes; a bear and bobcat killed the others. Caribou once were so abundant in Maine's north woods that a city was named after the animal. But overhunting and disease left the North American reindeer extinct in Maine more than 80 years ago. The restoration effort, which began with a caribou roundup in a remote corner of Newfoundland, was the second since 1963. When the lastest caribou releases were planned, project leaders' main worry was the deadly parasite known as brainworm. ``The whole black bear thing was something none of the (biologists) considered to be a critical factor in the beginning,'' project spokesman Richard B. Anderson said. ``I think it's possible to restore the caribou to its former range,'' he said. ``But you need a lot of animals.'' That would take more money that project leaders believe they can raise in a weakening economy. Biologists believe they'd need 50 to 100 more caribou to succeed, but it would cost at least $300,000 to capture, transport and monitor that many animals. The project, which officially ends Dec. 31, has raised $500,000 so far. ``We have come to realize that only under an extraordinary set of circumstances would it have been possible to complete a project of this magnitude without organizational and financial support of federal or state wildlife agencies,'' project leaders said in a statement. The project's failure shows money ``is far better spent to conserve Maine's endangered species today, while they still exist,'' the statement said. Project leaders said they will share information with officials in Minnesota, Wisconsin and Idaho, where caribou reintroduction projects are proposed or under way. The last caribou from a native Maine herd was spotted on mile-high Mount Katahdin in 1908. In 1963, about two dozen caribou were released in northern Maine's Baxter State Park. All of the animals disappeared because of poaching, disease, predators and natural dispersal, biologists believe. In 1986, more than two dozen caribou in Newfoundland were shot with tranquilizer darts and taken by helicopter and in trucks to enclosures at the University of Maine in Orono, 1,200 miles away. Biologists kept the ``nursery herd'' in Orono to breed young caribou for eventual releases in Maine's wilds. Of the dozen released in Baxter park in April 1989, only one was known to have survived by the end of that year. But project leaders discovered that caribou were more susceptible to brainworm when penned. So all 20 animals in the breeding herd were released, and plans were being made to import up to 75 more caribou from Newfoundland. In January, however, the Baxter park's board denied permission for a spring release. Board members criticized the way the project had been run.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Says Give Sanctions Time; Iraqi Shortages Expected In Mid-Winter
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The U.N.-ordered embargo on trade with Iraq are biting Baghdad ``every day more and more,'' and should force its economy to grind to a halt by midwinter, the Finnish diplomat overseeing the embargo says. ``Nobody really thought that the sanctions would have a great effect in a few weeks,'' Marjatta Rasi, Finland's deputy ambassador, said Wednesday. She heads the Security Council's committee on sanctions. ``I understand that at the beginning of next year they will have serious problems,'' Ms. Rasi said. ``It's not only food, it's everything.'' ``The functioning of the society will slow down because they cannot receive spare parts, even though they have taken everything they could from Kuwait,'' Ms. Rasi said. She said Iraq had also been a great importer of chemicals, ``and that is one great problem for them.'' Ms. Rasi said ``the sanctions bite every day more and more.'' ``The food situation is not that bad, but the selection is not that good,'' she said. Since no other nations are buying Iraqi or Kuwaiti oil, Baghdad is not earning any foreign exchange. The Iraqi dinar is almost worthless outside the country. In any event, the committee has no desire to starve the Iraqi or Kuwaiti population, she added. The only items that may be sent to Iraq under the embargo are medicine and medical equipment, and, in humanitarian circumstances, food. On Aug. 6, the Security Council ordered a trade and financial embargo of Iraq and occupied Kuwait. On Aug. 25, it gave the United States and other naval powers the right to enforce the economic embargo against Iraq and Kuwait by halting shipping to those countries. On Sept. 13, the council voted to allow humanitarian food aid into Iraq or Kuwait only ``to relieve human suffering,'' and said only the council could decide when those circumstances exist. The Council on Sept. 24 stressed that only its sanctions committee has the power to permit food, medicine or other humanitarian aid to be sent into Iraq or occupied Kuwait. The following day, the council explicitly expanded its economic embargo to include all air traffic in or out of Iraq and Kuwait, except for cargos of humanitarian aid specifically authorized by its sanctions committee. Passengers were not banned. Finland chairs the Security Council's sanctions committee; the membership is the same as the council itself: the United States, Soviet Union, Britain, France, China, Canada, Colombia, Cuba, Ethiopia, Finland, Ivory Coast, Malaysia, Romania, Yemen and Zaire.

DOC.HEAD: Amnesty International Accuses Britain Over Refugees
DOC.TEXT: Amnesty International said today that Britain has refused entry to asylum-seekers who risk being returned to countries where they could face imprisonment, torture and death. A report by the London-based human rights group said Britain's refugee-determination system fails to uphold its obligations under the U.N. Convention on Refugees. ``As many as 100, and possibly many more, persons seeking asylum in the United Kingdom have been summarily and unlawfully expelled without a proper examination of their asylum claim,'' the 42-page report said without giving a specific number or time frame. ``In addition, an untold number of would-be asylum seekers have been prevented from gaining access to the United Kingdom's refugee-determination process,'' it added. The Home Office, in charge of immigration, said the report failed to recognize that most asylum-seekers were not fleeing political persecution under the terms of the 1951 U.N. convention. It said unfounded asylum claims were now widespread as a means of circumventing normal immigration controls and that Britain has been flooded with applications in recent years. The Amnesty report charged that Britain gives insufficient advice to asylum-seekers and that officials subject them to arbitrary and prolonged detention while their cases are being considered. It said most of those who arrive saying they are seeking asylum have no right of appeal when refused it. It said visa requirements and fines on airlines that arrive with foreign passengers who don't have proper travel documents have combined to obstruct bona fide asylum-seekers from gaining effective access to Britain's refugee-determination system. The Home Office statement said refugee-determination systems throughout Europe and North America are overwhelmed by unfounded claims and that backlogs in the two regions have doubled to more than 400,000 cases since 1985. It said that in Britain, applications for asylum have risen fivefold since 1988 and have reached more than 20,000 in the past 12 months. It said backlogged applications in Britain now number 27,000.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Gains For Third Straight Day, Stocks Plummet
DOC.TEXT: The dollar gained against the Japanese yen for the third consecutive day today, while share prices tumbled. The dollar closed at 130.70 yen, up 1.35 yen from Wednesday's 129.35-yen finish. It opened at 130.60 yen and ranged between 130.35 yen and 130.81 yen. The dollar now has climbed 3.35 yen in three days. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues fell 898.94 points, or 3.57 percent, to 24,295.16. In bond dealings, the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds fell to 84.30 points from 84.60 points at Wednesday's close. Their yield rose to 7.860 percent from 7.790 percent. Foreign exchange dealers said the dollar's strength followed its rise on overseas markets. In New York, it climbed to 130.105 yen from 128.725 yen on Tuesday. ``The dollar is on an upward trend, and major participants are just buying the dollar,'' said Minori Takeuchi, an analyst at Chemical Bank. Trading was active, with spot transactions totaling $14.758 billion, up from Wednesday's $10.516 billion. ``Japanese investors are trying to find the upper edge of the dollar, and may push it as high as the 131-132 yen level,'' said Masato Hayashi, a Bank of Tokyo dealer. On the stock market, dealers said the weaker yen and declining bond prices pushed share prices down. Many investors were sitting on the sidelines, they said. ``Higher oil prices and prolonged pessimism over the Persian Gulf situation are other factors,'' said Kazuyuki Suzuki of Daiwa Securities. The Japanese economy is particularly vulnerable to a disruption of energy supplies from the Middle East. The country imports 99 percent of its oil, and about 70 percent comes from the Persian Gulf area. Trading was sluggish, and volume on the First Section was estimated at 350 million shares, down from 400 million shares Wednesday. Losers outnumbered gainers 1,003 to 29, with 41 issues unchanged.

DOC.HEAD: Gay Demonstrators Revile Christian Crusade
DOC.TEXT: An evangelist ordered the devil to get out of the San Francisco area without delay as a shrieking crowd of 1,000 pro-homosexual activists cursed him and his 5,000 Hallowen ``prayer warriors.'' The two-hour confrontation Wednesday evening took place at the Civic Center Auditorium, the site of a Christian crusade organized by evangelists who say the city is plagued by immoral homosexuals, crime, witchcraft and general sin. The protesters, who contended the meeting was an attack on homosexuality, shouted profanities, waved insulting signs, shrieked, chanted and blocked buses bringing the crusaders from some 250 Northern California churches. They put up a 12-foot paper penis in the form of a cross in front of barricades. ``We're queer, we're here, get used to it!'' they yelled. The demonstrators were held back by dozens of police in riot gear. At one point, police had to reach in and pull crusade participants through the crowd and into the auditorium, where they and and their belongings were searched. The shrieking got so loud that officers put their hands over their ears. The confrontation ended two hours after it started when the demonstrators matched to the mainly gay Castro District, where the city's typically outrageous Halloween festivities drew more than 150,000 people, many in drag. ``This is just good clean fun for us, a celebration of our lifestyle,'' said Joe Van Es-Ballesteros, organizer of the drag extravaganza. After the three-hour revival, motorcyclists tossed a tear gas canister into a crowd leaving the hall, police said. Police donned gas masks and some 300 people, their eyes tearing, fled upwind, holding handkerchiefs over their faces. Officers said the canister hit a youth, who was treated for a cut on his head. The motorcyclists escaped. Inside the hall, Texas evangelist Larry Lea, who organized the crusade along with San Jose minister Dick Bernal, told a rapt audience that the San Francisco region was beset by ``heavy ... depressing'' spirits. As the audience prayed and shouted their love of Christ, some in a joyful frenzy, the 39-year-old Lea ordered, ``Spirit of rejection, begone from this area.'' Lea, who distributes ``prayer army dog tags'' and has donned military fatigues in previous crusades, said Halloween was selected to launch his assault on sin because, according to legend, demons are strongest at that time. ``This is not just kids having fun,'' he said. ``There is actual worship of the devil.'' The event is a function of a Pentecostal-Charismatic movement that sees satanic princes and ``territorial spirits'' ruling over particular cities, industries and subcultures.

DOC.HEAD: Karpov and Kasparov End Ninth Game in Draw
With PM-Chess-Algebraic
DOC.TEXT: Anatoly Karpov blundered into a draw in the ninth game of the world chess championship against Garry Kasparov, leaving the match tied at 4{ points each. Karpov offered the defending champion a draw after 34 moves Wednesday night. Chess experts agreed Karpov's advantage slipped away when he lost a pawn on the 32nd move. Grandmaster Maxim Dlugy called it ``the most horrible blunder of this match.'' ``No one can remember Karpov making an error like this in his tournament career,'' said grandmaster Nick de Firmian. The contestants have a victory and seven draws apiece. A victory is worth a point, a draw a half-point. The first player to gain 12{ points wins the championship and $1.7 million of a $3 million purse. The first 12 games are being played in New York, and the remainder will be in Lyon, France. Game 10 will be Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Ship's Crew And Marines Remember Their 10 Dead Mates
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Navy sailors and Marines aboard the USS Iwo Jima held a memorial service today for 10 mates killed in a steam leak in the boiler room of the amphibious assault ship. More than 1,000 American servicemen stood to attention on deck to honor the victims of Tuesday's accident, which claimed the highest casualty toll the Navy has suffered since Operation Desert Shield began in August. ``It was a somber ceremony that lasted about 40 minutes,'' Lt. Jeff Gradeck, a spokesman for Command Naval Forces at Central Command, said after returning to Manama from the ship, which is anchored at the Bahrain Port. Six of the victims were killed instantly when the searing steam burst out of a ruptured pipe in the boiler room. Four died of severe burns after they were ferried to the USS Comfort, one of two hospital ships assigned to Operation Desert Shield. All the bodies had been flown out before the memorial service, which reporters and photographers were not allowed to attend. But reporters were later briefed on the event, which was launched by a Color Guard of Navy and Marine personnel carrying the U.S., Navy and Marine Corps flags and parading on deck. A Navy band played the national anthem. The servicemen sang the Navy hymn then let off a volley of rifle fire in salute as trumpets played taps. The Marines were in battle dress, the officers in khaki and sailors in dungarees. Servicemen told stories about their departed mates, remembering the laughs, games and work they shared. Chaplains read verses from the Bible and Capt. Michael O'Hearn, the Iwo Jima's commanding officer, paid tribute to the fallen men in a eulogy. With O'Hearn were Vice Admiral Henry H. Mauz, the overall commander of the more than 50 warships deployed in the region, U.S. Ambassador to Bahrain Charles Hostler and commanders from other warships. Also present was Rear Adm. J. B. Laplante, who was flown from the USS Nassau in the Arabian Sea to investigate the accident. Forty-three American servicemen have died in Operation Desert Shield, which has drawn more than 220,000 American forces to the region. It was launched in response to Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Before Tuesday's accident, the Navy had lost only one sailor who was electrocuted in August aboard the cruiser USS Antietam. The Iwo Jima, which is based at Norfolk, Va., has on board 1,100 Marines complementing the crew of normally 685 members.

DOC.HEAD: 7-Year-Old Dies, Poisoned Candy Suspected
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with report that girl also had heart condition; ADDS another youngster shot for refusing to hand over candy. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A 7-year-old girl collapsed and died while trick-or-treating, and police were investigating today whether her death was caused by a heart condition or poisoned candy. Ariel Katz had been collecting candy with a group of children chaperoned by two adults when she collapsed Wednesday night, said police Lt. James Dawson. Her parents told authorities she had a heart murmur, but police said they were checking her candy to see if it was poisoned. ``She had been eating some candy as she went,'' Dawson said. In nearby Los Angeles, an 11-year-old was shot and wounded on Halloween when he refused to hand over his candy to four teen-agers, police sad. He was treated at a hospital and released. No arrests were made.

DOC.HEAD: Military Government Bans Unauthorized Monks Organizations
DOC.TEXT: After sending troops to raid rebellious Buddhist monasteries, the military government has banned unauthorized monks' groups and threatened offenders with up to three years imprisonment. The prime minister, Gen. Saw Maung, issued a decree on Wednesday banning all groups except those formed under the auspices of the main Buddhist governing body, the central Sangha. Offenders faced six months to three years in prison, according to the decree, which was carried by the official Radio Rangoon Wednesday. The central Sangha was formed in 1980 by a previous military-backed government to regulate the clergy in the predominately Buddhist nation. The current military government came to power in crushing a 1988 national uprising for democracy. It has refused to hand over power to an opposition party that won May general elections, and instead arrested party leaders and other dissidents. Monks began their protest by refusing to minister to soldiers after troops in the central city of Mandalay broke up a demonstration in early August, reportedly killing two monks and two other people. On Oct. 21, Saw Maung issued a decree giving army commanders martial law power to bring monks before military tribunals for activities deemed disruptive to Buddhism. Sentences dispensed by such tribunals range from a minimum of three years to a maximum of death. The next day, troops began raiding monasteries in Mandalay to break the monks' boycott. Political sources in Rangoon, contacted from Bangkok, said many monks were detained in the raids, but it was unclear if the army had succeeded in forcing an end to the boycott. One source, speaking on condition of anonymity, said it would be difficult to break the boycott because groups of monks as large as 500 had entered into compacts to begin it. These vows could be undone only if all those who took the vow were reassembled, he said. State radio on Tuesday quoted the Mandalay commander, Maj. Gen. Tun Kyi, as saying registration cards should be issued to all monks as soon as possible.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Lifts `Learnfare' Injunction in Wisconsin
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge has lifted an injunction that had halted in the Milwaukee area a first-in-the-nation, statewide program that ties welfare benefits to school attendance. U.S. District Judge Terence Evans, who had suspended the Learnfare program in July because of administrative errors, said the state and Milwaukee County had agreed to safeguards to prevent families' benefits from being cut by mistake. Gov. Tommy G. Thompson hailed the decision Wednesday, saying it paved the way for the state to proceed with ``an even more effective welfare reform program.'' Learnfare allows the state to cut a family's welfare benefits if a teen-ager has more than two unexcused absences a month. A mother of two, for instance, can lose $77 of her $517 monthly check, and sometimes more. Learnfare's boosters had said it will help break the cycle of poverty. Others have branded it an administrative nightmare, but proponents insist it works well everywhere but in Milwaukee County. Evans issued the injunction July 10 after several welfare recipients complained they were sanctioned on the basis of inaccurate attendance records. Milwaukee County and the state Department of Health and Social Services have singe agreed to provide written notices to parents and take other steps to very that a student is indeed cutting class. If sanctions are to be imposed, the family will be given a notice that includes the dates the student was absent. While the agreement applies only to Milwaukee County, it could be expanded to cover the entire state, Legal Action lawyer Patricia DeLessio said. More than 13,000 teen-agers are subject to Learnfare requirements in Milwaukee County. About 12 percent were penalized in June, the last month the program operated before its suspension.

DOC.HEAD: GM Posts Record $2 Billion Loss to Close Auto Plants
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf pvs, `The automaker ...' with two grafs to ADD consolidations. PICKS UP 6th gra pvs, `GM estimated ...'; A version also moved on financial wires.
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. took a record $2 billion third-quarter loss to close four auto plants and stop production at several others. The $2 billion figure was the biggest quarterly loss in automotive history. But the announcement Wednesday was hailed on Wall Street as a signal that GM is serious about cutting costs and becoming more competitive. ``GM wants to begin the decade of the '90s with a clean slate and face the reality of the marketplace,'' said auto analyst Scott Merlis of Morgan, Stanley & Co. GM said assembly plants in Pontiac, Mich.; Kansas City, Mo.; Atlanta, Ga., and Framingham, Mass., that have been idle the past three years will close permanently. The automaker also said it will stop production over the next three years at truck plants in Scarborough, Ontario; Lordstown, Ohio; and Pontiac, Mich., along with closing or consolidating operations of some component plants. It was not immediately known how many workers would be affected. GM estimated the closures will cost $2.1 billion, including promised payments to laid-off workers. That amount was charged against $109 million in third-quarter earnings. During contract negotiations with the United Auto Workers last summer, GM agreed to guarantee the income of workers laid off from plants closed because of slumping sales. GM stock closed Wednesday on the New York Stock Exchange at $36.75 a share, up 12{ cents, an indication that analysts and brokers weren't worried about the loss. ``Most charges like this cause the stock to drop sharply,'' Merlis said. GM revenue for the third quarter rose to $30.8 billion, compared with $28.8 billion during the same period last year. The $109 million in earnings that would have been posted without the $2.1 billion charge were down sharply from $516.9 million during the year-ago period. Third-quarter results reported earlier this week were also dismal at Ford Motor Co., which posted a smaller-than-anticipated profit of $101.7 million, and at Chrysler Corp., which lost $214 million. ``There is no question that the quarter is dismal,'' Merlis said. ``This certainly reflects the further automotive downturn induced by the Gulf crisis.

DOC.HEAD: Infant Found Dead in Hospital; Breathing Tube Pulled Out
DOC.TEXT: Homicide detectives investigated the death of an 8-month-old boy found dead in a hospital, his breathing tube pulled out and heart monitor disconnected. ``Somebody did this,'' the boy's mother, Theresa Bostic, said through tears Wednesday. ``It didn't just come out, somebody did this, somebody did this.'' Detectives investigating the death of Nigel Bostic were ``leaning toward a homicide,'' said a police official who spoke on condition of anonymity. Nigel was found face down in his crib at Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx on Monday, said Brian K. Regan, hospital vice president of administration. He had been hospitalized Sept. 17 with breathing problems caused by a constricted windpipe. The infant's tracheotomy tube, which helped him breathe, had been removed from his throat and was found under his body by a nurse who checked on him, Regan said. ``This is clearly a tragic situation. ... We are doing our best to find out what happened, we are conducting a vigorous inquiry,'' he said. He said the baby had been doing well and was to have been released from the hospital this week. Nurses told police and hospital investigators they saw the baby playing in a walker earlier Monday and had checked on the child 50 minutes before he was discovered dead. ``The mystery is that 50 minutes between 3:25 p.m. and 4:15 p.m., and the focus of the inquiry is on that time,'' Regan said.

DOC.HEAD: CBS Founder Paley Left $500 Million Estate
DOC.TEXT: CBS founder William S. Paley left most of his $500 million estate to his children and a foundation he established. Paley, who died Oct. 26 at age 89, left 100,000 shares of CBS stock to the William S. Paley Inc. Foundation, as well as 84 works of art, including paintings by Renoir, Picasso, Gauguin and Degas. His will, dated July 31, 1985, was filed for probate Wednesday. Paley's two sons, two daughters, a stepson and a stepdaughter will receive lifetime incomes from the part of the estate not specifically bequeathed to someone else. The estate included property in the Bahamas and Southampton, N.Y. Specific bequests include ``my antique desk, which was formerly a gambling table,'' to the Museum of Broadcasting in New York. Paley's son William Cushing Paley of McLean, Va., also inherited a cigar store Indian that stood in his father's office. Paley's driver received $20,000, and his CBS secretary $10,000.

DOC.HEAD: Security Personnel Fire Tear Gas In Struggle With Boat People
DOC.TEXT: Masked Vietnamese wielding homemade spears battled tear-gas firing security personnel today at a camp for boat people. Authorities said at least 16 people were injured, including three security officers. The fight at the Whitehead Detention Center broke out in the early afternoon as corrections officers conducted a sweep for weapons, a government spokesman said. He said between 40 and 50 masked boat people were involved. Tensions are on the rise in Hong Kong's squalid detention centers for boat people, temporary homes for thousands of Vietnamese who fled their homeland only to face the likelihood of repatriation. Government officials said the three security officers suffered cuts and bruises, one Vietnamese woman was hospitalized and about 80 homemade spears were seized. The sweep for weapons followed a fight Wednesday night between two groups of newly arrived boat people from the Haiphong area of northern Vietnam. After firing three canisters of tear gas, the officers quelled the outbreak, said the spokesman, who cannot be identified under briefing rules. The violence was the latest in a series of skirmishes among boat people and between Vietnamese and security personnel who patrol the camps. Tensions have been rising in the camps following an agreement between Vietnam, Britain and the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees to speed the return of Vietnamese to their homeland. The agreement creates a new category of boat people - those who ``do not oppose'' being sent back to Vietnam. The UNHCR already supervises a program that returns volunteers to Vietnam. So far, 4,899 have returned voluntarily. In a major policy change, U.N. officials will now be urging Vietnamese who have no hope of achieving refugee status to return home. Many Vietnamese in the camps view the new category as a veiled way to force people back to Vietnam against their will. Since the announcement of the agreement in late September, dozens of boat people have gone on hunger strike opposing the agreement and the UNHCR. One U.N. official described Hong Kong's camps as a ``tinderbox waiting to catch fire.'' UNHCR's representative in Hong Kong, Robert Van Leeuwen, said U.N. officials have gone to great lengths to convince the boat people that the U.N. has not agreed to forcible repatriation. Today, he reiterated that point, saying his organization ``cannot and will not be associated with forced repatriation.'' But the U.N. official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the U.N.'s campaign has not convinced many boat people. He said special phones have been installed in U.N. offices in the camps in case of violence, adding that U.N. representatives are no longer encouraged to move around the camps alone. He said officials are worried about repeats of violence such as an incident in January during which six members of the Correctional Services Department were held hostage for six hours in Whitehead, the largest camp in Hong Kong. About 54,000 boat people, who fled communist Vietnam, currently occupy hundreds of tin warehouses and cement cells in the camps, where crime and other social ills flourish. Of them, 45,000 arrived after June 1988 when the British colonial government instituted a screening program to separate what it called legitimate political refugees from ``economic migrants.'' Before that all boat people were considered refugees. Under the screening process, those who are determined to be refugees will be allowed to stay and work in Hong Kong and await resettlement abroad, while the economic migrants will be sent home. So far, 15,000 of the 45,000 have failed the test. The Hong Kong government forcibly repatriated 51 of them in December but stopped that program after pressure from the United States. The new agreement was borne of efforts by London to convince the United States that the Vietnamese must be sent home. In a statement today, Leeuwen said the UNHCR hoped the first flight containing the new category of boat people would take off in November. Initially, the government planned to send the first group back in October, but so far interest has been low.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar and Gold Rise
DOC.TEXT: New worries of conflict in the Persian Gulf helped keep interest in the dollar high today in early European trading. Gold rose, also helped by the increasing talk of warfare. The major loser, European currency traders said, appeared to be the yen, which already had some its recent support knocked away by a sharp 898.94-point drop in the Nikkei index in Tokyo earlier today. At Chase Investment Bank, currency analyst Andrew Ellott said worries about the gulf were encouraging investors ``to err on the side of caution'' and hold onto the U.S. currency. He reported a renewal of strong interest in the dollar. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 130.70 yen, up 1.35 yen from Wednesday's finish. Later in London, it was quoted at 130.65 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Wednesday: -1.5229 German marks, up from 1.5150 -1.2925 Swiss francs, up from 1.2850 -5.0983 French francs, up from 5.0725 -1.7180 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7070 -1,141.50 Italian lire, up from 1,135.50 -1.1686 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1669 In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.9335, compared with $1.9440 late Wednesday. London's major bullion dealers fixed a recomended gold price of $380.10 per ounce at midmorning, up from $379.75 bid per ounce late Wednesday. In Zurich, the bid price was $380.65, up from $379.25 late Wednesday. Gold in Hong Kong dropped 36 cents an ounce today to close at $379.25. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $4.18 a troy ounce, down from Wednesday's $4.22.

DOC.HEAD: Computers vs. Shakespearean Scholars: Whose Labors Lost?
DOC.TEXT: Alas, they're doubting poor Shakespeare once more. This time, though, two computer whizzes have come to the bard's defense. They have developed a program than determined there could be no other author of the body of work attributed to William Shakespeare than Shakespeare himself. Armed with their data, Ward Elliott and Robert Valenza, a Claremont McKenna College computer science professor, challenged the Shakespeare Oxford Society at the organization's annual meeting in Pasadena on Saturday. The Shakespeare Oxford Society maintains that Shakespeare, the son of an illiterate craftsman, could not have had enough knowledge of the places and people to write the plays attributed to him. Society members say Edward de Vere, the 17th earl of Oxford, was more likely to have written them. The program by Elliott and Valenza analyzes blocks of text and looks for patterns in the way the words are strung together. Shakespeare's poems were plotted on a graph, as were other poets' works. Elliott on Wednesday said all of Shakespeare's works are similar, and those of the earl of Oxford look nothing like them. Elliott said he and Valenza also ran the poems through more traditional tests, such as checking for hyphenated words, exclamation marks, certain clauses and word endings. ``We gave the results of a half-dozen tests, including a new test that is not quite as powerful as fingerprints, but powerful enough to make every poet claimant that we tested an unlikely claimant,'' Elliott said. As for the theory that Shakespeare's work may have been written by a number of authors, Elliott said, ``If his work was written by a committee it was an incredibly consistent committee.'' Some Oxfordians dismissed the computer studies as ``word counting'' and complained they were done by students outside the field of literature. The program is run largely by economics, political science and computer science majors. Ruth Loyd Miller, a lawyer and author who has researched the question extensively, objected that the computer looked at words without regard for context. Elliott, who is himself a member of the society and whose father was an early Oxfordian, said, ``My conclusion was that the prospect for Oxford was pretty bleak, but there are a few little shrubs for cover.'' ``I'd be surprised to see (the group) break up over my evidence,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Aging Writer Arrested After Pro-Democracy Crackdown Is Freed
DOC.TEXT: A writer who's been imprisoned repeatedly for criticizing authorities is free again after spending 14 months in jail for joining the ill-fated pro-democracy movement - and said today that he'll keep on writing. But 72-year-old Wang Ruowang, who was released Monday from a Shanghai jail, refused to say whether he will speak out again for the democratic change that came to a halt when the government crushed the movement in June 1989. The prolific writer of essays and literary criticism laughed and said, ``That's a good question. You can say that basically I have studied well.'' All prisoners are advised to study the law and party line to avoid future offenses. In a telephone interview today from his Shanghai home, Wang said his case was not closed. ``I still have a tail,'' he said - a Chinese expression that means one remains under a cloud.
