Wang said he remained under investigation and was still subject to official questioning. He said he could not leave the city without official permission. Still, his spirit seems unbroken. He laughed frequently during the brief conversation and spoke in a strong, lively voice. Students and intellectuals demanding democratic reform marched and held sit-ins for several weeks in Shanghai and other cities in support of last year's student-led protests in Beijing's Tiananmen Square. The potests ended peacefully in Shanghai, but troops and tanks cleared Beijing's streets by force on June 4, 1989, killing hundreds of people. Tens of thousands of people were arrested nationwide and accused of counterrevolutionary crimes in connection with the protests. The government says 355 people are still jailed in Beijing and two in Shanghai, but it refuses to give a nationwide figure. Many, like Wang, have not yet been tried. Wang's satiric writings and calls for artistic freedom landed him in jail first under the Nationalist Chinese and later under the Communists. He was expelled from the Communist Party in 1987 for supporting student protests for democratic reform. When students began protesting again last year, Wang wrote an open letter of support to senior leader Deng Xiaoping and helped lead a march on Shanghai's city hall. He was placed under house arrest in July, the month after the crackdown began, and taken away in September 1989. Shanghai sources said he was not allowed during his imprisonment to communicate with his wife, and was kept in apart from other prisoners in relatively poor conditions. ``A writer not using his pen passes his days worse than a jailed man,'' the Hong Kong newspaper Ming Pao quoted Wang as saying. Ming Pao quoted Wang as saying he lost some teeth and that his eyesight weakened. But in the telephone interview today, he said he was basically in good health. ``I'm resting - after all, I'm an old man,'' he said. Friends have described Wang in the past as tough and defiant by nature. When expelling him from the party in 1987, Communist officials gave a similar description but in less flattering terms. ``The party organizations patiently criticized and educated him on many occasions but he refused to mend his ways. ... He asserted that he would fight to the end,'' a Shanghai party leader, Rui Xingwen, said in 1987. During his imprisonment, the Shanghai newspaper Wen Hui Bao accused him of polluting the minds of impressionable youth and of calling Deng a ``backstage emperor.'' Wang joined the party in the 1930s but was denounced as a ``rightist,'' a ideological backslider, in 1957 and spent nearly two decades in prisons or labor camps. He was rehabilitated in the late 1970s. In 1988, Wang and other intellectuals founded a journal called ``The New Enlightenment'' that published daring, probing essays on subjects such as alienation in a socialist society. Shanghai's Foreign Affairs Office said Zhang Weiguo, a reporter for the Shanghai World Economic Herald, remains in jail, along with a second person the office refused to identify. The Herald was shut down for advocating political and economic reform.

DOC.HEAD: Dry Weather Across Much of Nation
DOC.TEXT: Dry weather prevailed across most of the nation early today, and temperatures dipped below freezing in New York and Maine. Unseasonably warm weather was forecast for most regions east of the Rockies. Sunny weather was expected from the mid-Atlantic to the western Plains. Rain was likely in North Dakota, and across the mountains of Wyoming, Utah and New Mexico. Some rain also was likely in the Mojave Desert of California. Snow was expected in Montana. Record warmth was to spread north from the southern Plains, where temperatures were to hit the 80s. A large swath across the South, the Ohio Valley, Midwest and the central Plains was to be in the 70s. A cold front cutting east of the Rockies was to leave temperatures in the 50s in much of the West. DOC.HEAD: Arab Stabs Jew In Latest Apparent Revenge Attack
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 98 grafs to UPDATE with suspect apprehended, details. Picks up 8th pvs, `After revenge...'
DOC.TEXT: An Arab stabbed an Israeli garage owner 10 times in the chest and back in a Tel Aviv suburb today in the latest in a wave of Palestinian nationalist attacks, police said. Shlomo Shtezi, 48, was stabbed in his automobile workshop in Rishon Lezion by a former employee who had slept in the shop overnight. Israeli army radio said he was in intensive care in a nearby hospital. The victim's son, Kobi, said he rushed to the workshop after his father called home to say he'd been stabbed. ``I went in and saw my father lying on top of cartons, surrounded by blood, with stab wounds in his chest,'' the son told the radio. ``There were pools of blood all over the workshop and near the phone.'' The Palestinian suspect was caught by soldiers at a military roadblock as he was headed to his home in the Gaza Strip, District Police Commander Hezi Ledder told army radio. Police spokesman Eli Maimon said investigators classified the stabbing as a ``nationalist crime'' related to the Palestinian uprising. The assailant was not identified by name. Ledder told army radio that 200 Arabs were rounded up following the attack in an effort to both find the assailant and prevent revenge attacks by Israelis. They were later released. The attack was the latest in a spate of revenge attacks set off by the police response to an Oct. 8 riot on Jerusalem's sacred Temple Mount. Twenty Palestinians were killed by police gunfire. Since then, attacks by both Arabs and Jews have left six dead and more than 10 wounded. After revenge attacks last week, Defense Minister Moshe Arens closed off the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip for four days, barring Palestinians from entering Israel. On Monday, Arens announced tougher restrictions for Palestinians to come to Israel from the occupied lands, saying he would ban all those with records of crime or nationalist political activity. Increasing fear of Arab attacks by Jews was apparent in another Tel Aviv suburb, Ramat Gan, when parents blocked their children from taking a kindergarten day trip after discovering their bus driver was an Arab. ``The minute I saw the driver I felt uncomfortable,'' one mother, Ronit Bracha, said on army radio. ``After a few more parents saw the same thing ... we went into the kindergarten and said we didn't want our kids driven by an Arab.'' An incident last May in Rishon Lezion set off an upsurge in the 34-month Palestinian uprising. An Israeli civilian shot to death seven Arab laborers in the town after forcing them at gunpoint to sit on the ground. The incident set off protest rioting in the occupied Gaza Strip in which more than a dozen Palestinians died in army gunfire. Officials first said the Jewish assailant, 21-year-old Ami Popper, was deranged, but a panel of psychiatrists later ruled he was competent to stand trial. His trial has not begun, however.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Aide Says Saddam Seems to Favor Political Settlement
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein is more open to a peaceful settlement of the Persian Gulf crisis than he was in early October, according to a Soviet envoy who met with him this week. Yevgeny Primakov, an aide to Presidet Mikhail S. Gorbachev, told Soviet television Wednesday night that he detected a shift in Saddam's position on resolving the showdown over Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Primakov also said Iraq had agreed on a schedule for Soviet citizens to leave Iraq and that 2,500 would leave before the end of November. He said 34 Soviet military experts were flying home to Moscow today. Primakov, a Middle East specialist and close adviser to Gorbachev, has been shuttling across the region at the Soviet leader's behest. He met with Saddam on Oct. 5 and again on Sunday. He did not elaborate on what the differences were in the Iraqi leader's views other than to say that Saddam on Oct. 5 insisted that Kuwait was part of Iraqi territory, but on Sunday did not raise that issue. ``My impression is that he is more in favor of a political settlement, although I don't exclude the possibility that it will take a long long time to come to this solution,'' Primakov said in the TV interview. Although the Gorbachev envoy said the talks with Saddam focused mainly on getting the remaining Soviet people out of Iraq, he also said that ``I had instructions from the president to make it clear during the talks that it is absolutely necessary to free all foreign hostages.'' There have been suggestions that Saddam might be willing to withdraw from Kuwait if he is allowed to keep the Kuwaiti section of an oil field that straddles the Iraq-Kuwait border and two strategic islands that would improve Iraq's access to the Persian Gulf. Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady I. Gerasimov said Tuesday that there were 4,008 Soviets in Iraq, including military specialists and civilian contract employees. Primakov said he stressed again to Saddam that Iraqi troops must withdraw from Kuwait. Since Iraq invaded Kuwait, the Soviet Union has backed all U.N. Security Council resolutions that condemned Iraq and ordered an embargo on trade with Baghdad to force it to relinquish the oil-rich emirate. Primakov's trip also included stops in the United States, Saudi Arabia, Egypt and Syria.

DOC.HEAD: Attorney General Says a Free Press, Prosecutors Will Always Clash
DOC.TEXT: Reporters scrambling for stories and prosecutors trying to prevent news leaks that could jeopardize a trial will inevitably clash, says Attorney General Dick Thornburgh. Thornburgh told a luncheon session of the 56th annual Associated Press Managing Editors convention here Wednesday that he supports the media's right to publish without censorship. But he added that prosecutors must put an individual's right to a fair trial before any other concern. ``As much as the defendant has the right to remain silent before the court, the prosecutor has the obligation to remain silent outside the court,'' said Thornburgh, who has headed the Justice Department since 1988. Prosecutors who leak information on pending criminal cases to the media jeopardize not only a person's right to a fair trial but also place the judicial system's integrity at risk, Thornburgh said. ``His (a prosecutor) duties do not encompass the exposure of suspected criminal activities for exposure's sake,'' the attorney general told about 400 editors attending the luncheon. But he added that he appreciates the need for free and effective news media. ``I share with you an abiding interest in the freedom of the press, no matter how uncomfortable your copy makes us,'' he said. In a time of increasing crime, a free press is essential, Thornburgh said, because the public wants to know if it is receiving the ``truth, the whole truth and nothing but the truth.''

DOC.HEAD: Foreign Investment: Good or Bad?
DOC.TEXT: When foreigners invest $2 trillion in the American economy you might think Americans would be thankful, since that kind of money can make a real difference in living standards. But there's a drawback: Some of that money could lower rather than raise standards. A policy report just released by the Committee for Economic Development suggests that the good investment money often isn't differentiated from the potentially bad money, thus confusing public debates and discussions. The better money, it says, is direct investment in the ownership of American businesses and properties, because it brings benefits in the form of new productive capacity, technology, knowhow and jobs. The less good, and potentially damaging, investments are in portfolios of stocks, bonds and bank deposits - liquid investments that can be dumped overnight in a crisis, thus worsening any financial instability. Sudden withrawal of a sizable amount of stock investments, for example, could produce an aberration in the Dow Jones industrial average comparable in in destructiveness to last year's San Francisco earthquake. To clarify the matter, which is one of the most confused topics of debate in economic circles, the committee issued an explanatory booklet titled ``What Does It Signal,'' appropriately followed by three question marks. Claudia Feurey, vice president, said one goal of the corporate executives and academics who make up the CED is to clear up misconceptions about foreign debt, especially the difference between direct and portfolio investments. Direct investments, in the form of real estate or plant purchases, imply a long-term commitment to the U.S. economy, and a significant portion of earnings are reinvested within the country. These are relatively stable investments. They aren't altogether without potential drawbacks, among them national security. Some critics fear also that foreign companies might lower wages or weaken their U.S. subsidiary, but the CED found no such evidence. Their concern was reserved primarily for portfolio investments, by far the larger of the two types of foreign investment. Direct investment accounts for a ``mere'' $500 billion, portfolios for a giant $1.7 trillion. Not only are such investments unstable, they also are expensive to Americans. Indirect (portfolio) investments often represent U.S. debt, private and public, held abroad. Interest on it typically is sent abroad. Paying interest generally is a burden, but it becomes more so when the payment is spent elsewhere rather than reinvested locally. If it is used to lower the foreign exchange rate of the dollar, American living standards fall. The CED finds still another reason to worry about the level of portfolio investments by foreigners. Those investments, it says, seems to end up financing American consumption rather than production of goods and services. But don't blame the foreigners for this drawback. The reason their money isn't used for greater American production is because of America's avaricious appetite for borrowing money in order to consume. It's America's fault. This problem, says the report, is a direct result of national economic policies and attitudes. If Americans curtailed government and private borrowing for consumption, foreign capital could instead finance productive investment. For example, it cites the push given the U.S. economy in the 19th century, when British capital was used to help build railroads. As a result, jobs were created, efficiency of transport increased and transportation costs fell. Moreover, the opening of the relatively undeveloped parts of the continent produced economic benefits that can hardly be calculated in terms of return on investment. Foreign capital helped make the United States a powerhouse. The more precise question, therefore, may not be whether foreign capital is good or bad, an asset or a drawback. The CED's view is that it is both, and that for our own sake we had better get it clear.

DOC.HEAD: Detroit Survives Devil's Night, Welcomes Halloween Calm
DOC.TEXT: An organizer who walked the streets with other volunteers to deter arsonists on Devil's Night, Detroit's annual Halloween eve fire spree, said children took over the streets the next night to look for treats. ``The streets are overflowing with children. That's unusual,'' Ray Wright said Wednesday. ``But maybe all the positive feedback about the patrols keeping down the trouble convinced the parents they could go out with the kids tonight, unlike other years.'' Devil's Night arsonists set scattered fires that gutted vacant buildings and spread to occupied homes Tuesday night on Detroit's east side, but neighborhood watch groups kept vandalism down elsewhere in the city. Firefighters and thousands of block-watchers remained on guard for the tail end of the fire spree Wednesday night. Few fires were spotted by reporters driving around the fog-shrouded city, or reported by citizen patrol groups. City officials have not yet released fire statistics. Mayor Coleman Young said a news conference would be scheduled today or Friday to announce the number of fires. Officer Allene Ray said children poured into neighborhood police stations throughout the city to have their candy examined. ``The children are coming in in large numbers to get their goodies OK'd,'' she said. ``I can only hope it's because their parents feel safer this year. It's nice to see the kids in their costumes.'' Last year, the mayor's office reported 223 fires Oct. 29-31, 115 of those on Devil's Night. The firefighters union, however, said there were more than 400 fires. The worst Devil's Night was in 1984, when 810 fires were set during the three-day rampage. Dozens of families were left homeless. Police arrested 154 youths Monday night and 91 Tuesday night for violating 6 p.m. to 6 a.m. curfews imposed for Oct. 29-31 to quash Devil's Night. By midnight Wednesday, 330 curfew violators had been arrested. Police reported 379 curfew violations over the three-night period last year.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Disrupted Ovulation Linked with Rapid Bone Loss
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 13th graf, `In an...' to CORRECT to Longcope sted Longscope.
DOC.TEXT: Subtle menstrual-cycle disturbances in women who have outwardly regular monthly periods could be an important underlying cause of bone loss that leads to fractures later in life, a study today concludes. The hormones estrogen and progesterone are essential for building and keeping strong bones, and their release in the body follows the menstrual cycle. Doctors have long known that women who miss periods entirely, such as those who exercise strenuously or don't eat enough, risk weakening their bones. But the new research suggests that far less obvious disturbances in the monthly cycle also are bad for the bones. The study, conducted at the University of British Columbia, shows that women who do not ovulate, or release an egg, every cycle lose 4 ercent of the bone in their spines annually, even though they menstruate as usual. Jerilynn C. Prior, who directed the study, said stress and being too thin may disrupt ovulation, and women who regularly miss ovulation may need to take progesterone supplements to preserve their bones. Women can have menstrual cycles that are regular in length and flow but still not ovulate. In such cycles, women produce normal amounts of estrogen but less than usual progesterone. Some premenstrual symptoms may accompany ovulation. Prior said women can keep track of their ovulation by checking themselves for mild breast tenderness, which is a regular sign of the egg's release. In the study, published in the New England Journal of Medicine, doctors monitored the menstrual periods of 66 women ages 21 to 42. One-third were runners preparing for a marathon, one-third were recreational runners and the rest were normally active non-runners. The doctors expected to see more menstrual disruptions in the marathoners. Instead, they found that all the women had normal cycles 97 percent of the time, and ovulation disturbances occurred in 29 percent of their cycles. But the disturbances were no more common in the avid runners. ``These results suggest that the maintenance of peak bone density throughout adulthood requires normal ovarian production of both estrogen and progesterone,'' the researchers wrote. However, since the study was conducted on a small, carefully selected group, it is unclear whether ovulatory disturbances are anywhere near as common in the general population. In an accompanying editorial, Drs. C. Conrad Johnston Jr. of Indiana University and Christopher Longcope of the University of Massachusetts suggested that the bone loss cited in the study had been overestimated. ``If such loss were to continue, these women would have very low spinal bone mass at the time of their menopause,'' they wrote, much lower than is typically seen. However, Prior said she believes a lifetime of irregular ovulation may be to blame for many of the fractures that occur in women soon after menopause. Highly conditioned athletes frequently stop menstruating entirely and are at high risk of losing bone and increasing their risk of fractures. Dr. Deborah Riester of New England Medical Center in Boston, who is looking for treatments for these women, said she sees women in their 20s who have the bones of 50-year-olds. ``They think they are so healthy,'' she said, ``but they are going to run into a lot of problems with fractures.'' Riester said women who take birth control pills, which cease ovulation, are not more susceptible to bone loss because the pills contain hormones.

DOC.HEAD: Police Restrict Three Black Areas, Lift Regulations In 11 Townships
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to ADD talks with government talks with Inkatha leader. Picks up 2nd graf pvs, `Law and Order ...,' ADDS one graf on arrest on white right-wing suspects
DOC.TEXT: Police imposed curfews and other restrictions today on three violence-wracked black areas near Cape Town, but lifted similar measures in 11 townships outside Johannesburg. Also, President F.W. de Klerk held talks today with Mangosuthu Buthelezi, leader of the Inkatha Freedom Party, on plans for launching negotiations to end apartheid. De Klerk wants to begin talks next year with black opposition groups, including Inkatha and the African National Congress, led by Nelson Mandela. Faction fighting between the ANC and Inkatha has slowed efforts to begin negotiations. Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok said late Wednesday that recent violence had made it ``necessary to introduce extraordinary measures'' in three townships outside Cape Town - Khayelitsha, Crossroads and Lingulethu. Volk said township residents planned more protests and work boycotts, but that police would use their expanded powers to prevent unrest. A 9 p.m. to 4 a.m. curfew went into effect today in the three townships, which are home to hundreds of thousands of blacks. The measures announced by Vlok give police additional powers to restrict demonstrations and other forms of protest. They are not as severe as measures imposed under a four-year nationwide state of emergency that was lifted in June. The Cape Town townships had been relatively peaceful until two weeks ago. The recent conflict has been between anti-apartheid groups and local town councilors. Many anti-apartheid militants see the black councilors as collaborators with the white-led national government. More than 800 blacks have died in factional fighting outside Johannesburg since August. The violence eased in October, and Vlok said restrictions had been lifted in 11 townships east of Johannesburg. Several Johannesburg-area townships remain restricted ``unrest areas,'' including Soweto, where fighting Sunday left 17 people dead and more than 30 injured. Most of the battles around Johannesburg have pitted Zulus loyal to the conservative Inkatha Freedom Party against other blacks who support the ANC. The ANC and Inkatha are the two largest black opposition movements, and both oppose apartheid. But they differ over tactics and plans for a future South Africa. Also today, police announced the arrests of five white men believed linked to right-wing organizations. The men have not been charged, but are being investigated for the possession of illegal weapons and possible ties to the recent violence, the independent South African Press Association reported.

DOC.HEAD: Families, Freed Hostages Say Americans Need Food, Warm Clothing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with hostage family reax to Saddam's promise of videotapes and invitation to visit over holidays; picks up 6th graf pvs: ``We are ...''
DOC.TEXT: Patricia Hale hasn't heard anything of her husband since Aug. 24, so she welcomes Saddam Hussein's promise to release videotaped messages from American hostages held in Iraq. But that offer, and an open invitation to hostage families who wish to spend the Christmas and New Year's holidays with loved ones, does little to appease the Spring, Texas, woman. ``With a situation this bad, it's hard to say what makes you feel better. Of course I want to see Ed and make sure he's fine,'' Mrs. Hale said. ``But feeling better for me will be when I see him getting off a plane.'' With each day, winter draws nearer and Mrs. Hale grows angrier. Her husband, Ed, was wearing a short-sleeved shirt when invading Iraqi troops removed him from an oil rig on Aug. 2. Now the desert winter's unforgiving cold approaches. ``We don't want our husbands over there without proper food and clothing,'' Mrs. Hale said Wednesday. ``If there's a way my government can help alleviate that problem and they refuse to do it, well, I find that totally unacceptable.'' Hostage families said their minds were little eased by Saddam's latest offers, which came a day after freed French hostages widely criticized the conditions American hostages were facing. ``It's probably just another psychological ploy,'' said Dawn Bazner, whose husband was videotaped early in the crisis asking Saddam to let foreign women and children go. ``I'm hoping that we won't have to visit (my husband) there ... but if it comes down to it, I will go.'' ``Some of the hostages are probably being treated fine, and sure they'll videotape them,'' said Betty Seago of Johnson City, Tenn. Iraqi troops captured her husband, an oil worker, and three other Americans during an escape attempt. But, she asked, ``But what about the ones that aren't being treated fine?'' The families of many hostages held in Iraq and Kuwait have repeatedly called the Kuwaiti Task Force at the State Department in recent weeks to express concerns about the conditions under which their loved ones are living. ``We are looking into the possiblilty of sending packages to our embassy in Baghdad to be forwarded to the Iraqi government, which would then hopefully forward them to the hostages,'' said Diane Salisbury, a State Department spokeswoman. Similar attempts have been made to get letters to hostages, but Ms. Salisbury said the process was complicated and the results unclear. She also said it was not necessarily possible or advisable to make contact with Americans in hiding. ``In any case,'' she said, ``we are holding the Iraqis accountable for taking care of the hostages - whether or not they receive packages from home.'' Donnita Cole isn't willing to leave the situation up to the Iraqis. The Odessa, Texas, woman has been on the phone to Washington, D.C., daily for more than three weeks, pressing for a way to get her husband the clothes he needs. ``At this point in the game I don't care whose responsibility it is,'' said Mrs. Cole, who on Tuesday heard from a freed French hostage who spent much of his captivity with 50-year-old John Cole. ``The Frenchman's words to me were: Please, please tell your government it must get their men some cold-weather clothes,'' she said. ``I've got to help John. When thetemperature starts falling out there, I want him to have a pair of socks on.'' Like Mrs. Cole and many other oil workers' wives, Mrs. Hale has experienced the Middle East's frigid winters during stints living abroad with her husband, an oil worker with OGE Drilling Inc. ``I think a lot of Americans have some misconceptions about the desert climate,'' Mrs. Hale said. ``They think about sand and the sun burning all the time.'' ``But there's no place colder than the desert at night,'' said Mrs. Cole, who has become fast friends with Mrs. Hale since the crisis began. Mrs. Cole said that in his telephone call Tuesday, the freed French hostage also warned her husband and other Americans were not getting adequate nutrition. Freed foreigners have repeatedly warned of dwindling food supplies but Ms. Salisbury said such reports were impossible to confirm. ``We do think sanctions have taken some effect,'' she said. ``How much food is getting to people, however, is difficult to assess.'' Hostage families say they have grown increasingly impatient with the occasional letter and second-hand reports that have emerged with hostages - most recently about 300 French citizens - freed by Saddam Hussein. President Bush echoed the hostage families' concerns while on a campaign stop Wednesday in Alexandria, Va., where he declared: ``Do you think I`m concerned about it? You're darn right I am. I have had it ...'' Margaret Williams, whose son and daughter-in-law are among Saddam's ``human shields,'' has also begun to run out of patience. Simple daily rituals grow more difficult each day. She sets the dinner table and recalls a month-old letter smuggled out of Iraq in which her son says food is growing scarce. She pulls an electric blanket down from the closet and thinks of the desert winter. ``It's awfully hard to do these things when you know your kids are suffering,'' Mrs. Williams said Wednesday from Germantown, Tenn. ``We've just got to help these people out.''

DOC.HEAD: Former FDA Official Convicted of Perjury in Generic Drug Investigation
DOC.TEXT: A former chief of the U.S. Food and Drug Adminstration's generic drug division has been convicted of lying to FDA investigators and a congressional subcommittee. Marvin Seife, 66, was found guilty Wednesday of two counts of perjury for denying he accepted meals from generic drug company executives. Seife, who is retired, faces up to 10 years in prison and $500,000 in fines. He is free on bond pending sentencing, scheduled by U.S. District Judge John R. Hargrove for Jan. 23. Seife, who headed the generic drug division for 18 years, was the 15th person convicted in the investigation of alleged bribery and fraud in the generic drug industry. Also convicted were FDA chemists and others of Seife's subordinates who admitted accepting thousands of dollars in illegal gratuities. Several companies have admitted giving the gratuities to officials of the Rockville, Md.-based federal agency. Assistant U.S. Attorney Geoffrey R. Garinther said Seife ``set the tone for and presided over an unprecedented level of mismanagement and corruption that almost brought down the generic drug industry.'' But Seife's defense presented him as a champion of generic drugs and the small companies that struggled to get their cheaper versions of brand-name drugs onto the market for elderly and low-income consumers. By befriending generic drug executives and occasionally having meals with them, Seife said, ``I felt I was giving them the necessary encouragement to gain acceptance.'' Seife acknowledged at least 14 meals prosecutors documented in court but said he had forgotten about them. He said his memory was fading because he was heavily sedated with aspirin for arthritis pain. Seife's lawyer, Hamilton P. Fox, said he is considering an appeal.

DOC.HEAD: Interned Americans Describe Life in `Gulag'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 1 graf for 2nd graf, `The Americans...' to fix typo. Pick up 3rd graf, `The official...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Two American hostages, in letters released today by a U.S. official, described life in the ``Iraqi gulag'' as a nightmare of fear and uncertainty. The Americans were among thousands of foreigners trapped by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Many have since been released, including hundreds of Western women and children and, this week, French nationals. The official said the handwritten letters were brought to the U.S. Embassy in Baghdad by other, non-American foreigners. The identity of the letters' authors was not disclosed for security reasons, and the official also demanded anonymity. ``I have been in the Iraqi gulag system for almost two months. We are virtually prisoners in Iraq,'' wrote one of the Americans. Another, being held as a ``human shield'' at a different Iraqi installation, described his isolation. ``I have been moved five times, not heard from anyone since Aug. 16 except for a message from my wife on VOA (Voice of America) on Oct.5,'' he wrote. ``We are getting no mail or messages at all.'' The writer added: ``Tell my wife I love her and I have lost 35 pounds.'' The other American letter-writer compared the conditions of his captivity to a jail. ``No telephone calls to anyone. Facilities ... very much like a medium-security prison in the United States. Bars on windows, doors locked.'' The hostage said the windows were not barred, but about half a dozen Iraqis lived in an adjoining room and guards with automatic rifles guarded the facility at night. ``You can survive. But individually interned, (one) must be psychologically capable of living alone within himself,'' the letter said. It ended with a plea: ``Please do not forget the guest hostages.'' Iraq calls the detained foreigners guests. Iraqi officials have denied reports they are mistreating the foreigners, calling such claims falsehoods that could be used as a pretext for a U.S. attack. Diplomats in Kuwait and other foreigners are ``well-treated and all receive good care,'' an Information Ministry spokesman said Wednesday. The spokesman, commenting on condition of anonymity, also said Iraq is prepared to allow the families of foreign hostages to visit over the Christmas and New Year's holiday. The proposal appeared to be part of an overall Iraqi offer to relatives of its ``foreign guests.'' Several Britons have already visited captives, including wives visiting their husbands being held in Iraq. One Western diplomat, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the Iraqi offer of holiday visits boded ill for the captives. ``That's bad news,'' said the diplomat, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``That means they will be here until the new year if not later.'' President Bush said Wednesday that his patience was running out with Iraq's treatment of U.S. diplomats in Kuwait. The only Western embassies that have not shut down in Kuwait City belong to the Americans and British. Iraq's pressure tactics have forced all the others to close. ``Our people inside are being starved by a brutal dictator,'' Bush said. ``And do you think I'm concerned about it? You're darn right I am.'' Information Minister Latif Jassim said it was possible the United States was spreading ``false reports'' on conditions of ``foreign guests'' to seek an excuse to attack Iraq. ``I want to tell you that our guests live in good conditions at some places better than many Iraqi families, but Bush perhaps wants an excuse,'' he told a news conference. ``I think he wants to begin a war because his position at home is very difficult,'' Jassim said. Asked what would happen to the captives should war break out, Jassim said, `President Saddam Hussein has ordered that if war begins the guests should get into shelters first.'' ``You know we are Arabs, Arab Moslems. You know guests are very important to us,'' he said. Jassim also said that war could break out soon, and declared that the nation's 1-million-man army and civil defense were prepared. Saddam told his military commanders Tuesday to prepare for war with the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Wounds Would-be Halloween Robber
DOC.TEXT: A traffic court judge says he exchanged gunfire with would-be robbers masquerading as trick-or-treaters, wounding one of the pair after they rang his doorbell, grabbed his wife and shot first. Dade County Judge Harvey Baxter and his wife, Elaine, were uninjured and identified a man who turned up at a hospital with a gunshot wound, police said. ``I caught a guy in my home, and yes, I shot him,'' Baxter told radio station WINZ early this morning. According to police, the two would-be robbers rang the Baxters' doorbell at about 9:15 p.m. Wednesday night, when households were expecting trick-or-treaters. The pair were wearing gorilla masks. When Mrs. Baxter opened the door, the pair brandished guns, forced their way into the home and grabbed the judge's wife. She screamed, telling her husband the pair were armed. Baxter, 59, rushed from the kitchen into the front room with a .22-caliber pistol. ``We believe (one of the intruders) fired at the judge first. We believe the judge fired in self-defense,'' Metro-Dade Police Detective Tom Grippaldi said. The intruders fled in two pickup trucks, he said. Jeffrey Parnell, 37, was arrested this morning at Jackson Memorial Hospital after he showed up to have the bullet removed, Detective Lisette Williams said. Parnell was charged with attempted murder, aggravated battery and other counts, Williams said. Authorities were searching for the other suspect, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Halloween Trial Date Changed for Grave-Robbing Case
DOC.TEXT: A judge agreed to postpone a grave-robbery trial that had been scheduled to start on Halloween. Lawyers for both sides supported the change by Spokane County Superior Court Judge James Murphy, who set a new trial date of Nov. 7 for defendant Charles D. Vigil. ``I wouldn't want to turn it into a macabre circus,'' said Vigil's lawyer, Russell Van Camp. He contended starting the trial on Halloween could be prejudicial. ``It would be a little bit too sensational,'' Spokane County Deputy Prosecutor Steve Tucker said. ``I just believe the jury would be waiting for me to say, `Trick or Treat!''' Van Camp had said he hoped the trial would be postponed ``as far as possible away from this time of year, maybe until early December, around Christmas, when people are a little more forgiving.'' Vigil, a 28-year-old hairdresser, is accused of felony disinterment and mutilation of human remains. He was arrested May 20 at an old cemetery near Hillyard, northeast of Spokane. The prosecution's evidence includes a human skull, bones and two tombstones police said were found in a pickup truck in which Vigil had been riding.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Hindu Violence In Bangladesh Leaves One Dead
With PM-India
DOC.TEXT: Police imposed curfews in Bangladesh's two largest cities today after one person was killed and more than 100 injured in riots triggered by a Hindu-Moslem dispute in neighboring India. Trouble also was reported in six other cities in this Islamic nation, in response to reports that Hindu fundamentalists in India tried to replace a mosque with a Hindu temple. More than 175 people have died in violence in India. The curfews started Wednesday in parts of Dhaka and the entire port city of Chittagong after Moslem gangs attacked temples of Bangladesh's Hindu minority. Hindu idols were smashed, and hundreds of Hindu homes were set afire. The Dhaka curfew was extended today to the entire city of 7 million people. The police announcement of the curfew, broadcast by Radio Bangladesh, did not say why the curfew was broadened. But witnesses said Moslem gangs renewed their rampage by breaking into a Hindu temple in downtown Dhaka where a curfew already had been imposed. Riot police chased the crowd of about 500 people with steel-tipped batons. There were no immediate reports of injuries. A senior Home Ministry official said the curfew extension in Dhaka was a precautionary measure. ``The situation is under control, and we want to remain on the safe side,'' he said, speaking on condition of anonimity. The independent Ittefaq newspaper said a Moslem businessman who was shot during the anti-Hindu rampage in Dhaka died in a hospital late Wednesday night. There was no immediate indication who shot him. The newspaper said about 100 people were injured in Dhaka, most of them from stabbings. Twenty-six were hospitalized. Ittefaq also reported anti-Hindu trouble in Jessore, Narail, Gaibandha, Mymensingh, Sunamganj and Sylhet in northern and western Bangladesh. It gave no details except that gangs attempted to break into temples. Bangladeshi newspapers tend to be cautious in reporting sensitive issues such as religious strife. In Chittagong, the trouble erupted Tuesday evening, several hours after Hindu fundamentalists in India stormed into a 16th century mosque they want to replace with a temple in the Hindu holy town of Ayodhya. At least 11 Chittagong temples were vandalized. About 30 percent of the 2 million people in Chittagong, the nation's second-largest city after Dhaka, are Hindus. Police said they arrested 10 people in Chittagong, but witnesses said they saw at least 35 people being led away by police. The curfew in Chittagong was relaxed for two hours today so people could leave their homes to shop for food, but there was no break in the curfew in Dhaka, a city of 7 million. President Hussain Muhammad Ershad appealed for peace in speeches Wednesday and said his government would protect the minority communities. Bangladesh, formerly East Pakistan, is an Islamic state whose 110 million people are 88 percent Moslem. About 10 percent are Hindus. India, which borders Bangladesh on three sides, is predominantly Hindu but officially secular. Hindus comprise 82 percent of India's 880 million people, and Moslems make up 12 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Dentist Offers To Buy Halloween Candy
DOC.TEXT: A dentist hopes to save a tooth or two by offering to buy candy that children collected while trick-or-treating. Dr. Carol Moreno said she's offering 50 cents for each pound of candy kids are willing to part with Saturday at her office. She insists she isn't against sweets, just the damage they do. ``Even I have a soda at the movie theater,'' she said. ``But kids should realize it really is a treat ... a special thing.'' Besides the money - sorry, only $5 per child - Ms. Moreno will give the children a dental screening and a bag of goodies, which will include popcorn and a sticker or key ring. So far, the idea seems to have caught on with parents. ``They seem to think it's a fine idea,'' Ms. Moreno said. ``Probably because it's their children I've found cavities on.'' And what does Ms. Moreno plan to do with the candy? ``I don't know yet. We're not sending it to Third World countries or anything. We don't want any cavities there, either,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Escape Artist Dies in Coffin in Failed Halloween Stunt
DOC.TEXT: An escape artist who modeled himself after Harry Houdini died in a Halloween stunt when tons of dirt and wet cement collapsed the coffin in which he had locked himself. Joseph W. Burrus, 32, who billed himself as ``Amazing Joe,'' died at 9:30 p.m. Wednesday at Blackbeard's Family Fun Center, said police Lt. Roger Enmark. The exact cause of death was not determined. About 150 people, including some relatives, watched as aides frantically dug at the dirt and cement to try to rescue Burrus from the artificial grave. ``They attempted to get him out but it did no good,'' Enmark said. Before the stunt, Burrus said he considered himself a successor to the great escape artist Houdini, who died Oct. 31, 1926. ``I consider myself a master of illusion and an escape artist. I believe I am the next Houdini and greater,'' Burrus said. ``To me, that is what an escape artist is: to put myself in an impossible situation and get out of it.'' Burrus volunteered to do the stunt to benefit The Third Floor, a drug rehabilitation program, said program manager Charles Lewis. ``He told me he had perfected this act and said he was a recovering addict and wanted to do this show as a benefit,'' Lewis said. Burrus was handcuffed, wrapped in chains, locked inside the coffin, lowered into a 7-foot-deep grave and buried. Aides had lowered the coffin halfway when Burrus knocked on the sides to tell them the chains were choking him, said assistant Sean Henderson. They opened the casket so Burrus could loosen a chain around his neck, then locked it again. ``He knocked on the side and gave two thumbs up and told us to continue,'' Henderson said. Aides shoveled about three feet of dirt into the hole. A cement truck poured another three feet of wet cement into the grave. ``As soon as we finished and the truck pulled away the whole thing dropped. The cement busted the coffin. It buried him alive,'' Henderson said.

DOC.HEAD: Women, Blacks Seeking to Change the Political Landscape
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 16th graf, Appointed to, to CORRECT that Mink won special election sted being appointed to House.
DOC.TEXT: Women and black candidates are fighting to change the political landscape in high-profile races that could see them take over three governorships and several seats in Congress. National attention is focused on black candidate Harvey Gantt's strong bid to unseat Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., and the big-state gubernatorial candidacies of Ann Richards in Texas and Dianne Feinstein in California. A raft of women and blacks are seeking office at the congressional and state levels. Women's groups are pleased with the number of female candidates seeking statewide office in Tuesday's election - 85 in all, according to the Center for the American Woman and Politics. There are eight women running for governor and 19 for lieutenant governor, a 42 percent increase over 1986. Eight are running for the U.S. Senate and 68 for the House. Black candidates for statewide and federal office number 52, including 21 incumbents, according to figures compiled by the Joint Center for Political Studies. The research organization tracks black politics. Gantt is the lone black nominated for the Senate, and his race is a heated one. He has pulled a few points ahead of Helms in the polls, with his campaign hoping for a dramatic upset. The milestone for women this year is that many are mounting serious races for the Senate and statewide offices, political activists say. ``Having Dianne Feinstein and Ann Richards run as credible competitors for very major and very important governorships is history-changing,'' said Wendy Sherman, executive director of EMILY's List, a group that raises money for female Democratic candidates. ``Win or lose, it does change the landscape, we believe forever. Neither of them are beginners,'' in contrast to the ``lambs to the slaughter'' women candidates of the past, she said. In fact, said Jane Danowitz, executive director of the Women's Campaign Fund, ``If there's an irony to the 1990 election, it's that women are finally positioning themselves as traditional, serious candidates - and now the electorate favors the mavericks.'' ``Now that we've learned to play the game, they've changed the rules,'' she said. Nonetheless, women are looking to make significant gains. Rep. Pat Saiki, R-Hawaii, is considered the best shot women have at gaining a Senate seat. She is running against appointed incumbent Daniel Akaka. Two other Republican Senate hopefuls who have received considerable attention, but are lagging in the polls behind Democratic incumbents as Election Day nears. They are Rep. Lynn Martin, seeking to unseat Sen. Paul Simon in Illinois, and Rep. Claudine Schneider, running against Sen. Claiborne Pell in Rhode Island. Democrat Patsy Mink, an Asian-American and a former congresswoman, won a special election to fill the last few months of Akaka's House term and is in a good position to keep the seat. Other races where gains for women intersect with those expected for minorities include those of three likely new members of the Congressional Black Caucus: -Maxine Waters, a Los Angeles Democrat virtually assured to succeed Rep. Gus Hawkins, a retiring Black Caucus member. -Eleanor Holmes Norton, a Democrat trying to succeed Walter Fauntroy as the District of Columbia's non-voting delegate to Congress. -Barbara Rose Collins, a Democratic Detroit councilwoman who is considered a shoo-in over Carl Edwards to succeed outgoing Rep. George Crockett. Other House races to watch involving women include these contests where the incumbent is not seeking re-election: -Rosa DeLauro, a Connecticut Democrat, in a strong race against Thomas Scott, a Republican state senator. -Sandra Scofield, a Democrat running against Republican Bill Barrett, the speaker of the Nebraska legislature. -Trudy Coxe, a Republican environmentalist running against Democratic state Sen. John F. Reed in Rhode Island. With two women governors - Madeleine Kunin in Vermont and Rose Mofford in Arizona - stepping down, Democrats are putting high bets on Feinstein, Richards and Barbara Roberts, who has made a strong showing in Oregon. Other women seeking governorships include: Republican Arliss Sturgulewski in Alaska, Democratic state Treasurer Joan Finney in Kansas, Republican Barbara Hafer in Pennsylvania and Republican Mary Mead in Wyoming. In addition, Nebraska Gov. Kay Orr, a Republican, is seeking re-election. Observers say overt sexism has not played much of a role in this year's races, except in Texas where Republican Clayton Williams has made a practice of outlandish remarks. He made light of rape in one, and also joked he planned to ``hog-tie'' Richards and drag her through the dirt. ``Women have run pretty much genderless campaigns,'' said Danowitz, noting that the candidates have run, not just on issues like abortion rights, but also taxation, crime and defense platforms. In minority politics, the Republican Party is trying to make history by electing the first black GOP member of the House of Representatives since 1935, when Rep. Oscar DePriest of Illinois left office. The GOP has three blacks running: former Cincinnati Mayor J. Kenneth Blackwell against current Cincinnati Mayor Charles Luken, who wants to succeed his father, Rep. Thomas Luken, D-Ohio; Gary Franks, running against former Rep. Toby Moffett in Connecticut; and businessman Al Brown, who is trying to knock off Rep. Romano Mazzoli in Kentucky. Of the three, Blackwell is considered the most likely to succeed. In addition, blacks stand to pick up one seat held by a white person. Two black Democrats, attorney Marc Morial and state Sen. William Jefferson, are competing in the open-party runoff to succeed retiring Rep. Lindy Boggs in Louisiana. Another important signpost for blacks is the Democratic nomination of a black, Theo Mitchell, to run for governor of South Carolina. Although Mitchell isn't likely to win, his candidacy shows inroads by blacks at the state level in southern states, according to David Bositis, senior research director at the Joint Center for Political Studies.

DOC.HEAD: FBI Arrests `Most Wanted' Fugitive Accused of Molesting Girls
DOC.TEXT: A man added to the FBI's 10 Most Wanted List for fleeing child molestation charges was arrested one week after being featured on the television show ``Unsolved Mysteries.'' Kenneth Robert Stanton was arrested without incident by FBI agents as he emerged from a motel in Rock Hill on Wednesday. Agents began looking for him in the area after he was identified as a suspect in the molestation last week of a 9-year-old girl in Rock Hill, about 70 miles north of Columbia. FBI agent-in-charge John Harley said Stanton, who turns 52 today, was being held in Columbia and awaiting extradition to Georgia. The Huntington, Ind., native was charged with fondling two girls in Warner Robins, Ga., in June 1989 while posing as a police officer. In all, he faces 11 counts of child molestation involving girls in Georgia, Alabama and Mississippi last summer, Harley said. Stanton was not charged with the Rock Hill incident, but was a suspect, Harley said. Stanton posed as a variety of authority figures to gain access to homes, Harley said. Stanton fled his Moraine, Ohio, home after FBI agents were led there by the Oct. 24 episode of NBC's ``Unsolved Mysteries,'' Harley said. More than 150 people called to say he was living and working in the Dayton, Ohio, area, where he had gotten married two weeks ago, according to an ``Unsolved Mysteries'' news release. Stanton, who was wanted by federal authorities for unlawful flight to avoid prosecution, was placed on the 10 Most Wanted List last week by FBI Director William Sessions, Harley said. ``It appeared that (Stanton) was traveling throughout a broad area of the country molesting children in a calculated way, which indicated to us that he was going to continue doing it until he was apprehended,'' Harley said. The list normally is reserved for people accused of violent crimes. Stanton also faces charges of burglary and impersonating a police officer in Georgia. In the 1960s, Stanton was charged with sex crimes against children and was committed to a state psychiatric hospital in Michigan. He later escaped, but was recaptured in Arizona and returned. Stanton remained at the hospital until doctors decided he was fit for release.

DOC.HEAD: Hostage Families Call for Renewed Links with Syria
DOC.TEXT: A spokesman for the Archbishop of Canterbury urged the British government today to restore diplomatic ties with Syria to help secure the release of British hostages held in Beirut. Spokesman John Lyttle said the government's refusal to tal was a ``silly way to conduct foreign policy.'' On Wednesday, Lyttle attended a meeting in Dublin between the families of British hostages and the relatives of four Iranian diplomats missing in Lebanon since July 1982. The get-together was organized by the Iranian embassy in Dublin at the request of Brian Keenan, an Irishman who was freed from four years of captivity in August following intervention by Syria. Also at the meeting were the wife and brother of the Archbishop of Canterbury's special envoy, Terry Waite; the father of TV journalist John McCarthy; the nephew of retired pilot Jack Mann and Keenan's two sisters. ``It was a very moving meeting. It was an amazing demonstration, I think, of a shared common grief,'' Lyttle said in an interview on British Broadcasting Corp. radio. He said there was hope for a release of British hostages, but added: ``I think for the first time the families of the British hostages have a quite serious disagreement with the policy of the British government, that is the policy towards Syria.'' Britain broke diplomatic relations with Syria in 1986 after accusations of Syrian involvement in a terrorist plot to blow up an Israeli airliner at Heathrow Airport. Lyttle accused Britain of wanting Syria to admit its involvement and to ``in effect grovel.'' ``You cannot expect one state to grovel to another any more than you can expect one individual to grovel to another. If you want to have some successful outcome, you have to look at how Syria has behaved over recent years, whatever they may be accused of doing four years ago,'' he said. Lyttle noted that Syria has sent troops to the multinational forces arrayed against Iraq in the Persian Gulf following the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. ``Yet we maintain the attitude that we will not talk to them, we will not have diplomatic relations with them - that is a silly way to conduct foreign policy,'' Lyttle said. A Foreign Office spokesman responded: ``We have consistently made clear our wish to normalize relations with Syria but there are unresolved problems.'' He refused to elaborate, but observers say Britain is still concerned by Syria's alleged involvement in terrorism. Mariam Moussavi, whose husband Seyyed is believed to have been kidnapped by Lebanese Christian forces, said the Iranian families were ``asking other governments to help us see our loved ones again.''

DOC.HEAD: Justice Says No Evidence So Far Terrorists Used Drug Probe in Bombing
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department said today it had found no evidence so far that terrorists exploited an undercover drug investigation to bomb Pan Am Flight 103, but the allegations would be reviewed by the FBI. Deputy Attorney General William P. Barr said that ``while at this time we know of no evidence giving credence to these allegations, it is important to examine these allegations and to determine their credibility as soon as possible.'' As part of its ongoing investigation into the 1988 bombing over Scotland that killed 269 people, the FBI will review reports that terrorists used a Drug Enforcement Administration undercover operation in Europe to put explosives on the Pan Am flight. Both the DEA and the FBI have been looking into the allegations in the last few days since they were aired by NBC-TV. But law enforcement sources speaking on condition of anonymity said no substantiation had been found. After the report was aired Tuesday night, the DEA put out a statement that it was investigating the allegations that terrorists may have substituted luggage containing explosives for heroin that undercover agents were allowing on board U.S.-bound aircraft in Frankfurt, Germany. The undercover investigation, nicknamed ``Operation Courier'', was said by NBC to be aimed at tracking heroin shipments to Detroit by Lebanese drug traffickers. NBC reported that terrorists may have discovered that an arrangement between the DEA and German security officials would enable them to substitute luggage containing bombs for suitcases containing heroin. One of those killed in the blast over Lockerbie, Scotland, was a 21-year-old suburban Detroit resident, Khalid Jaafar, who was returning home from Lebanon. Investigators once believed that Jaafar had unwittingly checked a brown Samsonite bag containing a bomb before boarding the flight in Frankfurt. Later they determined that Jaafar carried two smaller bags on board the airplane. Both bags were subsequently recovered following the explosion over Scotland. The New York-bound flight originated in Frankfurt and stopped in London, where passengers and luggage were transferred to a larger airplane.

DOC.HEAD: Boston Globe Endorses Weld
DOC.TEXT: The Boston Globe today endorsed Republican William Weld for governor, saying the former U.S. attorney has the ``disposition and character'' to face the state's economic and fiscal problems. The Globe said in an editorial that Weld and his Democratic opponent, John Silber, were evenly matched on some scores but gave Weld the edge saying his leadership style was more likely to get results. The newspaper praised Weld's record as a U.S. attorney, saying he combatted organized crime and profiteering by defense contractors. The Globe also said Weld has come out ``unequivocally'' on women's issues - favoring job equity, expanded day care and abortion rights. Silber, on leave as president of Boston University, was credited by the Globe for his intelligence and competence in his professional field, but faulted for his ``tart-tongued behavior'' and his ``intimidating tactics.'' A smaller newspaper in the western Massachusetts town of Pittsfield, The Berkshire Eagle, endorsed Silber today in an editorial headlined ``A fingers-crossed vote for Silber.'' The Eagle said the risk with Weld is that it ``would take a long time for him to learn the ropes in state government and discover where savings can be achieved without hurting the state's vulnerable citizens.'' With Silber, the newspaper said, ``People have gotten a glimpse of a searching mind that is open to new approaches.'' ``Mr. Silber, for all his prickliness and occasional outright wrong-headedness, has earned a chance to show what he can do,'' the editorial said.

DOC.HEAD: Feds: 1972 Pipe Bomb Similar to Last Year's Bombs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf, `U.S. District...' to CORRECT by deleting phrase ``outside the 11th District.''
DOC.TEXT: Federal agents say they found similarities between a pipe bomb used by a Georgia man in 1972 and bombs that killed a federal judge and an attorney last year. The bombs' construction was unlike that of any of 10,000 bombs that federal agents have dissected, Agent Frank P. Lee of the federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms said in an affidavit made public Wednesday. Similarities included the use of ``square end plates with threaded rods extending from plate to plate within the pipe and secured with nuts,'' the February search warrant affidavit said. That construction ``is unique to the explosive device'' Walter Leroy Moody Jr. was convicted of having in 1972 and three of four mail bombs sent in December 1989, Lee said. He said he based the conclusion on a computer search of ATF and FBI records describing more than 10,000 bombs nationwide since 1975. One of the December bombs killed Judge Robert Vance of the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Atlanta. Another killed Savannah lawyer Robert Robinson. Two other bombs were safely intercepted at the 11th Circuit offices and at the Jacksonville, Fla., office of the NAACP. Moody, 56, of Rex, is a suspect in the slayings but has not been charged. He's being held without bail on unrelated charges. Moody and his wife, Susan, 27, are charged with obstruction of justice, bribery and witness tampering for allegedly trying to erase his 1972 conviction for possessing the pipe bomb that injured his ex-wife, Hazel. The Moodys have requested separate trials. Walter Moody's trial is set for Nov. 27. U.S. District Judge Anthony A. Alaimo on Monday granted the Moodys' request to move the trials from Macon to Brunswick, where he is based. The ruling was made public in a written order Wednesday. Alaimo gave no reason for moving the trial. The Moodys' attorneys had argued that extensive news coverage had hurt chances of getting a fair trial in Macon. U.S. District Judge Wilbur Owens of Macon had removed himself from the case at Moody's request and was replaced by Alaimo. Moody's attorney, Edward D. Tolley, also wants Alaimo removed, arguing that the case shouldn't be heard by any judge in the Georgia-Alabama-Florida region covered by the 11th Circuit.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Jets Raid Targets in Lebanon
DOC.TEXT: Israeli warplanes blasted guerrilla targets in Lebanon's Bekaa Valley today, the military command said. It said the targets were used as ``launching'' bases for guerrilla attacks on Israel. A command communique said the planes struck at the village of Madjal Balhees near Lake Qaraoun, 19 miles north of Israel's border. It did not identify the guerrilla group or say whether there were casualties. The planes returned safely, it said. Army radio reported that Israeli jets raided the same village in September 1989, hitting a base of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command headed by Ahmed Jibril. Today's raid was the 16th air strike by Israeli jets this year. The last raid was Oct. 24 when jets bombed sites used for launching Katyusha rockets fired at Israeli targets.

DOC.HEAD: McDonald's Says It Will Phase Out Plastic Burger Box
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with further comment from heads of McDonald's and environmental group, delete reference to largest user, which Rensi disputes, describe new packaging. Adds byline.
DOC.TEXT: Bowing to pressure from environmentalists, McDonald's Corp. announced today it will phase out plastic foam packages for its Big Macs and other food. ``Although some scientific studies indicate that foam packaging is environmentally sound, our customers just don't feel good about it,'' McDonald's USA President Edward H. Rensi said. ``So we're changing.'' The decision was hailed by an environmental group, which predicted McDonald's will be a trend-setter in the industry. ``McDonald's understands that the future is green,'' said Fred Krupp, executive director of the Washington-based Environmental Defense Fund. ``I think other companies will follow suit.'' Krupp's non-profit group has worked with McDonald's since August to devise the phase-out plan, said Krupp, who joined Rensi at the company's Oak Brook, Ill., headquarters for the announcement. ``I think it's a big day for the American public,'' said Rensi. ``We've been studying this issue of environmental problems and McDonald's is not interested in doing anything but the right thing.'' Rensi said the company, based in Oak Brook, Ill., will begin eliminating its foam sandwich containers within 60 days. He said the sandwich containers account for nearly 75 percent of the fast-food chain's foam use, and the move would mean a ``significant reduction'' in the volume of packaging used by McDonald's. Some communities have banned polystyrene containers outright, putting additional pressure on McDonald's 8,000 U.S. restaurants to eliminate the use of plastic foam. Jim Cantalupo, president of McDonald's International, said the company would continue testing for the best materials to replace plastic foam, and would ``phase them into our restaurants as they become available.'' The plastic sandwich boxes will be replaced by paper products manufactured in a new process that will preserve the food's temperature and freshness, Rensi said. The company is still trying to determine suitable replacements for plastic cutlery and the plastic cups in which coffee is served, he said. McDonald's has for years defended its use of the plastic, which lingers for decades in landfills. In April, Rensi said McDonald's, which serves 22 million people daily worldwide, had no plans to shift away from using plastics. He said polystyrene containers could be recycled, while coated paper used in food packaging often could not. He also said then that the company would spend $100 million a year on recycled materials when building outlets or renovating. McDonald's last week posted a record net income of $242.2 million or 67 cents a share for the third quarter.

DOC.HEAD: Air Force Delays Atlantis Flight Because of Satellite Problems
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs grafs 5-6, `NASA spokesman...' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with NASA plans for Columbia.
DOC.TEXT: Atlantis' secret military flight next week has been postponed because of problems with a satellite aboard the shuttle that reportedly will spy on Iraq. The Air Force said Wednesday it was delaying the Nov. 9 launch ``to resolve anomalies discovered during cargo testing.'' ``Details are classified, and it is too early to predict a new launch date,'' the Air Force said in a statement. Sources speaking on condition of anonymity estimated the delay would be one to two weeks. The delay was disappointing news for NASA, which just last week pronounced Atlantis free of dangerous hydrogen leaks and ready to fly after being grounded during the summer along with Columbia. Columbia passed a leak test as well on Tuesday. Shuttle director Bob Crippen said today that NASA is going ahead with plans to launch Columbia with the $150 million Astro observatory in December, following Atlantis' flight. He said NASA was working with the Air Force to resolve the problem with Atlantis' cargo. ``A specific target launch date for the (Columbia) mission will not be determined until after the flight readiness review has been conducted and performance data'' from Atlantis' flight have been analyzed, Crippen said. NASA officials have said they want at least three weeks between the flights. Civilian experts have said Atlantis' secret cargo is a satellite that will spy on Iraqi forces. It is the seventh shuttle flight dedicated entirely to the Pentagon, and the last classified mission. Two more military missions are planned, both next year, but their cargoes are unclassified. ``The bottom line is it's no longer affordable'' to maintain security, said a Pentagon official, speaking on condition of anonymity. The space agency had planned nine missions this year, but because of the leaks in Columbia and Atlantis, it hopes now to get six aloft. NASA last launched Atlantis on Feb. 28 on a classified mission; it carried a reconnaissance satellite into orbit. The Soviets reported in March the satellite blew up, but amateur astronomers said this week they spotted it orbiting 503 miles above Earth.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Limits Award in Marine's AIDS Lawsuit
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge has limited to $750,000 the money an AIDS-infected Marine Corps officer may collect for emotional damages in the AIDS-related deaths of his wife and son. Marine Chief Warrant Officer Martin Gaffney, a computer specialist at South Weymouth Naval Air Station, sued the Navy for $55 million. U.S. District Judge Rya Zobel earlier this year found Navy physicians in California were negligent in giving Gaffney's wife, Mutsuko, a transfusion with blood infected with the AIDS virus during a 1981 pregnancy. The judge said in a ruling filed last week that she was guided by California law, which limits money awards for emotional damages to $250,000, the sum she awarded for each infected family member. An award based on economic damages is yet to be determined. Gaffney has said he feels he also is dying of AIDS. He has said the trial, which was split into the liability phase and the damages phase, is taking longer than expected. Gaffney's daughter, Maureene, has tested negative for exposure to the virus. Gaffney has said the damages will provide for her after his death.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Upholds FAA's Mandatory Retirement Rule
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Court of Appeals in Chicago has upheld a 30-year-old Federal Aviation Administration rule that forces commercial airline pilots to retire at age 60. The three-judge panel voted 2-1 Wednesday against a group of airline pilots who sought to have the rule overturned. But all three judges voiced reservations about the ruling. The senior judge, Hubert Will, wrote a strongly worded dissent. The FAA established the retirement rule in 1960 and has argued consistently that allowing pilots to fly beyond age 60 would be dangerous. Critics say that pilots in their 60s have experience that benefits passengers, and cite the 1989 crash of a United Airlines jetliner in Sioux City, Iowa, to back their case. In that crash, a 57-year-old pilot landed a jet, despite a crippled hydraulic system. While ``safety is the dominant and controlling consideration ... the FAA should not take this (ruling) as a signal that the age 60 rule is sacrosanct and untouchable,'' U.S. Appeals Court Judge Richard Cudahy said in writing for the majority. But Cudahy said there was insufficient evidence to overrule the agency's concerns that older pilots pose health and safety risks. Lawyers for the 30 pilots said they had not decided whether to seek a rehearing from the appeals court or to take the issue to the U.S. Supreme Court. Pilots older than 60 have have twice as many accidents as those in their 50s, but they're still safer than pilots in their 20s or 30s, according to a congressional report released last month. The Office of Technology Assessment, which did the study, reached no conclusion on whether the Federal Aviation Administration should revise its regulation forcingretirement at age 60 for pilots on major major airlines - those which operate planes with more than 30 seats. No such requirement exists for corporate, private or commuter-airline pilots. Last month the federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission sued Lockheed Corp. over the company's requirement that its test pilots retire at age 60.

DOC.HEAD: Accused Terrorist Brought to Israel
DOC.TEXT: Police today began interrogating a man authorities said was the first suspect to be extradited from the United States during the 34-month-old Palestinian uprising. The man is accused in a fatal bus attack. Mahmoud Atta, also known as Mahmoud El-Abed Ahmed, was whisked away in a police van immediately after his arrival Wednesday night at Ben Gurion International Airport near Tel Aviv, said Justice Ministry spokeswoman Etti Eshed. Atta, 37 and a U.S. citizen, has been accused of taking part in a 1986 machine-gun attack on a bus carrying Jewish settlers in the occupied West Bank. The driver was killed and a passenger wounded. He was arrested in the United States three years ago. On Aug. 31, the Supreme Court rejected his final appeal against extradition. Two of his cousins were convicted of taking part in the bus attack and received life sentences for that and other crimes, Mrs. Eshed said. She said police had evidence Atta planned the attack and fired at least six bullets at the bus from an Uzi submachine gun, killing the driver. On Friday, the State Department said it had ``specific and credible'' information about possible attacks on passenger ships in the eastern Mediterranean by the Abu Nidal group, to which Atta belonged. The group, a renegade offshoot of the PLO known as The Fatah-Revolutionary Council, is headed by Sabri Al-Banna, uses the nom de guerre of Abu Nidal. The group is believed responsible for some of the worst terrorist incidents of the last decade, including 1985 attacks on the Rome and Vienna airports in which 16 people were killed. But the best-known attack on a Mediterranean cruise ship was carried out by another group, led by Abul Abbas. It hijacked the Italian liner Achille Lauro n 1985 and murdered an American passenger, Leon Klinghoffer.

DOC.HEAD: New York Homeless Sue for Public Toilets
DOC.TEXT: Four homeless people have filed a class-action lawsuit against the city seeking clean and safe public toilets. The suit filed Wednesday against the city and two transit agencies contends the failure to provide toilets constitutes a public nuisance. It says the plaintiffs, three men and a woman, are ``forced to endure continual embarrassment, humiliation, physical injury and hazardous conditions.'' The Legal Action Center for the Homeless, which represents the plaintiffs, said the lack of public toilets in the city is a hardship not only for the homeless, but also for pregnant women, the elderly, tourists and outdoor workers. ``It's getting worse every day,'' said executive director Doug Lasdon. ``It's disgusting.'' A report by the center said that of 105 Transit Authority rest rooms surveyed, fewer than one-third were open to the public, and half of those were in bad condition. A survey of 526 stations in the city's 1,540 parks found that nearly three-quarters were ``closed, filthy, foul-smelling or without toilet paper and soap.'' Leland Jones, a spokesman for the mayor's office, said, ``I'm not sure this lawsuit moves us any closer to really dealing with much more difficult issues, like the adequacy of housing stock.'' Betsy Gotbaum, commissioner of parks and recreation, said she was committed to solving the problem of unclean restrooms but added: ``I don't believe comfort stations should be used by homeless people to take baths, to take care of their personal needs, because that makes them unavailable for other people to use.''

DOC.HEAD: Party Nominates Nawaz Sharif As Next Prime Minister
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with Sharif assured of prime minister post following nomination by majority coalition. Picks up 9th graf pvs, `As leader ...' INSERTS 1 graf after 13th graf pvs, `Ms. Bhutto faces...' to UPDATE with Sharif comment, no further charges to be filed against Ms. Bhutto. Picks up 14th graf pvs, `Jatoi is...
DOC.TEXT: The leader of a right-wing coalition that defeated former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's party at the polls was chosen today to head Pakistan's fifth civilian government in 43 years. Nawaz Sharif, whose backers shared in a landslide victory in the Oct. 24 parliamentary elections, was assured the prime minister's post after receiving the nomination from 18 parties comprising the Islamic Democratic Alliance. The next prime minister will be elected by secret ballot in the 217-seat National Assembly, the law-making lower house of Parliament. Voting could take place as early as Sunday. The new Parliament is to be sworn in Saturday. Since the alliance controls 105 seats in the assembly, the vote for Sharif is seen only as a formality. A battle for the prime minister's job had been expected between Sharif and Ghulam Mustafa Jatoi, who served as caretaker prime minister after Ms. Bhutto's government was ousted on corruption charges three months ago. According to coalition members, Jatoi reluctantly bowed to Sharif. Sharif, 41, a wealthy industrialist, was Ms. Bhutto's fiercest opponent and chief minister of eastern Punjab, the largest province and the powerhouse of Pakistan politics. As leader of the winning alliance, he has been largely credited with orchestrating the campaign that denied Ms. Bhutto and her Pakistan People's Party a second chance at power. The Moslem League, the party that spearheaded the campaign for the creation of Pakistan in the 1947 partition of the Indian subcontinent, is the largest member of the Islamic Democratic Alliance, the loose-knit coalition that spans the ideological spectrum. The decision to choose Sharif was made during a meeting of senior party officials, said Moslem League president Mohammad Khan Junejo. It was not known when or where the meeting took place. Jatoi has headed the caretaker government since President Ghulam Ishaq Khan on Aug. 6 dismissed Ms. Bhutto's administration after only 20 months, alleging corruption and mismanagement. Ms. Bhutto faces several corruption charges filed by special courts investigating her former administration. Sharif told reporters today no new cases would be filed against Ms. Bhutto, disputing her claims that another 16 party loyalists would soon be charged. Jatoi is still believed to be heavily favored by the country's two most powerful institutions - the military and the bureaucracy. Sharif is seen by many groups in Pakistan as a possible catalyst to improve conditions in Pakistan, where most of its 110 million people are landless, illiterate and earn about $400 a year. His family's multi-million dollar steel foundary was launched by his father from a lone oven in the ancient eastern city of Lahore. The business diversified to include steel foundary, sugar and textile mills. Sharif closely guards information about his personal wealth. ``I'm certainly not as rich as the Bhuttos,'' he once told reporters when asked to estimate his wealth.

DOC.HEAD: Tass Says Explosion Hits Chemical Plant, Six Dead
DOC.TEXT: At least six people were killed and 22 wounded when an explosion rocked a chemical plant today in the Ural Mountains, Tass said. Rescuers were searching for survivors from the blast, which occurred at the end of the work day at the plant in Asbest, a small town north of Sverdlovsk, about 875 miles east of Moscow, the news agency said. The plant produces explosives for the mining industry, Tass said. There was no immediate explanation for the explosion. Tass gave no other details.

DOC.HEAD: Investigators Say Pierce Misled Congress
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs, inserting grafs 3, An attorney, and grafs 10-12, Pierce's lawyer, with Pierce reaction.
DOC.TEXT: Former Housing Secretary Samuel Pierce directed federal grants to political friends and later misled Congress about his involvement, congressional investigators said today. Their report stopped short of concluding Pierce committed perjury before a House panel or that he and others at the agency violated criminal laws. It said those questions would be left to the special prosecutor now investigating Pierce. An attorney for Pierce said the report was politically motivated and contained ``spurious allegations.'' The report, the result of a House subcommittee's 16-month investigation of the Reagan administration's Department of Housing and Urban Development, said Pierce concealed the extent of his involvement in the steering of federal housing grants. ``At best, Secretary Pierce was less than honest and misled the subcommittee about his invovlement in abuses and favoritism in HUD funding decisions,'' the report said. ``At worst, Secretary Pierce knowingly lied and committed perjury during his testimony.'' The report was released by the House Government Operations Committee, whose employment and housing subcommittee investigated the scandals involving favoritism, mismanagement and political abuse at HUD, where Pierce served as secretary throughout the Reagan years. Pierce appeared before the panel in May 1989, then invoked his Fifth Amendment rights against self-incrimination in refusing to appear for further questioning. Subcommitee Chairman Tom Lantos, D-Calif., said in an accompanying statement that Pierce ``tried to distance himself from the abuses and political favoritism at HUD'' when he appeared before the panel. ``He stated that he `never told these people to fund anything','' Lantos said. ``However, sworn testimony from other witnesses and a paper trail of documents suggest that he was directly and intimately involved in the abuses and favoritism in HUD funding decisions.''
