Pierce's lawyer, Paul Perito, said he had not seen the report but dismissed it as ``the last gasp of a politically oriented and motivated investigation'' by the House panel. ``With all of these spurious allegations, there is not one piece of evidence that Mr. Pierce violated his oath by receiving anything of value or in any way defrauding the United States government,'' Perito said. ``They have been suggesting alleged perjury from day one,'' he added. ``Once again, there is nothing in the record to support the conclusions regarding the alleged perjury.'' Among the report's findings: - HUD under Pierce was ``an agency in total disarray and was woefully mismanaged.'' Housing programs established to help the poor were abused, and HUD ``was enveloped by influence peddling, fvoritism, abuse, greed, fraud, embezzlement and theft.'' - The Section 8 Moderate Rehabilitation Program, a system of grants to private developers to renovate housing for the poor, ``became a cash cow which was milked by former HUD officials and the politically well-connected.'' Abuses in that program alone could cost the goverment $413 million in overpayments, the report said, while other HUD problems will cost taxpayers more than $1 billion. - Officials at many public housing authorities around the country were aware the selection process for the moderate rehabilitation program was being abused but chose to exploit it rather than attempt to expose abuses. - Deborah Gore Dean, Pierce's executive assistant from 1984 to 1987, was at the focal point of funding decisions for the moderate rehabilitation program. The panel cited as evidence many ``Dear Debbie'' letters from developers and politically connected consultants seeking grants, and Dean's actions in directing HUD officials to sign program-funding documents. But the report said congressional investigators were unable to conclude whether Dean acted on her own, or whether she was acting at the direction or with the approval of Pierce. It said evidence indictated she directed grants to political allies at the behest of Pierce on several projects, including the Durham, N.C., Hosiery Mill project, while on other projects, such as Seabrook Apartments in New Jersey, Dean appeared to be the chief proponent. Dean refused to testify before the panel, citing her constitutional rights against self-incrimination. - There was a pattern of favoritism shown to Pierce's former New York law firm, Battle, Fowler, Jaffin and Kheel, including assistance to clients of that firm who were seeking moderate rehabilitation grants. - The report criticized the HUD inspector general as unfairly singling out one HUD official, Thomas Demery, as the focus of the 700-page investigative report on the moderate rehabilitation program that triggered the HUD scandal in early 1989. Others, such as Pierce and Dean, were barely mentioned then. The congressional report praised the inspector general's office for revealing abuses but said ``the watchdog did not bark loud enough'' in its earlier reports on problems in the agency. It said Congress should have paid more attention. And it said Congress should halt the practice of earmarking funding in appropriations bills for specific housing projects it favors. The Bush administration's secretary, Jack Kemp, drew praise for acting to clean up the agency.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says He's `More Determined Than Ever' to Force Iraq Out of Kuwait
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 17 grafs to UPDATE with Fitzwater saying Bush deliberately raising profile on gulf crisis, additional details on embassy in Kuwait, administration strategy; picks up 11th graf pvs, Bush campaigned...
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today he is ``more determined than ever'' to drive Iraq's Saddam Hussein out of Kuwait. Bush, embarking on a six-day, cross-country campaign blitz for endangered Republicans, told a GOP rally in this Boston suburb, ``I want desperately to have a peaceful resolution to this crisis.'' At the same time, the president's spokesman told reporters Bush was deliberately raising his profile on the gulf crisis. ``If we do have to take dramatic action, we want them (the American people) to know why,'' White House Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater said. He did not elaborate. Bush said he wanted to make it, ``very, very clear, there will be no compromise'' on the United Nation's demands for a complete withdrawal of Iraq from Kuwait. ``Today I am more determined than ever: this aggression will not stand,'' he said. ``The brutality against innocent citizens will not be tolerated and will not stand.'' Bush said he still intended to give economic sanctions time to work. ``No one wants a peaceful end to this crisis more than I do, but no one is more determined to see this aggression turned back. And I will not change on that fundamental point of morality,'' he said. Bush said that the United States and the rest of the world remain ``united in anger and outrage'' at the treatment of hostages by ``Iraq's brutal dictator.'' The president asked his audience to join him in setting aside partisan politics when it came to his administration's Persian Gulf policy. ``I am not a cynic. I have no apologies, only pride at being at a partisan event,'' he said. ``But for the moment ... set partisan politics aside.'' Fitzwater also said there would soon be ``a turning point'' in the status of the U.S. diplomats remaining in the embassy in Kuwait City. ``At some point, they've either got to leave or be re-provisioned,'' he said. He declined to say how many days longer the group could hold out. He said he did not want to tip off Saddam. In Bush's campaign speeches today, the president appeared to tone down his harsh criticism of congressional Democrats on budget issues. Instead, Bush devoted nearly half of his first speech to discussing the gulf situation. Fitzwater said Bush was being urged to continue his caustic attack on Democrats ``in certain quarters ... but he surveyed the whole matter and decided this was the best approach.'' Thus, Fitzwater said, the president has decided to spend more time highlighting the gulf standoff. While realizing he might be subject to attacks for politicizing the gulf situation, Fitzwater said, ``because he is president, we didn't see how he could duck it.'' ``We want a public debate'' over new developments in the Persian Gulf. ``We want public knowledge of this,'' Fitzwater said. Responding to reports that Saddam had invited hostage families to visit their relatives in captivity in Iraq and Kuwait over the Christmas holidays, Fitzwater said: ``Why doesn't he let the hostages come home? That would be the best way - or better yet, Thanksgiving.'' Bush campaigned here for Republican gubernatorial candidate William Weld, who is seeking to succeed retiring Gov. Michael Dukakis, Bush's 1988 Democratic presidential opponent. While the president says he is keeping the two subjects - the Iraqi confrontation and politics - separate, Bush was expected to make repeated references to the Persian Gulf standoff as he travels. In a trip scheduled to keep him on the road until Election Day, Bush is campaigning for GOP gubernatorial and congressional candidates in close races in Massachusetts, Florida, Ohio, Minnesota, Iowa, California, New Mexico and Texas. After leaving Burlington, Bush was traveling to the Cape Cod community of Mashpee for another rally for Weld, who is in a close race against Democrat John Silber. Bush also was to speak in behalf of GOP Senate challenger Jim Rappaport, who is seeking to unseat Democratic Sen. John Kerry. Later, he planned to campaign in Orlando, Fla., before ending his day in Cincinnati. Bush's political journey will end Election Day in Houston, when he votes at his ``home'' precinct. His legal residence is a suite at the Houstonian Hotel. The president was focusing on a handful of tight races in the closing days of the midterm elections. In Orlando, he was seeking to rally last-minute support for Republican Gov. Bob Martinez, who is facing a spirited challenge from former Democratic Sen. Lawton Chiles. With the president's popularity in the polls slumping and Republicans seeing their hopes for big midterm gains evaporating, some candidates in tight races have been keeping Bush at arm's length. A stop planned for this week in Illinois was canceled after GOP Secretary of State Jim Edgar, who is running for governor, and Rep. Lynn Martin, R-Ill., who is running for the Senate, expressed displeasure with Bush's support for new taxes. Campaign stops planned for Oregon, Nebraska and Arizona also were scrubbed.

DOC.HEAD: Register Children as Sheep, Conference Told
DOC.TEXT: Registering children as sheep is one way New Zealand families might be able to afford to bring up children, an economist told a conference Thursday. As sheep, their food, accommodation and other expenses would be tax deductible, Brian Easton told the conference on child-rearing. ``The mother might even be eligible for shepherd's wages,'' he said. Easton was critical of New Zealand's claim to being ``a great place to bring up kids.'' He said parents are required to make great sacrifices to raise children and their financial struggles are largely ignored. New Zealand, dependent on a rural economy, has some 60 million sheep and 3.3 million people.

DOC.HEAD: Rare Tiger Sighted in Wild
DOC.TEXT: Forestry workers recently spotted a Manchurian tiger and cub in the wild, ending a three-year controversy over whether the animal has survived in China's forests, the Xinhua News Agency reported Thursday. The tigers were seen on the northern slope of Mount Changbai in northeast Jilin province. Zoologists estimated that only 80 Manchurian tigers roamed the region's wooded mountains in the late 1960s. Only 30 were left by the early 1980s due to hunting and destruction of their range by farmers and foresters. A 1987 aerial survey failed to find any trace of the tigers in China's wild. Xinhua reporter Zhu Youli, contacted by telephone in Jilin's capital of Changchun, said the foresters spotted the two tigers in July but told few people. He said traces of Manchurian tigers also have been seen in the past year in neighboring Heilongjiang province. About 100 Manchurian tigers live in Chinese zoos. About 300 survive in the wild in the Soviet Union and an undetermined number live in North Korea, according to the China Wildlife Protection Association.

DOC.HEAD: Insect Destroying Coffee Crops
DOC.TEXT: The feared berry borer is panicking coffee growers in southern India who say the insect is devastating their crops. Hundreds of acres already have been destroyed by the pest, which may have stowed away with refugees from Sri Lanka fleeing to southern India. Coffee earned India $195 million in foreign exchange this year, making it one of the nation's most important agricultural exports. The bug ``is slowly creating panic'' among growers, Anil Bhandari, chairman of the Karnataka Planters Association, told reporters Wednesday. The southern state of Karnataka supplies 70 percent of India's coffee. The berry borer, which attacks the coffee bean and bores into the seed, was first noticed in India about seven months ago in a region with a large settlement of Sri Lankan refugees, the association said. The insect has created havoc in some of the world's biggest coffee-growing countries, including Brazil, Ecuador, Kenya, Malaysia and Borneo, the growers said.

DOC.HEAD: Mounted Police Gallop Through Demonstrators
DOC.TEXT: Police galloped their horses through a crowd of several hundred demonstrators who had been pelting riot police with stones and bottles, news reports said Thursday. About 300 protesters, many masked and wielding clubs or chains, refused to clear the street Wednesday night outside a student seminar on nationalism. They tried to keep alleged racists from joining a debate panel. Ten mounted policemen charged the crowd and were followed by more than 100 officers, using shields and dogs to disperse the demonstrators. One policeman was slightly injured when he was dragged from his horse and clubbed. Several demonstrators also suffered minor injuries. One was arrested. ``They had been throwing stones at the police for a long time. In the end we had no choice. We either had to use tear gas or the horses. We chose the latter,'' Oslo Police Chief Willy Haugli told Verdens Gang newspaper. The protest was called by Blitz, a youth group known for violent confrontations with police. The panel continued the debate.

DOC.HEAD: Vermont Socialist in Tight House Race
DOC.TEXT: Vermont, once the most Republican state in the nation, may soon send a socialist to fill its lone seat in the House of Representatives. Bernard Sanders is emphasizing his long-standing disillusionment with Capitol Hill to mount a strong challenge to Republican Rep. Peter Smith. ``The U.S. Congress is hopelessly and pathetically out of touch with the needs of ordinary Americans,'' says Sanders, a socialist running as an independent. The latest polls show Sanders in a dead heat with freshman congressman Smith. The Democratic candidate, Dolores Sandoval, is running third. Most state Democrats are abandoning her as too liberal and too unlikely to win. Smith has questioned how effective an independent can be in Congress, where committee assignments are made by Republicans and Democrats. Sanders says he'll ask to caucus with the Democrats, but it's unclear whether he would be admitted. Sanders says he's not a member of the Socialist party but is a socialist ``with a small s.'' The last time an independent served in Congress was in 1975, and the last time a House member called himself a socialist was in 1929. Smith has countered his opponent's strong showing with television ads accusing Sanders of being sympathetic to the socialist regime in Cuba. The ads contend Sanders is a politician who doesn't represent Vermont values. Sanders says Smith's ads engage in ``vicious, dishonest redbaiting.'' Smith responds that Sanders is ``trying to outrun his history.'' Sanders, meanwhile, is relentless in his attacks on Washington. And while Congress-bashing is a newly popular song for some politicians this fall, it's an old favorite of Sanders'. ``What the two major candidates are saying is irrelevant regarding the problems facing this country,'' Sanders said in a 1971 special election campaign for a U.S. Senate seat. ``The people who make decisions which affect this country have little to do with the average man in the street.'' And in this campaign, he said: ``Multinational corporations and wealthy people are able to buy and sell politicians, who then go down to Washington to fight for tax breaks for the rich and cutbacks in programs for the elderly.'' Sanders also rejects the Democratic Party, which he once called ``ideologically bankrupt.'' Such comments alienated former Democratic Gov. Thomas Salmon, who is supporting Smith, one of the most liberal GOP members in the House. But former Democratic Gov. Philip Hoff sides with Sanders. Smith voted with Democrats more than half the time in 1989, according to Congressional Quarterly. He received a 65 percent approval rating from the liberal group Americans for Democratic Action, and a 27 percent rating from the American Conservative Union. Smith, just back from Capitol Hill after the lengthy budget battle, is encountering opposition from gun groups angry because he backed a measure to ban the sale of certain semiautomatic rifles. The National Rifle Association is airing anti-Smith radio spots and circulating bumper stickers. ``I would have voted for you, but the NRA says you're not the man to hire,'' one man said as Smith campaigned this week. Sanders began his campaign decrying Congress' handling of the savings and loan scandal, but has found new fodder in the fight over the federal budget. Smith was the first rank-and-file member of either party to back the original budget deficit-reduction package, a vote Sanders termed ``one of the most disastrous votes ever cast by a representative from Vermont.'' Smith defends the vote, saying because the budget package was only a start it was important to back the bipartisan plan developed by the Democratic and Republican leadership of Congress and the president. Smith was one of only 10 Republicans to support the Democratic budget plan that eventually passed the House. Sanders has said he could not support that plan because of its Medicare cuts.

DOC.HEAD: Drivers Stuck for Hours in 120-Mile Traffic Jam
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of drivers spent the night stuck in a 120-mile-long traffic jam on the autobahn between Nuremberg and Berlin. Police said Thursday they could not remember a bigger traffic tie-up. The two-lane stretch of the highway has been dubbed the ``Trabant Racetrack,'' named after the slow, two-stroke cars made in what was East Germany. They are used by most Germans from that part of the country. The backup developed late Wednesday as drivers from eastern Germany returned home after a one-day holiday. A series of minor accidents, rain and fog and construction delays brought traffic to a halt. Authorities also reported a 30-mile jam on the highway between Hanover and Berlin. Last year's opening of the borders between the two German states and the Oct. 3 unification has caused a huge increase in traffic between the two parts of the country. Traffic jams have become common on the autobahns, which are designed for high speeds and powerful cars. There are no speed limits on most parts.

DOC.HEAD: Quake Causes Rock Fall in Mine; One Killed
DOC.TEXT: A mild earthquake caused a rock slide in a gold mine, killing one miner and trapping four others working 1{ miles underground, officials said Thursday. The quake, registering 2.5 on the Richter scale of ground motion, hit the area around the Western Deep Levels East mine late Wednesday, the Anglo American Corp. said. The mine is near Carletonville, about 40 miles west of Johannesburg. Rescuers continued their effort to reach the four trapped miners on Thursday, the company said. It was the third such accident in the area in less than three weeks. Two mild temblors last month caused rock slides that killed a total of nine miners in Anglo American's Western Deep Levels West mine.

DOC.HEAD: Cops Can't Corral Llama On the Lam
DOC.TEXT: A loose llama dodged a dagnet until its owner foiled its frolicking with a fistful of food. Kindra, a 175-pound, 6-foot-tall llama, was reported missing Wednesday morning by owners Bill and Carol Blalock, who discovered a wire fence had been cut during the night, possibly by Mischief Night pranksters, police said. The animal was spotted grazing near a sewage plant and was confronted in a yard, but ran away every time police came near. Finally, Mrs. Blalock arrived, called Kindra by name and coaxed her over with a handful of food. The Blalocks breed llamas for sale on three acres in this Morris County community. They own 10 llamas, which are long-necked camel-like animals indigenous to South America.

DOC.HEAD: Gang of Youths Attacks Shantytown of New York Homeless, One Dead
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with detail on weapons, injuries.
DOC.TEXT: A gang of youths armed with bats, knives and meat cleavers, some wearing Halloween masks, attacked a shantytown where a group of homeless people lived, killing one man and injuring several others, police said. Investigators said they dd not know any motive for the attack, in which the dead man's throat was cut. The gang, numbering 10 to 12, crossed a footbridge from upper Manhattan to Ward's Island in the East River late Wednesday and attacked the shantytown in a wooded area, police said. The gang escaped after the attack and no arrests were made. A 35-year-old homeless man, whose name was not released while police searched for relatives to notify, was slashed across the throat and was pronounced dead at the scene, said police Officer Janice Swinney. At least six men were taken to hospitals with stab wounds and numerous bruises inflicted by baseball bats and pipes, and three were treated at police stations, Swinney said. One homeless man required 55 stitches after he was slashed in the face with a meat cleaver. Another required 30 stitches and one needed 20 stitches for similar injuries, Swinney said. But all three were treated and released. Ward's Island, beneath the Triborough Bridge, holds the Fire Department training academy, several psychiatric hospitals and a sewage disposal plant.

DOC.HEAD: Audit Blasts Agency For Bungling Forest Lands
DOC.TEXT: Federal mismanagement of some of the world's most productive timber lands has cost the government at least $90 million since 1986, an Interior Department audit disclosed Thursday. Mishandling of Bureau of Land Management forests in western Oregon is the result of financial shortcuts prompted by budget cutbacks, the department's Office of Inspector General said. The report said the BLM lost $90 million by failing to perform thinning, fertilization and other maintenance that resulted in fewer trees that could be cut. The BLM estimated it lost 94 million board feet of timber growth in the fiscal years 1986-89 due to inadequate management. A board foot is one foot by one foot by one inch. In addition, the BLM has failed to acquire easements to 132,000 acres with 800 million board feet of mature timber valued at $302 million. Losses could total as much as $1.7 billion over the forests' 60-to 80-year life cycles, the report said. The audit of BLM forestry operations on 2.4 million acres across 18 Oregon counties criticized the agency for failing to explain the magnitude of the losses to Congress and the Office of Management and Budget. BLM Director Cy Jamison said in response to the review that his budget requests have been ``somewhat constrained'' by funding targets provided by the Interior Department, its parent agency. ``These targets, which are less than ideal to accomplish the desired workload, are consistent with the goals of the administration to reduce federal deficits,'' Jamison said in a memo to the inspector general's office. The audit covering fiscal years 1986-89 noted that BLM forestry revenues will further decline as additional lands are taken out of production to protect the threatened northern spotted owl. The BLM estimated in June that efforts to save the owl from extinction may directly affect 23 percent of its lands in western Oregon, about 553,000 acres, and may indirectly affect another 1.5 million acres there. The BLM holdings are ``some of the most productive timber lands in the world,'' said the audit prepared by assistant inspector general Harold Bloom. Bungling of the forest program is especially costly because the program historically returns $4.30 for every $1 spent, the audit said. The review questions whether the BLM will be able to achieve next year's timber harvest target of 750 million board feet because the agency's funding request for its forestry program was more than 20 percent short of the $66 million needed. It also discounts BLM claims it can use smaller fragmented tracts of timber to replace timber from larger tracts of forests where logging is being banned to protect the rare owl. ``Easements for the smaller scattered tracts of timber lands have not been obtained because the bureau has concentrated on obtaining legal access for the larger consolidated tracts,'' the audit said. In addition, the audit said the BLM has: - Based its budgets on plans to use herbicides to control underbrush although herbicides have been banned on Oregon BLM lands since a federal judge issued an injunction in 1984. Manual efforts cost three times more than herbicides. - Failed to place sufficient priority or secure sufficient funds for maintenance of the tree plantations, including placing tubes around seedlings to protect them from wildlife. - Failed to perform intensive management programs, including fertilization and pre-commercial thinning to provide proper spacing between trees.

DOC.HEAD: Couple Says: `I Boo'
DOC.TEXT: They said, ``I do,'' but they could have said, ``I boo,'' too. In a Halloween night ceremony complete with jack-o'-lanterns and candelabra, a young couple dressed up as the Count and Countess Dracula exchanged wedding vows in a graveyard. Jody Hawley, 20, of Newark, N.Y., married 24-year-old Nelson Nieves of Walworth in a cemetery ceremony shortly after sundown Wednesday. ``We wanted to be different,'' the bride said. Among the 100 people at the ceremony was the maid of honor, who dressed as TV horror queen Elvira. The local fire company supplied lighting for the event. Hawley said it was her idea to get married and have a reception in the cemetery, although her parents weren't exactly tickled by the idea. ``My family thinks it's kind of morbid, but they're going along with it because it's my wedding,'' Hawley said. Walworth is about 20 miles east of Rochester.

DOC.HEAD: Quayle Says Saddam Shouldn't Be Allowed to Keep Missiles, Chemical Weapons
DOC.NOTE: EDs: ADDS last graf with Sununu comment
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle says the world cannot allow Iraq's Saddam Hussein to keep his ballistic missile and chemical weapons even if he withdraws from Kuwait. ``You cannot simply allow Saddam Hussein to have this military power and have the technology into the future,'' Quayle said Wednesday night in an interview on PBS' MacNeil-Lehrer Newshour. Quayle reiterated that the United States' main objectives in the Persian Gulf are the unconditional withdrawal of Iraq's troops from Kuwait, restoration of the legitimate government of Kuwait, release of all hostages, and peace and stability in the gulf. But Quayle said, ``We would have to go beyond that if those objectives would be achieved because you cannot simply allow Saddam Hussein to have this military power and have the technology into the future.'' ``I believe that the world certainly understands that. A Saddam Hussein who has ballistic missiles, who has chemical capability, biological capability, who would like to have the nuclear capability, cannot continue to have that capability even if he withdraws from Kuwait,'' said the vice president. ``This man is a terrorist, this man is a murderer,'' said Quayle. Craig Whitney, a spokesman for Quayle, said today, ``His comments were fully in line with the administration's views and policies.'' White House Chief of Staff John Sununu told reporters aboard Air Force One today between campaign stops in Massachusetts that Quayle's statement was in accordwith what President Bush has been saying. Sununu said Bush has ``made clear his problem is not with the Iraqi people but with the dictator who created the kind of problem we have.''

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Says It Will Free Four Hostages; ^Eds: Retransmitting a0559 for all needing. New thruout to UPDATE with Iraq saying four more Americans to be freed, edits to trim and conform. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Iraq said today it would free four American hostages ``soon,'' and scoffed at reports the captives were being ill-treated. Washington again demanded the freedom of all the captive foreigners. Aboard the amphibious assault ship USS Iwo Jima, Navy sailors and Marines held a somber memorial service for 10 mates killed in a boiler room steam leak. Tuesday's accident was the worst suffered by the Navy since Operation Desert Shield began in August. Iraqi Information Minister Ladif Jassim, at a news conference in Baghdad today, did not give the names or whereabouts of the four American hostages to be freed, but said they were elderly and sick. He did not say when they would be released. The Iraqi official repeated the Baghdad government's contention that the United States was trying to use the hostage issue as a pretext for a military attack. He insisted they were being treated well. ``All the Americans at sites have complete freedom. They can watch TV, read books and read newspapers. They also enjoy the friendship of Iraqi forces,'' Jassim told reporters. Iraq is holding hundreds of Westerners at strategic installations as shields against a feared attack. In letters released today by a .S. official, two of the captives described their isolation and anxiety. ``You can survive. But individually interned, (one) must be psychologically capable of living alone within himself,'' said one of the letters. It ended with a plea: ``Please do not forget the guest hostages.'' Iraq refers to the captives as guests. The names of the letter-writers were not released for security reasons. The letters were brought to the U.S. Embassy by non-American foreigners, said the official, speaking on condition of anonymity. President Bush, in a speech in Burlington, Mass., said today the United States and the world community were ``united in anger and outrage'' at the treatment of hostages by Iraq's ``brutal dictator,'' Saddam Hussein. Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater, asked about Iraq's offer on Wednesday to allow holiday visits by families of hostages, said: ``Why doesn't he (Saddam) let the hostages come home? That would be the best way - or better yet, Thanksgiving.'' Bush said today he still hoped for a peaceful solution to the gulf crisis, but insisted ``there will be no compromise'' on the United Nation's demands for a complete withdrawal of Iraqi forces from Kuwait. The White House, meanwhile, was silent today on comments made Wednesday night by Vice President Dan Quayle, who said it was not enough to force Saddam out of Kuwait. He said the world cannot allow the Iraqi leader to keep his arsenal of chemical weapons and ballistic missiles. ``We would have to go beyond that if those objectives would be achieved because you cannot simply allow Saddam Hussein to have this military power and have the technology into the future,'' the vice president said in an interview on PBS' MacNeil-Lehrer NewsHour. A Soviet envoy who met twice last month with Saddam says the Iraqi president is more open to a peaceful settlement than he was in early October. Yevgeny Primakov also said Wednesday that Iraq agreed that 2,500 Soviet citizens can leave Iraq before the end of November. He said 34 Soviet military experts were flying home to Moscow today. Meanwhile, a published report today quoted U.S. officials as saying that if there is an allied assault on Kuwait by sea, Iraq plans to blow up several oil tankers. The report in the Washington Times said three tankers are anchored near the Saudi Arabian coast, and there may be others as well. The information was attributed to Pentagon, military and intelligence officials, who were not named. The offer of holiday visits for the hostages, which came Wednesday from an Information Ministry spokesman in Baghdad, was branded by Britain's Foreign Office on Wednesday as ``a cynical propaganda move.'' ``It's probably just another psychological ploy,'' said Dawn Bazner, whose husband, Mark, was videotaped early in the crisis asking Saddam to let foreign women and children go. ``I'm hoping that we won't have to visit (Mark) there ... but if it comes down to it, I will go,'' she said in Palm Desert, Calif. Former West German Chancellor Willy Brandt announced Wednesday that he is traveling to Baghdad next week at Saddam's invitation. The German government today endorsed the planned trip as ``the most suitable way'' to try to secure the release of hostages. About 400 Germans are among thousands of foreigners stranded or held in Iraq. Brandt, who won the 1971 Nobel Peace Prize for helping improve East-West relations, said he was going as a private citizen and not to represent Bonn. Last weekend, European leaders meeting in Rome agreed not to send envoys to Baghdad to try to secure the release of countrymen, reasoning that doing so would only help Saddam in his attempts to divide the anti-Iraq alliance. Iraq has been allowing Westerners to leave on a piecemeal basis; nearly 300 French citizens left on Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Safety Officials Focus on Failure of Engine Part
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs.
DOC.TEXT: Federal safety officials focused today on failure of a critical plane engine part as they probed the probable cause of a crash-landing that took 112 lives at Sioux City, Iowa, in 1989. A metallurgist told the National Transportation Safety Board that a defect in a critical engine disc had been present ``since day one.'' The metallurgist, James Wildy, said a so-called ``Hard Alpha Defect'', a spot of nitrogen inside titanium from which the disc was made, was never detected over the life of the engine part. He said the defect was located less than an inch from the point on the disc ``where a defect would be most critical.'' ``That defect has been in there since day one,'' Wildy said, referring to the manufacture of the 370-pound fan disc by General Electric in 1971. The fan disc, originally 32 inches in diameter, was recovered in two pieces from corn fields in Iowa in October 1989, nearly three months after the accident at the Sioux Gateway Airport near Sioux City. During the board's meeting, members praised the response of the crew to the engine explosion, which shredded the hydraulic system of the United Airlines DC-10 jumbo jet, causing crew members to lose almost all control. A board staff member said the flight crew was able to keep minimal control of the plane by manipulating the two remaining usable engines in a ``very crude and rude flight control system.'' ``It was no mean feat,'' said board member John Lauber. ``It was in fact, exquisite and resulted in the saving of lives,'' he said. The transportation safety board was to vote later on a report drafted by its staff after a lengthy investigation into the disaster. The board will vote on the report's conclusions, its finding as to the probable cause of the accident and its safety recommendations. The crash of United Flight 232 occurred after an explosion in the tail engine of the DC-10 shredded the plane's hydraulic system, sending it into a 42-minute spiral during which pilots struggled to maintain control. At a hearing in Sioux City on Oct. 31, 1989, safety board investigators said they were not ready to conclude that a hairline crack in an engine fan disk caused the explosion. But they acknowledged that a focus of the investigation was the possibility that a flaw in the disk's metal caused the explosion, sending pieces of metal ripping through that aircraft's tail section and severing the hydraulic lines that give pilots control. The fan disk from the DC-10's tail engine was found in two pieces in corn fields near Alta, Iowa, about 80 miles east of Sioux Gateway Airport, where Flight 232 cartwheeled and burst into flames as its pilots tried to make an emergency landing. In July, the safety board, without concluding what caused the accident, called on the Federal Aviation Administration and the engine manufacturer, General Electric Co., to develop new inspection methods to detect cracks before they reach dangerous proportions. Last March, the FAA sought changes in the DC-10's hydraulic system to enable pilots to steer the plane even if hydraulic lines are severed in the plane's tail section. Crew members of Flight 232 said that once the hydraulic lines were cut, their only means of steering the aircraft and controlling its descent was to selectively accelerate the remaining wing engines.

DOC.HEAD: Tax Refunds Ordered in KC Desegregation Case
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge has ordered $10.7 million in tax refunds for property owners in the Kansas City School District, but only to the 9,000 taxpayers who filed formal protests. The refund involves a property tax increase ordered by U.S. District Judge Russell G. Clark in September 1987 to help finance school desegregation. The U.S. Supreme Court in April declared the 1987 increase unconstitutional. Its unanimous ruling said Clark exceeded his legal authority in directly raising the district's tax rate from $2.05 to $4 on each $100 assessed value. But it also said federal judges may order local officials to raise property taxes to help desegregate public schools. The money to be refunded has been held in an escrow account by Jackson County and will not come out of the district's current budget or from the state. ``I thought that was good for the district, because we don't have any money,'' said school board President Julia Hill. She applauded Clark's order implementing the refund. ``That's what the school board asked for. ... We're quite pleased about that.'' Clark's refund order, which was dated Oct. 29 but arrived from his office in Springfield on Wednesday, said refunds would go only to the taxpayers who followed the protest process required by Missouri law. Homeowners due refunds will receive $37.05 for every $10,000 of property value. Arthur Benson II, lawyer for the plaintiffs in the desegregation case, said that limiting refunds to the people who protested was appropriate. He did not protest his property taxes and will receive no refund. He said he was sympathetic to those who failed to protest their tax payments. ``I'm sorry for them, and I'm sorry they won't get a refund,'' Benson said. ``But people have an obligation to protest their rights.'' Some of Kansas City's largest businesses should receive a big portion of the refunds. Hallmark Cards Inc., for example, protested more than $1 million in tax payments. Thousands of people also paid their 1988 and 1989 property taxes under protest, but none of those payments will be refunded, Clark ruled. The Supreme Court ruling held that the method used to set the district's tax rate in 1988 and 1989, even though it did not rely on a vote of the people, was constitutional. Because of that, Clark said, there was no cause to refund those payments. On Monday, the Supreme Court let stand a ruling that boosted Clark's power to order predominantly white suburban schools to accept inner-city black students. The justices, without comment, rejected an appeal by three suburban school districts facing such a desegregation order.

DOC.HEAD: Jurors Say Tyson Fondled Woman
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with hearing resuming today. Picks up 4th graf, `The jury ...'
DOC.TEXT: Boxer Mike Tyson, fighting a demand for up to $2.5 million in punitive damages after a jury found he fondled a woman in a nightclub, testified today that he made more than $20 million in 1989. The former heavyweight champion was questioned by the woman's attorney about a financial statement putting Tyson's net worth at $15 million as of Feb. 28. Asked how much he earned this year, Tyson said, ``I had a bad year this year,'' apparently referring to his defeat in February by James ``Buster'' Douglas. The jury awarded Sandra Miller, a 26-year-old computer operator, just $100 in compensatory damages for the Dec. 10, 1988 incident. She had sought $1 million. The jury today began a second phase of the civil trial to determine whether the woman should receive punitive damages. Tyson, who testified earlier during the trial, acknowledged that he was at the Manhattan disco that night but denied knowing or ever touching Miller. Her lawyers planned to call as a witness today another woman who has sued Tyson over an allegedly similar incident the same night at the disco. The jury in the civil case deliberated 4{ hours Wednesday before finding that Tyson grabbed Miller's breasts and buttocks after she refused his advances at Bentley's Disco in 1988. Tyson had denied knowing or ever touching Miller. The fighter said of the verdict, ``If they thought it was serious, they would have given her more than 100 bucks.'' The jury ruled that Tyson committed battery but not assault. U.S. District Judge Michael B. Mukasey had told jurors that assault required no finding of contact but must include a threat, while battery requires actual contact. Miller said she felt ``great that they know that he did it.'' In closing arguments, Tyson's attorney, Robert Hirth, told the jury that Miller had made up her claims to get money from Tyson. ``You should send a message that if Sandra Miller wants to engage in a get-rich-quick scheme she should buy a lottery ticket,'' Hirth said. Compensatory damages are awarded to compensate victims for pain and suffering, medical bills and any losses, such as lost income or a damaged reputation. Punitive damages are awarded to punish the party responsible.

DOC.HEAD: Government Sets Medicare Hospital Deductible for 1991
DOC.TEXT: Federal health officials said Thursday that Medicare beneficiaries admitted to hospitals next year will have to pay deductibles of $628, which is 6 percent higher than this year's rate. The deductible is calculated according to a formula set by law and in 1991 will be $36 higher than this year's deductible, said the Health Care Financing Administration Except for the deductible, Medicare pays for all necessary hospital inpatient services for 60 days. If further hospitalization is needed, beneficiaries next year will have to pay coinsurance of $157 per day, $9 more than this year. These coinsurance payments are required to be one-fourth of the hospital deductible. If after hospitalization, extended care in a skilled nursing facility is required, Medicare pays for all approved services for the first 20 days. For the next 80 days in such a facility, beneficiaries will be responsible for $78.50 per day in coinsurance. That rate is $4.50 higher than the 1990 rate. The 1991 monthly premium for Medicare hospital insurance for those over 65 who have not earned entitlement to it will be $177. Entitlement is earned through employment under the Social Security or Railroad Retirement systems.

DOC.HEAD: Mrs. Bush: President Would Consider Meeting With Saddam
DOC.TEXT: President Bush would consider doing anything, including a one-on-one meeting with Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, to ease tensions in the Persian Gulf, first lady Barbara Bush said today. Mrs. Bush said Americans trapped in Kuwait since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion are on the president's mind 24 hours a day. When asked if Bush would consider meeting face-to-face with Saddam, Mrs. Bush replied: ``I think he would consider anything to get the Kuwaitis back in their own country, and to get our men out.'' Mrs. Bush appeared at a news conference to bolster Republican candidate Ally Milder, who faces Rep. Peter Hoagland, D-Neb., in next week's election. Bush, starting a separate six-day cross-country campaign swing, continued tough rhetoric against Saddam. In a speech to a GOP rally in Mashpee, Mass., Bush said he was ``more determined than ever'' to drive the Iraqi leader out of Kuwait and that Saddam's forces were more barbaric than Adolf Hitler. In an earlier appearance today in Overland Park, Kan., Mrs. Bush was asked her feelings on her husband's ``belligerent statements'' about Iraq. ``Isn't that funny because he's just being firm. There's a big difference,'' Mrs. Bush replied. ``I don't think of my husband as belligerent. I think of him as wise,'' she said. Mrs. Bush expressed confidence the United States will avoid war. ``When you have 24 countries in the world all working for peace ... trying to get something done, I think you will,'' Mrs. Bush said. Later at a speech before a partisan crowd in Omaha, her last campaign stop of the 1990 elections, Mrs. Bush made a slip of the tongue. She said Ms. Milder is independent and wouldn't vote with Bush 100 percent of the time. ``But I know she's going to vote 100 percent of the time for the people of Oklahoma,'' Mrs. Bush said, catching herself immediately. ``Oh, I knew I'd do that. Last day, last candidate. In Omaha,'' Mrs. Bush said.

DOC.HEAD: Dirt, Cement Collapse Plexiglas Coffin, Killing Magician
LaserPhotos FR1
DOC.TEXT: A clear plastic coffin buried under 6 feet of dirt and wet concrete for a Halloween escape trick collapsed under the weight and killed the would-be Houdini locked inside with chains and handcuffs. About 150 people, including the magician's children and wife, watched as aides frantically dug at the dirt and cement to try to rescue Joseph Burrus. ``They attempted to get him out, but it did no good,'' said Police Lt. Roger Enmark. Burrus, a recovering addict, was performing the stunt to benefit a drug treatment clinic. The 3 feet of dirt and 3 feet of concrete were estimated at 9 tons. Burrus, who billed himself as ``Amazing Joe,'' said before the stunt that he considered himself a successor to the great escape artist Harry Houdini. ``I consider myself a master of illusion and an escape artist. I believe I am the next Houdini and greater,'' Burrus said. ``To me, that is what an escape artist is: to put myself in an impossible situation and get out of it.'' Burrus was handcuffed and wrapped in chains, locked inside the coffin, lowered into a 7-foot-deep grave and buried. Burrus completed a similar escape last year in Salem, Ore., getting out of the coffin through a side panel and digging his way up through the covering of soil. He had said Wednesday's attempt was his first to escape through a layer of concrete. ``He told me he had perfected this act and said he was a recovering addict and wanted to do this show as a benefit,'' said Charles Lewis of The Third Floor, a drug rehabilitation group for which Burrus was doing the stunt. After the coffin was lowered into the grave, aides shoveled about 3 feet of dirt into the hole. A cement truck poured another 3 feet of wet concrete into the grave. ``As soon as we finished and the truck pulled away, the whole thing dropped. The cement busted the coffin. It buried him alive,'' said assistant Sean Henderson. ``Immediately everyone went into action to get him out,'' said Mark Crosse, a photographer with The Fresno Bee. ``I heard cracks. ... Somebody yelled, `get a paramedic' and `does anybody know CPR?' '' A backhoe dug a hole alongside the coffin to drain the concrete while workers frantically shoveled dirt from the grave. Burrus was declared dead at the scene, Enmark said.

DOC.HEAD: Albanian Cope With Hardships With Eyes on West
DOC.TEXT: A middle-aged woman pinched her shabby sweater in a gesture of disgust. It cost half her monthly wage of about $50. A teen-ager wore the same troubled expression in a murky, muddy alley five minutes' walk from Tirana's showcase Skanderbeg Square. ``These are the streets of a capital,'' he sighed. After more than four decades of isolationist rule under Enver Hoxha, the Balkan nation of 3.2 million is slowly opening to the outside. The glimpses offered are often of hardship and frustration. Official propaganda under Hoxha - who died in April 1985 - lauded the Communist leader's success in modernizing Albania. The Soviets helped until the 1961, when relations were broken because of Albania's Stalinist and pro-Chinese policies. Sixteen years later, Albania severed ties with the Chinese. Then Albania was largely on its own, importing items such as East European trucks or discarded West German buses in barter for exports of chrome, chemicals or produce. Progress was made. Albania, without railways in 1944, now has built up industry, harnessed its mountain rivers for power and expanded agriculture. Even with a larger education system, children may still tramp miles to school. The economy has a far longer journey to rival even former East Bloc nations. Windows are lacking in homes, schools and dingy buses, lopsided from decades of use and neglect. Factories in towns such as Kavaje, Fier, Patos and Ballsh, all south of Tirana, seem as if they were abandoned in war. Sometimes, a glimmer of light or a face at a window reveals that some work is going on. In these cities, most Albanians live in dingy, three-story apartment blocks. Many of the balconies, festooned with laundry, are stacked with firewood for winter heat. Cooking is mostly done by kerosene. Lamps are often just bare bulbs. In some cases, the environment has been sacrificed for industry. Oil derricks around Qitet i Stalin and Ballsh leak streams of black oil into the earth around them. Lignite mined for heat or power gives the air in Tirana a choking tang, familiar in many other East European cities. Industrial emissions spew uncontrolled into the air. In towns, one-story dwellings reminiscent of the stone huts seen in villages often nestle between the blocks. Sometimes they are surrounded by a walled garden. Sheep or other animals may be tethered nearby. In its efforts to improve daily life, the Communist government of President Ramiz Alia has begun to allow citizens to sell surplus produce from homes or collective farms at private markets. Prices, however, are relatively high. Meat, often scarce in state stores, goes for more than $1 a pound. Families drag their own sheep or goats to be slaughtered and cooked at communal bakehouses, where women also arrive with uncooked cakes for baking. Vegetables are generally available around the nation, which has many sunny, fertile plains. Leeks, spinach, carrots, beans, shriveled crab apples and eggplants were on sale in late October from 20 cents to 50 cents for a kilogram, equal to 2.2 pounds. Yet even agriculture has been hit hard by this summer's drought, which Alia admitted in August had cost the equivalent of $20 million in lost power generated by hydroelectricity, and an estimated $60 million in lost industrial production. Western diplomats in Tirana argue that Alia's new course of ``democratization'' in Albania was dictated solely by economic need. When communism fell across Eastern Europe, Albania lost virtually its only source of barter trade and was compelled to open up, the diplomats said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Foreign businessmen and experts trickle into Tirana to discuss helping the economy. American oil experts in the capital in late Otober said they were impressed with what Albanian experts had achieved with outmoded equipment, but said foreign help is needed for progress. There is talk in the official media of breaking with one of the most sacrosanct tenets of Hoxha - the ban on foreign loans - and indulging in joint ventures. Other articles have relied on more traditional propaoganda to encourage the people to work harder. ``There is no import without export'' is a popular slogan invoked in this effort. But Soviet toothpaste ($4 a tube), Italian dishwashing liquid ($2 a bottle) and sunglasses ($15 a pair) among the only foreign goods seen in stores. One way in which Albania could earn foreign currency is through tourism. Mountains, which cover 70 percent of the country, offer spectacular scenery and unspoiled wildlife. The Adriatic and Ionian coasts boast warm beaches. Yet the flow of tourists is presently only about 10,000 yearly, far lower than neighboring nations of Greece and Yugoslavia. Hints of the world beyond the borders comes from Yugoslav, Greek or Italian TV, or the Voice of America radio broadcasts in Albanian. Prized radio-cassette players offer a chance to play much-copied tapes of Western rock 'n' roll music. Many Albanians see their only hope as leaving. While children pester foreign visitors for gum or pens, adult Albanians often murmur ``visa, visa,'' to passing foreigners. ``I can stay,'' said a woman at a factory in Tirana. She then pointed to her son. ``But he, it's better he gets out.''

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Of Romanians Protest Price Increases
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with street protests. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Romanians took to the streets today to protest price rises that doubled or tripled prices on a wide range of goods. About 2,500 demonstrators occupied the main downtown square in Bucharest and about 10,000 people demonstrated in the central city of Brasov demanding that a partial deregulation of prices be rescinded. ``They should have made sure products are available before raising prices,'' insisted one man at the Bucharest rally. ``Their policy only creates fear.'' The Commerce Ministry said the new price policy, which officially went into effect this morning, would double prices for clothes, public transport and furniture, among other items. Essential foodstuffs, energy and rents remained protected for the time being. Romanians appeared increasingly frustrated and confused by the reforms, claiming they were not adequately informed about them. Their frustration was compounded by a lack of goods in the stores. Many shops were closed. ``No one has any idea what's going on,'' said one man who was shopping. Protesters shouted slogans accusing President Ion Iliescu and the government of being crypto-Communists and of unfairly raising prices under the guise of liberalization. Iliescu and his National Salvation Front, who took power in the December revolution that ousted Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, promised gradual reforms and social protection. But after the Front won overwhelmingly in May elections, Roman sped up the process of reform. Both chambers of Parliament resumed a joint session today. Premier Petre Roman asked the two houses to grant the government special powers to impose temporary value-added and income taxes by decree. But Finance Minister Teodor Stolojan and Economics Minister Eugen Dijmarescu, dispatched to parliament to argue the government's case, encountered opposition. Most of it came from members of their own National Salvation Front. Petrisor Morar, a deputy from the small opposition party Romanian Unity Alliance, demanded a no-confidence vote against the government and began collecting the 150 signatures necessary to hold such a vote. He accused the government of ``not providing social protection against the reforms.'' Valentin Gabrielescu of the National Peasant Party said his party would, but the National Liberal Party's Dinu Patriciu said he would back the government. ``It's inevitable that price reforms occur and it will require sacrifices... Any government would have to do this,'' Patriciu said. Deputy Reform Minister Dorel Sandor said that if the government fell ``it would only delay the same reforms by a year... (meaning) a tragedy for the economy.'' In July, legislation on the sale of failing state-owned industries was approved. Last month the government slashed their credits and energy subsidies. Roman, who attended a closed-door session of Parliament late Wednesday to discuss the economic program, was quoted by state radio as warning the only alternative to a market economy was ``a return to the past.'' In addition to the price reforms, the national currency was to be devalued today by more than 50 percent to help exports. The new rate was 35 lei to the dollar. Under the price increases that were to take effect today, 2.2 pounds of carrots would go from four lei (about 11 cents) to 10 lei (about 28 cents.) But most food items, energy and rents are to remain controlled until next year. ``I can't force stores to raise prices,'' said Finance Ministry Price Director Ghoerghe Oana. ``From this point on, factories are selling at different prices, and this will eventually affect the consumer. But stores are essentially free to do what they want.''

DOC.HEAD: Former Co-Workers Testify in Right-to-Die Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with four grafs to UPDATE with additional testimony. Picks up in 3rd graf, ``Colby represents ...
DOC.TEXT: Two former co-workers testified today that Nancy Cruzan, whose seven-year coma has been the subject of a long-running legal battle, would not want to continue being kept alive. ``I have no doubt,'' Mary Ann Smith of Joplin said when she was asked by attorney Bill Colby whether Ms. Cruzan would reject all efforts to keep her alive in her comatose condition. Tom Turner, former owner of an Oklahoma City office supplies store where Ms. Cruzan worked briefly, said in videotaped testimony that they once talked about the case of Karen Ann Quinlan, who lived in a similar coma-like condition for nine years after she was removed from a respirator. ``Nancy was very specific about what she would want if she were in Karen's situation. That was she would not want to be kept alive under those circumstances. It was almost like she found the thought of being maintained in a vegetative state unforgivable, reprehensible or repulsive,'' Turner said. Colby represents Joe and Joyce Cruzan, who are seeking to have their 33-year-old daughter's feeding tube disconnected so she may die as they believe she would want. The U.S. Supreme Court last summer rejected the parents' request. But Colby said he had new evidence showing that Ms. Cruzan would want to die. He planned to have three former co-workers testify in Jasper County Circuit Court. The three have not previously testified in the case. Mrs. Smith, of Joplin, said she and Ms. Cruzan worked as teacher aides at a private school for severely handicapped deaf and blind children in 1978 and ``got to be very close.'' She said they had several conversations about what they would want their family to do with them if they became as severely handicapped as some of the children they cared for. Mrs. Smith recalled a conversation with Ms. Cruzan and a teacher in March 1978 while Ms. Cruzan was holding and attempting to feed a 3-year-old girl who was the most severely handicapped child at the school. Ms. Cruzan was trying to feed the child with a tube inserted through the throat and into her stomach. ``She talked about how pitiful she (the girl) was and she didn't know she was alive - so severely retarded she could live all her life and not know the beauty of life,'' Mrs. Smith said. She said they talked during a one-hour period about how none of them would want to be kept on life-support equipment in such a state. Mrs. Smith said if she were in the girl's condition ``she would want the plug to be pulled.'' Ms. Cruzan ``shook her head yes,'' she said. ``We were all in agreement. We would not want to put our families through that,'' she said. Colby told the court in his opening statement ``you will find the Cruzans are almost out of emotions. It's been a long and trying three years.'' However, Colby said the family still has ``lots of love'' for their daughter. Ms. Cruzan suffered permanent brain damage when her car overturned on the road home from work on Jan. 11, 1983. Doctors say she is incapable of reacting or relating to her environment and can experience no thoughts or emotions. On Oct. 23, Judge Charles E. Teel Jr. dismissed the state as a party in the case at the request of Missouri Attorney General William Webster. Webster argued that his involvement was no longer necessary because the Missouri Supreme Court and the U.S. Supreme Court have set guidelines on when food and water can be withdrawn from comatose patients. In its first right-to-die decision, the U.S. Supreme Court ruled 5-4 in July that the state could keep a patient on life support in the absence of ``clear and convincing'' proof that the person would want to die. Ms. Cruzan left no written instructions about what she would want done under such circumstances. However, her parents and sister say they know she would have rather died than be kept alive in such fashion. Colby says the testimony by Ms. Cruzan's former co-workers will meet the ``clear and convincing'' standard.

DOC.HEAD: Death Toll in Nine Days of Religious Riots Tops 200
LaaserPhoto AYO1
DOC.TEXT: Religious riots sparked by Hindu fundamentalists' attempt to seize a Moslem mosque intensified Thursday, and the death toll in nine days of clashes rose to more than 200. News agencies and officials reported at least 31 people died across the country on Thursday. They were killed in battles between Hindus and Moslems or when police fired on mobs or when victims died in hospitals of injuries suffered in earlier riots. At least 210 people have died since Oct. 24, when the fighting began. Most of the deaths were in Uttar Pradesh, the state where the disputed shrine is located, and in Gujarat state. Both states have a history of sectarian clashes and simmering tensions between Hindus and Moslems. Uttar Pradesh is India's most populous state. At least 30 percent of its 120 million people are Moslems. Violence has erupted in 22 of its 63 districts, according to police officials in Lucknow, the state capital. The disput has also caused riots in neighboring Bangladesh, an Islamic nation, where Moslem mobs attacked temples and Hindu shops and homes after hearing of the violence in India. At least one person was killed in Dhaka, which is under curfew along with the port city of Chittagong. In Ayodhya, site of the disputed mosque, the bodies of three Hindus were found Thursday in the Saryu River. The victims were apparently killed Tuesday when police opened fire to throw back Hindus who stormed the mosque, residents said. At least seven people are previously known to have died in the police action. The discovery of the bodies led to the deployment of extra government troops around the dusty temple town and forced Hindu groups to postpone a fresh attempt to storm the mosque. But members of the fundamentalist World Hindu Council vowed to continue their efforts to take over the disputed site. Ashok Singhal, the council's general secretary, told a public meeting outside Ayodhya his group would not give up its campaign to replace the mosque with a temple. Singhal is wanted by the police. His appearance at a well-publicized meeting attended by thousands of people lent credence to reports that many police officers are sympathetic to the Hindu movement. ``There is no power on earth which can stop us from building the temple,'' Singhal told the crowd. ``There is no place for Islam in our nation.'' Singhal, who wore a bandage around his head, sustained injuries during Tuesday's attack on the temple. He later slipped away from the hospital where he was treated. The World Hindu Council says the 460-year-old Babri mosque is built over the birthplace of Lord Rama, one of the most revered Hindu gods. At least 900 people were killed in Hindu-Moslem violence last year when the group first announced its intention to take over the site by force. The dispute has threatened to bring down Prime Minister V.P. Singh's 11-month-old government. A pro-Hindu party, which had supported the government coalition, withdrew its backing two weeks ago when its president was arrested while leading a march to drum up support for the temple construction. In another political development Thursday, the Congress Party of former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi supported the government of Chimanbhai Patel, a member of Singh's National Front coalition, in a vote of confidence in the Gujarat state assembly. Patel's government had been reduced to a minority after the Hindu right-wing Bharatiya Janata Party withdrew support in line with its decision to jettison the National Front coalition in the federal Parliament. Congress Party leaders in New Delhi defended the decision by saying they were willing to support the National Front - but not Singh. They have said the party will oppose Singh in the Nov. 7 confidence vote - but could support a National Front government if Singh were replaced as prime minister. Political commentators and newspapers have attacked Singh for what they call his vacillation on the temple-mosque dispute, saying it is the greatest threat to India's political system since the country became independent in 1947. India is predominantly Hindu and all its prime ministers have belonged to the majority community, but tolerance of all religions and secularism is a part of its constitution. Hindus make up 82 percent of India's 880 million people and Moslems comprise 12 percent of the population. The others include Sikhs, Christians and Buddhists.

DOC.HEAD: Students Digging for Time Capsule for 10-Year-Old Prank
DOC.TEXT: Plymouth High School students digging for a time capsule buried by the Class of 1980 found a practical joke. Instead of finding the red tube that had been buried Oct. 31, 1980, they uncovered a note and a map in a glass jar. ``Better luck next time,'' the note uncovered Wednesday read. ``The Warriors. Dec. 20, 1980.'' Principal Brad Turson remembers the Warriors as a group of students who hung around together during the late 1970s. The map in the jar led students to the front corner of the school building where the time capsule had been reburied. Inside were predictions and notes on life in Plymouth by students of that era. Rick Stephens, Class of '81, was on hand for the capsule opening but couldn't recall what his capsule entry was. It was a prediction that the United States would be at war with Iran. The students replaced it Wednesday with their own time capsule, to be dug up Oct. 31, 2000. It includes forecasts for the year 2000 of a cure for cancer, a woman president, a national deficit in the ``quadrillions,'' gasoline priced at $2 to $3 per gallon, Japanese ownership of most of America's businesses, a World Series for the Cleveland Indians and a Super Bowl for the Cleveland Browns.

DOC.HEAD: Stop the Madness: Actor Brad Dourif Wants to Play a Real Person
DOC.TEXT: Actors often complain they never get a serious role. But Brad Dourif would like a role that's, well, less serious. A little more stable, anyway. Dourif began his film career in the role of mentally deranged Billy Bibbit in ``One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest.'' After playing an obsessed rat exterminator in ``Graveyard Shift'' and a drifter in ``Sonny Boy,'' Dourif says he's ``playing another crazy person'' in the current filming of Werner Herzog's ``Scream of Stone.'' But Dourif is campaigning for sane roles now. He was called to play the killer in ``Grim Prairie Tales,'' but held out, and is now playing an East Coast writer whose stories are highlighted in the film. Another role as a romantic lead in ``Hidden Agenda'' is helping Dourif fulfill his goals as an actor. ``I wanted to get the girl and make the big bucks, like everybody else,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Reports Slight Drop in Iraqi Armored Vehicles in Kuwait
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq has removed about 300 armored vehicles from Kuwait while adding more artillery pieces in the occupied Persian Gulf nation, the Pentagon said Thursday. Bob Hall, a Pentagon spokesman, said that Defense Department analysts see little significance in the changes. He noted that an estimated 430,000 Iraqi military personnel are still in and around Kuwait - the same number as a month ago. ``It doesn't change their posture, which is primarily one of defense'' with the capability to switch to an offensive campaign, Hall said. The spokesman said the Pentagon estimates that Iraq now has 2,200 armored personnel carriers and infantry fighting vehicles in Kuwait and southern Iraq, compared with 2,500 before. The number of Iraqi artillery pieces in the area has risen from 1,700 to 2,200, Hall said, while the Iraqi tank count remains at 3,500. The United States has at least 220,000 military personnel in the gulf, plus about 800 tanks. Hall said he could not comment on Bush administration plans to send additional forces to the gulf. He said any announcements would come only after the deployments were under way. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said earlier this week that the U.S. flow of military personnel to the gulf would continue, possibly adding as many as 100,000 forces. Hall also said the aircraft carrier USS Midway had arrived in the north Arabian Sea in the last few days, bringing the number of U.S. carriers in the region to four. Hall declined to discuss the movements of other U.S. warships in the area, but the Navy said recently that the carrier USS Independence was due to leave the area soon and that the Midway would be its replacement.

DOC.HEAD: New GOP Group Fights Pro-Choice Movement
DOC.TEXT: A group of anti-abortion Republicans led by Phyllis Schlafly said Thursday it will ask GOP officeholders to sign a pledge reaffirming the party's stand against abortion. The undertaking by the newly formed Republican National Coalition for Life is designed to counter efforts by another group whose members advocate abortion rights and a change in the plank the party has adopted in its last three national platforms. ``The purpose of our committee is to make sure the party does not abandon its principled stand,'' Mrs. Schlafly, president of the conservative Eagle Forum and a director of the new group, said at a news conference. She said more than 100 GOP officeholders already have signed the pledge to reaffirm the plank and support Republican candidates opposed to abortion. ``To be effective, elected officials must no longer waffle or be wishy-washy on their pro-life convictions,'' said Beverly LaHaye, president of Concerned Women for America. The National Republican Coalition for Choice, formed last year, supports candidates who favor abortion rights and advocates a change in the party platform, which states: ``The unborn child has a fundamental individual right to life which cannot be infringed.'' In 1989, Democrats running for governor and lieutenant governor of Virginia, governor of New Jersey and mayor of New York won on abortion rights platforms against GOP candidates who had anti-abortion records but tried to moderate their stance. The national party has said it welcomes pro-choice candidates despite its stance in the platform. Mrs. Schlafly said the new group isn't supporting candidates in Tuesday's elections, but that it likely would form a political action committee to support anti-abortion Republican candidates. ``What we want to say is that you make a great mistake when you abandon your position,'' Mrs. Schlafly said. ``Look at the way George Bush has fallen in the polls when he retreated from his `Read My Lips' pledge (against a tax increase). It's a loser.''

DOC.HEAD: Five New U.N. Security Council Members Elected
DOC.TEXT: The General Assembly on Thursday elected five new members of the Security Council, but they are not expected to shift the balance of power on the council significantly. The new members, which serve a two-year term beginning Jan. 1, are: -Austria and Belgium, replacing outgoing members Canada and Finland; -Zimbabwe, replacing Ethiopia; -India, replacing Malaysia; -Ecuador, replacing Colombia. Regional groups within the General Assembly nominated the candidates, none of which was contested. The five permanent members of the council are the United States, Soviet Union, Britain, France, and China. The other five non-permanent members are Cuba, Ivory Coast, Romania, Yemen and Zaire.

DOC.HEAD: Mrs. Bush: President Would Consider Meeting With Saddam
DOC.TEXT: President Bush would consider a one-on-one meeting with Iraqi President Saddam Hussein if that would ease tensions in the Persian Gulf, first lady Barbara Bush said Thursday. Mrs. Bush said Americans trapped in Kuwait and Iraq are on Bush's mind 24 hours a day. When asked if Bush would consider meeting face-to-face with Saddam, Mrs. Bush said: ``I think he would consider anything to get the Kuwaitis back in their own country, and to get our men out.'' Thousands of troops have been sent to the Persian Gulf since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. U.S. citizens and others who were in Iraq and Kuwait at the time have been held captive by the Iraqis. Mrs. Bush said she hoped and prayed that force would not be necessary in the crisis. Mrs. Bush appeared at a news conference to bolster the congressional campaign of Republican Ally Milder, who faces first-term Rep. Peter Hoagland, D-Neb., in next week's election. Mrs. Bush said she didn't even know Hoagland's name. ``That's how much of a mark he's made in Washington, incidentally,'' Mrs. Bush said. Later at a speech before a partisan crowd, her last campaign stop of the 1990 elections, Mrs. Bush said Ms. Milder is independent and wouldn't vote with Bush all of the time. ``But I know she's going to vote 100 percent of the time for the people of Oklahoma,'' Mrs. Bush said, catching herself immediately. ``Oh, I knew I'd do that. Last day, last candidate. In Omaha.'' After Mrs. Bush's talk, Ms. Milder presented her with a red Nebraska football team sweatshirt for the Bush's dog, Millie. The sweatshirt's back read: ``Millie for Milder.'' On Wednesday, Mrs. Bush was campaigning in Utah, where Republican congressional hopeful Genevieve Atwood assured her that she supports the president ``down to my underwear,'' even though she opposed a federal budget bill. Atwood is challenging incumbent Democrat Wayne Owens in Utah's 2nd District. After Atwood introduced the first lady and said she was a ``George Bush supporter right down to my underwear,'' Mrs. Bush replied, ``I can hardly wait to get back and tell George about that.''

DOC.HEAD: Greenspan Asked To Reduce Interest Rates
DOC.TEXT: House Democratic leaders called on Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan Thursday to show his support for a recently enacted budget compromise by reducing interest rates. ``The American families that will endure the hardship of deficit reduction now merit the rewards of lower interest rates and continued employment,'' House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., and Rep. Leon Panetta, D-Calif., chairman of the House Budget Committee, said in a letter to Greenspan. A driving force behind yearlong efforts to cut the deficit was an expectation that credit markets and investors would be convinced it would reduce government borrowing and ease pressure on interest rates. Gephardt said the agreement, which is expected to reduce the deficit by $490 billion over five years, provides the deep, enforceable cuts that Greenspan and others had recommended. ``Having honored our commitment to a sound national economy, we now ask that you provide the agreement with the endorsement that financial markets seek,'' the lawmakers wrote. That endorsement would be shown publicly, they continued, ``by allowing an easing of credit conditions in the United States.'' Gephardt and Panetta said a one-quarter-point reduction in short-term rates announced earlier this week ``sends an ambiguous message to the markets and would limit the benefit of the deficit-reduction package on our economic growth.''

DOC.HEAD: Consumer Debt Means Long Recession, Research Group Says
DOC.NOTE: For Release 6:30 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: American consumers' debt binge during the 1980s increases the likelihood the next recession will be long and deep, a liberal policy research group said Thursday. ``If we do experience a recession, its impact will be much more severe than if consumer debt were at a lower level,'' said University of California-Riverside economic professor Robert Pollin. Pollin's study, ``Deeper in Debt: The Changing Financial Condition of U.S. Households,'' said Americans' debt, compared with their disposable income, was at a post-World War II high of 93.9 percent in 1988. In the mid-1970s, the ratio hovered around 75 percent. The debt overhang will cause consumers to cut back spending even more sharply than they would otherwise in an economic downturn, deepening any recession, said the report, prepared for the Economic Policy Institute, a liberal think tank financed partly by labor unions. Any added pressure on consumers is particularly significant because their spending amounts to roughly two-thirds of the nation's economic activity as measured by the gross national product. Mortgage foreclosures and personal bankruptcies already have been increasing during the past decade and would rise even higher in a recession, the study said. All this would add to the pressure on the financial system, already troubled by the collapse of the savings and loan industry and a high rate of bank failures, it said. Banking regulators, who have vigorously urged institutions to use greater care in making real estate and corporate buyout loans, have remained relatively quiet about consumer lending. However one regulator, Comptroller of the Currency Robert Clarke, warned bankers in January about an increase in sour consumer loans. Economist Robert Dugger of the American Bankers Association suggested the effects of any consumer retrenchment would ripple through the economy unevenly. Manufacturers of luxuries would be hit harder than companies making necessities, he said. Also, people would default on unsecured credit card loans before falling behind on their mortgages. ``The credit situation of average- and moderate-income households is more fragile than it has been for years. Fragility, however, doesn't mean that it's going to break,'' he said. Bank data shows that lenders and borrowers already are exercising greater caution, he said. Outstanding consumer and home equity loans totaled $427 billion at the end of June, down $6 billion from six months earlier. Consumers tend to compensate for drops in income by borrowing more. For instance, inflation-adjusted, after-tax personal income in September fell 0.3 percent in September, but real spending rose 0.3 percent, according to the Commerce Department. Consumers did that by dropping their savings rate to a three-year low, but that can only go on for so long. Pollin disputed what he said were several widely-held notions about why consumer debt is increasing. The buildup is notthe result of a consumption binge, nor did it occur because the Baby Boom generation entered its prime borrowing years, he said. Most Americans - except for the wealthiest 20 percent - have needed to borrow more in order to maintain their living standard in the face of stagnating income and rising housing costs, he said. Although it is true that younger people borrow more heavily than people nearing retirement, older Americans also increased their borrowing in the 1980s, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Curfews Imposed on Townships To Curb Black-on-Black Violence
DOC.TEXT: Police placed hundreds of thousands of blacks under curfew Thursday, surrounding their townships with roadblocks under new restrictions intended to curb black-on-black fighting. The leader of the black opposition Inkatha Freedom Party, Mangosuthu Buthelezi, said the violence was the major obstacle to negotiations to include blacks in a new constitution. But a spokesman for the African National Congress, Inkatha's main rival, denounced the government measures as a ``high-handed, bully-boy action'' and said they would only lead to more bloodshed. Buthelezi met with President F.W. de Klerk as part of the South African leader's effort to begin talks with black opposition groups on ending apartheid. Factional fighting between Inkatha and the ANC, led by Nelson Mandela, has slowed efforts to begin the negotiations. Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok said late Wednesday the recent violence had made it ``necessary to introduce extraordinary measures'' in three townships outside Capetown - Khayelitsha, Crossroads and Lingulethu. Similar restrictions were lifted from 11 townships around Johannesburg where fighting has died down. Vlok declared the Capetown townships ``unrest areas'' and said police would use their expanded powers to prevent violence. The restrictions give police wider powers to prevent demonstrations and other forms of protest but are not as broad as those in effect during a nationwide state of emergency that was lifted in June. Reinforcements were called in from Pretoria to enforce the measures, which included a 9 p.m. to 4 a.m. curfew that began Thursday. Officers set up barriers at the entrances to the townships and searched cars. ``The police have information of further planned violence coupled with intimidation ... and protest marches,'' Vlok said. In Cape Town, ANC spokesman Trevor Manuel said the actions would only further anger residents and that violence would not end unless town councilors in the townships step down. The recent conflict has been beteen anti-apartheid groups and the local town councilors. Many anti-apartheid militants see the black councilors as collaborators with the white-led national government.
