The Cape Town townships had been relatively peaceful until two weeks ago, when the wife of a leading anti-apartheid militant in Khayelitsha was slain. Since then, clashes have broken out involving the militants and supporters of the town councilors. Unrest in the Johannesburg townships has been more along tribal lines, with supporters of the Zulu-based Inkatha party facing off against Xhosas and other blacks linked to the ANC. Both groups oppose apartheid but differ on tactics to fight it and on their vision of a future South Africa. Restrictions were lifted Wednesday on 11 Johannesburg townships, where more than 800 blacks died in violence in August. The measures were kept in effect in Soweto, the biggest township, where at least 16 people were killed in unrest this week. In Natal province, meanwhile, where thousands of blacks have died in factional fighting, a regional Inkatha leader was critically injured Thursday after a bomb exploded in his car, police said. Lancelot Ntombela was driving in Greytown when the device went off, officials said. Also Thursday, police announced the arrests of five white men believed tied to right-wing organizations. The men have not been charged, but are being investigated for the possession of illegal weapons and possible links to recent violence, the independent South African Press Association reported.

DOC.HEAD: Mansion Built by Admitted Embezzler Being Sold
DOC.TEXT: A mansion built for a woman who admitted embezzling millions of dollars from Citibank may soon be home to the former head of a collapsed guarantor of student loans. Richard C. Hawk, president and chairman of the Higher Education Assistance Foundation in Overland Park, confirmed Wednesday he plans to buy the Colonial-style house, dubbed ``Tara'' by neighbors. U.S. Department of Education officials, who have asked Hawk to resign, say the foundation this year guaranteed more than $1 billion of the country's defaulted student loans. Hawk has been cleared of any wrongdoing in the collapse of the company, but federal officials said Hawk was responsible for ``bad business decisions.'' Hawk said he expected to move into the house by December. The house, in Hallbrook Farms, one of the area's most exclusive residential communities, was built for Becky and Peter Schafer, a Nebraska couple who bought it with money Mrs. Schafer embezzled from her employer, New York-based Citibank. Citibank took possession of the house in August after Mrs. Schafer was arrested and charged. She pleaded guilty to embezzlement last month for taking at least $3.5 million. ``I saw the house for sale, and I made an offer,'' Hawk said. ``My wife and I happen to like Colonial-style homes.'' The house, which cost $1 million to build, has marble floors, custom-made stairwells and leaded-glass doors. Hawk is paying $900,000 for the house, according to unidentified sources quoted by the Kansas City Star. Hawk said Wednesday his foundation guaranteed 40 percent of the $2.1 billion in student loans Citibank had outstanding last year. He said the purchase was not connected to his work at the foundation or its dealings with Citibank. ``HEAF is a non-profit organization and does not constitute what might be considered my net worth,'' Hawk said. ``If the only thing I was involved in was HEAF, I wouldn't have the capital to purchase the home in Hallbrook. That should be obvious.'' A Citibank spokesman declined to comment.

DOC.HEAD: McGrath Released From Hospital; Hopes To Campaign in New York
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Raymond J. McGrath, R-N.Y., was discharged from the hospital Thursday, one week after he was stricken with a blood clot in his lung, according to a spokesman. ``He went home with his wife,'' said Dan Zielinski, McGrath's press secretary. ``He's under strict doctor's orders to get plenty of rest.'' The congressman has a home in the Maryland suburbs, as well as on Long Island, N.Y. McGrath is planning to go to New York on Sunday and hopes to make some campaign appearances, Zielinski said. ``He realizes he's missed quite a bit during the last week and he wants to do as much as he can.'' McGrath is still taking blood-thinning drugs and has to have his blood checked daily for the next week to make sure no new clots appear, Zielinski said. McGrath was hospitalized after becoming sick at his Capitol Hill office Oct. 25. After a series of tests, doctors at Walter Reed Army Medical Center diagnosed a pulmonary embolism, or a blockage in a blood vessel in the lung. McGrath, 48, of Valley Stream, is running for a sixth term from a heavily Republican district in Nassau Count. He is being challenged by Democrat Mark Epstein, an environmental lawyer.

DOC.HEAD: Sharif Chosen to Head Pakistan Government
DOC.TEXT: Nawaz Sharif, the architect of ousted Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's stunning election defeat, was poised Thursday to head Pakistan's fifth freely elected government in 43 years. Sharif, a wealthy 41-year-old industrialist with humble beginnings, was nominated by the right-wing Islamic Democratic Alliance to be the next prime minister. But a militant group in Ms. Bhutto's home province of Sind warned his election would bring protests and demonstrations. Sharif led his party to a landslide victory over Ms. Bhutto's Pakistan People's Party in the elections on Oct. 24, winning 105 of the 217 seats in the National Assembly, the policy-making lower house of Parliament. The assembly, scheduled to convene Saturday, will elect the prime minister by secret ballot, but the vote is seen only as a formality. The battle for the prime minister's chair was expected to be a hard-fought contest between Sharif and Ghulam Mustafa Jatoi, the caretaker prime minister since Ms. Bhutto's government was ousted on corruption charges three months ago. Jatoi reluctantly bowed to Sharif, who offered him any Cabinet post he wanted. The offer was declined. ``I'm not a job hunter,'' Jatoi said after a coalition meeting that ended his brief tenure. Throughout Ms. Bhutto's 20 months in power, Sharif governed Punjab province, the powerhouse of Pakistan politics and home to about 60 percent of the country's 110 million people. Shortly after Ms. Bhutto became prime minister in December 1988, Sharif organized 18 diverse parties into a coalition that became known by its Urdu-language intials of IJI. It had one goal: to bring down Ms. Bhutto. Twice, Ms. Bhutto and Sharif tried but failed to oust each other. Ms. Bhutto governed until President Ghulam Ishaq Khan dismissed her on Aug. 6 for corruption, incompetence and abuse of power, charges she steadfastly denies. With the 37-year-old former premier and her party effectively weakened, many are now questioning whether the alliance of such diverse ideologies will hold together. Ms. Bhutto predicts its collapse within six months. Sharif's government will face daunting problems on all fronts. Tensions with its eastern neighbor, India, continue to smolder over disputed Kashmir, while a military and political stalemate in Afghanistan, Pakistan's western neighbor, drags on and prevents the return of some 4 million refugees. The economy is on the verge of collapse, facing $2 billion in lost revenues from the Persian Gulf crisis. Washington has suspended nearly $600 million in economic and military aid because of suspicions about Pakistan's nuclear program. Although he has little experience in national government, supporters say Sharif is conscious of his weak spots and willingly accepts advise. Sharif's political career was launched in the early 1980s when the army ruled Pakistan. He is more in tune with the urban middle class than the landed families who have ruled Pakistan since its creation in the 1947 partition of the Indian subcontinent. He is seen even by the country's left as a break from tradition and a catalyst that could end feudal control in Pakistan, where more than three-fourths of the people are landless, illiterate and earn less than $400 a year. He is seen as a man of humble beginnings who worked hard to gain support. His family's multimillion-dollar steel foundary was launched by his father from an oven in a ramshackle building in the heart of Punjab. The business expanded and then diversified to include sugar and textile mills and now employs about 10,000 people. Sharif, often described as shy, appears uneasy when asked about his family or their personal wealth. ``Certainly not as rich as the Bhuttos,'' he once replied when asked to estimate his wealth.

DOC.HEAD: Navy Releases Names of Sailors Killed in Ship Accident
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Navy on Thursday released the names of the 10 sailors killed in a boiler accident aboard the amphibious assault ship USS Iwo Jima in the Persian Gulf. The 10 were identified as: -Tyrone Michael Brooks, 19, a boiler technician fireman recruit from Detroit. -David Alan Gilliland,21, boiler technician 3rd class, from Warrensburg, Mo. -Mark Edward Hutchison, 27, boiler technician 2nd class, from Elkins, W.V. -Daniel Lupatsky, 22, electrician's mate 2nd class, from Centralia, Pa. -Michael Nunnally Manns, Jr., 23, fireman from Fredericksburg, Va. -Daniel Clayton McKinsey, 21, boiler technician fireman apprentice, from Hanover, Pa. -Fred Russell Parker, Jr., 24, boiler technician 2nd class, from Reidsville, N.C. -James Arthur Smith, Jr., 22, machinist's mate 3rd class, from Somerville, Tenn. -Lt. John Mather Snyder, 25, of Milltown, N.J. -Robert Lee Volden, 38, boiler technician 1st class, from Rego Park, N.Y.

DOC.HEAD: I Was Right, Former East German Leader Says
DOC.TEXT: Former East German leader Erich Honecker says in a published interview that his countrymen are becoming aware of the rights and social services they have lost, and he predicted that communism will recover. ``In the end I will be seen to have been right,'' Honecker was quoted as saying in Friday's edition of The European newspaper. Honecker, interviewed in his small flat in a Soviet military hospital compound outside Berlin, expressed no fear of facing criminal charges. ``I am not afraid of a show trial. I consider all the charges so far brought by the prosecutor's office untenable,'' Honecker was quoted as saying. ``I also reject responsibility for the figure, cited by the prosecutor's office, of 200 killed on the GDR (East German) borders. I have no personal guilt for that. And what, I ask myself, about those who killed GDR border guards while violating our frontiers?'' The European said Honecker was interviewed by Heinz Judge, a comrade of Honecker in the anti-Nazi resistance. Honecker, whose Communist regime was toppled in October 1989, said it had been ``a great disappointment for me that so many people have forgotten socialism and turned to the D-mark instead.'' ``But I am not afraid that former GDR citizens would threaten me or lynch me, despite the demonstration cries and banner slogans of the so-called `Democrats.' Quite the contrary; in the end I will be seen to have been right. ``It has already become quite obvious to all what rights and social services they have lost,'' Honecker said. He contended that the Communist parties of the old East Bloc had been brought down by intrigues, but that they could bounce back. ``What is needed now,'' Honecker was quoted as saying, ``is a merciless investigation of the reasons for what has happened and the relevant conclusions to be drawn. The Communist movement has certainly suffered a defeat but it will recover.'' He offered no apologies for his years in power. ``Everything I did, I did in the knowledge that I was doing something for the people and for peace. In the present situation they need scapegoats and I am being made the biggest one. ``My wife and I are shocked by the allegations and calumnies against us. We are accused of corruption and self-enrichment at the expense of the people. But Margot and I have nothing to reproach ourselves with. We did not lead a life of luxury and we do not have a bank account in Switzerland. ``We are well enough looked after here by our friends. At least my medical treatment is looked after. ``But my wife and I do not understand why a basic constitutional right in the GDR is denied us - that is, the right to a proper apartment of our own. ``We do not ask too much and want no privileges. All we want is a perfectly normal flat like all other citizens here.''

DOC.HEAD: Los Angeles Basin Residents Breath Easier as Ozone Drops
DOC.TEXT: Residents of the Los Angeles region breathed easier during the summer of 1990 because ozone pollution dropped to its lowest level in more than 40 years and smog alerts declined 60 percent this year. Thanks to strict auto and industrial emissions standards and favorable weather, the ozone level during the May-to-October smog season was down 24 percent from the period last year. ``This is mind-boggling,'' Joseph Cassmassi, senior meteorologist with the South Coast Air Quality Management District, said Wednesday. ``When you compare it with the past, it's like night and day. There's really been a dramatic improvement.'' Ozone, released when the sun heats certain airborne pollutants, is a powerful lung irritant. It is especially harmful to children, people with respiratory disorders, the elderly and people who exercise outdoors. However, in the upper atmosphere it shields the Earth from the sun's harshest ultraviolet radiation. Alerts for high levels of ozone were issued in at least one of the region's cities on 41 days, records show. That compares with 54 days in 1989 and 77 in 1988. Going back to 1977, smog days occurred three times as often. Compared to the May-October period of 1989, there was a 60 percent decline in the number of hours that the region exceeded the Stage 1 level of smog containing .20 parts per million of ozone or more, Cassmassi said. In addition, the ozone problem from year to year has been shrinking in duration as well as the number of days, the data shows. The management district last year adopted a plan aimed at eliminating Stage 1 alerts by the year 2000. The plan increases emissions controls for cars and industry, and regulates various household products and even charcoal lighter fluid. The lower pollutant levels were not apparent to the casual observer. Haziness produced by a mixture of soot and moisture continued to turn the horizon a dull brown, officials said. ``We can get ozone to zero and the public might not even notice it because they gauge air quality by visibility,'' said district chairman Norton Younglove. Ozone levels peak from May through October because of strong sunshine and stagnant air that traps pollutants close to the ground. A 24 percent ozone reduction should produce health benefits, said Dr. Robert Phalen, director of the Air Pollution Health Effects Laboratory at the University of California, Irvine. ``People with lung disorders would notice that this was an easier year for them,'' Phalen said. ``And those of us who don't have a lung disorder are benefiting even though we don't notice it because smog episodes slowly erode lungs.'' However, Dr. Ray Casciari, a physician in Orange, said he has seen no improvement in the health of the estimated 2,000 lung patients his office treats annually. But he said his patients have severe ailments, and ``all they need is one sudden bad exposure'' to require medical care. ``We're encouraged, but it's still flat out awful,'' said Tim Little, executive director of the Coalition for Clean Air, a Santa Monica environmental group. ``It doesn't show enough of a decline to even put us in the same league with the rest of the country.'' Cassmassi said 75 percent of the improvement in air quality is the result of lower emissions and 25 percent a consequence of the weather. The biggest emissions drops traditionally have come from turnover of automobiles. Two million new cars are purchased each year in California. New cars must meet stricter emissions standards that reduce pollutants by 90 percent compared to 15 years ago. Reductions also come from controls on heavy polluters such as oil refineries and aerospace plants. The controls were enacted years ago but some are only now being enforced.

DOC.HEAD: School Van Crashes With Student at Wheel, One Killed
DOC.TEXT: A van carrying a college choir group and driven by a student overturned Thursday on Interstate 65, killing one student and critically injuring at least three others, police reported. Witnesses said the van, carrying 11 students from Olivet Nazarene University in Kankakee, Ill., was southbound on I-65 northwest of Indianapolis when it edged off the shoulder of the pavement. The driver apparently over-corrected and the van then entered the median, flipping over several times before coming to rest in the northbound lanes, witnesses said. The driver was an Olivet Nazarene student, said school spokesman Gordon Wickersham. Several students were thrown from the rear doors, which flew open. The student who was killed apparently suffered a head injury when he landed on the pavement. Most of the students landed on the grassy median, witnesses said. Three students were in critical condition at Home Hospital in Lafayette with head injuries, said hospital spokesman Mike Adler. Seven others were treated at St. Elizabeth Hospital, spokeswoman Joanne Willis said. She would not release their conditions. No charges had been filed. The driver, who was pinned in his seat for about 20 minutes before being freed, was wearing a seat belt. Two other students who also were wearing seat belts suffered minor injuries. Olivet Nazarene spokesman Gordon Wickersham said the students were members of the 63-student Orpheus Choir, which was on its way to Indianapolis for an appearance this weekend. ``They are all responsible students. I know every one of them,'' he said. The choir director, George Dunbar, and the 52 other students were passengers on a bus traveling in front of the van. Wickersham said the choir's appearance in Indianapolis was canceled.

DOC.HEAD: Marines, Sailors Honor Dead Crewmen
LaserPhotos DOD3, LaserColor DOD104
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: An honor guard fired a 21-gun salute and a lone bugler sounded taps at a memorial service Thursday honoring 10 U.S. sailors killed in a steam burst aboard the USS Iwo Jima. About 1,000 servicemen, including Marines in battle dress and sailors in dungarees, snapped to attention during the tribute. They stood motionless on deck, moving only to wipe away a tear or bow their heads during the 40-minute ceremony. A table set up on deck served as an altar, with a cross flanked by two candles. In front was an officer's cap, a seaman's round hat and a folded U.S. flag. ``The price of freedom is high,'' said Vice Adm. Henry H. Mauz Jr., commander of the U.S. Naval Forces Central Command. ``The standards we live by have never been more clear, and have been defined by our fallen shipmates. May God bless them and keep them.'' The sailors died following an accident Tuesday in the boiler room aboard the Iwo Jima, an assault ship that is a helicopter launching pad for a U.S. Marine force. The ship was leaving port at Bahrain when steam heated to 850 degrees burst through a pipe, Navy officials said. The cause of the accident is under investigation. Six of the crewmen died instantly, and four others died later aboard a hospital ship. Their bodies were shipped back to the United States for burial. Reporters and photographers were not allowed aboard ship for the memorial service, but they were briefed later and shown Navy videotapes. ``We lost 10 very good friends,'' said Petty Officer Robert Jones. ``It doesn't seem like any period of time can heal the wounds that were inflicted on us. ... I know for myself, when they died, a part of me died with them.'' Capt. Michael O'Hearn, a Vietnam veteran and the ship's commanding officer, delivered a eulogy and urged the crew members to honor their fallen mates with their work. ``Our resolution to go on and restore this ship and ourselves, so that we can restore our combat readiness, is within itself a tribute to our fallen shipmates,'' O'Hearn said. Chaplains read verses during the service, which included a taped version of the National Anthem and the singing of the Navy hymn. The boiler room accident brought to 43 the number of American deaths in Operation Desert Shield. More than 220,000 American troops have been deployed since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Before Tuesday's accident, the Navy had lost one sailor who was electrocuted in August aboard the cruiser USS Antietam. The Iwo Jima, whose home port is Norfolk, Va., has a crew of 685 and a complement of 1,100 Marines. A psychiatric team was sent to the Iwo Jima to help the crew deal with the emotional scars of the accident. The Navy has more than 50 ships deployed in the Middle East region. ``We know it's a dangerous job,'' said Master Chief Dan Titsworth, 42, who serves aboard the guided missile cruiser USS Biddle in the Red Sea. ``It's one of the things we live with.''

DOC.HEAD: Voters Could Restore Sweeping Shelter Measure For The Homeless
DOC.TEXT: Homeless advocates predict that District of Columbia voters on Tuesday will restore one of the nation's most comprehensive homeless shelter laws, which was gutted because of city budget woes. The city council, fighting a $100 million budget deficit, scaled back the 1984 law earlier this year amid complaints that housing the homeless has grown too expensive. Homeless advocates argue that costs have risen because city shelters are run inefficiently. The advocates gathered petition signatures from 43,000 voters to place a referendum on the ballot for Tuesday's election. It would reinstate the requirement to provide emergency overnight shelter to anyone who requests it. ``I think we're going to win, maybe by a small margin, but we are going to win,'' said Carol Fennelly of the Community for Creative Non-Violence. ``The people of this city still want the district to do the right thing.'' A poll in June showed support for such a ballot proposal at 71 percent. But an economic downturn has advocates worried that the referendum won't gain sweeping support. ``We live in a time right now where people feel a certain amount of economic instability themselves,'' Fennelly said. ``Even though some of these people may now realize they are one or two paychecks away from homelessness, the tendency may be to be conservative.'' Democratic mayoral nominee Sharon Pratt Dixon and Maurice Turner, her Republican counterpart, oppose the measure. Homeless advocates got a boost last week from a judge. A temporary restraining order now bars the district from distributing anti-initiative literature that had been printed with taxpayer money. ``That they have the audacity to print this material, and use tax dollars to defeat something that voters say they want, shows how the city feels about this,'' said Susie Sinclair-Smith, director of the Washington Legal Clinic for the Homeless. ``They have been trying to dismantle the program all along.'' The district government has wasted money by housing the homeless in expensive hotels, says Fennelly. Mayor Marion Barry showered lucrative overnight shelter contracts on friends and campaign contributors, Fennelly and the late Mitch Snyder have said.

DOC.HEAD: Police Minister Orders Changes After Temple Mount Shootings
DOC.TEXT: The head f Israeli police said Thursday the force will be reorganized following last month's killing of 20 Palestinian protesters at Jerusalem's Temple Mount. Police Minister Roni Milo would not say whether he would fire senior officers. Few other details about the plan were immediately available. Near Tel Aviv, a Palestinian stabbed his former Israeli employer 10 times. It was the latest incident of violence between Jews and Palestinians since the Oct. 8 Temple Mount shootings. A three-member commission appointed by Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir concluded police shot in self-defense, but criticized senior commanders for ignoring advance warnings of the trouble. A statement from Milo's office said the changes were drafted ``after studying the ... committee report, its decisions and recommendations.'' Israel Army Radio said the reorganization will take effect in about two months. Under the changes, Israeli media said Jerusalem would become a separate police district, rather than being part of the Southern District. The other districts include Tel Aviv, Central and Northern. The reports said Milo would not fire senior commanders, but delay promotions or urge early retirement. There are between 16,000 and 17,000 police officers in Israel, including paramilitary border police, said police spokeswoman Ruth Shlezinger. Following the stabbing attack, police arrested 20-year-old Ahmed Hamad Azufi from Gaza's Rafah refugee camp at an army roadblock in Gaza. The victim, workshop owner Shlomo Shtezi, was in stable condition at Wolfson Hospital near Tel Aviv late Thursday. Police also rounded up about 200 Arabs working in Rishon Lezion factories after the stabbings. Police said the assailant slept overnight in the workshop in Rishon Lezion near Tel Aviv, where he had been employed for a short period until three weeks ago. ``The assailant fled, leaving his shoes behind. The victim managed to get to a phone to call his wife, even though he dripped blood throughout the factory,'' district police commander Hezi Ledder told Israel television. Ledder said Shtezi was stabbed after a work-related discussion, but denied this was the reason for the attack. Police spokesman Eli Maimon said investigators classified the stabbing as a ``nationalist crime'' related to the Palestinian uprising. Since the Temple Mount incident, three Israelis and two Arabs have been killed in attacks. Also Thursday, Israeli warplanes blasted guerrilla targets in Lebanon's Bekaa Valley. It was the 16th such attack of the year. The army did not identify the targets, but Israel army radio said a 1989 raid in the same village struck a base operated by the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command headed by Ahmed Jibril. In other developments Thursday: -The army said 24-year-old Mohammed Rashad Jerusi from the West Bank refugee camp of Tulkarem died after being shot by troops in clashes Wednesday. His death brought to 770 the number of Palestinians killed by Israelis during the 34-month uprising. Another 293 Palestinians were slain by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of helping Israel. Fifty-one Israelis have also died in the violence. -Flight information monitors broke down at Israel's international airport and more telephones went unrepaired as a strike by 120,000 government technicians entered a third day. -Officials reported that 21,744 Soviet Jews arrived in Israel in October, setting a record in the current Soviet immigration wave.

DOC.HEAD: House Republicans Contend Lawmakers Got a Tax Cut
DOC.TEXT: House Republicans trying to capitalize on anti-Congress feelings across America unveiled a television spot Thursday accusing lawmakers of voting themselves a tax cut in the just-completed budget deal. The problem is, it's not true. Like as many as 4 million other Americans whose incomes are in the range of $100,000 to $200,000, members of Congress will see their top tax rate drop from 33 percent to 31 percent. But also included in the package was an increase in the tax those same people would pay to support Medicare, more than wiping out the income tax cut. In addition, taxpayers in that bracket would lose some or all personal exemptions and some itemized deductions. One analysis by the Senate Budget Committee found a typical married member of Congress with two children would pay 3.8 percent more in total federal taxes under the new law. House members are paid $96,600 a year, but their salaries will increase to $124,424 next year. The GOP television spot, which will run nationally on Cable News Network this weekend and on local channels in three targeted congressional districts, contends ``the average congressman will have their income taxes cut by $3,500.'' ``Most Democrats voted to raise their taxes and cut their own,'' the ad contends. ``Most Republicans voted against the tax increase and against the tax cut for congressmen.'' Rep. Guy Vander Jagt, R-Mich., chairman of the GOP House campaign committee, said he hopes the attack on Congress will hurt Democratic incumbents in Tuesday's elections. The TV spot does not mention that President Bush, who is stumping for GOP candidates, was instrumental in engineering the tax package, or that it is part of an effort to cut the nation's out-of-control deficit by $496 billion over the next five years. The three districts where the GOP is paying to run the spot locally are the Second District in Utah, where Democratic incumbent Wayne Owens is in a tight re-election race; Cincinnati's First District, where Democratic incumbent Rep. Thomas Luken is retiring to make way for his son, Mayor Charles Luken, who faces a dead-heat race with former Mayor Ken Blackwell; and the Illinois 16th, a GOP district being vacated by Republican Rep. Lynn Martin.

DOC.HEAD: Way of Life at Stake for Pressman in Daily News Strike
DOC.TEXT: Patrick Loughlin's father was a Teamster who taught him early in life that a decent living depends on a high school diploma or a union card. Loughlin opted for the latter when he was a teen-ager whose family needed money. He joined the Newspaper Pressmen's Union, one of nine unions striking the Daily News. ``I would have a job for life, I figured,'' Loughlin said. Since 1947, Loughlin, 61, has worked for three newspapers that folded. He's hoping the Daily News, which is mired in a strike, doesn't become the fourth. ``I've always made a good living,'' Loughlin said Wednesday. ``I went into the service, came back and I had a job waiting for me. My seniority was protected, everything was protected through the auspices of my union and their agreements with management,'' he said. As the strike against the News marks its first week, Loughlin doubts whether the nine unions on picket lines can reach new agreements with the newspaper. ``It's as if they're saying to you: `All the things you've done and all the things you've gotten over the years are no longer there. So start from Page 1 again,' '' Loughlin said. Loughlin, married and the father of two daughters, said he got his union permit for his 18th birthday. ``I paid $3 a month to the union and that guaranteed me some kind of standing on the line,'' Loughlin said. ``You would show up and state to the foreman that you were available and they would put you on a list. And if there was work - and there was at that time - they put you to work.'' He got his junior pressmen's card while he was in the military, serving in Korea. In 1960, he became a journeyman pressman. The job wasn't glamorous. ``You work nights. You work Saturday and Sunday. And you had to wait a long while to get different days off, vacations,'' Loughlin said. It was dirty. ``You have to be willing and able to get covered head to foot with ink mist and paper dust and oil spinning off the presses.'' And it was loud. ``In the middle of that room, with all those presses running, it's like standing at 42nd Street in the subway with all the express trains going through without stopping, continuously.'' The union made it bearable by winning decent wages, hours and benefits for its members and their families, Loughlin said. Loughlin said he plans to retire next year. Because of his seniority, he expects he'll find enough work until then, even if the News shuts down. But the prospects of younger pressmen aren't as good, he said. ``Some people will get some work at the New York Times and the Post,'' he says. ``The majority of them ... I don't know what they're going to do. Many of them will lose their homes, their plans for their children's education will have to be changed.'' Local 2 of the pressmen's union has dropped from more than 3,000 members in the mid-1960s to about 900 members now as newspapers closed and others automated. If the News closes, another 400 members will be out of work. Loughlin said he will stick with the strike to the end. He's not very optimistic about how it will end. ``I don't see too much future,'' he said. ``I know we're in for hard times, no matter what happens.''

DOC.HEAD: Bank Of Finland Halts Soviet Trade Following Ruble Devaluation
With AM-Soviet-Ruble, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Bank of Finland halted trade with the Soviet Union on Thursday because of confusion over exchange rates set by the Soviets, the central bank announced. The bank did not publish its usual quotation for the ruble and the Finnish mark, meaning there was no official basis on which to exchange the two currencies. ``To put it mildly, we are somewhat unsure of what is going on,'' said Kari Holopainen, director of Soviet trade at the Bank of Finland. On Thursday, the Soviets adopted a new exchange rate for commercial transactions that is nearly 70 percent lower than the official rate. The move was designed to make Soviet exports more competitive while discouraging imports. Holopainen said central bank officials were not informed by the Soviets which of three ruble exchange rates now in effect applied to the ``clearing ruble'' used in Finnish-Soviet trade. ``In any case, we have stopped all payments in the clearing-house trade with the Soviet Union for the time being,'' he said. Under arrangements dating to World War II, three-quarters of Finnish-Soviet trade is conducted by barter through a clearing house, with cash accounts used to smooth out inequitis. Although barter with the Soviet Union represents only 11 percent of Finnish total foreign trade, 90 percent of Finland's oil comes from Soviet sources. Central bank officials said they believed it was the first time since the war that trade between the two countries was stopped. Finnish-Soviet trade totaled 16.7 billion marks, or $4.6 billion, in the first nine months this year, Holopainen said. The currencies had been exchanged recently at rates near 6.5 marks to one ruble. Earlier this year, officials announced the two countries would scrap their barter arrangement and conduct trade on a conventional basis. The Soviet Union trades mostly raw materials for Finnish industrial and wood products. The barter system has already been eroded by trade with exchangeable currencies. Finnish-Soviet barters accounted for 26 percent of Finland's foreign trade in the early 1980s, compared with the present 11 percent level. Finnish officials said recently the Soviet Union owed Finland about $1.9 billion in exchangeable currencies.

DOC.HEAD: Two Executed, Five Sentenced to Death for Murder, Rape, Robbery
DOC.TEXT: Two men have been executed in Shanghai and five others sentenced to death for murder, rape and armed robbery, an official newspaper reported. Convicted murderer Wang Weiqian and armed robber Tang Shuigen were executed Tuesday, Shanghai's Wenhui Daily reported in its Wednesday issue. The report, seen Thursday in Beijing, did not give any other details about the executed men. Executions in China are by a single bullet to the back of the head and are usually carried out shortly after sentencing. The Shanghai Intermediate People's Court sentenced to death Tie Huaqing, a factory worker, and Yang Renjie, unemployed, the paper said. The two killed a man, taking his gold ring, gold bracelet, a large sum of Chinese and Hong Kong currency and other items worth thousands of dollars, it added. Also sentenced to death, it said, were Yan Tinggui, a sales clerk, for five armed robberies and two rapes; Jin Shijian, who raped two women; and Sha Zhide, unemployed, who killed a nurse and set her home on fire. According to official reports, nearly 800 people have been sentenced to death so far this year as part of an anti-crime campaign begun in May.

DOC.HEAD: Mrs Mandela Fined After Pleading Guilty to Work Insurance Claim
DOC.TEXT: Winnie Mandela, wife of ANC leader Nelson Mandela, was fined $80 on Thursday after pleading guilty to failing to pay unemployment insurance for workers at her fish-and-chips shop. Charges were filed after Mrs. Mandela failed to pay contributions to the unemployment insurance fund from January to August. Mrs. Mandela's attorney, Ismail Ayob, produced a receipt in court Thursday showing the insurance had since been paid. A warrant for Mrs. Mandela's arrest in connection with the case was issued last month after she missed an Oct. 25 court appearance. Ayob told the magistrate the summons was served at the fish-and-chips shop but that Mrs. Mandela had not been there for some time and never received it. The magistrate accepted the explanation. Mrs. Mandela is scheduled for trial in February on kidnapping and assault charges involving the abduction and beating of four young men in December 1988. One of the four was found dead. Mrs. Mandela has denied wrongdoing.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Plans Eight Press Pools if Hostilities Begin
erjbjj
DOC.TEXT: The military plans to form eight press pools of six journalists each if combat begins in the Persian Gulf, the Pentagon's chief spokesman said Thursday. ``In the event of hostilities, if they occur, we have a plan in place which we are continually refining,'' Pete Williams said. Williams, the assistant secretary of defense for public affairs, launched the Pentagon's national press pool four days after President Bush committed troops to Saudi Arabia in August. The pool was disbanded about three weeks later after Saudi officials began to allow more journalists into the country. During military operations, a press pool is a representative band of reporters who are escorted to a military area and then return to share information with reporters left behind at a press center. As many as 400 foreign journalists have been in Saudi Arabia to cover the U.S.-led military buildup since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. There are about 180 journalists in the country now, Williams said. Two-thirds of them are from the United States. President Bush increased his verbal attacks on Iraqi president Saddam Hussein this week. The president's spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said Bush is trying ``to prepare the American people for any eventuality.'' ``We will not rule out the military option,'' Fitzwater said in Washington Thursday. Williams said the leaders of Operation Desert Shield may begin testing how quickly press pools can be mobilized in Saudi Arabia. During the tests, reporters would be trained to use equipment that protects them from chemical weapons, which Iraq has stockpiled, he said. ``We think it's essential if we take pools out that we give them chem gear, flak jackets and helmets,'' Williams said. He outlined the pool plans to conferees attending the Associated Press Managing Editors convention. Williams made his comments during a panel discussion of the pool operations. Also participating were John King, a Washington-based reporter for the Associated Press, and Kevin Merida, assistant managing editor of The Dallas Morning News. King was in the pool that went to Saudi Arabia in August. Merida was in the pool that covered the Panamanian invasion in December.

DOC.HEAD: Americans Get Tips on Sending Goodies to Troops in Mideast
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Agriculture Department is offering tips on a toll-free hotline about sending home-cooked food and other goodies to the troops in the Mideast. ``The most important thing to remember is don't send foods that are perishable or can't tolerate rought handling,'' hotline supervisor Sue Templin said Thursday. Temperatures in Saudi Arabia are cooling somewhat, with daily averages of 78 degrees Fahrenheit in November and 70 degrees in December, but potential food spoilage is always a problem, she said. Hotline home economists worked with USDA food scientists, the military and the U.S. Postal Service on a list of things to do and not do. Most importantly, don't send fresh meat. ``Stick to dry beef, like beef jerky or beef slims,'' she said. ``Canned meats, including chicken and tuna are okay, but high temperatures may reduce quality.'' Templin said it would be a good idea for families to remind troops not to eat foods that arrive in damaged or swollen cans. That often is a sign of food poisoning organisms. Also, don't send high-moisture baked goods, such as pumpkin bread, because those are susceptible to mold. Pork and pork products, along with alcohol, are taboo in Saudia Arabia for religious reasons. Fragile good such as delicate cookies won't survive the trip intact. And products containing chocolate can melt in high temperatures. Foods recommended by hotline people include dense and dry baked goods, such as fruit cakes, commercially packaged cakes and cookies in tins, dry cookies like ginger snaps, and crackers. Others on the send list, include: raisins, apricots and other dried fruits, along with canned nuts and fruit, and commercially prepared trail mix. Jams, jelly and peanut butter packed in jars also can be included, along with hard candies and candy-coated gum. Specialty items like instant soup, fruit drink mixes and commercially packaged popcorn in tins are others. ``Some regional favorites like Texas hot sauce and Cajun seasonings are being sent to troops, and that's a great idea, as long as they aren't perishable and can handle transport and heat,'' Templin said. For more advice on shipping food and other food safety issued, the USDA hotline is available at 1-800-535-4555 weekdays from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Eastern time. Residents in the Washington, D.C., area should call 202 447-3333.

DOC.HEAD: Youths Yell `Trick or Treat' Before Fatal Attack on Homeless
DOC.TEXT: A dozen youths, some wearing Halloween masks, screamed ``trick or treat'' before attacking a homeless settlement with bats, pipes, knives and meat cleavers, killing one man, police said Thursday. Nine people were injured. ``Why did they do it? It was Halloween,'' said a policeman close to the case who would only speak on condition of anonymity. ``Last night, things just got out of hand.'' A 35-year-old homeless man, whose name was not released while police searched for relatives to notify, had his throat slashed and was pronounced dead at the scene, said a police spokeswoman, Officer Janice Swinney. The wooded area where the attack occurred ``looked like a horror movie, it was in the dark, down a little path,'' the police source said. The gang, which police said consisted of 10 to 12 people, crossed a footbridge at 102nd Street in Manhattan into Ward's Island on Halloween night. Ward's Island is home to the Fire Department training academy, several psychiatric hospitals and a sewage disposal plant. It lies beneath the Triborough Bridge in the East River. ``They went armed with meat cleavers, bats with nails in them, and pipes. They were going to do serious damage,'' the source said. The gang walked to the homeless settlement, where at least one of the gang members screamed out ``trick or treat,'' followed by a epithet, before the group began attacking the homeless men, the source said. ``There was no rhyme or reason to it, other than out and out violence,'' he added. The gang also robbed two or three of the homeless men of about $10 to $15 in pay they had received for performing minor chores. ``It was a mixture of payday and Halloween,'' the source said. ``Gettin' paid'' or ``payday'' is a street term used by roving gangs who rob people. The gang escaped after the attack. Five of the injured homeless were treated at a hospital and released. Three others were treated by police at a precinct house, and another man was listed as stable at Harlem Hospital after he was beaten about the face with a baseball bat.

Williams, assistant secretary of defense for public affairs, launched the Pentagon's national press pool four days after President Bush committed troops to Saudi Arabia in August. The pool was disbanded about three weeks later after Saudi officials began to allow more journalists into the country. During foreign military operations, a press pool is a representative group of reporters who are escorted to a military area and then return to share information with reporters left behind at a press center or with the rest of the media back in the United States. As many as 400 foreign journalists have been in Saudi Arabia to cover the U.S.-led military buildup since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. About 180 journalists are in the country now, Williams said, two-thirds of them from the United States. Bush stepped up his verbal attacks on Iraqi President Saddam Hussein this week. The president's spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said Bush is trying ``to prepare the American people for any eventuality.'' ``We will not rule out the military option,'' Fitzwater said in Washington Thursday. Williams made his comments during a panel discussion on pool operations. Also participating were John King, a Washington-based AP reporter, and Kevin Merida, assistant managing editor of The Dallas Morning News. King was in the pool that went to Saudi Arabia in August. DOC.HEAD: Rwanda's Government Claims Victory Over Invading Rebels
DOC.TEXT: The central African country of Rwanda claimed victory Thursday, saying loyalist troops had defeated rebels who invaded from Uganda a month ago. The announcement created overnight street celebrations in Rwanda as army troops started returning to the capital, Kigali, according to state radio and a Western diplomat. ``The armed struggle is over with Rwandan forces being victorious against the rebels,'' the government said in a nationwide broadcast. ``Citizens applauded the Rwandan soldiers all the way from Kagitumba to Kigali.'' Kagitumba is the border post through which the rebels, predominantly members of Rwanda's minority Tutsi tribe, invaded from Uganda Sept. 30. The rebel Rwandese Patriotic Front accused President Juvenal Habyarimana's single-party government of corruption and say they want to replace it with a democracy. The broadcast said the Rwandan forces had waged a 36-hour offensive Monday and Tuesday to retake Kagitumba. The insurgents emerged from a 250,000-strong population of Rwandan refugees in Uganda. They were among hundreds of thousands of Tutsis who fled Rwanda when the majority Hutu seized control in the late 1950s and early 1960s in a bloody power struggle. Reporters were taken to the border area of Gitumba on Wednesday to witness what the radio described as Rwandan troops ``ejecting the nation's enemies.'' The broadcast quoted civilians who said the rebels had retreated to Uganda, taking livestock and at least one young Rwandan girl. Uganda's President Yoweri Museveni, who has condemned the invasion waged primarily by Ugandan army deserters, repeatedly has said his nation's borders were closed to the insurgents and that he would arrest any who tried to return. ``Museveni is a man of his word and he said if the rebels return to Uganda he will put them in jail,'' said the Western diplomat. ``What we don't know is whether the Ugandan government has arrested them.'' There also were reports rebels could be hiding in Rwanda's Kagera National park, which borders Uganda and Tanzania to the east. ``What we know is that the face-to-face war is over. There is no rebel army,'' said the diplomat. Talks reportedly had been taking place between Rwanda's government and the rebels in Zaire under the mediation of President Mobutu Sese Seko. ``If there is no rebel army, what are they talking about?'' the diplomat said. The rebels reportedly were led by a former Ugandan deputy army commander, Maj. Gen. Fred Rwigyema, a Tutsi of Rwandan origin.

DOC.HEAD: Coast Guard: Refugees Say 10 Thrown From Boat
DOC.TEXT: Haitian refugees jammed into an overloaded sailboat told rescuers that 10 passengers were thrown overboard before a patrol found the survivors Thursday, a U.S. Coast Guard spokesman said. The Haitians were battling each other when the cutter Northland pulled alongside about 6 a.m. just 20 miles north of Haiti, said Lt. Cmdr. Jeff Karonis. ``They were fighting not with us, but among themselves,'' said Karonis, who added it was not immediately known what sparked the fighting or the alleged drownings. Ninety-four people were packed into the 45-foot boat, and examinations showed many had cuts, bruises and broken bones. They also suffered from exhaustion and malnutrition. The refugees told interviewers that several healthy people, none wearing life jackets, had been thrown off the boat about six days previously. Four nights later, some sick and dying passengers were reportedly tossed overboard as well. The Haitians supplied the names of their missing boatmates and the people who allegedly threw them into the ocean, but Karonis said the Coast Guard could not independently confirm the drownings. ``We don't have any way of proving it,'' he said. ``But there have been other incidents.'' Up to 60 Haitians were thrown from a boat on its way to the United States in one 1985 incident, and up to 100 people were drowned in another, according to in investigation by the U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service. All the Haitians intercepted Thursday will be brought back to Port-au-Prince on Friday, Karonis said. Reports on the case have been turned over to the U.S. Embassy in Haiti, he added. He said he did not know if or when the alleged culprits would be arrested, but said none were taken into custody aboard the Northland.

DOC.HEAD: Commission Says No Evidence That Speculators Causing High Oil Prices
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Commodities Futures Trading Commission said Thursday that, contrary to White House assertions, there is no evidence speculators are responsible for the recent escalation and volatility of oil prices. Commission officials told the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee that producers, refiners and end users such as airlines account for 85 to 90 percent of the trading in crude oil futures on the New York Mercantile Exchange since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. ``If anything, it (speculation) has been at an unusually low level,'' said Commissioner William P. Albrecht. ``Speculative ... activity in these markets has actually fallen from pre-invasion levels in terms of market share.'' Albrecht said a review of daily trading between July 30 and Oct. 9, when prices peaked at $40.42 a barrel, shows that cash market prices for oil equalled or exceeded increases in prices on the futures market. Meanwhile, he said, oil prices have risen more in foreign markets than they have in the United States. For example, while the price of West Texas Intermediate exactly doubled on both the cash market and the Merc, prices for North Sea oil on the London market increased 115 percent. Claiming there is no shortage of oil, the Bush administration has repeatedly blamed speculators in the futures markets for the spiraling prices since the embargo against Iraq and Kuwait cut off 4.3 million barrels per day - or about 8 percent - of the world's supply. ``Frankly, there just is no way to justify price increases from $24 to $39 a barrel ... except through speculation of futures buying,'' White House Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater said in September. However, Albrecht, citing Energy Department figures, said the high prices reflect a daily shortfall in world production of 3.4 million barrels a day in September and 1.1 million barrels in October despite increased production by Saudi Arabia and other exporting countries. The Energy Department predicts that a daily shortfall of at least 350,000 barrels will continue through December. ``More recently,'' he said, ``concerns about the possibility of military hostilities and the effect this might have on oil production facilities and the future supplies of oil seem to have been the primary factor underlying rising and falling prices.'' For example, prices fell by more than $5 a barrel on Oct. 22 when newspapers carried reports that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein had a dream about settling the controversy. And they jumped $1.83 a barrel Wednesday upon President Bush's claim that Iraq was starving U.S. hostages and that he's ``had it'' with Saddam. ``Energy industry participants, particularly refiners, do not want to risk being caught short of oil in the event of further supply disruptions resulting from hostilities in the Persian Gulf,'' said Albrecht. ``Consequently,'' he said, ``their ... buying activity has bid up the prices of near-term oil. We have observed no excessive or suspicious concentrations of trading or positions. Nor have we found evidence of threatened or actual manipulations.'' Private analysts, meanwhile, repeated their assertions that Bush's reluctance to tap the Strategic Petroleum Reserve early in the crisis is responsible for oil prices going above $25 a barrel. ``The high prices are attributable to the failure of government energy policy, not organized commodity markets,'' Philip Verleger, an oil market analyst with the Institute of International Economics, told the committee. Bush could have saved the world's consumers about $40 billion by pumping 500,000 barrels of oil a day from the emergency government stockpile into the market in August and September, Verleger said.

DOC.TEXT: Asked about Saddam's offer to permit families of the hostages to visit thekm during Thanksgiving and Christmas, Bush said, ``I see it as a ploy,'' and said the visits should take home in the United States after the hostages are freed. ``I don't think he'll win the humanitarian of the year award for that,'' he said, reiterating government advice that Americans not travel into Iraq or occupied Kuwait. Bush said he was speaking out so forcefully about the Persian Gulf so the American people would know where he stood after a month in which attention was diverted to budget deliberations with Congress. ``They must know how strongly I feel'' about the hostages and the treatment of the American diplomats who have been holed up in the U.S. Embassy for several weeks, he said. Earlier, White House spokesman Fitzwater said the recent switch in emphasis had ``nothing to do'' with political motives or the beating Bush had taken in public opinion over the recently concluded budget battle with Congress. DOC.HEAD: Agriculture Department Forecasts World Cocoa Bean Production
DOC.TEXT: Global production of cocoa beans in the 1990-91 marketing year is forecast at 2.39 million metric tons, about the same as last season, the Agriculture Department said Thursday. The department's Foreign Agricultural Service said that would be about 3 percent below the record 1988-89 harvest of 2.47 million tons. ``Larger crops are expected for Brazil, Malaysia and Indonesia, while most West African producers are anticipating smaller outturns because of less favorable growing conditions,'' the agency said in its report. Production in the Dominican Republic is also expected to be down, following a bumper 1989-90 harvest. ``Low world cocoa prices are discouraging most growers from making new plantings and providing adequate cultural practices to existing trees,'' the report said. ``However, world production still remains at high levels, as a significant number of young trees are reaching their maximum bearing age in the Cote d'Ivoire and Malaysia, in addition to new plantings coming into bearing in Indonesia.'' World inventories of cocoa probably will be close to a record 1.5 million tons by the end of the 1990-91 marketing year next Sept. 30, the report said.

DOC.HEAD: By-Election Watched for Attitudes Toward Gulf, Prime Minister
DOC.TEXT: A parliamentary by-election is being closely watched for signs of voter attitudes toward Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu's leadership and his proposal to send Japanese soldiers abroad for the first time since World War II. Kaifu, who has never had a strong power base in the governing Liberal Democratic Party, has been on shakier ground in recent weeks because of parliamentry opposition to his plan to send troops to the Persian Gulf. The proposal, known as the U.N. Peace Cooperation bill, would permit dispatching members of Japan's Self-Defense Forces for non-combat roles only. The Socialist Party, Japan's leading opposition group, is seeking to make the dispute a central issue in Sunday's election of a legislator to Japan's upper house of Parliament. The election is in Aichi in central Japan, Kaifu's home base. ``A loss in his own prefecture would undoubtedly cast a shadow of questions on his leadership and harm his image,'' said Toshihiko Kurachi, secretary general of the Liberal Democratic Party in Aichi. Kaifu was chosen last summer to head the party and become prime minister when senior party leaders with stronger backing were under a cloud because of money and sex scandals. His clean image and oratorical skills helped him win popular support, and his party won lower house elections in February. But senior party leaders also viewed those elections as giving them a clean slate, and Kaifu's public support has eroded amid the troop controversy. Japan's post-World War II constitution bans the use of force to settle international disputes. The opposition parties, which control the upper house, insist this rules out sending Japanese troops abroad. Kaifu does not have solid support on the question even within his own party. Kaifu proposed sending troops in September after international criticism of Japan's failure to provide more than financial backing to the U.S.-led international force arrayed against Iraq in the gulf. Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Socialist Party spokesman Osamu Yamaguchi said the group was urging Aichi voters ``to show what the nation thinks about dispatching the Self-Defense Forces.'' Takeshi Kataoka, a lower house legislator from Aichi who is a member of the governing party, said his constituency's overwhelming opposition to sending troops to the gulf would not necessarily be reflected in a vote against the party. ``People know the law is not going to lead to the draft as the opposition claims,'' Kataoka said. The Chunichi Shimbun, a newspaper in Aichi's major city of Nagoya, said that a voters' poll showed 63.9 percent of respondents oppose sending troops. The poll also indicated much lower voter interest in Sunday's election than in nationwide upper house elections last year, when an unpopular sales tax and scandals affecting the governing party helped the opposition win control of the house. As a result, it is unlikely that Kaifu's government can win passage of the bill to send troops before the current session ends on Nov. 10. The national newspaper Asahi Shimbun said a poll of 396 of the 511 lower house members showed 223 opposed as long as the bill provides for sending troops abroad. A majority in the poll, however, favored other steps to assist in Middle East peace efforts, such as financial backing or help for refugees, the Asahi said.Japan already has pledged $4 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Fisher-Price Recalls Risky Carriage Strollers
DOC.TEXT: Fisher-Price is recalling about 60,000 of its Carriage Strollers, Model No. 9121, because they have been known to collapse with children in them, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said Thursday. In some cases, the side tubes don't slide properly when the stroller unfolds. This can prevent the locking mechanism from engaging fully, leading the strollers to collapse. Fisher-Price said it is aware of 23 injuries to children using the strollers, ranging from bumps and bruises to one broken arm. The strollers have been sold nationwide since June 1989, for about $120 to $140. Consumers who own this stroller should call Fisher-Price, toll-free, at 1-800-527-1034 between 8 a.m. and 5 p.m. daily, in most time zones. However, consumers in Alaska and Hawaii should call between 8 a.m. and 5 p.m. Pacific Time.) Fisher-Price will send consumers a prepaid mailing package with instructions to return a wheel from their stroller. Those who return a wheel will receive a new Carriage Stroller free of charge. The new stoller will be modified to assure the locking mechanism will engage fully. Consumers should not return strollers to the store where it was purchased. Fisher-Price, of East Aurora, N.Y., is no longer manufacturing or selling this product.

DOC.HEAD: Peru's Government Launches First Birth Control Program
DOC.TEXT: Peru's government began distributing free and subsidized birth control pills and condoms on Thursday, marking a new era in this overwhelmingly Roman Catholic nation. Since it was announced on Oct. 23 by President Alberto Fujimori, the birth control program has been harshly criticized by the Catholic Church. Fujimori has strongly defended the plan. ``There is nothing terrible in not wanting more children eating trash in the streets,'' Fujimori said in a speech on Wednesday. He said the program was part of his government's efforts to ``combat the principal elements that generate unemployment, poverty and hunger.'' Press reaction to the plan has been largely positive. ``Fujimori's birth control proposition may soon become a national consensus,'' said an editorial in the magazine Caretas. Once a virtually taboo subject, birth control in the past week has become the national rage. Newspapers publish guides to devices and methods. Radio talk shows have become moral battlegrounds. Condoms are now a staple of political cartoons. Pills and condoms have been available for years in private pharmacies. But public discussion of birth control has been minimal and sex education programs are almost non-existent. A Health Ministry spokesman confirmed Thursday that the devices were being distributed by clinics throughout Peru. Health Minister Carlos Vidal Layseca, dubbed the ``minister of condoms'' by the press, said last week the $1.2 million program is supported by the United Nations. In five years, the government hopes to raise the percentage of Peruvian women who understand birth control methods from 28 percent of the population to 45 percent, he said. The fight marks the second time the Church has strongly criticized Fujimori. Fujimori's political party is largely composed of members of Peru's small evangelical sects, and the Catholic Church launched numerous attacks on the president in the weeks before he was elected June 10. About 95 percent of Peruvians are Catholic, although Peru has no official religion. The birth control battle has become largely a debate over how to eliminate poverty in Peru, where over half the population of 22 million is poor. The country is suffering from its worst economic crisis this century. In announcing the plan, Fujimori said there was ``still time'' to avoid a population explosion in the country. But Peruvians ``must take corrective measures, planning without fears or taboos,'' he said. He said his birth control program would cut annual population growth from 650,000 people to 360,000 within 10 years. ``It's very strange the government is worrying about children who have yet to be born and not about those who were already born and who are dying because of poverty and sickness,'' Monsignor Luis Bambaren said after the plan was announced. Monsignor Ricardo Durand Flores, president of the Peruvian Episcopal Conference, said birth control would lead to more ``sexual excess, sexual licentiousness.'' This in turn would lead to the use of abortion ``as a means of birth control,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Legislative Leaders Turn Up Heat Over Revolution Day
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with new poll showing most oppose the event. Picks up 9th pvs, `The resolution...'
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's allies in the national legislature warned opposition groups Thursday against holding counter-demonstrations on Revolution Day in Red Square. ``We should be careful not to let this holiday be darkened by conflicts or clashes,'' Anatoly Lukyanov, speaker of the national Supreme Soviet, warned in an interview on the nightly newscast Vremya. The resolution by the legislature's presidium, run by Lukyanov, was not a formal ban on counter protests. But it increased the pressure on an opposition coalition that called this week for an ``alternative'' rally Nov. 7 to protest the official parade. The call led to speculation of clashes with police. The parades celebrate communism and the ascent of the Bolsheviks, now called Communists, in 1917. They were turned into rolling displays of weaponry by Josef Stalin and traditionally also include a ``people's demonstration'' of the city's residents. While the official ideology has fallen from its sacred position in recent years, the parades carry great weight in the country as a symbol of Communist authority. The liberal mayors of Moscow and Leningrad last month called for a boycott of the parades. Many of the 15 republics, including the secessionist Baltic states and restive Caucasus republics, voted to ban parades in their capital cities. However, Gorbachev last month issued a presidential decree ordering the parades to be held in most major cities across the country, and the national Supreme Soviet approved a special resolution echoing his order. The state-run press has quoted generals as saying they planned to cary out Gorbachev's order in their cities, and Moscow's Communist Party leaders also promised to hold the traditional parade. A poll published Thursday night indicated most Muscovites were against the celebration. A survey of 2,222 people in Moscow from Oct. 27-28 by the independent All-Union Center for Public Opinion found 29 percent supported the parade but 56 percent were against it, according to the independent news agency Interfax. The rest said they were unsure. The poll, which gave no margin of error, said elderly people and people without college educations were more likely than younger people and college graduates to support the parade as a celebration of the revolution, Interfax said. The resolution Thursday urged the opposition to hold its counter-demonstration on any day other than Nov. 7-8, the official dates of the anniversary. Soviets should ``celebrate the major state holiday in an atmosphere of calm, consolidation and cooperation between all public forces in the country,'' the resolution said, according to the official news agency Tass. Lukyanov, in an apparent effort to de-emphasize the communist aspect of the parade, added in the television interview: ``They ought to let this celebration be held as a holiday for national consolidation.'' Gorbachev, speaking to a group of students Thursday in the Kremlin, also called the holiday a ``global event'' and said he thought most of the country would celebrate the anniversary, Tass reported. However, plans for the parades were being assailed from all sides. The Ukrainian pro-independence group Rukh said Thursday it planned an anti-Communist protest next Wednesday. A leader of the Russian nationalist organization Pamyat said Thursday his group would not mark the anniversary of a revolution that ``has led to a complete disintegration of the great state and to the murder of our legitimate Monarch,'' according to the independent Postfactum news agency. On May Day this year, another major Soviet celebration, tens of thousands of people marched in a mass counter-demonstration passed through Red Square, many jeering Gorbachev and shouting ``Resign!'' He withstood the catcalls for 20 minutes before leaving the reviewing stand.

DOC.HEAD: Survey: Public Health Programs Lagging Behind Recommendations
DOC.TEXT: Compliance with recommendations to the states on how to improve public health is lagging, a survey released Thursday showed. The survey of health officials from all 50 states was conducted to determine how well they are implementing recommendations from the Institute of Medicine, a government advisory group on public health. The officials were in near unanimous agreement with many of 25 proposals they were asked about, but fewer than half had implemented the recommendations, the federal Centers for Disease Control said in a report on the survey, conducted by an organization of state health officials. For example, 48 of 50 state health departments agreed their agencies should ``link with mental health services to improve the integration of service delivery.'' Only 13 had implemented such a plan. Eighteen said they planned to do so. All 50 state agencies agreed the public should be better educated on community health needs and policy issues, but only 34 had a program in place to achieve that goal. Forty-five of the agencies surveyed agreed they should develop comprehensive strategies to influence health-related behavior, but only 21 had implemented a plan. A recommendation that state health departments should be concerned with the public's exposure to toxins won unanimous agreement from the agencies. Only 33 had implemented a plan. The Institute of Medicine said it made the recommendations because shortcomings in the nation's public health system, including inadequate resources and weak leadership, limited availability of effective preventive health services in the United States. Dr. Arthur Liang, a CDC epidemiologist who wrote the agency's report on the survy, said implementation has been slow in part because of a lack of government money. ``Some of it may be that we as a nation haven't come to grips with what we expect of public health,'' he said. The recommendations were made in 1988. The survey was conducted in 1989 by the Association of State and Territorial Health Officials. The CDC said legislation has been proposed to increase financial support to state and local health agencies to help them achieve public health objectives by the year 2000. Implementation of the recommendations wasn't so bleak in some areas. For instance, 49 state health departments agreed that food protection is a job for the agencies and 48 had such programs in place.

DOC.HEAD: Many School Children Drink lead-Contaminated Water
DOC.TEXT: Despite laws aimed at reducing lead in drinking water, federal investigators believe hundreds of thousands of children continue to drink lead-contaminated water at school. An internal report by the Environmental Protection Agency said that states have failed to enforce requirements that schools test drinking water for lead and that the EPA has not provided adequate guidance on what water coolers pose a health risk. Lead is a powerful poison. Even traces can be particularly harmful to children because it can hurt development of the brain and nervous system. Children under 7 are considered to be particularly vulnerable. Auditors in the EPA's inspector general's office estimated that, based on a limited survey, fewer than half of the school districts in the country may be testing thoroughly. An examination of 13 school districts in the mid-Atlantic region revealed that three had not tested for lead while most of the others conducted inadequate tests. ``Our findings confirm that harmful amounts of lead exist in the drinking water provided by schools. Both the EPA and the states must be more aggressive in eliminating the health hazard imposed by lead in drinking water,'' said the report from the inspector general's office, made available by the agency Thursday. The investigation was concluded last April with the report completed in September, agency officials said. Three of the school districts - Pittsburgh, Richmond, Va., and Charleston, W.Va. - had not tested for lead at the time of the survey. The other 10 school districts were Philadelphia and Chester in Pennsylvania; Baltimore and Montgomery County in Maryland; Huntington and Jackson in West Virginia; Alexandria, Caroline County and Fairfax County in Virginia and Washington D.C. ``Many schools were either not testing their water or, if they were testing, may have been testing improperly,'' said the report. The EPA considers lead concentrations above 20 parts per billion to be hazardous to school children. The report said that the agency believes every year more than 250,000 children are exposed to lead level in drinking water that are high enough to impair their intellectual and physical development. There are about 44 million youngsters in the nation's schools, 33.6 million in kindergarten and the elementary grades. Nationwide, only Minnesota requires local school officials and day care centers to test their drinking water for lead, the auditors said. Other states only recommend such tests. Congress passed a law in 1988 that requires EPA to issue testing guidelines and provide help to schools for the tests. The report blamed both the EPA and states for lack of vigor. While there are an estimated 600 different models of water coolers that have lead components and, therefore, pose a health hazard, the EPA so far has identified only 33 such models in guidelines to school districts. A number of the schools surveyed had limited their test programs to only coolers singled out by the EPA, the auditors said. The EPA auditors found that coolers on the EPA warning list were found to be operating in seven of the 10 school districts where testing had been done. Four of the districts had coolers that were not on the EPA list, but were providing contaminated water. Six of the school districts had drinking water contaminated because of lead in fountains and plumbing. ``At one school, 15 coolers were tested and all 15 exceeded 20 parts per billion,'' said the report. Drinking water was found in five of the school districts that had lead levels in excess of 100 ppb, or five times the levels considered safe for children. They did not identify the schools. The report attributed many of the shortcomings to school officials not having the money to conduct tests. It noted that while the 1988 Lead Contamination Control Act authorized $30 million a year to help schools test, none of that money so far has been appropriated by Congress.

Here is the text of President Bush's news conference Thursday: President Bush: Let me just make a brief statement and then I'll be glad to respond to questions. I want to begin today by simply restating for the American people some of the key points about our efforts to turn back aggression in the Persian Gulf. I believe that it is essential that the American people fully understand the objectives of the United States and the United Nations, as well as the magnitude of the outrage perpetrated by the government of Iraq. The United States and the rest of the world are united in the condemnation of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. We have no quarrel with the Iraqi people. Our problem is with Iraqi's dictator Saddam Hussein. I want a peaceful resolution to this crisis. We're giving the United Nations sanctions imposed on Iraq time to work. But let me be very clear, there will be no compromise on the stated objectives of the United Nations Security Council resolutions. Iraq's brutality against innocent civilians will not be permitted to stand, and Saddam Hussein's violations of international law will not stand; his aggression against Kuwait will not stand. And now I'd be glad to take questions. I think, Tom, you have the first one. Q: Yes, Mr. President, - (inaudible) - say that your comments in recent days have been aimed at least in part in preparing the American people for the possibility of war. Is that true? (And do you think the American people are ready, that they have no problems with it?)
