DOC.HEAD: Excerpts from Sir Howe, Mrs. Thatcher Letters
With AM-Britain-Howe
DOC.TEXT: Here are excerpts from Sir Geoffrey Howe's letter of resignation as deputy prime minister, and the response from Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher:

Letter from Howe: It gives me all the more sadness .... to acknowledge the growing difference which has emerged between us on the increasingly important issue of Britain's role in Europe. As much as you, I have wanted to make the most of Britain's influence in the world, to deploy Britain's sovereignty to the best advantage of our people. Ever since our original application to join the European Community in 1962, that has clearly involved Britain's firm, practical commitment to the historic process of closer European partnership ... My vision of Europe has always been practical and hard-headed. I am not a Euro-idealist or federalist. My concern is less with grand schemes than with immediate realities, as they affect our well-being and prospects as a nation. Like you, I have fought too many European battles in a minority of one, to harbor any illusions on that score. Our conduct of policy on the crucial monetary issue in Europe - first on ERM (the Exchange Rate Mechanism) and now on EMU (European Monetary Union) - has given me increasing grounds for concern ... We mst be at the center of the European partnership, playing the sort of leading and constructive role which commands respect. We need to be able to persuade friends as well as challenge opponents, and to win arguments before positions become entrenched ... I am deeply anxious that the mood you have struck - most notably in Rome last weekend and in the House of Commons this Tuesday - will make it more difficult for Britain to hold and retain a position of influence in this vital debate. Of course, there are still huge questions to be considered and resolved in this discussion. None of us wants the imposition of a single currency, but more than one form of EMU (European Monetary Union) is possible. The important thing is not to rule in or out any one particular solution absolutely. We should be in the business, not of isolating ourselves unduly, but of offering positive alternatives that can enable us to be seriously engaged. Cabinet government is all about trying to persuade one another from within. So too, within the unique partnership of nations that is making the European Community. Plain speaking certainly - but matched always by mutual respect and restraint in pursuit of a common cause. The need to find and maintain common ground on the European issue within our own party will be crucial to our electoral success and the future of the nation. In all honesty I now find myself unable to share your view of the right approach to this question. On that basis, I do not believe that I can any longer serve with honor as a member of your government ...

Letter from Mrs. Thatcher: ... Your letter refers to differences between us on Europe. I do not believe these are nearly as great as you suggest. We are at one in wishing to preserve the fundamental sovereignty of Parliament. We want Britain to play a leading part in Europe and to be part of the further political, economic and monetary development of the European Community. As I made clear in my statement to the House, our aim is to find solutions which will enable the Community to go forward as twelve. I believe the party is united behind these aims and demonstrated that very clearly in the House on Tuesday: we have always been the party of Europe, and will continue to be so.

DOC.HEAD: Conflicting Polls in Final Days of Governor's Race
DOC.TEXT: Final polls on California's costly seesaw battle for governor reported conflicting results Thursday. Republican Pete Wilson was leading Democrat Dianne Feinstein in one statewide survey and was running neck-and-neck with her in two others. To date, both candiates have spent a total of about $40 million on their campaigns since last year. Final spending is expected to approach $50 million. The Los Angeles Times' poll, a survey of 1,993 voters over four days ending Tuesday, showed Wilson with 43 percent and Feinstein with 42 percent, and a statistical margin of error of 3 percentage points. Pollster Mervin Field reported Wilson with 47 percent and Feinstein at 39 percent, with 1,248 voters surveyed over five days ending Tuesday. Field said his margin of error was 2.9 points. Field's California Poll showed Wilson had increased his lead by 3 points over an earlier October survey. In the Times poll, however, Wilson had declined 2 points. The earlier polls were 47-42 for Wilson in Field's poll and 45-42 for Wilson in the Times poll. A third survey by Southern California pollster Steve Teichner reports Wilson with 37 percent to Feinstein's 36 percent, compared with 37-30 for Wilson in mid-October. One thousand registered voters were polled. The margin of error was 3.2 points.

DOC.HEAD: Jewish Leaders Says Bush's Saddam-Hitler Comparison Exaggerated
With AM-Bush, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Some Jewish leaders said President Bush overstated the case when he suggested Thursday that Saddam Hussein had surpassed Adolf Hitler in at least one form of brutality. One called it ``an unfortunate exaggeration,'' another ``a slip of the tongue.'' But several said Saddam-Hitler comparisons were apt to a certain extent, and one said he thought the president was just using an understandable figure of speech. Bush, speaking at a Republican rally in Mashpee, Mass., said the Iraqi leader's forces ``have committed outrageous acts of barbarism.'' And he said American hostages were being ``held in direct contravention of international law. Many of them reportedly staked out as human shields near possible military targets, brutality that I don't believe Adolf Hitler ever participated in.'' Later, at a news conference in Orlando, Fla., Bush said, ``I don't think I am overstating it. I know I am not overstating the feelings I have about it.'' Rabbi Abraham Cooper, associate director of the Simon Wiesenthal Center in Los Angeles, said, ``Saddam Hussein has a list of crimes that I don't think has to be compared with anybody in order for the people of America to understand how serious a threat he represents.'' Cooper said he believed there were comparisons that could be made between the Iraqi president and the World War II German dictator whose regime resulted in the extermination of about 6 million Jews. ``But let's also keep this thing in some sort of perspective,'' he said. ``And to say that he outstrips Adolf Hitler, I just think it's either a slip of the tongue or a speech writer got carried away. No one yet, and I hope no one ever will, match up to the systematized brutalities and racist policies that Adolf Hitler committed.'' Abraham Foxman, national director of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, called Bush's remark ``an unfortunate exaggeration that could hurt the president's credibility at a time when it is very important that he remain credible.'' ``Saddam Hussein is writing his own chapter of barbarism,'' Foxman said. ``It's the Saddam Hussein chapter and one need not compare or exaggerate.'' Elan Steinberg, executive director of the World Jewish Congress, asked about the president's remark, said, ``I think he is being figurative in using Hitler as the supreme standard or measure of brutality. In a figurative sense, we understand why he is making the comparison to Hitler. I don't think even President Bush means to make the literal comparison as to who is more evil.''

DOC.HEAD: Elections Officials Give Opposition Group Victory in Georgia
DOC.TEXT: The opposition group Round Table-Free Georgia nearly swept parliamentary elections in the southern Soviet republic last week to win most of the seats in the new legislature, official results showed. The official Central Election Commission said Thursday that the non-Communist group, led by popular Georgian independence activist Zviad Gamsakhurdia, won slightly more than 54 percent of the popular vote in the final tally from Sunday's voting, the official news agency Tass reported. The Georgian Communist Party, which had embraced many of the radical positions of the nationalists, won 29.4 percent, likely making it the second most powerful bloc in the new parliament but dashing predictions of a close race. Both groo lead the multi-ethnic Caucasus republic to independence from the Soviet Union. Half the members of the 2ups have vowed t50-seat legislature were chosen from the lists of individual candidates to represent various districts. The rest were chosen at large, in proportion to the number of votes cast for each party or bloc throughout Georgia. The results gave Gamsakhurdia's group 114 seats and the Communists 60 seats in the voting by party lists. The remainder will be decided in a runoff election Nov. 11 in districts where candidates did not receive at least 50 percent of the vote, Tass he mountainous republic, which is dotted with pockets of Azerbaijani and other ethnic groups. His party won on a platform calling for independence from the Soviet Union, private ownership of land and a capitalist economy. No date has been set yet for convening the Georgian Supreme Soviet legislature, which is expected to declare independence from the Soviet Union. Among the 15 Soviet republics, all but Kirgizia have declared some form of sovereignty or independence.

DOC.HEAD: Joseph Papp Turns Down More NEA Grants
DOC.TEXT: Producer Joseph Papp turned down $323,000 in grants from the National Endowment for the Arts on Thursday, the second time this year he has refused money from the federal government. In a letter to NEA chairman John Frohnmayer, Papp, who heads the New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater, said the festival found ``the new legislation for the continuance of the National Endowment for the Arts punitive and an infringement on the civil rights of artists and arts institutions.'' The money would have been used for the festival's theater and music-theater programs. Papp's action came despite the NEA's decision last month to drop its policy of requiring grant recipients to sign a pledge saying they would not violate restrictions imposed by Congress on obscenity. ``What this means financially is a substantial increase in our problems as an institution to raise additional funds,'' Papp told reporters. The Public has a yearly budget of some $14 million and has been able to raise about $12 million each year to cover costs. That still leaves a deficit of about $2 million that must be erased each year, he said. In April, Papp rejected a $50,000 grant from the endownment to help underwrite the Festival Latino, a month-long program of Latin American theater, music and films at the Public Theater.

DOC.HEAD: ORLANDO, Fla.: ... with it?)
DOC.TEXT: A: Tom, I want to have a peaceful resolution to this question. And our dealing through the United Nations and working with them for common objectives I think is evidence of that. I've indicated we're prepared to give sanctions time to work, and I'll repeat that here again today. But I am not ruling out further options, and I'm not trying to prepare our country for war. We have a little bit of a hiatus, because of the attention on the budget and other matters, from keeping in focus our objectives in Iraq. There's been a little less attention to it in some quarters, and I want to - in a sense, Tom, it's a little bit awkward because here we are just a few days before an election, and I want to continue to work for Republican candidates, but I must continue to keep our objectives regarding Iraq in focus. And so what I try to do is separate out the foreign affairs, the Iraq question, from domestic politics. But it is essential that I do the latter, but it is not - in doing that, I am not trying to sound the tocsin of war, but I am trying to point out the concerns that I feel, for example, on the hostage question. And I'll continue to do that. Q: Do you think the American people though, sir, are ready for war? A: Well, I don't - I think the American people feel as I do, that they'd much prefer to have a peaceful resolution of this question, but who can tell what would happen in a situation of this nature. There's a lot of unforeseen things that can take place, and I think I would have to go to the American people with my recommendations, if it regarded the safety or defense of our key interests. Yeah? Q: Mr. President - Mr. President, you said today - A: Sorry. Q: I know you said that Saddam Hussein was even more brutal than Adolf Hitler, talking about starving out the Americans in the embassy in Kuwait City. Is there a chance that you might be exaggerating a bit for effect? And coming just one week before the election - I know you said that you keep these separate - but you're making these statements on the bandstand with your political party behind you. If you really want to keep these separate, why don't you just address the nation in some other forum? A: Well, I'm addressing it in another forum now, and this is in a nationally covered press conference, I'm sure. I don't, I don't think I'm overstating it. I know I'm not overstating the feelings I have about it. The reports coming out of Iraq just today cause even further concern, these reports of the way our innocent civilians are being treated. I think the American people are as outraged as I am about the treatment of the people in our embassy for example, and I think it's important that they know my concerns on this subject. So, I don't, I don't the last question that you raise does concern me some, but it is very important that I keep pointing out the objectives and where I think Iraq stands. All the people we're addressing are extraordinarily interested in that, and I go to great ends to make sure that I give proper credit to the Democrats and the Republicans in Congress, make clear that this is not a partisan effort that we're involved in here. I have been very gratified for the enormous support from both houses of Congress and from the American people. But I, as we continue to move forces and as we see the various events taking place over there, I think it is important that the President continue to spell out for the American people not only our objectives, but telling them how I feel about the various events. Q: Mr. President, are you - one follow-up - are you considering now a reprovisioning mission of some sort? A: Well, I am hopeful still that the United Nations resolutions that call for reprovisioning will be followed, and I'd rather leave it there. But I am very concerned about the people in that embassy. It's cut off from food. They have enough right now, but the whole - whole ploy by Saddam Hussein is to starve them out. And I think that is unconscionable, and I think the world needs to know how strongly those of us in the United States responsible for this policy feel about it. Q: Mr. President, apart from the distraction that may have been caused by the budget battle, what other factors have caused you to approach this task of readdressing this issue with such urgency?

DOC.HEAD: Popular Front Leader Calls for U.N. Troops to Intercede
DOC.TEXT: Moldavian nationalist leaders on Thursday blasted the Kremlin's deployment of security forces in the embattled republic and demanded U.N. peacekeeping troops replace the Soviet soldiers, news reports said. The Moldavian Popular Front asked the republic to ``declare immediate and unconditional secession from the U.S.S.R. and press for the withdrawal of all Soviet troops from the territory of the republic and suspension of the activity of KGB bodies,'' according to a statement reported by the official news agency Tass. The statement said the legislature also must ``ask the United Nations to introduce its troops into Moldavia for a period determined by the republic leadership,'' Tass reported. The front, a leading nationalist group, has been caught in the middle of a secessionist battle between the Gagauz minority and the government of Moldavia, a republic of 4.3 million bordering Romania. The Gagauz minority, a Christian people numbering about 150,000 and living mostly in the southern corner of the republic, declared sovereignty last week and began holding elections for its own government. They claim Moldavia has been discriminating against minorities in the republic during its own drive for independence. Bands of Moldavian nationalists rushed to the area to oppose the Gagauz, triggering the deployment of two Interior Ministry regiments last weekend. The first violence came Wednesday when Moldavians attacked the frontier with Romania, threatening to kill guards and their families unless Soviet forces withdraw, Tass reported. The militants gave up. No casualties were reported. Similar separatists movements have sprouted nationwide, and are hampering Gorbachev's efforts to negotiate a union treaty that would solidify ties among divergent peoples and regions. Gagauz representatives have been negotiating with a joint Moldavian-Soviet committee trying to resolve the standoff in the Gagauz districts. Both sides agreed to pull back their defenders, mostly youths armed reportedly with sticks and metal rods, and allow the security forces to establish a buffer. The Gagauz also have postponed their elections for an independent government during the negotiations. The Popular Front's statement also urged the parliament in neighboring Romania, whose people share a common language and culture with Moldavians, to ``immediately consider giving assistance to Romanians who are discriminated against by the U.S.S.R,'' the independent Postfactum news agency reported. Romanian President Ion Iliescu said in an interview on Austrian television Wednesday that Romania would not seek to alter its border with Moldavia, Tass reported.

DOC.HEAD: Contribution Limits Dumped; Ruling Affects New Initiatives
DOC.TEXT: The California Supreme Court discarded a ban Thursday on legislative fund raising in non-election years and raised the stakes for competing ballot measures in next week's election. The court said that when two rival measures are on the same ballot and get majority votes, the one with more votes takes effect and the other cannot be enforced. The 5-2 ruling voided what remained of Proposition 68, a campaign finance initiative for legislative candidates that was approved in 1988 by 53 percent of the voters. Proposition 73, a milder campaign finance measure on the same ballot, got 58 percent. The court rejected arguments by Common Cause and other groups backing Proposition 68. They maintained parts of the measure that did not expressly conflict with Proposition 73 could be salvaged - an overall limit on contributions to legislative candidates and a ban on fund raising during non-election years. Contribution limits in Proposition 73 were ruled unconstitutional by a federal judge but were allowed to remain in effect for legislative races until appeals were resolved. Thursday's ruling could affect several sets of competing initiatives on Tuesday's ballot, wiping out all provisions of a measure that passed by a majority but got fewer votes than a conflicting measure. For example, Propositions 131 and 140 contain rival sets of term limits for officeholders, but each also contains other provisions: voluntary spending limits and partial public financing of campaigns in Proposition 131, and a cut in the Legislature's budget in Proposition 140. Propositions 130 and 138, regulating logging, and Propositions 128 and 135, affecting pesticides, also could be affected. When a second measure is ``directed to the same subject and offered as a competing regulatory scheme ... only the provisions of the measure receiving the highest affirmative vote are operative,'' Justice David Eagleson wrote. Lower courts had interpreted state law to require comparison of each provision of rival initiatives to decide whether parts of a measure receiving fewer votes could be enforced separately. Eagleson rejected that approach as ``judicial legislation.'' Justice Stanley Mosk, in a separate opinion, said patching together parts of two competing initiatives could create ``a Frankenstein's monster whose existence the voters never contemplated.'' But dissenting Justice Joyce Kennard, joined by Justice Allen Broussard, said the approach the court rejected was required by state law. The ruling does not become final for at least 30 days. It would not appear to affect fund-raising for legislative candidates in next week's election, currently governed by Proposition 73.

DOC.HEAD: ORLANDO, Fla.: ... such urgency.
DOC.TEXT: A: Well, we're getting, you know - the sand is running through the glass. And we've got these economic sanctions in play and I think there's an urgency on the part of people to understand - desire on their part rather - to understand whether the sanctions are working. We continue to move force, and I think it's important that the American people know why I'm continuing to do this. And so, I think it's just rather that there was a period where I didn't do as much of it. But now I'm going to keep on - now and on past the election as well. Q: Mr. President, I know you say that you're not trying to prepare the American people for war, but could not your message of today and this week be summed up as that you are seeking a peaceful resolution if possible, but a military one if not? A: Well, I think that I've made those statements before. I think I've been rather consistent in pointing out that I would not rule anything out. If you go back and look at the things I've said, I believe I've been on the record before with that kind of comment, Brit. Q: Mr. President, Saddam Hussein today invited American families to come visit the hostages over the next holiday. The two-part question, sir, is would you welcome such visits by Americans? And what do you make of that kind of offer to them? A: I think it's a well, let me start. I think that those people should come home to visit with their families. I think they should be released from captivity. This canard of calling people that are held hostage - calling them ``guests'' when they're hostages is turning off the whole world. And further, the reports that are coming out from some of these French hostages coming home of their understanding of the way the Americans are being treated is just terrible. And the whole concept of staking out people for - next to what might become military targets is also unconscionable. So I see it as a ploy, but I don't think he'll win the ``humanitarian of the year'' award for that. I think that people see it as a rather brutal toying with the emotions of families, frankly. Charlie? Q: (Inaudible.) A: I would - we have a notice out that we are discouraging Americans from going there. And that would hold. Q: Mr. President, you said on one occasion that your patience is running out, that you've had it. You're telling us on this occasion you're willing to wait and see if the sanctions work. We've see your senior staff out today - (inaudible) - consistency, but yet there seems to be a variance there. Are you having trouble getting your message across? A: No, and I don't think there's any inconsistency. And if you'd like - I don't want to take up your time, but, thinking I might get a question of this nature, I wrote down the various things that I've said on this subject for some time, and they are quite consistent. One time you might have a little more emphasis on one point, like yesterday on the outrage I feel about the hostages; at another you might have a little more emphasis on having the sanctions work. But I think we have been extraordinarily consistent. And I think our - I think the key point on this regarding substance is that our allies understand this. They know exactly where the United States stands in terms of our determination to see the United Nations sanctions fulfilled. So I'm not worried about it. There was one story today that was, you know, just clearly wrong in that regard. But I think we've had a rather consistent approach to this, very consistent, and so I don't worry about that. And I - the key point would be if our allies thought that, and they don't, or Saddam Hussein thought that - and he doesn't. He can't. Q: I'd like to just follow up. Before you were concerned about an erosion within your alliance - (inaudible) - Saddam Hussein may be successful in trying to keep apart - (inaudible.) A: I know he's going to continue to try to do that, Charles. He's doing it every way he can. He did it first - an interesting point. He contacted, his people contacted a parliamentarian in Canada, roughly the same day they contacted the Foreign Minister of Germany, roughly the time they contacted a member of parliament in the United Kingdom. And the whole concept was, ``You come; we'll parcel out some hostages.'' Trying to divide and show a humanitarian side of some sort. He continues to - through the Primakov visit, I think his concept there was to try to find some division, and I don't think that division exists. But it does concern me that he not be successful. And that's why I think it is important that the United States continue to reiterate our conviction on seeing that there can be no compromise with this aggression and that these United Nations resolutions must be fulfilled in their entirety. Yeah?

DOC.HEAD: Bush's Staff-Change Comment Sparks Interest
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said casually at his news conference Thursday that there would be an announcement soon about a staff change involving ``one of our top people.'' Noting the interest the comment sparked among reporters, he quickly added that it was not anyone whose name had been mentioned in recent speculation following the contentious budget battle with Congress. When questions persisted after the news conference ended, Bush returned with Joe Hagan, head of the White House scheduling office, and said Hagan was resigning.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Marines Practice Invasion Techniques in North Arabian Sea
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of U.S. Marines aboard several amphibious assault vessels on Thursday simulated a landing on the beaches of Iraqi-occupied Kuwait. It was the second such major exercise for the U.S. Navy and Marine Corps deployed to the region as part of the mass land, air and sea buildup following Iraq's invasion three months ago. The first, in which the amphibious warship USS Iwo Jima took part, had been ``successfully accomplished,'' said Lt. Kevin Wensing, a spokesman for Command Naval Forces, Central Command. Elsewhere Thursday, colleagues stopped to mourn 10 of the crewmen of the Iwo Jima killed in a boiler-room accident off Bahrain. The Iwo Jima accident occurred Tuesday as the warship ended a rest and recreation spell at Bahrain's Mina Sulman port and was heading out to participate in the assault exercises starting that same day. Wensing said elements of the 4th Marine Expeditionary Brigade, and Amphibious Task Group 2, were conducting the amphibious training exercise in the north Arabian Sea from Oct. 30 to Nov. 8. The exercise, he said, involved ``surface and heliborne operations on a remote beachhead'' in which 20 fixed-wing aircraft and 75 helicopters were being employed. ``The purpose is to continue Navy and Marine Corps training in amphibious landing skills and to familiarize these forces with the desert environment,'' he said. Exact location was not given for security reasons, he said. But it is known the first exercise took place somewhere off Oman. Wensing, noting there were 18-20 amphibious assault ships in the region, declined further detail on the marine exercise but stressed the accident was not in any way affecting the Amphibious Task Force. The Iwo Jima is one of Amphibious Task Force ships assigned to assist Operation Desert Shield, preparing to storm Kuwait from sea if the military option is decided to try to end Saddam Hussein's occupation. There are 46,000 Marine Corps personnel deployed in the task force, with 11,000 aboard the ships and the rest in Saudi Arabia.

DOC.HEAD: Huge Advantage For Incumbents In Money
DOC.TEXT: Congressional incumbents had a huge 20-to-1 money advantage over their challengers heading into the final push of this year's election campaign, the Federal Election Commission said Thursday. Incumbents in House and Senate races had a combined $120 million in cash on hand, compared to just $6 million for the challengers, according to federal election disclosure forms for the period ending Oct. 17. Overall, $303 million had been spent on the congressional elections through that date, 2 percent less than in the comparable period two years ago and just slightly more than in 1986. The FEC data included all candidates, even those without competitive elections. An analysis of the data on Senate races by Common Cause showed that the the 27 Senate incumbents who have major-party challengers had a combined $23.9 million in the bank. The challengers had $3.5 million. Those incumbents raked in more money in part because of a 4-to-1 edge in donations from political action committees, and they have outspent the challengers through Oct. 17 by $99.7 million to $34 million. Not surprisingly, only a handful of the 32 incumbents who sought re-election this year are at risk of losing their seats. ``The election process will not be competitive as long as the huge financial gap continues between incumbents and challengers,'' said Common Cause President Fred Wertheimer. Common Cause supports public financing of elections. The fattest Senate campaign chest as of Oct. 17 was that of Sen. Phil Gramm, R-Texas, with $5.26 million. Next was Sen. Bill Bradley, D-N.J., with $2.35 million. Neither was considered in political trouble. The most expensive Senate contest is in North Carolina, where incumbent Republican Jesse Helms spent $10.8 million through Oct. 17 defending his seat from Democratic challenger Harvey Gantt. Gantt, the former mayor of Charlotte, spent $4.6 million. Overall, $134 million has been spent on this year's Senate races. Through Oct. 17, all candidates had raised $151 million, compared with $157 million in the similar period for the 1988 elections. In the House, $206 million has been raised this time, compared to $202 million two years ago. $169 million of that has been spent this year, compared to $165 million in the same period in the 1988 elections. Several House incumbents had more than $1 million in reserve, even though they had no serious opposition.

DOC.HEAD: Philadelphia Connection Spells Kiss of Death in Election
DOC.TEXT: The spectre of Philly-phobia is haunting Democratic legislative candidates as Republicans scare taxpayers by telling them a vote against the GOP is a vote for a bailout of the state's largest city. Electing Democrats will mean dumping millions of state dollars into Philadelphia's supposed fiscal black hole, Republicans across Pennsylvania contend. As far away as Erie, in the state's northwest, Republican Harry Bowser, who was bounced from his House seat two years ago by Democrat Thomas Scrimenti, is mounting a campaign of revenge. He says Scrimenti is a lackey of the Philadelphia House leadership. House Speaker Robert O'Donnell, a Democrat, is from Philadelphia. Earlier this week, House Minority Whip Samuel Hayes said a Democratic candidate in Lancaster would be ``like an orange, ready to be squeezed'' by Philadelphia lawmakers seeking money for their beleaguered city. In Crawford County, incumbent Rep. Connie Maine's opponent, Republican Teresa Brown, is saying Maine has voted for Philadelphia politicians and that when it comes time for a bailout she'll do it again. Pennsylvania politicians have long practiced Philly bashing as an easy way to lay blame for problems and threaten voters that ``this could happen here.'' They complain that the state's biggest city gets it all, while the little guy goes without. But this year with increasing regularity, the question of whether a lawmaker voted in favor of legislation to benefit Philadelphia, supported Philadelphia lawmakers, or was backed by Philadelphia lawmakers is turning into a major election issue. Philadelphia faces a $206 million deficit in the fiscal year that ends next June 30. Mayor W. Wilson Goode has frozen hiring and delayed pension fund payments and tax refunds, but the city expects to go broke by Dec. 1. Few taxes can be raised or added without state approval and its wage tax already is among the nation's highest. Standard & Poors' has lowered the city's bond rating to CCC. Officials from both sides of the legislative aisle say Philly-phobia is a good way to win votes. Especially when candidates try to link their opponents with Philadelphia's financial problems and charge they'll send taxpayers' money to help rescue the city. Jack Stollsteimer, aide to O'Donnell, said the ``divide and conquer'' strategy usually means the candidate doesn't have much else to attack. ``It's on a much larger scale than it's ever been done in the past. It's much more orchestrated,'' Stollsteimer said. Republicans use the tactic to scare voters into thinking that supporting Democrats will mean a spread of Philadelphia's liberal, Democratic thinking, he said. ``Both sides are trying to win the middle class and the Republicans always try to say that the Democrats represent `them' - the lower class, poor people, black people - not `us,' the middle class voters,'' Stollsteimer said. ``With the city's financial trouble, they think they have an issue that plays to people's worse fears.''

DOC.HEAD: Amnesty International Asks Saudis to Check Torture Reports
DOC.TEXT: Amnesty International announced Thursday it is asking Saudi King Fahd to investigate allegations that his security forces have tortured and otherwise mistreated hundreds of Yemenis. The Yemenis are being forced out of Saudi Arabia in retaliation for Yemen's position on the Persian Gulf crisis. Yemen is widely seen as a tacit supporter of Iraq, which it has been reluctant to condemn for the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. In its statement in London, the international human rights group said the Yemeni victims ``were among the thousands of Yemeni nationals who were rounded up in the space of a month.'' The group said the roundup, expulsions and ill treatment were ``for no apparent reason other than their nationality or their suspected opposition to the Saudi Arabian government's position in the gulf crisis.'' At least 400,000 Yemenis left Saudi Arabia between late September and late October. ``More than half the Yemeni population in Saudi Arabia already has left the country. We don't want those still in the country to suffer the same abuses,'' Amnesty said. Yemen's foreign minister, Abd al-Karim al-Iryani, said in an interview last month that the expulsions were intended to cripple his nation's fledgling government. He said the Saudis hope the deluge of refugees will overwhelm Yemen. The Yemenis in Saudi Arabia send remittances home. Those funds constitute about one-third of the gross national product of Yemen. The country, which is at the tip of the Arabian Peninsula, is one of the poorest in the Arab world. It was created in May by the unification of pro-Western North Yemen with Soviet-allied South Yemen. On Sept. 18, Saudi authorities withdrew special status for the 1-2 million Yemenis in the kingdom, including many who lived there more than 30 years. They were given about two months to find a Saudi sponsor or go home. The Saudis have invited U.S. and other national forces onto their soil to counter Iraq's army, which is just across the Kuwaiti border. In addition to appealing to King Fahd, a representative of Amnesty International raised the group's concerns about torture, detention and arrests last week with the Saudi Arabian ambassador in Washington, D.C., the statement said. ``We want the government to ensure that the investigation is carried out,'' Amnesty said. It said the inquiry should be public. In the group's release, the Saudi government was quoted as saying it did not believe there had been any ``widespread violation'' of its policy of treating Yemenis with ``affection and dignity.'' Saudi authorities said they would look at the information submitted by Amnesty, the statement said. However, there was no public comment from the Saudis. An Amnesty research team in Yemen spent several days interviewing people crossing from Saudi Arabia and collected information on 800 people arrested and detained, including many who had been tortured or mistreated, the statement said. The team saw some people with torture marks, the statement said. The group interviewed a man who had been beaten so badly he had to be hospitalized. The researchers said Yemenis reported beatings on the feet, near suffocation and sleep deprivation, according to the statement. Most of those interviewed said that after they were arrested, Saudi officials asked them if they supported Yemen's position in the gulf crisis.

DOC.HEAD: Warm Winds Sweep the Plains, Snow in the West
DOC.TEXT: High pressure Thursday over the mid-Atlantic states produced warm winds from Texas to the plains and the Mississippi Valley to the Great Lakes region. Afternoon temperatures in the Midwest and East were in the 60s and 70s. A low pressure system that could grow into a winter storm developed in the Southwest and the West's central mountain ranges. A cold front moved southeast across Utah. About six inches of new snow was expected in the state's northern and southern mountains by Friday. Alta, Utah reported two inches of snow by Thursday morning. Lighter snow fell across parts of western and southern Wyoming, with 1 to 3 inches reported at Yellowstone Park. Windy conditions were reported in the Arizona and Southern California deserts and scattered showers fell across sections of Arizona. Record high temperatures reported Thursday include 75 degrees in Aberdeen, S.D., and Alpena, Mich., 85 in Dodge City, Kan., 83 in Concordia, Kan., and 79 in Kansas City, Mo. Heavier rainfall during the six hours ending at 1 p.m. EST included nearly a quarter inch at Glasgow, Mont., and more than a tenth of an inch at Malad, Idaho. The nation's low Thursday was 20 degrees in Saranac Lake, N.Y. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 32 degrees in Ely, Nev., to 89 degrees at Gage, Okla.

DOC.HEAD: ORLANDO, Fla.: ... entirety. Yeah?.
DOC.TEXT: Q: Mr. President, in the beginning of this crisis you held out little hope for a diplomatic solution. Today - A: Did you say ``a little hope'' or ``little hope''? Q: Little hope for a diplomatic solution. Today you talk about hoping that there's a peaceful resolution. I'm just wondering, are we any closer to possibly having a diplomatic solution? A: I don't see that. I don't see that we are. I've said from the very beginning I hoped that the sanctions would have an effect that would cause him to comply with the resolutions. I think they're having an effect. But our problem is, and the problem of our allies around the world is we can't certify for the world how disastrous or strong an effect these sanctions are having. But from the very beginning I've been saying I would hope that the sanctions would be effective. And we'll give them time. Again, my problem is, and the problem with those with whom I consult very closely, is we can't say how much is enough in terms of the sanctions or how much time it would take. Q: Well, sir, if you do not expect a diplomatic solution, but you're hoping for a peaceful resolution, does that mean you expect Saddam will just give up? A: That's what I would like to see, yeah. That's what the United Nations calls for - calls for him to withdraw; calls for the restoration of the rulers. And so that's exactly what he ought to do. And I think if we hold firm - and we are holding firm in this coalition with some 25 countries in the Gulf or on the sea there, plus the solidarity that the United Nations has demonstrated - I think he'll eventually - you know, the hope is eventually he might do that. But we can't guarantee to the American people how long will it take. Yeah? Q: Sir, your wife was campaigning in Omaha today, and I don't know if you've seen reports about that. She was asked if you would consider meeting face to face with Saddam Hussein, and replied, quote, ``I think he would consider anything to get the Kuwaitis back in their own country and get'' - (inaudible). That is being interpreted that you would consider a one-on-one meeting with Saddam. Would you? A: I would consider it without - if there was an agreement that he would totally withdraw and comply fully, with no conditions, to the United Nations sanctions. I mean, I think anybody would do that. But that would mean that he has to do exactly what I've been saying here, with no condition, no negotiation - just leave. But I don't at that juncture that it would be much of a pleasant meeting. But I never - that's something that I guess Barbara was asked on her own. I've not discussed it with her or anybody else. But that's the only way that it would be productive for me to have a meeting, it seems to me, because there is no flexibility on our position. There is no compromise, there is no conditionality. My position, and I think it strongly represents the coalition partners' position, is he must comply. And so I don't think a meeting short of just acceptance of those terms would be in the national interest or in the interest of the coalition. Yeah? Q: I have a question - A: Yes, sir, John, and - Q: - about the self-serving skepticism - (inaudible) - speaking out on Iraq. It's not just because of the elections - (inaudible). It's also because of the signals we've been getting about the embassy in Kuwait had plenty of food and water for the time being. The ambassador - the Dutch ambassador's wife said Tuesday morning on one of these morning television programs that they were planting vegetables there, that they have a well there, all seems to be going well. All of a sudden, the next day, we're - (inaudible). What caused this change? A: I don't think it is a change. I've been increasingly concerned about it. I'm delighted to know about the vegetables. That's the first time I've heard of that. And I've known that they've had enough tuna fish for some time. There was earlier estimates that the embassy would have to be closed before now, and they've stretched the time frame there. But it's that plus the reports coming out of Iraq that make me feel I must keep this in focus for the American people. They must know how strongly I feel about an American embassy, the American flag flying, and these people inside being cut off, and I would say brutalized by that behavior; and secondly, how strongly I feel about the Americans that are held hostage in Iraq itself. And it is essential that we not lose track of that - of those key points. These people are not guests. They are hostages. And I think there hasn't been - I think you're on to something, because I don't think there has been that much discussion lately of these things that really concern me, John. These matters concern me deeply. Yeah?

DOC.HEAD: ORLANDO, Fla.: ... deeply. Yeah?
DOC.TEXT: Q: Mr. President, a political question. If you're - (inaudible) - for Clayton Williams. (Inaudible). Is there any - (inaudible) that at this stage of the game due to the fact that - (inaudible). A: Well, I'm not familiar with the details of that. I am strongly in favor of Clayton Williams over his opponent, not just for personal reasons, either. And don't ask me for a review of the ballot items yet. I will be voting down there Tuesday and take a look at them. And don't ask the people of California, where they don't have one, but they have I don't know how many on there of these referendum items on the ballots. So I'm not troubled by that, because what I see in Clayton William (sic) is a person that will be a very good, strong governor for the state. And I am enthusiastically for him, and I'm not even familiar with the details of the amendment - you know, the ballot item you're talking about. Yeah? Q: Mr. President, - (inaudible) - Mr. Quayle said yesterday that the United States must - (inaudible) - Iraq's chemical, psychological, and nuclear - (inaudible). A: Well, I think from the very beginning an objective - we spelled out some objective, but one that I think has been clearly spelled out has been ensuring the security and the stability of the Gulf. And that obviously is affected by the possession of these chemical and biological weapons and things of that nature. So I don't think that the goalposts are being moved. I think it's just simply a statement of reality. . If you're going to have a stable and you're going to have a secure Gulf after Kuwait is freed and the Iraqis have withdrawn their invasion, you're going to have to have some arrangements, I'm sure - I think others would agree with this around the world - that guarantee the peace there. And I would hope that, as I've said early, I want all United Nations - United States forces out of there as soon as possible, every single soldier. And it's important I keep repeating that, because there's this - the allegations by some over in that part of the world that we want to keep forces there. That's not what we want to do. We want to come out. But there has got to be some security arrangements worked out, absolutely. Q: Mr. President, just to make sure I understand what you're saying, the United States and this international force we have cannot successfully leave, first of all, until we have secured in some manner the - (off mike). A: Oh, no, I wouldn't say that, but there have to be some security arrangements that guarantee against a future aggression of this nature. Yeah, Maureen? Q: Mr. President, you said today that Saddam Hussein had committed atrocities that were reminiscent of Adolf Hitler. Could you tell us what Hussein has done that compares with the holocaust? A: Worse than what - compares with what Hitler has done? Q: With the holocaust. A: Yeah. Go back and - well, I didn't say the holocaust. Q: Well, you said - A: I mean, that is outrageous, but I think brutalizing young kids in a square in Kuwait is outrageous, too. And I think if you go back and look at what happened when the Death's Head Regiments went into Poland, you'll find an awful similarity. I was told, and we've got to check this carefully, that Hitler did not stake people out against potential military targets and that he did indeed respect - not much else - but he did indeed respect the legitimacy of the embassies. So we've got some differences here, but I'm talking - when I'm talking about - there - I see many similarities, incidentally. I see many similarities by the way the Iraqi forces behaved in Kuwait and the Death's Head Regiments behaved in Poland. Go back and take a look at your history and you'll see why I'm as concerned as I am. Yeah. Q: Mr. President, you've spoken out about the brutality against the so-called - the hostages in Iraq. However, there's a report today by Amnesty International that there has been some of our own allies - the Saudi Arabians have been guilty of committing some kind of atrocities, at least torturing some citizens of Yemen who are in their country. What do you say to that and will you put any pressure on them to change their ways?
DOC.NOTE: MORE:

DOC.HEAD: ORLANDO, Fla.: ... their ways?
DOC.TEXT: PRESIDENT BUSH: Yes. I think I did - I have not seen that. And I don't think that - I think that violations of individuals' rights or torture should not take place. And I'll be glad to represent that. Q: How do you feel, though, about the United States helping someone who's doing the same sort of things as you're criticizing the Iraqis for? A: I feel that I'm delighted that we are there with the Saudi Arabians to stand up against this kind of aggression - international aggression in violation of international law. And that is the question and that's where I'm going to keep my focus. Because it is very important, one, that Saudi Arabia be defended. And I think - now I think that we can certify that Iraq does not have the capacity to invade Saudi Arabia. And secondly, we are united with Saudi Arabia in our determination to overthrow this aggression. Yeah? Q: Secretary Baker is going to meet Shevardnadze in Europe in the next few days. Is that because you can't stand that the Soviet Union is drifting in the Gulf strategy? Or is it because of their - their appeal behind the scenes after Primakov's visit in Baghdad? Or is it only because you want to push the START treaty? A: Well, we've got a broad agenda of items. We've got to finish up CFE. We want to move START towards conclusion. We have these common interests that you're asking about in the Gulf. And then we have economic problems that we discuss all the time. So, there'll be a broad agenda in the meetings with Shevardnadze. And I'm sure that one of them will be a discussion of the Primakov visit to Iraq, and the Primakov visit that preceded that to Egypt, and the Primakov visit that followed that to Saudi Arabia. So, I'd - but the mission, if I understand the question, is not simply to focus on this Gulf question. Because we - I am anxious to get these other matters resolved. The CFE is all but put to bed but there's a tiny technical matter that's, I think - well, hopefully it's been resolved by now. But it's a broad agenda. Q: So, you're not concerned that the Soviet Union is drifting in the Gulf strategy? . A: No, I don't. And I think one point that we ought to keep reminding the American people of is that we are very fortunate in wrestling with this problem of international aggression - that the Soviet Union and China have been with us, or we've been with them, however we want to look at it, in the United Nations as we try to bring international pressure to bear, and have brought it to bear. Yeah? Q: Mr. President, in your - (inaudible) - this morning you were a lot softer on the Democrats than you've been in recent days. Now, why the change of heart? A: It's not a change of heart, it's a question of - I think I've made my point. But I'll have a shot at them here as we get into the - depending how warmed up I get today, campaigning enthusiastically for Governor Martinez. And I'd like to finish on a positive note for - in these campaigns, but I think it's a little early to say that there will be no more flamboyant rhetoric about the Democrats, because I'm absolutely convinced if we had more Republicans things would be a lot better. Yeah, Michelle. And then Ann. Q: Mr. President, early in the course of this - the Persian Gulf crisis you said that you would not allow hostage-taking to dictate your policy. You said that would endanger every American because every American would then be subject to being held hostage. Your comments today seem to change that. It seems to highlight their situation. Have you changed your mind about the importance of highlighting hostages - the hostages in this crisis? A: I know - I don't - I want to be sure I understand your question. I'm not sure I understand it on ``highlighting'' hostages. What I think I said before was hostage-taking punishes the innocent and separates families, back in September, it is barbaric, it will not work - Sept. 16th - and it will not affect my ability to make tough decisions. Now there are other quotes here, but - so I want to be sure I understand, you see, because what I think some are picking up is there's a different emphasis. But I think - is that one in accord with what you're asking about?

DOC.HEAD: Man Claiming to be Kuwaiti Escapee Details Prison Torture
DOC.NOTE: Eds; SUBS graf 4 `His claims' to ADD dropped word `not.' Picks up 5th pvs, `He said...'
DOC.TEXT: A man claiming to be a Kuwaiti resistance member who survived three weeks in an Iraqi prison said Thursday that prisoners are being tortured and killed to break their opposition to Saddam Hussein. He told a news conference organized by Kuwait's government-in-exile he escaped and spent three days hiding in Kuwait before making his way across the desert and across the border to Saudi Arabia. He said would not describe his method of escape, in order to protect those who helped him. The young man, who spoke on the basis of anonymity, said he was arrested Sept. 20 and held 23 days. He said he was raped by Iraqi soldiers and hanged upside down for hours from a ceiling fan while his interrogators demanded, ``Do you belong to the resistance? Are you loyal to (Kuwaiti leader) Sheikh Jaber? Do you oppose Saddam?'' His claims could not be independently verified. He said he was held in the basement of a house in the Iraqi port of Basra with more than 80 others. He said they were permitted little or nothing for clothing, were awakened each morning at 5, when they were hosed down with water, and had only bread and water to eat and drink. He said other methods of torture in the prison included pulling out the fingernails of prisoners, chopping off pieces of their fingers and hands, yanking out the hairs of their mustaches and beards with pliers, and burning them with hot irons. The man said his captors promised him the ``best'' life if he would join Saddam's Baath party.

DOC.HEAD: ORLANDO, Fla.: ... and ever.
DOC.TEXT: And I don't know how long, as I've tried to be very frank with you all. I don't know how long is long enough. But I've just got to keep putting the focus there and keeping everybody on notice that we are going to be successful. But it's, you know - I'd leave it right there. Yeah? Q: Mr. President, sir, my question goes back to the issue of whether to keep the embassy open. Sir, you do seem to have changed your position. In August in Kennebunkport you ordered the State Department and the administration to order all non-essential personnel home; the Marine Guards were ordered home. There are very few people there today. Why is it so important to keep the embassy open? And if an - it sounds as if perhaps an armed conflict might be triggered ... whether the Embassy gets a resupply of food. A: I believe that the Embassy should remain open because I don't believe a dictator should violate international law by starving out or isolating another person's embassy. I think there's a fundamental principle involved in that. And I view the embassy as entitled to certain international respect and international protection. And so I just want to be sure everybody knows that I feel this way. What was the second part? Q: Do you ... triggering an armed conflict - whether or not - whether the Embassy gets a resupply of food? A: Well, I don't - I'm not going to - it's too hypothetical. I mean, you're assuming that it would trigger an armed conflict. And I'm not going to discuss what will or won't trigger an armed conflict. But let me simply repeat: this one is one that I believe is of enormous concern to our allies and to the American people. And I can certainly recertify, as I did yesterday, that it is of that kind of concern to me. But I don't want to go into what incident, what provocation would stimulate military action. But I'm very concerned about this. The last one, he said. Tom, you had your hand up. Q: Mr. President, some of your closest friends, some senior members of your government, and even a lot of Republican members of Congress who support you are telling us that your White House staff is simply not strong enough, not heavy enough, to serve you well; and that further, that's one of the reasons why you've taken political heat lately. Are any of these people telling you that? And if they are - A: No. Q: - how do you react to that? A: No, they're not telling me that, because they know that I have full confidence in my White House staff and full confidence in my cabinet, and I have been blessed with good advice, some of which I take and maybe more of which I should have taken in one thing or another. But I have not - nobody has come and presented that to me at all. I've read meaningless speculation about that in certain periodicals, but I'm inclined to discount it, because I know what I feel about my top staff and I know whether they have - whether they have my confidence or not - and they do. Do you have a followup to that one? (Laughter.) Q: Over the next couple of months, do you envision any shakeup at all in the White House staff, either in terms of personnel or in terms of the structure of the operation? A: There may be some. I think we'll have an announcement very soon on one of our top people - none that has been - not one that's been speculated about, incidentally. But there could be. It'll be two years into an administration, and I think if you look back at history, why, there's been very, very little turnover, so there could be one or two. But it won't be because of the kind of dissatisfaction with somebody's performance at all, and it damned sure won't be related to any standing in the polls or anything as - am I ever glad that I told you all - (laughing) -- and I would like to remind you of it - months ago, Sept. 3 - (laughter) - no, but seriously, I think it's fair to point out. I told you, when things were soaring like eagles, ``Don't believe the polls.'' And I think now I'm entitled to say ``Hey, they're going to come on back; don't worry about them. They'll be all right.'' Thank you ever so much. Thank you. Thanks a lot.
DOC.HEAD: END TEXT
Quizzed On Texas Ballot Proposal
DOC.TEXT: Don't ask President Bush, who votes in Texas, his position on that pesky ballot proposal in Texas that tripped up GOP gubernatorial candidate Clayton Williams earlier this week. Bush, during a campaign trail news conference Thursday, was asked about the proposed constitutional amendment and acknowledged he was ``not familiar with the details of that.'' ``I am strongly in favor of Clayton Williams,'' Bush said, hastening to add: ``And don't ask me for a review of the ballot items yet. I will be voting down there Tuesday and take a look at them.'' Williams earlier this week stumbled when reporters asked his position on the proposed amendment, which deals with appointments by the state's chief executive. Williams said he was unfamiliar with the amendment, the only one on the ballot, and was unclear how he had voted on it when he cast his absentee ballot. ``I'm not troubled by that,'' Bush said, ``because what I see in Clayton Williams is a person that will be a very good, strong governor for the state. And I am enthusiastically for him, and I'm not even familiar with the details of the amendment.'' Polls show the race between Williams and Democrat Ann Richards is too close to call.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Promises to Free Four Americans
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 10 `Jassim allowed' to restore dropped words; ADDS four grafs on complaints coinciding with Iraq offer to let relatives visit foreign `guests' over holidays, British officials dismiss offer, some Brits said to be going. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq said four American hostages it described as elderly and sick would soon be freed. It said the move was in response to a plea from a private group. Information Minister Latif Jassim, at a Baghdad news conference, did not say exactly when the four would be released, but said it would be soon. He did not disclose the names of those to be freed, but later, the official Iraqi News Agency identified them as Randall Trinah, Dr. Abdul Kanji, Raymond Galles and Michael Barnes. The report did not give their ages or hometowns. It said they were being released in response to a petition from a group called the Arab-American Reconciliation Society, and that a delegation from the group would accompany them back to the United States. A U.S. Embassy spokesman welcomed the news, and said it was seeking details from Iraq's foreign ministry. ``It is good news, our top priority is to get Americans out,'' said an embassy spokesman, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Other Americans have been released in groups at the intervention of another Arab-American group. The Rev. Jesse Jackson brought out another group. The Iraqi official accused President Bush of using the hostage issue as a pretext for a military strike, which he said could come any time. Jassim added that reporters will be allowed to go to strategic installations to visit hostages who are being held as human shields against attack. ``All the Americans at sites have complete freedom. They can watch TV, read books and read newspapers,'' the Iraqi official said. ``They also enjoy the friendship of Iraqi forces.'' Two smuggled letters from captive Americans made very different claims about life in Iraqi captivity. One said he had lost 35 pounds, and that he had received no mail or messages in two months of captivity. The other described the toll of isolation as captivity stretched on. ``You can survive. But individually interned, (one) must be psychologically capable of living alone within himself,'' he wrote, adding a plea: ``Do not forget the guest hostages.'' The letter-writers were not identified, and the official releasing the letters demanded anonymity. He said non-American foreigners being freed had carried the handwritten letters addressed to the embassy. Iraq refers to the estimated 600 foreigners interned at strategic military and industrial sites in Iraq and occupied Kuwait as guests. The complaints coincided with a report that the Iraqi Foreign Ministry has instructed missions abroad to issue visas for foreigners wishing to spend the Christmas and New Year holidays with their relatives. The British Foreign Office dismissed the offer as ``a cynical propaganda move on the part of the Iraqis'' and advised the relatives not to go. Several relatives told the British Broadcasting Corp. television that they intended to go. And the Iraqi News Agency said former Prime Minister Edward Heath, who had helped secure the release of more than 50 Britons in October, called on the families of ``British guests'' in Iraq to accept the offer. INA said its correspondent in London reported 10 wives would do so. Saddam banned foreigners from leaving the country and interned some of them after the U.S.-led multinational military buildup began in the Persian Gulf. The deployment was triggered by Saddam's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Since then, some groups of foreigners have been allowed to leave. More than 250 French nationals were released this week after Iraq decided France was making a good-faith effort to resolve the crisis. On Thursday, the official Iraqi News Agency said the National Assembly would begin deliberations this weekend on whether to allow an estimated 690 Bulgarians in Iraq and Kuwait to leave. Saddam asked lawmakers to consider freeing the Bulgarians after a visit to Baghdad by a Bulgarian delegation headed by Vice President Atanas Semerdzhiev.

DOC.HEAD: International Ownership Should Be Welcomed, Neuharth Said
DOC.TEXT: The United States should give up its barriers to foreign ownership of broadcast outlets and European governments should give up their broadcast monopolies, the founder of USA Today said Thursday. ``We should be less afraid of being fleeced by foreign investors and more receptive to being fed by them'' said Allen H. Neuharth, chairman of the Gannett Foundation, in a speech at the Center for Strategic and International Studies. Cross-border ownership will bring ``better information products to readers and viewers'' just as the expansion of major U.S. newspaper companies to ownership of publications far from their home markets has improved newspapers in this country, said Neuharth. ``I am delighted at the foresight of Robert Maxwell, Rupert Murdoch and others in making media investments in Eastern Europe as soon as the walls came tumbling down,'' he told an audience of news executives. Maxwell is a British publisher; Murdoch is an Australian by birth with worldwide media interests who became an American citizen to satisfy the ownership rules for television stations. Neuharth urged the newly free journalists of Eastern Europe not to yield to the temptations of ``journalistic arrogance'' but to ``search for the truth, with fair and balanced reporting.'' When he was chairman and chief executive of Gannett Corp., publisher of daily newspapers in several cities, Neuharth oversaw the development of USA Today, the national daily newspaper published in Arlington, Va. near Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Mulroney Announces Creation of Forum on Canada's Future
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Brian Mulroney said Thursday that Canada risks splitting along French-English and regional lines, and he announced creation of a 12-member forum to seek a consensus on the country's future. The announcement, made in a speech to the House of Commons, came four months after the failure of the Meech Lake accord, which was aimed at winning the signature of French-speaking Quebec on the 1982 constitution. Mulroney also spoke five days before a Quebec commission is to begin its own work reconsidering the ties that bind Quebec to Canada. ``The situation is urgent ... the problem is serious,'' Mulroney said. He said the new federal forum is made up of Canadians from all walks of life, though none is a politician. Its mandate will be to seek consensus on what people want from Canada and what they want Canada to be. ``The idea is to have people who are not `tainted' by partisanship,'' said Harvie Andre, House leader of the governing Conservatives. The new forum is to report back to the government by July 1, Canada's national holiday. The Meech Lake accord failed in June, when the legislatures of Manitoba and Newfoundland decided against ratifying it. Their refusal to sign angered many of the 6.7 million Quebecers and touched off huge protests across Quebec. Some demonstrators demanded that Quebec separate from Canada. Recent polls show that 60 percent of Quebecers favor a new status for Quebec, with options ranging from greater autonomy to full independence. French-speaking Quebecers, known as Quebecois, are a minority among Canada's 26 million people. They have long felt treated as second-class citizens by English-speaking Canada. The French fear that without special measures and privileges, their culture will be overwhelmed by English Canada. The Meech Lake agreement would have designated Quebec as a ``distinct society'' and given it and the other provinces more power in such areas as Supreme Court appointments and Senate reform. The ``distinct society'' clause did little more than acknowledge the obvious, but it was of tremendous symbolic importance to the French speakers. ``It's time we all did some soul searching,'' Mulroney said, acknowledging that finding a consensus will not be easy. In a country where all citizens are legally equal, how can the special needs of the French-speaking minority as well as natives and residents of the poor Atlantic provinces be accmmodated, the prime minister asked. It seems clear there will be some change in the relationship between Quebec and the rest of Canada after the failure of Meech Lake. The only question seems to be how far down the road to sovereignty the Quebecois want to go. Quebec Premier Robert Bourassa clearly does not want separation. Justice Minister Gil Remillard said recently that both the status quo and total independence are out of the question. In any case, it's unlikely that most Quebecois will be too excited about Mulroney's commission. ``They are not hanging on the results of this exercise,'' said Richard French, a former Quebec minister. ``They are hanging on the (findings of the Quebec) commission,'' he said. That 36-member group, known as the Commission on the Political and Constitutional Future of Quebec, is to issue its report in March. Richard Spicer, the former head of the Canadian Radio, Television and Telecommunications Commission, is heading the government forum. ``The assignment is awesome,'' he said. ``The procedures are ill-defined and completely untested. The outcome is entirely dubious, and there is a very high potential for fiasco.'' But he added, ``We all think that Canada deserves another chance.'' ``We are cordially inviting the politicians to keep their noses out of this; they are not welcome,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Federal Judge Sentenced For Leaking, Lying to FBI
DOC.TEXT: U.S. District Judge Robert Aguilar was sentenced to six months in prison Thursday for leaking a wiretap to a former mobster and lying to the FBI. Aguilar was convicted of the two felonies in August. He plans to appeal the convictions but faces likely impeachment by Congress. U.S. District Judge Louis Bechtle of Philadephia, assigned to the case by Chief Justice William Rehnquist, said Aguilar's crimes would normally warrant a sentence of 21 to 27 months in prison, including time added for ``abuse of trust.'' Bechtle said he imposed a shorter sentence than called for in federal guidelines because of the ordeal Aguilar will experience in impeachment and disbarment proceedings. ``These proceedings will be long and humiliating and embarrassing and burdensome, a major and substantial punishment,'' Bechtle said. He also said the jury's verdict of obstruction of justice ``by a judge no less is a chilling message indeed.'' The maximum possible sentence was 10 years in prison and $500,000 in fines. Aguilar's sentence includes fines and assessments of $2,100, and 1,000 hours of community service during two years of supervised release after imprisonment.

Aguilar, 59, of San Jose was the third federal judge convicted of a felony in the last decade. He was appointed by President Carter in 1980. In 1984, U.S. District Judge Harry Claiborne of Nevada was convicted of tax evasion. In 1986, U.S. District Judge Walter Nixon of Mississippi was convicted of perjury. Both were impeached and removed by Congress, the only way a federal judge can be forced out under the Constitution. U.S. District Judge Alcee Hastings of Florida was acquitted in 1983 of conspiracy to solicit a bribe, but he removed from office based on a congressional finding of perjury. In two trials, Aguilar was acquitted of approaching two fellow judges to seek favorable treatment for former Teamsters leader Rudy Tham, who was trying have his embezzlement conviction overturned, and businessman Ronald Cloud, then facing trial for bank fraud. Aguilar said he made only innocuous inquiries in each case. He was convicted during his second trial of two coverup charges: disclosing a wiretap in February 1988 to Abe Chapman, an elderly ex-mobster who was Tham's go-between, and lying in April 1988 to FBI agents who questioned him about the wiretap and his involvement in Tham's case. Prosecutors sought a three-year sentence for Aguilar, citing the seriousness of any crimes by a federal judge and saying Aguilar repeatedly lied as a witness in his own defense. Aguilar's lawyer, Paul Meltzer, sought probation and community service, saying he had an ``exemplary record,'' had been ``destroyed'' by the case and faced possible danger in prison. Aguilar did not make a statement during the one-hour sentencing hearing. Afterward, he approached Meltzer in the hallway with a big smile and thanked him. Jess Aguilar, one of the judge's brothers, said it was ``a lighter sentence than we anticipated.''

DOC.HEAD: Immigration of Soviet Jews to Israel Breaks Record
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS dropped word `recent' to clarify graf 5 `October's was.' Picks up 6th graf pvs, `The immigration...'
DOC.TEXT: At least 21,744 Soviet Jews arrived in Israel in October, setting a record in the current Soviet immigration wave, officials reported Thursday. According to the Absorption Ministry, 134,000 immigrants have arrived so far in 1990, among them 122,000 from the Soviet Union. The rest were from Argentina, Europe and North America, ministry spokeswoman Ida Ben-Shitrit said. She said 20,000 Jews came from the Soviet Union in October. Gad Ben-Ari, spokesman for the quasi-governmental Jewish Agency that helps handle immigration, said 21,744 came. Israeli officials expect 200,000 Soviet Jews to arrive by the end of the year and say more than 1 million Soviets might come before 1993. October's was the highest monthly immigration figure since the massive influx of 1948-51, the nation's first years of statehood. The previous recent high was in September when 19,500, nearly all of them Soviets, arrived. The immigration is aggravating unemployment, housing problems and straining the government's budget. A family of three receives about $9,000 in government subsidies during its first year in the country, the daily Jerusalem Post said. Israel has budgeted $2.3 billion over the next three years for immigrant absorption and is seeking financial aid from outside sources. The Jewish Agency has gotten $740 million in help from abroad, and its Board of Governors appealed to world Jewish groups Thursday, asking them to mobilize $1.3 billion in addition to the $600 million they have pledged to gather by the end of 1991. The numbers coming in are causing a strain. On Thursday, the Jewish Agency decided to limit to one ton - as opposed to the previous two tons - the luggage that an average Soviet family of three is allowed to bring to Israel. Transfer of the luggage belonging to Soviet immigrants cost the organization $8 million in September. The Agency also decided to limit to 10 months the period during which the immigrants are allowed to keep their belongings at state warehouses in Israel, Ben-Ari said. A family of four that agrees to leave its belongings in the Soviet Union will get $1,000, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Safety Board Says United Airlines Inspection System At Fault In Iowa Crash
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS lede to bring higher number of fatalities; SUBS 2nd graf to note board acted without dissent; ADDS 20 grafs findings and background; adds byline
DOC.TEXT: Federal safety officials on Thursday blamed the United Airlines inspection system for failing to detect a flawed engine part that caused an crash in Iowa last year that killed 112 people. The National Transportation Safety Board, issuing its opinion without dissent, said at a hearing that a yearlong investigation had concluded that United did not properly consider human limitations in its quality control procedures. The board said that as a result, inspectors missed a fatigue crack in a critical area of a titanium fan disk in the tail engine of the DC-10 aircraft. The plane, United Flight 232 en route from Denver to Chicago, crashed when trying to make an emergency landing in Sioux City, Iowa, killing 112 of 296 aboard. The safety board said the disk, made by General Electric Aircraft Engines disintegrated with force so great that the protective housing of the aircraft's hydraulic system used to control its flight was shredded. United officials, who attended the daylong hearing, rejected the board's conclusion, saying there is no evidence a half-inch crack in the bore area of the fan disk could have been detected when the part was last inspected in April 1988. Bob Doll, United's vice president for engineering and quality assurance, put the airline's position more succinctly. ``GE gave us a bum part,'' he said. He said United had fully cooperated with the safety board's inspection and said the board's staff did not understand the zeal with which the airline's inspectors look for defects. The flight was en route to Chicago when pieces of metal from the fan disk pierced the tail section of the aircraft, leading to a series of events in which all three hydraulic systems aboard were disabled. The three-man flight crew, joined by another United pilot who was a passenger on the flight, flew the aircraft to the airport at Sioux City, Iowa, using the thrust of the remaining two engines to partially control the aircraft. But the plane crashed on touchdown. During the hearing, safety board staff members testified that in repeated simulations of the situation faced by Flight 232's pilots, the conclusion was reached that the plane could not have been landed safely. John K. Lauber, a safety board member, hailed the pilots, saying, ``the team performance was in fact exquisite in this case and in fact resulted in the saving of lives.'' The titanium alloy fan disk in the tail engine of the United plane was manufactured by General Electric in 1971. It weighed 370 pounds and was about 32 inches in diameter. The safety board concluded that a flaw in the disk, which later resulted in a half-inch long crack in a vital area of the engine part, was formed during manufacture of the titanium ingot from which the disk was forged. It said that crack could have been detected in the disk's most recent inspection by United. James Wildey, a metallurgist who assisted in the investigation, called the flaw ``a buried defect'' and added: ``That defect has been in there since day one.'' ``There is no way to introduce this kind of defect through operations or anything else,'' he said. Merritt Birky, a chemical research investigator for the board, said that using normal inspection procedures there was no reason why United shouldn't have found the crack. He noted that chemicals used to detect flaws in airlines inspections of engine parts were found on the failed disk and said they should have warned of a defect. The chemicals are expected to penetrate any cracks on the surface. The surface is wiped clean, then a blotter-like substance applied that should draw the chemical back out of the crack. The blotter will fluoresce under ultra-violet light if any of the chemical has been absorbed from the interior of the metal. The disk in question had been inspected six times, the last time 17 months before the crash, without any flaws being found. The board concluded that hundreds of inspections of such disks over the course of 17 years without ever discovering a flaw led to laxity on the part of the airline's engine inspectors. The board said that available inspection methods at the time of the manufacture of the disk by GE did not detect the existence of the defect. But it did not otherwise blame GE, other than to complain that GE production records relevant to the failed disk were incomplete and did not insure adequate traceability of the engine's component parts. The safety investigators performed exhaustive tests on the failed disk after its two broken parts were found in corn fields some 80 miles from sioux City. In other conclusions, the safety board said that the emergency response at the Sioux City airport was ``initially effective.'' But it said the presence of a corn field near the crash site and the failure of a water supply truck ``adversely affected fire fighting operations.'' Noting that a number of small children were killed or injured in the crash, the board also said that the Federal Aviation Administration has not adequately addressed the issue of infant protection on passenger aircraft, including the possibility of requiring child safety seats. The FAA is considering such a requirement. The board also issued a series of recommendations, including these to: -Identify emerging technologies that can simplify or automate the inspection process with the aim of developing a ``second set of eyes'' to intensify inspection of critical engine rotating components. -Encourage research and development of backup flight control systems for new wide-body aircraft using an alternative source of power for control systems. -Conduct safety reviews of currently operating aircraft to give all possible consideration to developing alternative power sources for flight and engine controls and to protect them from unforeseen accidents.

DOC.HEAD: EPA Approves New Mexico Site
