Left-wing extremists are against the institution of the emperor, which they view as the core of imperialist sentiments among conservative Japanese. About 26,000 police already are on security-related assignments in the capital as the enthronement approaches. Further reinforcements would bring the total number of officers deployed in Tokyo for security to 37,000 on the day of the coronation.

DOC.HEAD: State Lawmaker Sentenced to Prison in Bingo Case
DOC.TEXT: A state legislator was sentenced Thursday to five years in prison and ordered to pay $48,000 in restitution for setting up an illegal bingo hall in 1986. U.S. District Judge Thomas Higgins sentenced Rep. Tommy Burnett, once one of the most powerful Democrats in the Legislature, on charges of illegal gambling, conspiracy and six counts of mail fraud. He said he would wait to sentence Burnett, 48, on an additional mail fraud conviction until he served the five-year prison term. ``It's a sad, sad day,'' Burnett told reporters. ``I think you always feel bad when something like this happens in your life.'' Burnett's lawyer Bob Lynch, in arguments before Higgins, characterized Burnett as an enigma - a popular, successful legislator and lawyer who could not manage his personal finances and fell deeply into debt. ``Perhaps I am,'' Burnett said when asked later by a reporter about the description. ``Perhaps sometimes I can do good things and sometimes I can do stupid things.'' Burnett must report for prison Jan. 2. Burnett faced up to 45 years in prison and fines of up to $1.75 million. He remains a member of the state House of Representatives until the Nov. 6 general election. He dropped out of the Democratic primary for re-election to the seat he held for 20 years and has lost his law license because of the felony convictions. Burnett stood with folded arms and fought back tears as Higgins imposed the sentence. ``Mr. Burnett stands before this court a broken man. I can't think of another better example of a broken man,'' Lynch said. Higgins called the case a ``classic example of basic right and wrong'' and said Burnett had ``clearly stepped over the line.'' He said Burnett failed to ``pay the piper'' when he served 10 months in federal prison in 1984 for failing to pay his income taxes in a timely manner, a misdemeanor. He was on probation when the latest charges were filed. The $48,000 in restitution must be paid to Florida businessman Joseph Cappello, who served time with Burnett at Maxwell Air Force Base prison camp. Cappello testified at the trial he gave Burnett money to set up a bingo hall in Crossville. Lynch would not comment on the sentence, but he said he will appeal. Assistant U.S. Attorney Robert Washko, who prosecuted the case, called it a tragedy. ``It's a tragedy that stems from a life of financial difficulties. A lot of it stemmed from is deep indebtedness,'' Washko told reporters. Washko said he will wait until Burnett becomes eligible for parole before deciding whether he will oppose Burnett's early release from prison. Burnett was named in a 10-count indictment that accused him of conspiracy, illegal gambling, mail fraud and perjury. Also named in that indictment were Knoxville bingo operator Virginia Hurst and Columbia businessman E.E. Shutt, who were accused of illegal gambling and conspiracy. Mrs. Hurst was sentenced to five years probation and community service and ordered to pay a $50,000 fine. Shutt is serving a two-year prison sentence for his role in setting up the Crossville bingo hall.

Iraqi troops seized scores of documents when they invaded Kuwait, but the papers are unlikely to compromise the United States because of Kuwait's limited intelligence service, officials and private analysts say. ``They obviously got a lot of documents,'' said Ali Al-Sabah, a spokesman for the Kuwait Embassy. ``They have to sift through them and they have the labor to do that.'' Attention focused on Kuwaiti documents Wednesday when Iraqi Ambassador Mohamed Al-Mashat released one he said was taken from files at Kuwait's internal security bureau after the Aug. 2 invasion. But officials said the fact that the documents belonged to Kuwait makes the situation different from 1979, when Iranian revolutionaries seized the U.S. Embassy in Tehran. ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - Five years after it started withholding dues from the United Nations to force a belt-tightening in the world organization, the United States is paying up. The 101st Congress, in its final days, passed legislation to pay nearly $800 million in current and back dues owed to the United Nations, its specialized agencies and other international and regional bodies to which the United States belongs. President Bush has indicated he will sign the bill. The United States pays one-fourth the cost of U.N. operations, the largest share of any country. The congressional action ``underscores the increasingly important role the United Nations is playing in a changing world,'' Assistant Secretary of State John R. Bolton said Wednesday. ---= BOSTON (AP) - In a few years, college-bound students will have to give their own answers to some Scholastic Aptitude Test math problems instead of picking from multiple choices. But they'll be able to use a calculator. Those are among changes announced Wednesday by the College Board, sponsor of the SAT, the most widely used college entrance exam in the nation. The revisions - the most drastic in the test's 64-year history - also include more emphasis on reading comprehension. The revised SAT, called SAT-I, will be introduced in 1994, board President Donald M. Stewart said. In addition, an optional test, known as the SAT-II, will be phased in starting next year and will include an essay section. ---= ATLANTA (AP) - Atlanta's rapid transit system is beckoning to booming suburban Gwinnett County, but some voters there want to derail the expansion because of fears that blacks from the city will stream out on buses and trains. Others say they simply don't want to pay for it. Gwinnett County voters decide Nov. 6 whether to bring the Metropolitan Atlanta Rapid Transit Authority into the county in exchange for a 1 percent sales tax. County Commissioner W.J. Dodd said his constituents oppose the idea, and he predicted it would fail. ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - Women and black candidates are fighting to change the political landscape in high-profile races that could see them take over three governorships and several seats in Congress. National attention is focused on black candidate Harvey Gantt's strong bid to unseat Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., and the big-state gubernatorial candidacies of Ann Richards in Texas and Dianne Feinstein in California. A raft of women and blacks are seeking office at the congressional and state levels. Women's groups are pleased with the number of female candidates seeking statewide office in Tuesday's election - 85 in all, according to the Center for the American Woman and Politics. Black candidates for statewide and federal office number 52, including 21 incumbents, according to figures compiled by the Joint Center for Political Studies. The research organization tracks black politics. ---= CHICAGO (AP) - When Jim Adduci settles into class with a bunch of 20-year-old college students, he feels a little odd. Same thing when he suits up in a minor league baseball clubhouse. ``Being 31 and in the minor leagues is like being 31 and a student,'' he says. Nonetheless, Adduci got out the books this fall after packing up his glove and spikes at the end of the season with the Scranton, Pa., Triple A ballclub. Like thousands of other athletes, Adduci cut short his college education to turn pro. Now he's trying to make up for it through an 80-college consortium that makes it easier for athletes to transfer credits, attend class, find scholarships and earn their degrees.

DOC.HEAD: Soldiers Drive Tamil Rebels From Positions
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers in camouflage gear lay on their bellies, firing automatic rifles and mortars into the scrub jungle at Tamil rebel positions. Overhead, the whine of a Sia-Marchetti attack plane grew louder as it dive-bombed a bunker. A burst of .50-caliber machine gun fire from a Bell Ranger helicopter slammed into concrete. Tamil Tiger rebels replied with automatic rifles, the bullets kicking up turf and chipping bits from the walls of a Hindu temple. The skirmish was about 1,000 yards from Kankesanthurai, a port town on the rebel-controlled Jaffna Peninsula in northern Sri Lanka. ``There are only eight to 10 rebels, but they are well entrenched in concrete bunkers,'' Maj. Deepal Subasinghe said, ducking behind the temple wall. ``Earlier, there were about 30 rebels armed with mortars, rocket-propelled grenades and rifles, but we forced them to withdraw from this temple.'' Subasinghe's mission was the final phase of a week-long operation, carried out during the monsoon rains of October to secure and link three army positions that had been isolated for four months, under rebel siege. The operation was called Jaya Shakthi, ``victorious strength'' in Sinhalese. The government said its forces captured 16 square miles in an arc from the military airstrip at Palali to Kankesanthurai harbor. It was one of the largest battles in the recent resumption of the 7-year-old civil war by the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam. The rebels are fighting for a Tamil nation in the northern and eastern part of the island, where the ethnic minority predominates. Reporters taken to the captured zone were shown fortified bunkers of concrete and steel, and a maze of underground communication trenches and tunnels that linked nearly all the homes. ``We have shifted our defense positions around the airstrip, giving us a secure area to land aircraft uninterrupted,'' said Lt. Gen. Denzil Kobbekaduwa, commander of the northern province. Three battalions - 3,000 soldiers - began the operation with an advance south of the airstrip. A column broke out to the northeast and another force moved northwest to relieve the garrison at Kankesanthurai, four miles from the airstrip. At least 117 rebels and 22 soldiers were killed in the week of fighting, Kobbekaduwa said. ``Troops suffered 170 injured, but only 17 can be considered serious,'' he told reporters at the Palali airstrip while a field cannon boomed in the distance. A statement from the rebel office in Europe said 100 civilians were killed and 200 wounded, and that at least 32 villages were destroyed. The rebels said 100 soldiers were killed, and acknowledged losing 36 Tamil fighters. No civilians were seen in any of the areas visited. Military officials said they had been warned and left before the fighting. Evidence of the guerrillas was everywhere. The floor of a two-story school at Vasavilan had been dug out to make underground bunkers. Unopened lunch packets, clothing and other personnel belongings were strewn in bunkers, indicating a hasty retreat. ``They fought a series of defensive battles from bunker to bunker before withdrawing,'' said Lt. Col. Abdul Zahir. This was clear at the Hindu temple, where reporters had to crouch and run about 50 yards, dodging rebel bullets, to reach a forward position. The Tigers had vacated bunkers in front of the temple, falling back to others at Kiramala village about a mile away. At least 14,000 people have been killed in the Tamil rebellion since it began in 1983. Tamils, most of whom are Hindus, claim discrimination in jobs, education and land policy by the Sinhalese, who are predominantly Buddhist. Tamils make up 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people and 75 percent are Sinhalese. In May 1989, the rebels accepted President Ranasinghe Premadasa's offer to negotiate. The resulting truce was shattered June 11 when the guerrillas overran several police stations and military camps in the Tamil region. Kobbekaduwa estimated 2,000 rebels were operating on the Jaffna Peninsula, about one-fourth of the guerrilla force active in Sri Lanka. He claimed 2,000 had been killed or seriously wounded since June. When asked how he planned to hold the recaptured area, the general replied: ``I am not interested in real estate. We want the rebels to come. We will ambush them and destroy them gradually.''

DOC.HEAD: Gold Sales Become Political Issue
DOC.TEXT: Many Uruguayans look upon the central bank's thousands of gold ingots as symbols of past prosperity and future promise. The government sees them as a way to reduce the deficit. A spirited argument has arisen over a new policy of exchanging ingots for cash on a ``swap'' basis that gives the government the right to reclaim the gold later. ``This is the national patrimony,'' said Ricardo Lombardo of the opposition Colorado Party. He said the policy ``compromises not just the past ... but also the future,'' and ``demands'' public debate. Uruguay is a small country, with only 3 million people, but has one of Latin America's largest stocks of gold: 3.1 million ounces, about one ounce per citizen, worth more than $1 billion. It was earned, for the most part, by beef and grain exports in the first half of the century, when Uruguay's high standard of living and comprehensive social welfare programs made it known as the ``Switzerland of South America.'' The gold lay in the vaults for decades, but the central bank has swapped 214,000 ounces for cash in three transactions since President Luis Lacalle took office in March, and prepared for others by shipping 800,000 ounces to overseas banks. Swap arrangements allow the government to reclaim the gold by agreed dates. Lombardo, one of three central bank directors, said the government lost $732,000 in the first buyback, of nearly 60,000 ounces on Oct. 30. The gold was immediately swapped the gold out again. The purpose of the swaps is to convert an unproductive asset into an investment - a basket of foreign currencies, for example - that can earn interest or other revenue and help with the deficit. Another possibility is to use some of the cash to reduce the foreign debt, now $6.9 billion. Foreign banks to which Uruguay owes $1.6 billion agreed last month to sell the debt at its secondary market value, about half the face amount. ``We can't have a pile of gold in the bank and make genuflections or some ritual of a barbarian religion before it,'' said Ramon Diaz, president of the central bank. ``We have to see what the world is doing, what other countries are doing, to deal with gold as an asset.'' When Lacalle took office, the deficit was 6.1 percent of the gross national product, a prime cause of rising inflation that reached 15 percent for September alone. Repaying the foreign debt, which Uruguay has done regularly, costs nearly $300 million a year. Few new resources are available to finance the government and pay the debt. Even supporters in the president's National Party are nervous about the gold swaps. Sen. Manuel Singlet described the transactions as ``irregular'' and said, ``The public interest cannot be managed this way.'' Lacalle, central bank president Diaz and Economy Minister Enrique Braga have refused to say whether the government will buy back more swapped gold. ``It is an asset of the country, part of the national patrimony which we can sell if it's more convenient to have ... foreign exchange than gold,'' Diaz said. If cash from the sale of gold is used to buy Uruguay's debt back at half price, he said, ``that would be like selling the gold for more than $700 an ounce.'' Sen. Daniel Astori of the leftist Broad Front coalition, an economist, spoke for the opposition: ``Uruguay should not be left without gold reserves in order to pay the foreign debt with private banks.''

DOC.HEAD: `Good Morning America' Turns 15 Years Old Today
DOC.TEXT: It's a little before 7 a.m. and weatherman Spencer Christian gestures at the bright blue backdrop while the magic of television cooks up the maps and graphics you see at home. ``Good Morning America,'' which celebrates its 15th birthday Friday, is about to go onto the air. Christian is doing the weather wrapup for ABC's early morning news, which originates in another studio. If you don't get into live TV studios very often, the surreal aspects of a grown man gesturing at a blank wall are quite droll. If you don't get up that early, it's not funny. It's not funny at all. ``You never get over the adversity of sleep deprivation,'' he tells a bleary-eyed visitor, smiling broadly. ``Imagine getting up every morning at 3:45 a.m., no matter what you've done the night before.'' Maybe it would make you gesture at blank walls, eh? Since Nov. 2, 1975, ``GMA'' has originated from the soothing dimness of ABC's cavernous Television Studio Number Two off Central Park on Manhattan's lower Upper West Side. The show, with host David Hartman and co-host Nancy Dussault, was designed by ABC's entertainment division as a lighter, feature-driven competitor for NBC News' aging ``Today'' show, which had been on the air since Jan. 14, 1952. The new show beat ``Today'' in the ratings, but ``Today'' got anchor Bryant Gumbel in 1982 and fought its way back on top. Hartman, who left in 1987, is expected back on TV in 1991 with a syndicated, weekday magazine show. ``Today'' was No. 1 from 1985 on, with ``GMA'' a strong second overall, beating the NBC show in key markets and demographic groups. By 1989, ``Today'' was fading and ``GMA'' gaining. Gumbel's infamous 1989 memorandum blasting other ``Today'' talent made public the show's internal strains. When executives engineered the departure of popular and longtime co-host Jane Pauley, ``Today'' slipped into No. 2. It's stayed there for 43 consecutive weeks. Today there's laughter and easy banter on the ``GMA'' set. Its cocoa browns, pink pastels and blond furniture are as familiar to some Americans as their own living rooms - and much more comfortable at 7 a.m. The co-hosts settle into the tan couch before two big, low-slung cameras, cross-angled for head-and-shoulders shots. The floor director relays the countdown, silent for the last three seconds. The camera's red light goes on. ``Good Morning, America, I'm Joan Lunden,'' she says. ``And I'm Charles Gibson,'' he says, and another edition of ``Good Morning America'' has begun. Two hours later, Gibson has interviewed White House chief of staff John Sununu; Ms. Lunden has interviewed a Houston woman cited for using a stadium men's room. And the final, hour-long segment of a series on AIDS has aired. The showis over and Ms. Lunden, Gibson and Christian are relaxing on the set. None of them has been with the show from the start. Ms. Lunden began as a consumer reporter in 1980. Christian joined in 1986, and Gibson took over from Hartman in 1987. With the departure of Jane Pauley, Ms. Lunden has become the longest-serving woman on morning television. ``I live here,'' she said. ``I just come down in the morning and dust off the sofa.'' All three acknowledge that their show's stability has contributed to its dominance in the ratings. ``I think at this time period in the morning, stability and consistency is always crucial,'' Ms. Lunden said. ``People ... don't like change. It's that one time period of the day that you don't have the freedom to fool around with it and change things.'' And the easygoing amiability that emanates from them doesn't fade when the camera goes dark. They seem genuinely to like one another. ``Are we conscious of the fact that it's necessary to maintain a harmonious relationship?'' said Gibson. ``Absolutely. Sure. You have to sublimate your ego, which for Spencer and I is very easy, but for Joan is very difficult.'' Barruump-bump! ``You talk about moody!'' Christian pitches in. ``We never know which Joan Lunden's going to show up! You talk about the seven faces of Eve, how about the 15 faces of ....'' The laughter bubbles out of them. It's good to be No. 1 in the morning ratings, Gibson said, but no one assumes ``GMA'' can't get knocked out of the top slot. ``It'll happen,'' he said. ``People will get tired of us and we'll move off. And hopefully we'll be as sanguine about moving in another direction as we were about the move up.'' --- Elsewhere in television ... ``HAMLET'' RETURNS TO PBS - Kevin Kline stars tonight on PBS in William Shakespeare's tragedy of Hamlet, a prince of Denmark. It's also his debut as a director on television, in the role that won him an Obie award when he directed himself in the title role onstage. This sumptuous modern-dress TV production, is a fine piece of work, beautifully adapted to the strengths and limitations of television. It's dark, intimate, obsessive. Tune in.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Fri PMs, Nov 2

DOC.HEAD: Peter Kann: Taking Charge at Dow Jones
DOC.TEXT: The newly designated leader at Dow Jones & Co. Inc. won a Pulitzer Prize for reporting at The Wall Street Journal, launched the paper's Asian edition and spent a decade apprenticing to the boss at the publishing and business information giant. But on a wall in his corner office, Peter R. Kann displays a whimsical drawing of a speckled green fish wrapped in a copy of the Journal. The Journal publisher, selected earlier this month to succeed retiring Warren H. Phillips as chief executive of Dow Jones on Jan. 1, is known as a smart, low-key and affable man who doesn't take himself too seriously. ``He has a fun-loving streak that makes him a lot of fun to be around,'' said the Journal's Washington bureau chief Albert Hunt. Kann, 47, once led Wall Street Journal bureau chiefs on late-night golf cart races on a Florida golf course. He lost $700 to the paper's bureau chiefs in a more recent poker game. Hunt recalls taking Kann, by then a Dow Jones executive, on a 1980 campaign trip with presidential candidate Ronald Reagan. Kann had complained to Hunt that the Washington press corps wasn't tough enough in its questioning of Reagan, so Hunt deferred to Kann when the pair was invited into Reagan's cabin on a flight between appearances. ``Pizza was being served as we walked in, and they spent the whole time talking about pizza,'' Hunt recalls. Kann grins when the story is recounted and concedes he ``got taken in'' by Reagan's affability. Nonetheless, Kann's associates say he is a good listener, a shrewd judge of people, a quick study and an able improvisor who gets the job done. Former Wall Street Journal reporter Seth Lipsky told the story of how Kann got past a skeptical border guard while on assignment covering the war in Southeast Asia in the 1970s. After the guard rejected every legitimate identification pass offered, Kann made a big flourish and produced a flashy new gasoline credit card. That impressed the guard, who let him pass. The ability to improvise may serve Kann well as he tries to steer Dow Jones through turbulent economic times and toward global growth. The slump in the financial services industry has staggered Dow Jones' earnings. Operating earnings were off 41.4 percent in the third quarter and 31.1 percent for the first nine months of the year. Advertising volume has fallen at the Journal, Barron's and the Ottaway Newspapers subsidiary. Losses are mounting from a new foreign exchange trading system at the company's Telerate financial information division. The company recently asked its divisions to hold 1991 spending at 1990 levels and boosted the Journal's cover price. Nonetheless, Moody's Investors Service Inc. cut its ratings this week on $200 million in Dow Jones debt. Kann said in an interview he is optimistic that Dow Jones will bounce back when the economy rebounds. Global expansion also will help, he said. The Journal, for instance, became the largest circulation daily newspaper in the United States despite competition from three national newspapers - USA Today, Investors Daily and the national edition of The New York Times - and intensified business coverage by local papers, he said. The growth also came despite corporate consolidations that eliminated jobs for thousands of middle managers who were avid Journal readers, he said. ``The paper has done pretty well in a very tough five-year period and it has an awful lot of potential to grow again in every sense,'' he said. But is an executive who grew up on the editorial side of the business best qualified to guide a company that last year got 57 percent of its earnings from electronic information services? Kann's supporters note Dow Jones has a tradition of having ex-editorial staffers at the helm, and say the experience makes them better top executives. The son of a history professor, Kann was graduated from Harvard. He joined the Journal as an intern in 1963 in San Francisco, worked in the Pittsburgh and Los Angeles bureaus and became a Vietnam War correspondent in 1967. His Pulitzer Prize in 1972 was for coverage of the war between India and Pakistan. The Journal started an Asian edition in 1976, and Kann became editor and publisher. ``It didn't seem ision that would affect the rest of my career at the time,'' he recalled. Three years later, Kann came home as assistant to the chairman, Phillips. He is succeeding Phillips as chief executive and it is widely expected he will becomsuch a grand dece chairman as well when Phillips retires from that post in July 1991. Kann became associate publisher of the Journal in 1979 and took on increasing responsibility within Dow Jones. He became publisher of the Journal in early 1989, a position he retains, and was elected president and chief operating officer of Dow Jones in July 1989. ``There never was any feeling there was a ceiling on his potential,'' said James Riordan, who has been a Dow Jones board member for more than 20 years. Kann is married to Karen Elliott House, a Pulitzer Prize-winning reporter for the Journal who is now vice president of Dow Jones' international group. They live with three children in Princeton, N.J. Bush has made no secret of the fact that he would like to see Saddam out of power, but has not made that a stated objective for the U.S. military deployed in the gulf. Their mission, he has said, is merely to push Saddam to remove his troops from Kuwait and restore the previous government there. However, Vice President Dan Quayle on Wednesday said in an interview on PBS' MacNeil-Lehrer Newshour, ``You cannot simply allow Saddam Hussein to have this military power and have the technology into the future.'' ``I believe that the world certainly understands that. A Saddam Hussein who has ballistic missiles, who has chemical capability, biological capability, who would like to have the nuclear capability, cannot continue to have that capability even if he withdraws from Kuwait,'' Quayle said. Deputy National Security Adviser Bob Gates, traveling with Bush on Thursday, said Quayle's comments did not indicate a shift in U.S. objectives. Bush spent the first half of his day at campaign appearances in Burlington and Mashpee, Massachusetts, for GOP gubernatorial candidate William Weld and Senate candidate James Rappaport. After stopping in Florida and then Cincinnati, he was traveling Friday to Minnesota, Iowa and California. Bush on Thursday spent less time blasting Democrats on budget and other issues and more talking about the gulf crisis. ``I want you to put politics aside,'' he told an audience in Mashpee. Fitzwater said that Bush was urged to continue his attack on Democrats ``in certain quarters ... but he surveyed the whole matter and decided this was the best approach.'' The gulf matter, said Fitzwater, ``is a very serious and far reaching problem,'' and the president wanted to talk about it to his audiences despite the potential for allegations that he was politicizing the crisis. ``We want a public debate'' over new developments in the Persian Gulf, Fitzwater said. As to Saddam offer to allow hostage families to visit their relatives in Iraq and occupied Kuwait over the Christmas holidays, Fitzwater called it Saddam's ``latest ploy'' and said it would be better for the Iraqi to let the hostages come home for Thanksgiving.

DOC.BYLINE: Cold War Is Over; Where Are All the Spies? ^By TERRENCE PETTY
DOC.TEXT: The Cold War is over, but not all the spies have come in. Markus Wolf, the East German master spy, may be in Moscow, maybe not. Klaus Kuron, who tracked Wolf's operatives for West Germany, is accused of being a double agent. Germany was a crossroads for spies in the 1930s and became a hive of espionage after World War II, when Hitler's secret agents went to work for East or West, depending on where they were captured. Spies penetrated the highest ranks on both sides; a West German chancellor was brought down when his top aide was exposed as a Communist agent. There was a saying in intelligence circles that West Germany had more spies per acre than any place in the world. Some were captured and exchanged. They walked across Glienicke, the ``bridge of spies'' that spans the Havel River, passing each other without turning their heads. It is easy to imagine the ghosts of George Smiley and Karla lurking there on a silent, snowy night. What of the future? Cold War or no, Germany is the center of Europe, the powerhouse that will drive the continent. Whether for industrial, political or military purposes, the spies are certain to be here. Lutz Stavenhagen, security aide to Chancellor Helmut Kohl, believes some will be from Moscow because what goes on in the new Germany is ``of enormous interest for the Soviets.'' Even Bonn, the dowdy little capital on the Rhine, has long exuded an atmosphere of intrigue. Communist spies infiltrated government offices, including the chancellery. Guenter Guillaume attached himself to Chancellor Willy Brandt, the architect of ``ostpolitik,'' the opening the the East, and Brandt was forced to resign in 1974. During the war, the Allies had secret agents in the Third Reich, gathering intelligence and aiding the resistance. Immediately afterward, Berlin was infested with spies, a window of easy passage for agents hunting secrets. It was ``the most productive intelligence collection center in the world,'' Peter Wyden, a German-born American author, wrote in ``Wall,'' published just before the Berlin Wall was opened last year. ``Counting the delegations from Greece and Norway, 86 separate intelligence operations stumbled over each other's tracks'' in Berlin, he said. Wyden wrote that the CIA alone had 40 ``safe houses'' in Berlin at one time, as shelters and meeting places for control officers and their agents. In the mid-1950s, the CIA and Britain's MI6 undertook one of the most extraordinary espionage operations of the Cold War, digging a tunnel from which they tapped communications between KGB headquarters in East Berlin and Moscow. According to Wyden and some other writers, the Soviets knew of the operation and played along to protect an important ``mole'' in Western intelligence. Many writers, John le Carre and Wyden among them, have questioned the competence of Western intelligence operations in Berlin. Wyden, for example, points out that the West was surprised when the wall went up in August 1961. Le Carre transformed spies from superheroes into lonely men plying a questionable trade. Perhaps his most dramatic evocation of the image was in ``The Spy Who Came in From the Cold,'' when the aging British agent Leamas and an innocent friend are shot down at the wall, victims of a double cross. The list of real spies who found fame, infamy or death in Germany seems endless. There was George Blake, a British agent unmasked in 1960 as one of the most damaging sources of information for the KGB. Heinz ``Fiffi'' Felfe, a former Nazi SS officer hired by West German intelligence, was considered one of the finest spy fighters - until 1961, when he was found to be a double agent for the KGB. Wolf, the master spy known as ``Misha,'' ran a string of agents and ``moles'' in West Germany who got their hands on some of NATO's most precious secrets. He scored coup after coup in West Germany, sending East German agents across the border as refugees to infiltrate government, intelligence and industry. Wolf ran Guillaume, who ended Brandt's career as chancellor. If East German agents couldn't get into the government themselves, they went after people already there. Intelligence officials tell of one ``Romeo'' agent who used several aliases in seducing West German government secretaries to obtain secrets. In June at Koblenz, Clyde Lee Conrad, a retired U.S. Army sergeant, was convicted of treason for spying. Conrad, who had been in charge of a vault filled with classified documents, was part of a ring that sold Army and NATO secrets to the Soviet bloc. Betraying the information could have started a world war, the judge said, and sentenced Conrad to life in prison. Western nations ran their own espionage operations in the Communist East, sometimes with fatal consequences. Double agent Horst Galau was arrested by East Germany in 1985 and died three years later in Bautzen prison. East German officials said he hanged himself, but West German intelligence said it might have been murder. Germany is united now, but spy scandals continue. The arrest of Klaus Kuron might have been enough to destroy the government a few years ago. His surrender Oct. 7, however, seemed merely to underscore the old assumption that East Germany had seriously compromised West German intelligence. At least 12 other alleged spies were arrested in connection with the Kuron case and dozens more are on the run. Officials say some have been taken over by the KGB. Intelligence officers expect spying to continue in Germany, but now that the Soviet bloc has collapsed, there is no more flavor of a morality play. ``One shouldn't see this in a moralistic way,'' a German official said. ``Fashion designers send their own snoops off to see what the competition will have in the latest collection. That's not much different from espionage.''

DOC.HEAD: Black, Blind and Successful in South Africa
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: By his own reckoning, Brian Mashile should have become a blind begger. Instead, he made himself into a successful lawyer. Eleven years ago, Mashile was a poor black teen-ager who had lost his sight in an assault. His mother was dead and his father worked far from home. No one in his family had completed high school. He lived in one of the worst slums of a nation that offers little opportunity to blacks even if they are not handicapped. His options were limited, but his determination was not. Today, at 30, Mashile works for a leading corporate law firm that has two other black attorneys. ``I am motivated every time I think of the alternative, he said. ``The alternative would be to go to the streets and become a beggar.'' Mashile succeeded in a country where apartheid laws and crushing poverty have made black achievers an exception. Before he was blinded, he dreamed of being a doctor, but never told anyone for fear of ridicule. In Alexandra, a poor black township next to Johannesburg's wealthy white suburbs, youthful dreams usually die in the day-to-day struggle for survival. Goats and dogs roam the streets, competing for scraps of rotting garbage. The pungent smell mixes with eye-watering smoke from coal fires and the choking dust of the orange dirt streets. ``To leave this was almost beyond my comprehension,'' Mashile said of Alexandra. He was the youngest of six children, in a two-room house without electricity, running water or indoor plumbing. His mother died when he was 10 and his father worked as a gold miner, hundreds of miles away. At 16, he quit school to work as a delivery man and saved money to return to Alexandra High School a year later. Then, one night in 1979, four men attacked him and a friend on an Alexandra street. One hit Mashile in the face with a wooden stick that sent shards of his glasses into his eyes. He was blinded in the right eye and the left only distinguishes light from dark. In the hospital, he cried for weeks. ``Why me?'' he said. ``You just can't find an answer. After you cry, you get angry, and finally you decide to become rational and say, `What am I going to do with my life?''' Mashile's depression lifted when he fell in love with a nurse. ``It was the first time I felt I could be accepted as a blind person,'' he said. ``My whole attitude changed.'' The relationship didn't last, but his motivation did. In 1981, when he was 21, Mashile returned to Alexandra High School, his guidance stick in one hand, a portable typewriter in the other. He graduated two years later with the highest marks of 70 students. He was accepted at Johannesburg's University of the Witwatersrand, one of South Africa's most respected schools. The campus is only a few miles from Alexandra, but neither Mashile nor anyone he knew had set foot on its manicured lawns. Mashile painstakingly transcribed classroom lectures into braille. He had o rely on fellow students to read to him. For three years as an undergraduate and three more as a law student, he began classes at 9 a.m. and often would study past midnight. ``He never asked for favors,'' said Tony Leon, one of Mashile's law professors and now a member of Parliament. ``He never missed an assignment, even though everything took him much longer to do than it would a sighted person.'' For any black to become a lawyer is noteworthy. Three-fourths of South Africa's 40 million people are black, but only about 500 of the 7,000 lawyers are black. After graduation in 1988, Mashile applied to 30 law firms. Only three interviewed him, and they were skeptical. His one job offer came from Edward Nathan and Friedland, a corporate firm with more than 50 lawyers. The young lawyer has ``done everything we expect without any special assistance,'' said Pierre Ferreira, head of the litigation department where Mashile works. He has applied for a scholarship to study labor law in the United States and, if accepted into the program, hopes to attend an Ivy League school, the University of Michigan or the University of California at Berkeley. Mashile has a voice computer and an assistant whose whose salary is subsidized by the government because of Mashile's handicap. Beyond that, he functions as any other lawyer. He does not tell clients he is black or blind before they meet him. They arrive on the 23rd floor of one of the city's sleekest buildings to find a handsome young attorney in a conservative suit with a thin mustache, a wisp of a beard and sunglasses. ``Welcome. You are going to be led by a blind man,'' Mashile says by way of introduction. Last year, another lawyer from the firm always appeared in court with Mashile. This year, he's on his own. ``He's got a gift for appearing in court,'' Ferreira said. ``He examines witnesses extremely well because he retains everything, whereas a sighted person would keep referring back to his notes.'' Mashile assesses his performance more modestly. ``I've messed up some,'' he said. ``I've had judges yell at me. I don't like it, but it makes me know I'm not getting any special treatment.'' He still lives in Alexandra, but in a small, modern, four-room house with a garden, which he shares with two relatives. From habit, Mashile rises at 4 a.m. He exercises and is off to the glass and steel towers of Johannesburg by 7 a.m. He jogs often, holding hands with a friend who runs at his side. Every Friday, he visits his old friends at the university and meets his girlfriend. He still misses playing soccer. ``I have achieved many things I once only dreamed of,'' Mashile said. ``Maybe blindness was a blessing in disguise.''

DOC.HEAD: Throw the Rascals Out, but Leave My Rascal Alone
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: On one point, at least, politicians agree: voters are fed up with politicians. But the voters may not do much about it in the congressional elections on Tuesday. After all, when it comes time to vote, the choice is between politicians. Even when the mood is sour, and people are complaining about Congress, they tend to approve the performance of their own congressmen. It's other people's incumbents they want fired. In 73 of the nation's 100 congressional elections, at least 80 percent of the House incumbents who sought new terms got them, according to a Library of Congress study. It hit 98 percent in 1986 and 1988. Incumbent re-election rates in the House have exceeded 90 percent in every election since 1968 save one - the Watergate year of 1974. The Senate's incumbent re-election rate isn't quite as high, but it still points to the advantage of being there - 85 percent of those who sought new terms in 1988 won them. House incumbents certainly can't count being as safe as those of the 1988 elections, when only seven congressmen ran and lost. The average during the past two decades has far higher - 24. But strategists in both parties agree that this year, only about 25, and certainly no more than 30 congressmen are up against challengers who stand a realistic chance of ousting them. The powers of incumbency are one reason. Another is that the Republicans didn't gain seats in the last election, when they won the White House again: They actually lost three. Off-year elections often have reversed the coattail winners of the presidential year. There aren't many to reverse this time - with 259 House seats, Democratic strength is the highest it has ever been two years into the term of a Republican president. Sixty-one incumbents are running unopposed, 18 more have no major party challenger. So, for all the signs of frustration and anger at Congress, it would take an upheaval of historic proportions for incumbent bashing to bloom into wholesale incumbent beating. But the Republicans' most visible national campaigners certainly are trying. President Bush says voters can ``vent their frustration, their anger, and the betrayal they felt'' by ousting incumbent Democrats. ``The American people are fed up to here with incumbents,'' says Vice President Dan Quayle, taking his argument to unlikely lengths by claiming it is Democrats who really are in trouble, never mind Bush's dive in the polls or the discomfort of some Republicans over administration turnaround on taxes and the worsening economic situation. Bush and Quayle are talking about Democratic incumbents, and while there are more of them, the tactic does have an ironic side. Republicans boasted early in the season of a strong lineup of Senate challengers, with five GOP House members running against Democratic senators. Now that undercuts their own anti-incumbent argument - those GOP challengers are part of the same unpopular Congress. Four of the five are trailing in the pre-election polls. The hole in the campaign against incumbency is that while most people are saying they don't approve of the way Congress is doing its job, they tend to support their own congressman. In an ABC News-Washington Post poll, 63 percent of the people said they disapproved of Congress, though 64 percent said they approved of the job their own member is doing. Bush's job approval rating, however, was 55 percent, down 20 points in two months. While that may affect Republican fortunes now, Gov. Richard F. Celeste of Ohio, chairman of the Democratic Governors Association, thinks ``the longer-term fallout is going to be equally on Democratic members of Congress.'' ``I think people are fed up,'' he said, and may show it by staying home, keeping down the turnout in an off year, when it is likely to be low anyhow. ``That may be the place where we most see the reaction against incumbents.'' Curtis Gans, director of the Committee for the Study of the American Electorate, anticipates a voter turnout similar to that of 1986, when 36.4 percent of eligible voters actually cast ballots. That was the lowest since the wartime election of 1942. In modern elections, the rate at which congressional incumbents have returned to office has ranged between 82 and 86 percent. That's likely to hold, too. Dissatisfaction notwithstanding, the next Congress probably will look a lot like the one that just struggled to adjournment. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Walter R. Mears, vice president and columnist for The Associated Press, has reported on Washington and national politics for more than 25 years.

DOC.HEAD: Novelist Sets New Book in Her Own `Haunted' 130-Year-Old Mansion
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The park ranger leads a gaggle of tourists up to the elaborate cast-iron fence and points to the big violet-gray house with three styles of Greek columns. ``This house was built in 1857. The hexagonal bay was added in 1869. ... Do you know who lives here?'' Its owner, novelist Anne Rice, gives a different tour: The house as setting for ``The Witching Hour,'' her new novel about a line of women seduced by an evil spirit that wants to take flesh. The sunny porch is where the witch Dierdre Mayfair sat, drugged senseless but still entranced by her demonic lover's murmurs. The swimming pool outside was filled with champagne for Stella Mayfair's gaudy parties. Rice points to a tall door in the hallway. ``That's the elevator. I gave Stella the elevator. ... It was, in fact, put in by a woman by the name of Pamela Starr Clapp, who's supposed to haunt this house. But I haven't seen her.'' Rice said Mrs. Clapp lived in the house from 1867 to 1932, and she's heard that the previous owners saw her apparition in the dining room. Even though it was said to be a good presence rather than a malevolent one, Rice would just as soon not see it herself. ``I've never talked to the previous owners myself. I guess I should. But I'm scared of the dark and being alone, and I don't encourage apparitions,'' she said. ``If they're there, I don't want to see them. I'm not sure I could survive it mentally.'' This from a woman made famous by a series of sensuous novels about vampires, a woman whose next book is ``In the Frankenstein Tradition.'' ``The supernatural novel is a wonderful frame for what I want to do. But I haven't seen ghosts myself,'' she said. What she wants to do is write serious books that are both enjoyable and unforgettable, though she's also written sadomasochistic pornography under the name A.N. Roquelaure and erotic contemporary novels as Anne Rampling. Why the supernatural? ``I really don't know. You might as well ask John Updike why he writes about New England. You write what works for you.'' Rice, 49, also has written two non-supernatural novels under her own name: ``Cry to Heaven'' about the 18th-century opera singers who underwent castration to keep their beautiful soprano voices, and ``The Feast of All Saints,'' about the free people of color who lived in New Orleans in the 1800s. The supernatural, she says, allows her to pull together all the disparate elements of her life. ``I like to talk about history, I like to write from a larger perspective, see our lives as if from the outside. All that works wonderfully when I'm writing about an immortal - an imagined character that is immortal.'' Her mad scientist's creation in ``In the Frankenstein Tradition'' also provides an outside view. ``It gives me again the grand perspective on humans - a way to talk about humanity that is completely fresh,'' she said. The advance from ``The Witching Hour'' gave her the money to buy the house. She had already finished about five chapters, with the story set in a different kind of house. After moving, she switched the locale. The macabre is an occasional note in her decorations: a small skull on the mantelpiece above her doll collection, a life-sized carved wooden skeleton in a burgundy velvet chair facing 12-year-old Chris' mini-trampoline. She and her husband, poet Stan Rice, 47, and their son moved from San Francisco because Rice wanted to return to the city she left when she was 15 years old. ``I was dying to come home. ... I never got New Orleans out of my blood. I would feel cravings for New Orleans that were positively physical. I would turn off songs like `Do You Know What It Means to Miss New Orleans.''' They moved into another house in July 1988, then bought the $1.2 million mansion a few blocks away at 1239 First Street, in the Garden District. The house, identified by a plaque on the woven iron fence as ``Rosegate - the Brevard-Clapp House,'' is light and airy, not brooding or gloomy. ``We spent a lot of time bringing light into it,'' said Rice. ``It was a great deal darker before we painted it.'' The tour continues. This half-tester bed, with the gathered green velvet panel high above the head, is where both Deirdre and her ancestor, Mary Beth, died. Antha leaped or was shoved out of this many-paned floor-to-ceiling window in the front bedroom. ``They're very, very real. But the house is real in a totally different dimension,'' said Rice. ``You know, I don't walk around this house thinking about the Mayfair witches. It's my house. And the real history of this house is significant. ``Eisenhower has visited this house, President Carter slept here, and the author Eudora Welty came here once. ... Judge John Minor Wisdom lived here for a year. He was a great desegregation hero. ... That's more vital to me, day in and day out.'' Park ranger Gilbert Campa would agree. The house has been part of the Garden District tour as long as the National Park Service has been giving it, he said. ``This fence, they say, is the prototype for chain-link fence,'' he told the tourists. Some characters have another peculiar sort of reality. When Rice was a child, her mother told her that when Charles Dickens was writing ``The Old Curiosity Shop,'' people waited on a New York pier for the ship carrying the next installment from England. ``People yelled from the shore, `Is Little Nell dead?' The captain yelled, `Yes,' and people sat down and cried. I want to make people do that.'' And in the past couple of years, she said, two women have called - Rice's telephone number is listed - to ask if her vampires were real. When she said no, the women burst into tears. ``I was deeply, deeply touched. Here was this woman on the phone crying because Lestat was not real. ... They believed that it happened. I know I believe it - that's a foregone conclusion. But to make somebody else believe it - that was a very, very important moment.'' At least some of ``The Witching Hour'' characters will return. Rice said she hadn't planned a sequel at first, but friends who read the book wanted to learn what happens to protagonist Michael Curry. ``Everything I wanted to put in it was there. But afterward, the first people I showed it to would ask, `What happens next? You have to get Michael out of there,' is what they would say. `You can't do that to Michael.'''

DOC.HEAD: Mercury Danger Rises Across the Country
DOC.TEXT: Poisonous mercury is spewing unregulated out of the nation's smokestacks and reaching dangerous levels in soil, plants and animals. Twenty states from Florida to Minnesota to California have limited or banned consumption of fish from some lakes and streams. One of the highest mercury concentrations in the country is poisoning the once-pristine Everglades, and has been blamed for the death of at least one endangered Florida panther. Scientists and environmental groups are pointing the finger at two mercury emission sources left unregulated by the Environmental Protection Agency - coal-fired energy plants and the fastest-growing threat, trash-burning municipal incinerators. ``In the past, we would take our mercury wastes and bury them so they would contaminate the ground water in just one place,'' said Gary Glass, an EPA mercury researcher in Duluth, Minn. ``Now we've gotten smarter - we're blowing it into the air so it can go everywhere.'' Washington-based Clean Water Action, using data supplied by industry and the EPA, reported last month that 187 incinerators nationwide emit almost 75,000 pounds of mercury each year. Ninety more incinerators are planned. Massachusetts, New York, Florida and Ohio led the list, but all but four states have incinerators emitting mercury; those four are planning facilities. ``Mercury emissions have doubled in the last decade and will probably double again if all planned incinerators are brought on line,'' warned Henry Cole, who helped write Clean Water Action's study. Mercury comes from a variety of sources in trash, including batteries, paints, dyes, electronics, fluorescent lights, plastics - and even yard cuttings, which have picked up the contaminant from previous airborne pollution. Municipal garbage-burning plants spread the indestructable mercury by heating it into a vapor that can travel 200 miles, said Paul Connett, a chemistry professor at St. Lawrence University in Canton, N.Y. The mercury ultimately settles in soil and water. It accumulates exceptionally well in moist peat, helping to explain the high Everglades readings. But a California study found forest canopies can collect mercury even under drier conditions. The poison moves up the food chain, concentrating more at each level, a process called biomagnification. From soil it travels to plants, fish, and on to rccoons, otters, eagles and other predators - including people. Concentrations found in fish at one Minnesota lake have increased 5 percent a year since 1970, according to a Minnesota Pollution Control Agency study. In humans, mercury can damage the brain, liver, kidney and blood, and is often characterized by tremors and confusion. It also causes deformations in fetuses. Cole is researching whether mercury collects in breast milk. As Glass observed, incinerators were initially hailed as a solution to keep mercury and other toxic wastes out of landfills, where they often leached into groundwater. But only belatedly have studies shown that the scrubber and filter technology that cleans smoke of toxic gasses fails to work on mercury. Ray Morrison, mercury project officer for the EPA, said a recent check of California incinerators showed that instead of pollution control devices collecting 70 percent of the mercury as expected, ``the collection rate is dropping off to zero.'' Some states have adopted their own mercury emission levels, but environmentalists say EPA acted too little and too late on airborne mercury contamination. There are no mercury emissions limits for the trash-burning facilities, although the agency expects to have some in place by December, EPA spokesman David Ryan said. ``Obviously we think mercury is a problem, and we are moving on it,'' he said. Under EPA pressure, battery makers have drastically cut the amount of mercury they use, and mercury fungicides are being removed from paints. But Ryan acknowledged there are no plans to limit mercury from coal-burning energy plants, believed to be the biggest source of contamination in some parts of the country. EPA critics, while welcoming the incinerator standards, complain that even those proposed standards are based on direct inhalation of mercury, not accumulation in the environment. In the meantime, incinerators face growing opposition. Environmental officials in Ontario sued Detroit's municipal incinerator, the largest in the United States, angered in part because of excess mercury emissions that forced Michigan to shut the facility down briefly in April. A trash-burning incinerator in Stanislaus County, Calif., was found to have excessive mercury emissions and was told to suspend operations by the state. The Georgia environmental group Citizen Action has publicly blamed mercury contamination in the Turtle and Brunswick rivers on the state's only operating municipal waste incinerator, nearby in Savannah. Greenpeace in Florida has blasted the giant incinerators ringing the Everglades on the Gulf and Southeast coast. Scientists around the world cite the moist, peat-filled Everglades as having the ideal meteorolgical and biological conditions for concentrating mercury. Europeans have acted faster than Americans. In June, scientists at an international conference in Sweden declared airborne contamination the largest source of the problem and said concentrations worldwide are reaching dangerous levels. The Netherlands imposed tough new regulations on incinerators after finding widespread mercury contamination. Germany, where some doctors in Bavaria warn mothers not to breastfeed because of mercury, is also tightening restrictions. Clean Water's study concludes that tougher regulations and better technology are required to deal with mercury contamination in the United States. But environmentalists warn that pollution control is not enough. Mercury, they note, cannot be destroyed and remains in the environment forever. ``People have to demand recycling,'' said Brian Hunt, southern regional toxics coordinator for Greenpeace. ``Mercury is a global pollutant, and there is no pollution control equipment that captures all of it. We must never, never burn garbage.''

DOC.HEAD: New Drug Does Wonders for Some Who Can Afford It
DOC.TEXT: At 19, Nancy W. became sure she was being followed - her first symptom of acute schizophrenia that would for 10 years turn reality into a protean monster, holding her hostage to delusion and paranoia. It would drive her to live in a car, emerging late at night to eat from tin cans in her parents' kitchen. She was in and out of mental hospitals, and spent six months roaming the East Coast alone. Communication became impossible. ``She just did not have that ability at all - to laugh, to cry,'' said her father, George W., of Hampstead, in a voice as flat as the emotional terrain he described. Nancy never will eliminate the chemical mbalance spawning the demons in her brain. But with a new anti-psychotic drug, she coexists with them in guarded neutrality. At 29, she has her own apartment in Salem and takes courses at a community college. The drug clozapine, marketed as Clozaril, has elicited similar success stories, particularly among severely ill people whom other medications have failed. Unlike other drugs prescribed for schizophrenia, such as thorazine and prolixin, clozapine doesn't cause involuntary facial tremors known as tardive dyskinesia - a condition that is sometimes irreversible. Many of those ``cured'' by clozapine are described as having awakened. George W. and his wife, Catherine, saw almost immediate improvement in Nancy. ``We got our daughter back. She got herself back,'' he said. Clozapine is touted by many experts as the first significant breakthrough in psychopharmacology in 30 years, and the harbinger of a new wave of anti-psychotics. But its cost - $9,000 a year per patient - has some in the mental health community up in arms. Nationally, the Food and Drug Administration estimates 200,000 severe schizophrenics could benefit from the drug. But because of the cost, only about 7,000 people are taking it. Pennsylvania will spend $2 million this fiscal year to treat schizophrenics with clozapine in state hospitals, enough for about 220 patients. Officials say there are 4,500 schizophrenics among the 7,000 patients in Pennsylvania's state hospitals. A coalition of mental health groups in Pennsylvania has sued seeking to require the state to buy clozapine for all eligible patients in its hospital system. A group of patients in New York also has sued trying to force that state to offer Medicaid reimbursement for clozapine. In Kansas, a federal judge's ruling requires Medicaid to pay for the drug. Last month, New Hampshire approved spending $135,000 for the drug, enough to treat only a few of an estimated 250 people who could benefit from it, said Mental Health Director Donald Shumway. Shumway, along with counterparts in other states, is trying to negotiate a lower price with clozapine's sole U.S. manufacturer, Sandoz Pharmaceuticals Corp. of East Hanover, N.J. Much of the cost is for monitoring patients for agranulocytosis, a potentially fatal side effect that reduces the level of infection-fighting white blood cells. Studies have shown the condition can be reversed if caught early. Under the monitoring system, a home health care company distributes the medication each week and collects blood samples for analysis. Administrators say the monitoring could be done much more cheaply by state hospitals. Shumway tried to cut costs by taking over the monitoring from Sandoz. ``They're willing to let us do the work, they're just not willing to reduce the price once we do the work,'' he said. Six states, led by Minnesota, have threatened antitrust lawsuits, and legislation has been introduced in Congress to make the drug more affordable, Shumway said. The company won't budge. ``All the states are talking to us. We have a fixed price for a fixed set of services and I don't think that price is going to change much,'' said Sandoz spokesman David Winter. The root of the problem is ``that the states don't wan't to put money into take care of the mentally ill,'' he said. Agranulocytosis occurs in 1 percent to 2 percent of patients taking clozapine. Shumway said many medications have similar risks, and manufacturers are never the only ones liable if something goes wrong. He said the drug is available at a fraction of the cost in Europe, where governments do the monitoring. ``Remember you have national (health) systems in Europe,'' said Winter. ``There are obvious differences in the systems: differences in the approach toward liability and medical issues.'' Sandoz, citing competitive reasons, hasn't broken down its clozapine costs in the United States. While financially strapped state governments scoff at what they consider the company's liability paranoia and accuse it of reaping tremendous profits, some doctors sympathize with Sandoz. ``The litigation issue is an enormous issue,'' said John Docherty, medical director at Brookside Hospital in Nashua, N.H. ``It's a big problem in this country if you take a look at the number of lawsuits here vs. in Europe or in Japan.'' Brookside helped test the drug before Sandoz began marketing it in February. Schizophrenia, considered the most disabling and serious of all mental illnesses, afflicts 1 percent of the U.S. population. Symptoms generally appear in early adulthood and include high anxiety, confusion, language and reasoning problems, hallucinations and withdrawal. ``A lot of times, it's a problem with how clear you think or how able you are to connect your thoughts,'' Nancy said in deliberate, measured phrases. For her and others, clozapine is a protective shield. ``It's a very good drug for keeping away thoughts that should not be there,'' she said. ``It helps keep what is happening in real life apart from that which is not there.''

DOC.HEAD: Diseases Ravage Trees of World's Biggest Cork Producer
DOC.TEXT: Forestry experts are asking cork oak plantation owners and bark strippers to come up with measures to stop the rot in the evergreen trees that produce more than half the world's cork. Pests and disease have spread because of years of tree neglect, attempts to increase production on shallow soil and careless and excessive bark stripping. An estimated 20 percent of Portugal's cork oak forests have been decimated and infection could reach epidemic level, experts say. Spain, responsible for an additional 25 percent of world production, is also threatened. Farmers from the worst-hit region south of Lisbon commissioned a four-year study by Lisbon's Agricultural Institute to pinpoint the causes and help save trees. ``By the time the causes of tree deaths have been analyzed, the trees might all be dead,'' said Joao Bentes, assistant director of Portugal's Forestry Commission. Raul Sardinha of Lisbon's Agronomy Institute said the problems date to agrarian reforms introduced after the leftist army revolution in 1974, when plantations run by absentee landlords in central and southern Portugal were turned into cooperatives. State subsidies promoted growing cereal cash crops among the oaks, which only turn a profit long-term. Modern machinery that replaced the traditional mule-drawn plough damaged the roots of the trees. Government statistics show a 14 percent drop in cork production from 1969-77 to 1978-86, the two nine-year stripping cycles. Some experts say the figure is low. Only three-quarters of the 4 million acres of cork forest in Portugal is in full production. Cork prices have rocketed. Edmundo Pereira, president of the Cork Industrialists and Exporters Association, said top-quality cork sold at 20 cents a kilogram (2.2 pounds) in 1982, while last year, medium-quality cork fetched nearly $2 a kilogram. Now, although some of the land is back in the hands of its former owners, and government and European Economic Community aid is available to cork farmers, there's no rush to plant new oaks. ``The man who starts a cork plantation today must have his grandchildren in mind,'' said Ewan Rankin, who runs his family's forest northeast of Lisbon. It takes 25 to 30 years before an acorn grows into a tree that will produce its first harvest, he said. Apparently worried about spreading disease, the government last year hired 300 new rangers to enforce forestry regulations, particularly regarding cork stripping - a craft traditionally passed from father to son. But Ranki and others say that is not enough. ``There should be more research into genetic growing in nurseries, because now it's only after 30 years that you know whether a tree is of good or bad quality,'' he said. The Portuguese wine trade is probably the hardest-hit by the cork crisis. Cork stopper quality has fallen as prices have risen. Wine-producing countries like France and the United States are threatening to switch to plastic stoppers. ``I cannot imagine drinking a good wine with a plastic stopper in the bottle. It has to do with the dignity with which good wine has to be served,'' said Jose Cyrillo Machado of Abrigada, a vineyard north of Lisbon. Cork has been used to stop wine bottles since the 5th century B.C.

DOC.HEAD: Researchers Hope To Change America's Diet
DOC.TEXT:
Nutritionists say many Americans don't buy enough of the food that's good for them, so Iowa State hopes to change what consumers want. ``We demand fuel efficient cars that protect us in a crash; there's no reason you shouldn't demand the same for food,'' said university researcher Murry Kaplan. When Americans get hungry, they reach for fat and sugar, Kaplan said. ``We know what's good for people, but they won't listen. Dietary advice has been a failure.'' Iowa State soon will take bids for a $6.5 million Center for Designing Foods to Improve Nutrition, where researchers will investigate what drives people to buy thed how to make nutritional products more tasty. ``The center will be the only one of its kind in the countr food they do any to tie together the two ends of the food chain - food production and human consumption,'' said Beverly Crabtree, dean of the university's College of Family and Consumer Science. ``Researchers will start with what consumers want or need, whether it be low-fat meats or better-tasting soy products, and alter food production techniques to develop the new foods,'' she said. Kaplan, acting coordinator of the center, said the country seems to be ignoring all the hehour from The Associated Press. The General Desk supervisor is Marty Sutphin (212-621-1602). DOC.HEAD: Retransmitting to correct release date
Harvard Uses Hypermedia To Study Turnpike
DOC.TEXT: With the tap of a computer key, Boston's suburbs flit by on the screen and you're out on the Massachusetts Turnpike, traveling at 12,000 miles an hour. ``We'll be in New York in about 40 seconds,'' said Stephen Ervin, assistant professor of landscape architecture at Harvard University. Last year, the Massachusetts Turnpike Authority asked Harvard's Graduate School of Design to develop a framework for the turnpike's safety, structure and appearance. Harvard dreamed up what is called hypermedia - ``pictures and graphs and text all tied together in a database,'' Ervin said. Carl Steinitz, professor of landscape architecture, spent four days with a film crew, taking photos of the entire 135-mile highway from Boston west to the New York border. Steinitz and Ervin compiled the photos on computer and linked the location of each image to map data. The database also includes information on local zoning laws and population densities. ``We have a connection between visual information - what does it look like - and a map form - where is it, what are some of the attributes about it,'' Ervin said. For example, the hypermedia system can confirm visually that a certain stretch of road has room for a truckstop. It also can check to see if the noisy truck stop would be too close to neighborhoods. Steinitz and Ervin gave their creation to graduate students as a project. Using image processing, the students painted in pylons or banks of flowers on images of the road on the computer screen. They also explored putting rest stops close to nature trails or near Springfield to promote the city's mill town heritage. ``It means that you can be very creative ahead of time as you make plans for the turnpike,'' said Ann Hershfang, vice chairwoman of the turnpike authority. Turnpike engineers want to start using the hypermedia program within the next few years, Hershfang said. ``It can help us with accidents, it can help us with snow clearing, it can help us with safety in a lot of ways.'' Major computer companies are working on hypermedia systems, which require little new technology but could have a broad impact on highway engineering, Steinitz said. The system could even help police determine why accidents occur in certain places. ``Do these all happen on a downhill slope in Christmas when its icy?'' Ervin said. ``Well, we have all the data now to be able to check some of that stuff out.''
