DOC.HEAD: Filmmakers Say Octopuses Have Gentle Tentacles
DOC.TEXT: For filmmaker Victoria Stone, the brush of a gentle tentacle across her lips was ``quite nice.'' The encounter occurred when Stone and her partner Mark Deeble, who are making a documentary on giant octopuses for the British Broadcasting Corp., were diving in Puget Sound. One of their eight-armed subjects stretched a tentacle and softly touched Stone's lips - the only part of her body not covered by wetsuit. ``It was quite nice,'' she said. ``I could feel one sucker come down, and then the next, and then the next.'' The tender meeting was no surprise to the filmmakers, who know the octopus as a good-natured, intelligent creature that has been miscast as a horror film man-hungry villain. The team also found that octopuses quickly learn to recognize people and react to their presence by swimming excitedly. ``These are not non-feeling, gooey entities,'' said Brian Baldissin, the zoo's marine education specialist who has taught Pacific octopuses how to open a plastic container to get at crabmeat inside. He and the filmmakers found the animals are adept at negotiating mazes and opening a series of doors that swing in different directions. ``It's very dramatic what they're capable of,'' Deeble said. ``Just from what we've seen, I believe octopuses are on a par with dogs and cats in terms of intelligence.'' The film is scheduled for January in the ``National Geographic Explorer'' series on British and American public television. ---
DOC.HEAD: Acute Shortage of X-Ray Technologists
DOC.TEXT: Hospital workers who operate X-ray equipment and related high-tech machinery say staffing shortages are worsening in their field, partly because people seeking careers are unaware of the opportunities. ``A lot of people - when they think about careers in health care - think `doctors and nurses,''' said Arlene Adler, a radiology educator who met over the weekend with other members of a coalition called the Summit on Manpower. The Summit, which comprises 18 groups including the American College of Radiology and the American Hospital Association, says 3 percent to 15 percent of hospital positions for X-ray technologists are going unfilled. For nuclear medicine technologists, who use radioactive drugs to take pictures of the body, vacancy rates also range from 3 percent to 15 percent. For radiation therapy technologists, the rates are higher, 5 percent to 21 percent. And for sonographers, rates are 4 percent to 17 percent. Government studies indicate that radiological and related technology jobs will be among the top 10 in demand by 2000, said Ms. Adler, director of the Radiologic Technology Program at Indiana University Northwest in Gary. Radiology and sonography positions usually require two years of course work after high school. Chris Hornback, an X-ray technologist in Chicago Heights, said starting annual pay is $24,000 to $26,000, and after five years can range from $33,000 to $35,000. About 600 programs exist for radiological technology training, and 100 programs exist for each of the other fields, Ms. Adler said. --- Editor's Note: Information about educational programs for radiation technology and related fields is available through the Summit's hot line from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. EST, 1-800-432-3247.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday, Nov. 5

DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. said it lost $2 billion in the third quarter, the biggest quarterly loss in automotive history, largely due to the enormous costs of retooling or closing inefficient factories. Without the $2.1 billion in restructuring charges, the world's largest automaker Wednesday said it made just $109 million during the quarter, far less than Wall Street forecasts. --- ROCHESTER, N.Y. (AP) - A $909.5 million patent infringement judgment against Eastman Kodak Co. resulted in a $206 million third quarter loss for the photographic company. Kodak said Wednesday its earnings would have increased 19 percent for the quarter without the judgment. Kodak was ordered by a U.S. District Court judge in Boston earlier this month to pay Polaroid $909.5 million in a 14-year-old patent infringement suit over Kodak's sales of instant cameras and film. ---
DOC.HEAD: By The Associated Press
DOC.TEXT: The price of oil could easily ``explode'' to $100 per barrel if war broke out in the Persian Gulf, a panel of experts told a Senate committee. Wednesday's comments came as the International Energy Agency reported that threats of oil shortages due to the Persian Gulf crisis are easing as OPEC countries boost output and industrial nations cut demand. However, higher oil prices are shaking the confidence of consumers and businesses in many regions of the country, the Federal Reserve Board said in a generally bleak assessment of the nation's economy. Oil prices rallied late Wednesday to move above $35 per barrel in a third straight erratic trading session that largely ignored news on the Persian Gulf standoff. --- LONDON (AP) - Reuters, the international news and financial services agency, said it would cut 300 jobs - 3 percent of its worldwide workforce - because of unsettled market conditions. In reaction to Wednesday's news, Reuters shares dropped 83.6 cents to $10.69 on the London Stock Exchange, a low for the year. Reuters said the jobs to be cut will be in the central corporate departments covering finance, marketing and administration. A small number of editorial jobs also could be affected. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Developer Donald Trump raised new doubts about his financial stability by telling the American Stock Exchange it was unclear whether he would make a big interest payment on Taj Mahal casino bonds next month. Bob Shabazian, an exchange spokesman, said Wednesday the Trump Organization made the statement in response to a question from the exchange, where the bonds are traded. Shabazian said Trump didn't say whether the payment would be made or not. --- HOOFDDORP, Netherlands (AP) - A Dutch computer firm is packing its software diskettes in popcorn - hold the salt and oil - to replace the foam nuggets that used to cushion its product. Corblan International said Wednesday it made the switch because of concerns that polystyrene foam is damaging the environment. The replacement ``costs us about 40 percent more, but at least the popcorn is biodegradable,'' Corblan director Hans Coreen said. --- JACKSONVILLE, Fla. (AP) - Bendix Field Engineering Corp. said it was laying off 300 workers because most of the equipment the company maintains locally for the U.S. Marines has been shipped to the Middle East. The company said Wednesday the workers would be recalled as soon as the equipment is returned or replaced. Bendix maintains 13 combat-loaded ships and their cargo, but nine were deployed to the Middle East as part of Operation Desert Shield and four others are not due for maintenance until November 1991. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Americans' consumer spending jumped 1.1 percent in September, the government said, outpacing a 0.5 percent growth in personal income and contributing to the lowest savings rate in three years. Also Wednesday, factory orders for manufactured goods inched up 0.1 percent in September but would have fallen except for the added cost of oil products, the government said. In other news, the small business community's economic mood this year took the steepest drop since the recession year 1982, Dun & Bradstreet Corp. said in an annual survey. --- NEW YORK (AP) - In a final bid to persuade a judge to give Michael Milken a long prison term, prosecutors claimed the junk-bond financier committed ``serious'' crimes beyond those he has admitted. The government said Wednesday in a closing statement that it ``conclusively'' proved at a special hearing that Milken broke the law during three transactions, despite scant hard evidence presented in testimony. ---

The stock market drifted through a mixed session Wednesday as traders kept a watchful eye on oil prices and the Persian Gulf. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials slipped 5.69 points to 2,442.33. Bond prices jumped amid fresh indications that the nation's economic slide may be worsening. The dollar advanced against most major foreign currencies in domestic trading Wednesday after generally finishing lower abroad. Gold prices were mixed. Corn and soybean futures retreated, while livestock and meat futures rose.

DOC.HEAD: Florida Worries About Tourist Plans After Encephalitis Outbreak
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Florida's worst outbreak of mosquito-borne encephalitis in 13 years has the tourism industry dismissing the chances of people catching the virus but still worried that visitors might change their travel plans. The outbreak of the disease has thrown a scare into the $26 billion a year industry already feeling sluggish from declines in the national economy and rising gasoline prices. But while some local tourist officials feared a disaster, there have been few reports of trip cancellations. ``The majority of calls are from people saying `How bad is this, really?''' said Jennifer Clark, spokeswoman for the Palm Beach County Convention and Visitors Bureau. But Jack Smith, executive director of the Key West Hotel and Motel Association, said he's seen several groups cancel trips in recent weeks. So far this year, 76 cases of St. Louis encephalitis and three deaths have been confirmed in 23 counties stretching from Tampa to Miami. Orange County, with tourist-rich Orlando as the county seat, accounts for the greatest number of cases with 14. Flu-like symptoms are most common, but the young and old are susceptible to complications. The traditional ``snowbird'' winter tourist season falls beyond the reach of mosquito season, state health agency spokesman David Adams said Wednesday. ``We've never had a confirmed case after the first week in December.'' He said cases being reported now actually were contracted in September, but tests take four to six weeks to confirm the virus. Realizing the potential for lost business in a state that welcomes 40 million visitors each year, Florida tourism and health officials combined on a damage-control campaign. State Commerce Secretary Bill Sutton advises in a recorded telephone message that the disease has affected only 5 people in a million and that resorts have bolstered their pesticide spraying to kill the disease-carrying mosquitoes. His department has issued an encephalitis fact sheet and travel tips to keep tourists coming while advising them to take simple precautions. They include using insect repellent and wearing long-sleeved shirts and pants at night, when the mosquitoes come out to feed. Walt Disney World, the biggest attraction, suspended a campfire sing-along and an evening water pageant and moved a lakeside luau to a hotel, but otherwise is operating normally, said spokesman John Dreyer. ``We do make our resort guests aware of it with a little flier in their room,'' he said. ``But there's really no reason people can't come and enjoy the same vacation they could as any other time.'' Some tourism officials say the medical threat has been overblown and that state officials share some of the blame, but others say the state is doing its best to ward off an unwarranted panic. Ronald Rose, Chamber of Commerce executive director in Jensen Beach, which bills itself as the sea turtle capital of the world, wrote Sutton and Gov. Bob Martinez to show his displeasure with state efforts. ``We may have a disaster in the making for the Florida tourism industry, small retailers and fairs and festivals across the state,'' Rose wrote earlier this month. A suggestion that people stay indoors at night ``has panicked people into shutting themselves up in their houses at night.'' John Rutherford of the Orlando-Orange County Convention and Visitors Bureau already is tired of the media attention and offended by coverage by some British tabloids. He recalled a headline that said ``Brain-Bug Terror Strikes Brits in Florida.'' Out of 4,500 delegates to an American Bankers Association convention in Orlando this month, Rutherford noted only three canceled their plans because of the encephalitis scare. Word of the outbreak has spread, but travel agencies say they are seeing little effect. ``Out of all of my clients I have had one, believe it or not, who was concerned,'' said Tina Vespoli, manager of Creative Travel in West Islip, N.Y. About 60 percent of the agency's airline tickets are sold for Florida destinations.

DOC.HEAD: New Random House Division Boss Finds Himself in Charge of Ex-Boss' Book
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: In taking a top post at Random House, Harold Evans becomes publisher of the memoirs of Rupert Murdoch, the media baron Evans clashed with before quitting as editor of The Times of London in the early 1980s. But Evans indicated Wednesday in the wake of his appointment a day earlier to one of the most prestigious posts in American book publishing that he harbors no ill will toward his old boss. ``Now that I'm your publisher, you can be sure that your book will be published under me at Random House with maximum panache,'' Evans said he wrote in a letter to Murdoch. ``And by the way, don't pull any punches.'' Evans became editor at The Times, a British daily newspaper, in early 1981 after 14 years as editor of The Sunday Times of London. But he resigned in March 1982 after repeated disagreements with Murdoch over the political independence of the newspaper. Murdoch is chief executive at News Corp. Ltd., which owns both newspapers as part of a media emprire that includes a movie studio, the Fox Television network, TV stations, newspapers and magazines in the U.S. Random House obtained the rights to publish Murdoch's memoirs only recently, and Evans was named Tuesday as president and publisher of the division of Random House that will publish the book. A spokesman for Murdoch did not return phone calls Wednesday for reaction to Evans' appointment and letter. In a telephone interview, Evans said he plans to promote Murdoch's book ``in a very big way.'' He described his departure from the Times as ``one little incident.'' ``We both moved beyond those arguments of 10 years ago,'' he said. Random House publishes about 120 books a year including works by authors such as James Michener, Norman Mailer, William Styron and Robert Ludlum. It is the nation's biggest publisher of general trade books, which include fiction and non-fiction for adult readers as well as books for children. The book industry newsletter BP Report of Wilton, Conn., estimates that Random House had $850 million in sales of general trade books in 1989, well ahead of second-place Bantam Doubleday Dell at $595 million. The company declined to comment on sales. It is owned by the privately held Advance Publications Inc., controlled by the Newhouse family. Evans, 62, was named president and publisher of the adult general books division of Random House with responsibility for that imprint as well as those of Villard Books and Times Books. He replaces Joni Evans, 48, who had been publisher of the Random House adult division since 1987 and will now found a new imprint for the publishing company. Harold Evans and Joni Evans are not related. Evans said he was approached about taking the new job in the past week or two after Joni Evans persisted with her longstanding desire to start her own book imprint. Harold Evans will become executive vice president of Random House, a post which Ms. Evans retains as well. Harold Evans comes to the new job from another Newhouse company, Conde Nast Publications, where he was founding editor in chief of Conde Nast Traveler magazine. That publication has won plaudits from media critics for occasionally publishing stories critical of potential advertisers. After leaving The Times of London in 1982, Evans was editor in chief at The Atlantic Monthly Press and editorial directoe of U.S. News & World Report from 1984-86. He helped found Conde Nast Traveler in 1986. He is married to Tina Brown, editor of Conde Nast's Vanity Fair magazine.

DOC.HEAD: Berlin Beckons Travelers with New Direct World Flights
DOC.TEXT: Despite a rocky start, Berlin is back as a world destination for air travelers after a 45-year interruption. Until airlines changed to a new winter timetable last Sunday, rights to fly the Berlin route were closely restricted to the airlines of the victorious World War II Allies. You could fly to Berlin from London, Paris, Moscow and a few other European cities outside Germany. Pan Am had four New York flights a week. Otherwise, Berlin was an international air-traffic deadend, though for isolated West Berlin its air routes were a treasured bridge across Communist East Germany. The German flag carrier, Lufthansa, was founded in Berlin in 1926 but could not fly to the city, frozen out by the special rights given to the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union as occupying powers of the divided city. A typical long-haul journey to Berlin would mean changing planes in Frankfurt, often to Pan Am, which had the lion's share of Frankfurt-Berlin traffic. No more. The Allies' special privileges ended on Oct. 3 when the two Germanys united. Lufthansa paid Pan Am $150 million for its domestic German operations, and last Sunday Lufthansa made its first Berlin flight in 45 years. The German airline has plastered the city with ads saying ``We're home again,'' and now offers nonstop flights from Berlin to Tokyo, Moscow and Newark, N.J., serving New York. Airlines from other countries, including Iberia, Alitalia, Singapore Airlines, Swissair and El Al are shouldering into the Berlin market. But last Sunday, a surprise job action disrupted the gala welcomes laid on for a raft of new international flights. Thirteen Pan Am pilots who were supposed to be flying Lufthansa flights called in sick. Lufthansa spokesman Peter Hoebel said four flights had to be canceled and 40 were delayed as the airlines struggled to deal with the unexpected difficulty. Tegel airport was chaotic. Some passengers waited hours for baggage, several flights had to share the same departure lounge, and access roads were jammed with double-parked cars left by people waiting for delayed passengers. ``We sent a message to New York, asking Pan Am to work on the problem,'' Hoebel said, ``and the next day the pilots were suddenly well again.'' Hoebel said the pilots were all Americans who have settled in Germany and want to be taken over into Lufthansa as Pan Am cabin crew workers were. But they were not part of the takeover deal and Pan Am must eventually find other jobs for them, the Lufthansa spokesman said. For the time being, the pilots are flying old Boeing 727s in Pan Am colors under Lufthansa flight numbers, but Lufthansa plans to stop using the 727s next year. Despite the startup confusion, Lufthansa sees a great future for Berlin as an air-travel hub and expects it to grow to equal Frankfurt, Germany's busiest, Hoebel said. But the city suffers a lack of capacity even with three airports currently in operation, and there are only vague plans to build a new airport south of the city. Environmental issues are expected to complicate the choice of a site for a major airfield. Meanwhile, the former western sector of Berlin has Tegel airport as the main international flight center and Tempelhof for short-haul flights. In former East Berlin, Schoenefeld airport is in operation for long-haul flights. The Soviet airline Aeroflot, formerly restricted to Schoenefeld in the east, has started daily flights to Moscow from Tegel in the west. Lufthansa has gone the other direction, basing some of its flights in Schoenefeld.

DOC.HEAD: GM Loses $2 Billion in Third Quarter
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp.'s $2-billion third-quarter loss, which includes a huge expense to permanently close four plants and stop production at others, was viewed on Wall Street as a positive move for the company. ``This shows a serious commitment on GM's part to improved domestic financial performance,'' auto analyst Doug Laughlin of Bear, Stearns & Co. said Wednesday after GM announced the results. The loss, the biggest in automotive history, stemmed from a one-time, $2.1-billion charge the automaker took for the closings of four assembly plants and the idlings and consolidations of other factories during the next three years. During bargaining with the United Auto Workers late this summer, the company agreed to guarantee the income of workers laid off from plants shut down because of sales slumps. The labor costs are part of the $2.1 billion charge. GM is formalizing the closing of four plants, one each in Pontiac, Mich.; Kansas City, Mo.; Atlanta, Ga.; and Framingham, Mass. The four had been indefinitely closed during the past three years. GM common stock closed Wednesday on the New York Stock Exchange at $36.75 a share, up 12{ cents. That showed that analysts and brokers, who anticipated some kind of charge during the quarter, weren't especially worried about it. ``Most charges like this cause the stock to drop sharply,'' said auto analyst Scott Merlis of Morgan, Stanley & Co. in New York. ``It's seen as a positive.'' Without the charge, GM earned $109 million. Revenues for the quarter rose to $30.8 billion compared with $28.8 billion during the same time last year. GM's profits were far less than expected by analysts last week. In the third quarter of last year, GM earned $516.9 million. On a per-share basis, GM lost $3.54 during the quarter this year, including the charge, compared with a 72 cents-a-share profit last year. Dismal third-quarter results for each of the Big Three - including a lower-than-expected profit for Ford Motors Co. and a $214 million loss for Chrysler Corp. - depict a sputtering auto industry. In all, without discretionary charges by GM and accounting changes by Ford, the Big Three reported a combined loss of $21.2 million during the July-September period. ``There is no question that the quarter is dismal,'' Merlis said. ``This certainly reflects the further automotive downturn induced by the (Persian) Gulf crisis. ``The sad irony is that the autos have outperformed many service companies and banks in the third quarter.'' For the first nine months of this year, excluding the charge, GM earned $1.7 billion, down 51.4 percent from the $3.5 billion it earned during the same period last year. Including the charge, GM lost $368.7 million. Revenues for the January-September period fell to $94.8 billion from $95.6 billion. Ford on Tuesday reported a $101.7 million profit for the third quarter, but that was inflated by $86.9 million in accounting changes. Ford's profits were cut by $69 million when it bolstered its loan reserves at its First Nationwide Bank subsidiary. Taking into account all accounting changes and the loan reserve shift, Ford's profits were $83.8 million during the quarter. Aside from formalizing the closure of four plants, GM also has announced that it will stop production at truck plants in Scarborough, Ontario; Lordstown, Ohio; and Pontiac, Mich., along with closing or consolidating operations of some component plants. It wasn't clear precisely how many employees would be affected by the actions. ``I would say the restructuring is being seen as a positive on Wall Street,'' Merlis said. ``GM wants to begin the decade of the '90s with a clean slate and face the reality of the marketplace.'' A GM official, speaking Wednesday on condition of anonymity, noted that Chairman Robert Stempel immediately ushered in a new management plan when he took over from Roger Smith on Aug. 1. ``You are at the start of a new management team and new leadership under Bob Stempel,'' the official said. ``And one could say that better early than late. ``Why dribble it out?''

DOC.HEAD: Burger King Boycott Called Off, Ads Touting `Traditional Values' Planned
DOC.NOTE: Eds: TOPS with 3 new grafs to show proposed yearlong boycott was called off after only two months and narrow description of ad plans. Picks up 4th graf, ``it must ...
DOC.TEXT: A religious group pressing companies to drop advertising from racy television shows has ended a boycott of Burger King, which will run newspaper ads this weekend touting support for family values in television. The activists, Christian Leaders for Responsible Television, had singled out the fast-food chain earlier this year because the religious group said it found the company's commercials often appeared in TV shows that featured sex, profanity and anti-Christian stereotyping. The group said Wednesday it reached a mutual understanding with company officials. It called off the proposed yearlong boycott that began Sept. 1. ``It must be stressed that Burger King Corp. did not change its principles of its media buying policies as a result of the boycott,'' said Cori Zywotow, a spokeswoman for Burger King. ``We are convinced that Burger King shares our concern about the quality of television programs and will put that concern into practice in the future,'' said Billy Melvin, chairman of the religious group that calls itself Clear-TV. Ms. Zywotow said the company explained its ``past and present advertising buying policies'' to the group over the past few weeks and said the boycott was called off as a result of those discussions. At the same time, she said the company feared its customers may have been misled about the incidents, and Burger King would run half-page ads in newspapers across the country to clarify its position. The half-page ads, which carry the headline ``An open letter to the American people,'' will appear in newspapers this weekend and early next week, Ms. Zywotow said. ``Burger King wishes to go on record as supporting traditional American values on television, especially the importance of the family,'' the ads say. ``We believe the American people desire television programs that reflect the values they are trying to instill in their children. We pledge to support such programs with our advertising dollars,'' the ads say. Ms. Zywotow declined to say how much Burger King was spending to run the ads and said she did not know precisely how many newspapers would get them. Clear-TV is based in Tupelo, Miss., and says it includes approximately 1,600 Christian leaders who have a constituency of about 60 million people. While it was not clear what shows Burger King sponsored to draw the group's wrath, Clear-TV has previously objected to episodes of such shows as ``Saturday Night Live,'' ``L.A. Law'' and ``Married ... with Children.'' Donald Wildmon, executive director of the American Family Association, a group that is part of the Clear-TV coalition, said leaders of the group had encouraged people to boycott Burger King through church bulletins, newsletters and the like and would now encourage people to patronize the stores. Ms. Zywotow said the boycott had no impact on systemwide sales for the chain, which has 5,400 outlets nationwide. Wildmon declined to speculate on whether the boycott hurt sales at Burger King, but added, ``Many companies respond only when sales are affected.''

DOC.HEAD: FDIC Rejects Purchase Offer of Bank Shares
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. has rejected an offer by managers of Continental Bank and a group of independent investors to acquire the agency's share of the bank's stock. The FDIC on Tuesday rejected an offer of $7.87 per share made by the management of Continental, bank spokesman Ted McDougal said Wednesday. The agency also turned down a similar offer by several independent investors. Tuesday's offer was based on Monday's closing price of Continental stock. It placed the value of 14.2 million shares - 26 percent of banking firm's outstanding stock - controlled by the FDIC at $111.5 million. ``The FDIC board concluded the offer was not in the FDIC's best interest at this time,'' said spokesman Alan Whitney. Before making their latest bid, Continental executives were led to believe the FDIC would accept a bid at the market price of Continental stock, said bank vice chairman Richard Huber. ``So we got a group together and made a bid at the market,'' he said. ``We're obviously disappointed. We seem to be ill-fated, don't we?'' McDougal refused to identify the independent investors who made an offer for the shares held by the FDIC. But he said some of them also made an offer in June to buy the stock. That group, which included the Tisch family of New York and former Treasury Secretary William Simon, made an offer of $15.50 a share that was rejected by the FDIC. The Tisch family in October increased its ownership of Continental Bank Corp. to 8.5 percent. The family, including Laurence A. Tisch, chief executive of CBS Inc. and chairman of Loews Corp., says it is buying stocks of a number of banks for investment purposes in the belief bank stocks are undervalued. In 1989, the FDIC canceled a planned public sale of the stock when it was trading at $22 a share. Continental officials said they were confused by the rejection of offers by the FDIC. ``I'm at a loss to explain why they have rejected the third market-based offer in a year, nor can I guess what they're waiting for,'' said bank chairman Thomas C. Theobald. ``We have done everything possible to make it easy for them to sell.'' The FDIC obtained its stake in Continental Bank when the agency saved the institution from collapse in June 1984, halting a run on deposits prompted by concerns about the stability of the bank, at the time one of the world's largest. The agency has not indicated whether it would seek a private placement of the stock or a general public offering.

DOC.HEAD: Zapata Corp. Sells Offshoe Drilling Rig Fleet to Arethusa Limited
DOC.TEXT: Zapata Corp. has completed the sale of its offshore drilling rig fleet and related assets to Arethusa (Offshore) Limited for $298 million, officials said. Zapata chairman and chief executive R.C. Lassiter said Wednesday that under the terms of the previously announced sale Zapata has purchased an 8.75 percent share of Arethusa, a new Bermuda company, and will continue to manage 12 rigs. Lassiter said selling the rig fleets moves the Houston-based company toward completing its comprehensive debt restructuring plan. The three-part program that calls for the sale of its offshore rig fleet to help reduce the company's debt to a manageable level. Zapata's $560 million in bank debt is to be reduced to $115 million with the banks receiving $160 million in cash and 94.5 million common shares to increase their ownership to approximately 80 percent of the company. Cash offers for Zapata's debentures make up the third part of the company's plan. In addition to oil and natural gas production, Zapata's fishing operations produce fish meal and edible oil. The company is also the largest shareholder in Zapata Gulf Marine Corp., the world's largest operator of marine service vessels.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Down at Midday
DOC.TEXT: Share prices were down at midday Thursday on London's Stock Exchange after the Treasury and the Bank of England said it would be inappropriate to cut a key lending rate which is now at 14 percent. At midday, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was down 9.4 points, or 0.5 percent, at 2,040.9. Volume was 199.6 million shares.

DOC.HEAD: Average Worker Received $3,900 Bonus This Summer
DOC.TEXT: The average Japanese worker received a summer bonus of $3,859 this year, up 7.1 percent from a year earlier and the biggest year-to-year-increase in 13 years, the Labor Ministry said Thursday. Yoshiaki Kashiwagi of the ministry attributed the increase to Japan's economic boom. It was the biggest increase since 8.0 percent in 1977, he said. Japanese companies pay bonuses twice a year. Summer bonuses at companies employing 30 or more workers in 1989 averaged $3,663, up 6.9 percent from 1988, and winter bonuses averaged $4,331, up 6.5 percent, Kashiwagi said. He said summer bonuses at construction companies rose by a record 14.0 percent this year to $4,011. The average monthly wage at Japanese companies employing more than 30 workers was $2,034 in 1989, up 3.7 percent from a year earlier, he said.

Stock prices were mixed today in an ambivalent response to accumulating evidence of weakness in the economy. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 9.16 to 2,433.17 in the first half hour of trading. But gainers outnumbered losers by about 4 to 3 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 510 up, 383 down and 473 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 20.91 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. A collection of reports from the 12 district banks in the Federal Reserve System painted a picture of slumping business conditions in most sectors of the country. On Friday, monthly data from the Labor Department are expected to show a decline in payroll employment and an increase in the unemployment rate, probably to 5.8 percent in October from 5.7 percent the month before. Interest rates declined in the credit markets in response to these developments and prospects. But stock traders took a warier view, faced with increasing concern about the outlook for economic growth and corporate profits. Losers among the blue chips included General Electric, down [ at 51~; General Motors, down \ at 36{; Boeing, down { at 44\, and International Business Machines, down \ at 105\. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks slipped .22 to 165.95. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up .18 at 287.97. On Wednesday the Dow Jones industrial average slipped 5.69 points to 2,442.33. Advancing issues slightly outnumbered declines on the NYSE, with 744 up, 736 down and 472 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 156.06 million shares, against 153.45 million in the previous session.

Stock prices declined slightly today amid accumulating evidence of weakness in the economy. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 7.92 to 2,434.41 by 11 a.m. on Wall Street. Losers outnumbered gainers by about 7 to 6 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 527 up, 614 down and 546 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 50.17 million shares at midmorning. DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Open Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Wheat futures prices opened lower this morning on the Chicago Board of Trade, extending a monthlong slide. Corn and soybean futures were narrowly mixed. The slight decline in wheat prices reflected continued slack export demand for U.S. wheat and beneficial weather for the newly planted winter wheat crop in the Great Plains, analysts said. Wheat also was pressured this morning by rumors of a large sale of Canadian wheat to the Soviet Union. There was speculation earlier this week that the Soviets were shopping for U.S. grain. Corn and soybean prices were little changed in early trading. Any rally attempts continued to be limited by selling linked to the corn and soybean harvest, which is nearing completion. In early trading, wheat futures were { cent to 2 cents lower with the contract for delivery in December at $2.61 a bushel; corn was \ cent lower to \ cent higher with December at $2.29{ a bushel; oats were unchanged to \ cent higher with December at $1.21{ a bushel; and soybeans were 1 cent lower to { cent higher with November at $5.92{ a bushel. Livestock futures were mostly lower in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange; pork bellies rose slightly. Live cattle futures were .02 cent to .28 cent lower with December at 77.17 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .32 cent lower to .03 cent higher with November at 87.40 cents a pound; live hogs were .15 cent lower to .05 cent higher with December at 51.77 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .08 cent to .30 cent higher with February at 61.55 cents a pound. Livestock and meat futures rose on Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: MMUC Chairman Resigns, No Replacement Planned
DOC.TEXT: Osamu Nobuto resigned Thursday as chairman of Mazda Motor Manufacturing (USA) Corp., Mazda Motor Corp. said. Nobuto, 58, a Mazda senior managing director, was placed in charge of the Japanese auto company's worldwide purchasing activities in June. Nobuto was named MMUC's first president in May 1985. He returned to Japan in March 1990 and was named chairman at that time. Mazda's U.S. car-making operations will continue under the direction of Masahiro Uchida, named MMUC president in March 1990, and the company said no replacement for Nobuto as chairman was planned. ``MMUC is now well-established under the leadership of Mr. Masahiro Uchida and I am now turning my full attention to my duties with respect to Mazda's worldwide purchasing activities,'' Nobuto said.

Stock prices slipped a notch today amid accumulating evidence of weakness in the economy. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 2.97 to 2,439.36 by noontime on Wall Street. DOC.HEAD: Earnings Nearly Double in Fourth Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Ralston Purina Co. reported Thursday its profit for its fourth quarter soared 81.4 percent compared to the same period last year mainly because of lower advertising and administrative costs. The consumer products company earned $82.0 million, or $1.37 a share, in the three months ended Sept. 30 compared with $45.2 million, or 65 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales edged up 1.7 percent to $1.79 billion in the quarter from $1.76 billion in 1989. The company reduced its advertising costs for pet foods and cereal by 15 percent in the quarter and also reduced its overall general administrative costs by 5 percent from last year when costs were high because of the introduction of several new products. The cost reductions boosted profits despite lackluster sales, the company said. Ralston Purina is a leading maker of pet food and cereal. The company also makes Eveready and Energizer batteries and owns Continental Baking Co., which makes such products as Wonder bread and Hostess Twinkies. For the year, Ralston Purina reported a profit of $396.3 million, or $6.46 a share, down 6.2 percent from $422.5 million, or $6.44 a share, for last year which included a $71.3 million one-time gain from the sale of the company's seafood subsidiary. Sales for the year rose 7.6 pecent to $7.1 billion from $6.6 billion in 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Telephone Companies Sign Cooperative Agreement
DOC.TEXT: Bell Atlantic International signed a wide-ranging cooperative agreement Thursday with the national telephone company of Taiwan. The companies agreed to work together to explore specific marketing opportunities and research programs, as well as personnel and information exchanges. They also said they would explore other business activities worldwide to identify joint investment and development opportunities. ``The agreement will enhance the relationship between our company and the (Taiwanese company), and we believe it will be long and mutually beneficial,'' said Hyde Tucker, president and chief executive officer of Bell Atlantic International. Earlier this year, Bell Atlantic signed a similar agreement with the Korean Telecommunications Authority. Bell Atlantic International is a subsidiary of Bell Atlantic Corp., a telephone company with 17 million customers in the mid-Atlantic region of the United States. Outside North America, it has investments and operations in 11 countries. The Taiwanese company, Directorate General of Telecommunications of the Republic of China, serves more than 7 million access lines.

DOC.HEAD: Tentative Agreement Reached in Kaiser Negotiations.
DOC.TEXT: Kaiser Aluminum & Chemical Co. and the United Steelworkers of America reached a tentative contract agreement Thursday, averting a strike by 3,500 employees in three states. Agreement on the four-year contract was reached shortly after 4 a.m., said Kaiser spokeswoman Susan Ashe. A ratification vote was expected to be completed by next week. Ashe said the new agreement would increase base pay by 50 cents an hour in the first and fourth years, increase pension benefits, provide a signing bonus of $1,000, continue a bonus plan tied to the price of metal and introduce a managed health care program. The contract would last through Oct. 31, 1994, and replace a three-year contract that expired at midnight Wednesday. Kaiser, which is owned by Maxxam Inc., a Los Angeles holding company, has 2,400 employees in Washington state. Another 750 are employed in Gramercy, La., Newark, Ohio, and Toledo, Ohio.

DOC.HEAD: Construction Spending Makes A Steep Drop
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Construction spending fell 2.8 percent in September, its steepest drop since the last recession, the government said Thursday, and analysts said any recovery is at least months away. ``Given what we see now ... we have several more months to go before we can say we've hit the bottom,'' said Daryl Delano, an economist with Cahners Economics in Newton, Mass. The Commerce Department said residential, non-residential and government spending totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $428.7 billion - the lowest dollar level since $423.1 billion was spent in November 1988. Declines in all categories led to the sharpest tumble since a 3.0 percent drop in January 1982 during the 1981-82 recession. September spending was 1.1 percent below the $433.4 billion posted in the same month of 1989. ``The weakness across the board probably reflects the overall decline in business confidence to go along with the well-documented decline in consumer confidence,'' Delano said. The Conference Board, a New York research group, reported last Friday that consumer confidence in the economy plunged in October to the lowest level since the last recession. It said its index tumbled more than 24 points, the biggest one-month drop in the 20-year history of the survey. The construction industry also has been wracked for months by high interest rates, tight lending requirements and, in some areas, lofty vacancy rates. It has not posted an increase since it rose 0.4 percent last March. The Labor Department has reported the loss of more than 100,000 construction jobs in the last four months alone. This included 20,000 jobs in September, after seasonal adjustment. Residential spending fell 2.3 percent to an annual rate of $182.2 billion after a 1.1 percent decline in August. ``Residential spending has been down so long, we're still searching for the bottom,'' Delano said, noting weak building permit applications and new home sales, both barometers of future building plans. Single-family spending was down 2.7 percent to $105.6 billion following a 1.9 percent loss the previous month. Apartment construction declined 3.7 percent to $18 billion after being unchanged a month earlier. Non-residential spending fell 2.3 percent to $101.8 billion after a 4.8 percent plunge in August. ``The weakness is more pervasive now than it was even three months ago, when we still had good industrial spending, fairly good retail and other commercial spending as well as (spending) for education and hospitals,'' Delano said. ``Those that had been good are at best holding their own now and the others are continuing to deteriorate.'' The often-volatile government spending, which rose 6.5 percent in August, fell back 5.0 percent in September to $109.3 billion. Spending on streets and highways, which paced the August advance, was off 3.5 percent in September.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Down In Europe
DOC.NOTE: EDS: NEW thruout to UPDATE with closing Europe, midday NY figures; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar fell in Europe today, buffeted by a surge in buying of German marks. Gold was little changed. An announcement that Germany's central bank was raising the Lombard rate, a key interest rate, a half a percentage point to 8.5 percent prompted dealers to sell dollars and buy marks. The dollar also lost ground against the British pound after the British Treasury and the Bank of England denied rumors of a cut in interest rates, dealers said. In Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 130.70 Japanese yen, from 129.35 yen on Wednesday. But later in London, it fell to 130.40 yen. At midday in New York the dollar was trading at 130.56 yen. In London, the British pound rose to $1.9525, from $1.9440 late Wednesday. In New York it cost $1.9513 to buy one pound. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Wednesday's rates included: 1.5070 German marks, down from 1.5150; 1.2745 Swiss francs, down from 1.2850; 5.0525 French francs, down from 5.0725; 1.6980 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7070; 1,129.75 Italian lire, down from 1,135.50, and 1.1650 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1669. Selected midday dollar rates in New York included: 1.5063 German marks, 1.2745 Swiss francs, 1,129.25 Italian lire and 1.1646 Canadian dollars. Gold was unchanged in London at a late bid price of $379.75 a troy ounce. In Zurich, the metal rose to a closing bid of $380.70, from $379.25 bid late Wednesday. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold fell 36 cents to close at a bid $379.25. Silver bullion fell in London to a late bid price of $4.19 a troy ounce, from $4.22 bid late Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Audit Blasts Agency For Bungling Forest Lands
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 13th graf pvs, The review, to include BLM comments. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Federal mismanagement of some of the world's most productive timber lands has cost the government at least $90 million since 1986, an Interior Department audit disclosed Thursday. Mishandling of Bureau of Land Management forests in western Oregon is the result of financial shortcuts prompted by budget cutbacks, the department's Office of Inspector General said. The report said the BLM lost $90 million by failing to perform thinning, fertilization and other maintenance that resulted in fewer trees that could be cut. The BLM estimated it lost 94 million board feet of timber growth in the fiscal years 1986-89 due to inadequate management. A board foot is one foot by one foot by one inch. In addition, the BLM has failed to acquire easements to 132,000 acres with 800 million board feet of mature timber valued at $302 million. Losses could total as much as $1.7 billion over the forests' 60-to 80-year life cycles, the report said. The audit of BLM forestry operations on 2.4 million acres across 18 Oregon counties criticized the agency for failing to explain the magnitude of the losses to Congress and the Office of Management and Budget. BLM Director Cy Jamison said in response to the review that his budget requests have been ``somewhat constrained'' by funding targets provided by the Interior Department, its parent agency. ``These targets, which are less than ideal to accomplish the desired workload, are consistent with the goals of the administration to reduce federal deficits,'' Jamison said in a memo to the inspector general's office. The audit covering fiscal years 1986-89 noted that BLM forestry revenues will further decline as additional lands are taken out of production to protect the threatened northern spotted owl. The BLM estimated in June that efforts to save the owl from extinction may directly affect 23 percent of its lands in western Oregon, about 553,000 acres, and may indirectly affect another 1.5 million acres there. The BLM holdings are ``some of the most productive timber lands in the world,'' said the audit prepared by assistant inspector general Harold Bloom. Bungling of the forest program is especially costly because the program historically returns $4.30 for every $1 spent, the audit said. The review questioned whether the BLM will be able to achieve next year's harvest target of 750 million board feet, because the agency's funding request for its forestry program was more than 20 percent short of the $66 million needed. However, BLM spokesman Joe Zilincar said Thursday that despite the lower request Congress funded the progam at $66.5 million. He said he did not know if that action was a result of the audit, which was completed more than a month ago but not made public until Thursday. ``The funding that we got this year is right on target with what we need,'' Zilincar said. He said the problems cited in the audit will be reviewed. The audit also discounts BLM claims it can use smaller fragmented tracts of timber to replace timber from larger tracts of forests where logging is being banned to protect the rare owl. ``Easements for the smaller scattered tracts of timber lands have not been obtained because the bureau has concentrated on obtaining legal access for the larger consolidated tracts,'' the audit said. In addition, the audit said the BLM has: - Based its budgets on plans to use herbicides to control underbrush although herbicdes have been banned on Oregon BLM lands since a federal judge issued an injunction in 1984. Manual efforts cost three times more than herbicides. - Failed to place sufficient priority or secure sufficient funds for maintenance of the tree plantations, including placing tubes around seedlings to protect them from wildlife. - Failed to perform intensive management programs, including fertilization and pre-commercial thinning to provide proper spacing between trees.

DOC.HEAD: New Ruble Rate Spawns Confusion in Dollar Shops
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS three grafs after 17th graf, At other, with trading halted with Finland. Picks up 18th graf pvs, Since there. Version also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's decree creating a new commercial exchange rate for the ruble created confusion and chaos Thursday in Moscow's hard-currency shops. ``Closed for inventory,'' read a sign at the Swiss-Soviet joint venture shop Sadko. ``Sorry, I am taking stock,'' said a counterman at the Kodak film shop at the Mezhdunarodnaya Hotel in central Moscow. A cashier at the hotel studied a chart listing the different exchange rates. Gorbachev introduced the new rate, which took effect Thursday, with the publication on Oct. 26 of a presidential decree setting the value of the currency at 1.8 rubles to the dollar in commercial transactions, nearly 70 percent lower than the official rate. The primary goal of the new rate is to make Soviet exports more competitive while discouraging imports, economic officials said. It is part of Gorbachev's program to switch from central planning to a market-based economy in the next two years. As of Thursday, there were three government rates, as well as the black market price of the dollar. These were the official rate of .56 rubles, the commercial rate of 1.8 rubles and the special, or tourist, rate of 6.2 rubles. The black market rate is 20 to 25 rubles to the dollar. Ivan Ivanov, deputy chairman of the State Foreign Economic Commission, said the three-tier system should be seen as transitional while the real value of the ruble emerges. He described the official .56-ruble rate as ``obsolete,'' but said it was being kept for international currency comparisons and to protect Third World countries whose debts are in rubles. ``Gradually, these rates will be brought together, with the disappearance of the official and special rates. The commercial rate will become basic,'' he told the government news agency Novosti. But for Soviet citizens, anticipation of the new devalued rate heightened fears that rubles would be worth less and spurred rumors that their bank accounts would skrink in value by nearly 70 percent. In Moscow, Soviets have been swarming into the handful of hard-currency shops over the past week and buying foreign goods ranging from basic foodstuffs to fur coats and car parts. ``People heard rumors. They are buying everything they can get their hands on,'' said a cashier at the Sadko shop, a favorite of Soviets who were given the right in August to have and spend foreign currency without explaining its source. The rush came despite assurances the government would reimburse anyone whose holdings in bank accounts were decreased by the devaluation. Sadko and several hard-currency shops in major hotels were closed Thursday morning, ostensibly for inventory, as bookkeepers and cashiers grappled with how to handle the new ruble rates. ``We are tripling our prices in rubles,'' said Antonina Maksimova, Sadko's director. However, she said, customers wouldn't feel the difference because the hard currency price they pay is unchanged. Cash registers automatically convert the ruble prices at the commercial rate. At the Mezhdunarodnaya Hotel ice cream shop, the manager said: ``In dollars, I am charging the same as yesterday'' although the ruble price is three times higher. At other shops, cashiers said they had no instructions. ``We are charging the old rate,'' said a register worker at Kalinka, a Soviet-Finnish joint venture. ``Nobody has told us different.'' In Helsinki, Finland, meanwhile, the Bank of Finland halted trade with the Soviet Union because of confusion over the new exchange rates. Kari Holopainen, director of Soviet trade at the central bank, said the bank was not informed which of the three new rates applied to the ``clearing ruble'' used in Finnish-Soviet trade. ``To put it mildly, we are somewhat unsure of what is going on,'' he said. ``In any case we have stopped all payments in the clearing-house trade with the Soviet Union for the time being.'' Since there is no official currency exchange for the rank-and-file Soviet, the Gorbachev decree only affects those Soviet citizens possessing money earned legally abroad and banked in the Soviet Union in the form of rubles. None of the three ruble rates now in effect, set artificially by the Soviet government, reflect the true worth of the currency, either to companies trading shiploads of commodities or tourists buying souvenir matryoshka dolls. Many companies get around the exchange rates by bartering goods, such as Pepsico Inc.'s practice of selling Pepsi Cola to the Soviet Union and taking its profits out of the country in Stolichnaya vodka and other commodities.

DOC.HEAD: American International Group Income Up Slightly
DOC.TEXT: American International Group Inc., a worldwide insurance company, said Thursday that third-quarter profits rose 4 percent on gains in general and life insurance. AIG reported net income of $337 million, or $1.62 per share, in the three months ended Sept. 30, up from $324 million, or $1.57 per share, in the 1989 period. The company said revenue rose by about 12 percent to $3.9 billion from $3.5 billion in the year-ago quarter. AIG said pre-tax operating income for general insurance rose 20.3 percent to $276 million from $230 million a year earlier. General insurance premiums written for the quarter increased slightly to $2.3 billion. The company's worldwide life insurance operations reported pre-tax operating income of $117 million in the third quarter, up 14.2 percent. AIG said its foreign opererations contributed about half of its total operating income. It said the foreign underwriting division showed a profit despite almost $15 million of insured losses from an earthquake in the Philippines and damages from civil unrest in Thailand. The insurance firm said it increased its general worldwide loss resevres by $447 million in the quarter to $14.3 billion. For the first nine months of 1990, AIG said net income rose 4 percent to $1.06 billion, or $5.13 per share, from $1.02 billion, or $4.95 per share in the same 1989 period. Nine-month revenue was $11.4 billion, up 8.9 percent from $10.4 billion a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Production Goes Down This Week
DOC.TEXT: Domestic automakers were scheduled to produce 220,160 cars and light trucks this week, down from last week's 225,196, Ward's Automotive Reports said Thursday. This week's production is lower than the same week a year ago, in which 223,452 cars and light trucks were produced, the trade journal said. U.S. automakers were scheduled to make 142,567 cars this week, compared with 146,927 a week ago and 144,105 in the same week in 1989. Light truck production for the week was scheduled at 77,593, compared with last week's 78,269 and last year's 79,347. Canadian automakers were to build 25,960 cars this week, up from 25,943 a week ago and down from last year's 26,037. Canadian light truck production was scheduled at 13,960, compared with 19,453 a week ago and 17,055 in the same week last year.

DOC.HEAD: Xerox Restructuring South Pacific Region Operations
DOC.TEXT: Xerox Corp. announced Thursday it would restructure its operations in the South Pacific, resulting in an expected 40 cent to 50 cent boost per share to its fourth-quarter earnings. Under the plan, Fuji Xerox Co. Ltd. will assume management responsibilities and ownership of Rank Xerox Ltd.'s operations in Australia, Malaysia, New Zealand and Singapore. Rank Xerox, based in the United Kingdom, is a joint venture between Xerox and The Rank Organization PLC. It manufactures and markets almost all Xerox business products and systems in 80 foreign countries. Tokyo-based Fuji Xerox, a joint venture between Rank Xerox and Fuji Photo Film Co. Ltd., manufactures and markets Xerox business equipment in the Far East and Southeast Asia. Fuji Xerox will pay a total $410 million to Xerox and Rank Xerox for the operations. Xerox said it would repay short-term debt from its net proceeds, which will total approximately $200 million after taxes and after receipt of a special cash dividend from Rank Xerox. The transaction, after taxes and deferrals, is expected to add 40 cents to 50 cents per share to Xerox's fourth-quarter results. In the 1989 fourth quarter, Xerox earned $212 million, or $1.93 per share, on revenue of $4.7 billion. No layoffs are expected from the restructuring. The South Pacific operations employ about 6,200 people. The new Fuji Xerox company will have its headquarters in Singapore with about 60 employees. The restructuring is subject to approval by various governmental bodies.

DOC.HEAD: Treasury Sets Savings Bond Rates
DOC.TEXT: U.S. savings bonds will earn interest at a rate of 7.19 percent from Nov. 1 through April 30, up slightly from 7.01 percent during the previous six months, the Treasury Department said Thursday. Catalina V. Villalpando, treasurer of the United States, called the new rate ``a positive sign for savers and investors who are looking for competitive rates in today's market.'' Savings bond interest rates are changed each May 1 and Nov. 1 to reflect open market rates. They are based on 85 percent of the yield on five-year Treasury securities, which have averaged 8.46 percent. Savings bond yields at redemption are the average of semiannual market-based rates during the time held, compounded semi-annually, or a minimum rate, whichever is greater. The current minimum rate is 6 percent.
Stock prices rose today, drawing support from hopes for lower interest rates. Shortly before the close, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was up 22.03 at 2,464.36.
