DOC.HEAD: Retired Worker Says TRW Defrauded Air Force
DOC.TEXT: A TRW Inc. division has been accused in a whistleblower's lawsuit of inflating bids and double-billing the Air Force on classified contracts, an attorney said Thursday. Frank M. Breene, a retired TRW acquisitions manager, alleges in the $20 million federal suit that TRW violated the False Claims Act by submitting false bids and falsely allocating costs between 1982 and 1990. Under the False Claims Act, Breene would receive 15 percent to 20 percent of any damages awarded, with the rest going to the federal government, said Breene's attorney, David Francis Pace. TRW spokesman Julian Levine said the lawsuit was ``frivolous and totally without merit.'' TRW's Security and Defense Sector, based in Redondo Beach, produces several highly classified systems, including spy satellites designed to eavesdrop on foreign radio and telephone communications. The specific nature of the contracts in question cannot be disclosed because of security concerns, the lawsuit said. Breene contends TRW intentionally defrauded the government and ignored his request that actual accounting figures be used in the contract proposals. The suit does not explain the accounting methods TRW used to hide any alleged false bids and billings. The allegations involve complex ratios for allocating costs of production, support, labor and planning. In general, federal rules require contractors to allocate contract costs to a variety of special accounts, only some of which are fully reimbursed by the government. Rules also require that all work performed under a contract be paid only from funds in that contract. Breene brought the charges in an amended complaint filed under the federal False Claims Act in June. However, the charges were sealed while the Justice Department studied whether to join the case. U.S. District Court Judge Edward Rafeedie lifted the seal Oct. 26 after denying a stipulation to extend the Justice Department's 60-day study period.

DOC.HEAD: Purchasing Managers Report Economy Declined in October
DOC.TEXT: The nation's industrial sector weakened in October, pushing the overall economy into a decline for the first time in nearly eight years, said a closely followed survey of purchasing executives released Thursday. The National Association of Purchasing Management's survey, considered one of the best monitors of the nation's economic heartbeat, contrasted sharply with an assessment Tuesday by the Commerce Department that said the economy continue to grow. Private economists agreed with the purchasing managers' more pessimistic conclusion. The association's monthly index of economic activity dropped a full percentage point to 43.4 percent in October, its lowest level since it fell to 42.8 percent in December 1982. Robert Bretz, chairman of the trade group, said that by falling under 44 percent, the index reached the point where it signaled a small decline in the gross national product, the broadest measure of the nation's economic health. Virtually all the components of the index ``confirmed the growing weakness in manufacturing, which was enough to pull the overall economy into slightly negative growth,'' Bretz said The components include production, new orders, supplier delivery rates, prices for raw materials, inventory levels and employment. Donald Ratajczk, director of economic forecasting at Georgia State University, said of the purchasing managers report, ``I think that's a realistic assessment'' of the economy. Alan Levinson, an economist with Wefa Group, a private economic forecasting service based in Bala Cynwd, Pa., also agreed that the economy was in a decline last month and added, ``My feeling is the recession probably started in August or September.'' The purchasing managers' survey and the economists were at odds with the Bush administration's view of the economy. On Tuesday, after the release of a stronger-than-expected GNP figure for the third quarter, Commerce Undersecretary Michael R. Darby stated that the government expected the economy would expand at a modest pace in the fourth quarter and next year. But Bretz said of the October results, ``The fourth quarter began like the third quarter ended, with a decline in the manufacturing economy.'' The association's survey of purchasing executives at more than 300 industrial firms around the country found production levels fell for the third consecutive month as new orders declined sharply. Thirty-one percent of the executives reported production was off from the previous month, while 52 percent said it was the same and 17 percent reported production was up. That compared with 29 percent reporting lower production in September, 48 percent saying it was unchanged and 23 saying it was up. New orders fell for the fourth straight month. Thirty-four percent of the respondents said orders were down, 47 percent reported they were unchanged and 19 percent said they were up. In September, 30 percent said new orders were off, 47 percent said they were the same and 23 percent said they had picked up. The survey found that export orders grew last month, but their rate of gain was the smallest in the nearly two years that export orders have been tallied by the purchasing managers. The report also indicated that suppliers' deliveries were faster, a bad sign because it indicated vendors had less demand for goods. Industrial companies also felt the bite of inflation in October, the survey showed. Its price index rose to 76.4 percent from 73.4 percent in September, with the increase blamed entirely on fallout from the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. Prices for crude oil and chemicals derived from it rose sharply, but purchasing executives also reported suppliers were using the Persian Gulf crisis as an excuse to make unnecessary price hikes. Employment continued to drop last month, a result of the drop in production. Twenty-eight percent of the respondents said employment fell at their companies in October, while 63 percent said it was unchanged and 9 percent said employment rose. In September, 27 percent reported lower employment, 65 percent reported the same employment levels, and 8 percent said employment was up. Ratajczk noted other evidence that employment continued to weaken last month. He pointed to Thursday's Labor Department announcment that initial claims for state unemployment benefits rose by 33,000 in the week ended Oct. 20 to 454,000. The department releases October employment figures on Friday. Private economists said they were not surprised by any of the numbers announced by the purchasing managers. ``None of the components of the index just fell out of bed,'' said Levinson. ``Everything continues to be weak.'' Added Ratajczk, ``This is the beginning. This is what you see when you are in recession.''

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices chalked up a moderate gain Thursday as traders studied accumulating evidence of weakness in the economy. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials climbed 12.62 points to 2,454.95. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by nearly 3 to 2 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 896 up, 618 down and 487 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 159.27 million shares, against 156.06 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 191.52 million shares. A collection of reports from the 12 district banks in the Federal Reserve System painted a picture of slumping business conditions in most sectors of the country. On Friday, monthly data from the Labor Department are expected to show a decline in payroll employment and an increase in the unemployment rate, probably to 5.8 percent in October from 5.7 percent the month before. Separately, the Commerce Department is due to report on the index of leading economic indicators for September. The investment firm of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. estimates that the index will show a decline of 0.8 percent, after falling 1.2 percent in August. Interest rates declined in the credit markets in response to these developments and prospects. But stock traders took a warier view, faced with increasing concern about the outlook for economic growth and corporate profits. Gainers among the blue chips included International Business Machines, up 1} at 107\; Philip Morris, up } at 47~; General Electric, up ] at 52], and Procter & Gamble, up ] at 79. General Motors rose [ to 36~ in active trading. After a $2.1 billion charge GM announced Wednesday for plant closings, some analysts said the company might have improved its chances for better earnings performance in the future. Utilities attracted buyers looking for stocks well insulated from the effects of recession and likely to benefit from lower interest rates. The five Big Board issues that made new 52-week highs during the session were all electric utilities in the Sunbelt and Midwest - Central & South West, up \ at 44[; Houston Industries, up ] at 36[; Union Electric, up \ at 29[; Teco Energy, up \ at 30~, and Texas Utilities, up | at 38]. Manufacturers Hanover rose 1\ to 17. A company official said his recent remarks had been ``misinterpreted'' as signaling a possible cut in the dividend. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market increased $22.94 billion, or 0.81 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks gained 1.42 to 167.59. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 2.98 to 359.80, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was up 3.02 at 307.02. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market added .76 to 330.60. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 288.90, up 1.11.

DOC.HEAD: Big Board Freezes Salaries; Plans Job Reductions
DOC.TEXT: The New York Stock Exchange board Thursday froze officers' salaries for 1991 and said it expects to reduce staffing by about 8 percent next year. The moves by the nation's largest stock exchange reflect an entrenched slump on Wall Street that has seen thousands of layoffs and a decline in business since the 1987 stock market crash. John J. Phelan Jr., the NYSE's chairman and chief executive, said the early retirement program is expected to reduce the exchange's staff to 1,700 from 1,850. He said nearly 100 jobs have been cut through attrition this year. Exchange officials said about 100 executives would qualify for the early retirement program and the other 50 jobs would be eliminated through attrition. The expected cuts would drop the NYSE's employment to 1983 levels, Phelan said in a statement. The voluntary early retirement plan will offer enhanced pension payments to managers and professionals who are eligible to retire at age 55 and have met certain service requirements by Jan. 31.

DOC.NOTE: EDs: CORRECTS 1st graf to show prices closed lower
DOC.HEAD: Show Little Change
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices showed some early strength Thursday on fighting words from President Bush, but they eventually slid back and closed slightly lower. Light sweet crude oil fell 6 cents to $35.17 per barrel on contracts for December delivery traded on the New York Mercantile Exchange. January delivery contracts were 3 cents higher, while later months closed lower. Thursday's trading session was the fourth straight in which crude seemed to have little direction for what may be its quietest week since Iraq invaded Kuwait in early August. After a series of wild fluctuations in recent sessions that came on any shred of news or rumor, oil has virtually refused to budge much this week, even on stronger-than-usual statements from ranking U.S. officials. ``People are getting a little tired of trading the market,'' said Brendan Dolan, a broker with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. ``They're waiting for substantial news.'' Dolan said some participants were perhaps staying out on Thursday as they waited for a late afternoon news conference from President Bush, who earlier in the day had said Iraqi President Saddam Hussein was perhaps more brutal than Hitler. ``I think this darn market is just trying to read too much into every piece of news it can find,'' said Bob Baker, an analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. ``I've read probably 18 times that Bush said he's had it with the situation. I don't know whether these things help it or hinder it.'' Futures for unleaded gasoline moved higher Thursday. Baker attributed the rise to news that Venezuela, an important producer and refiner of petroleum, might have some supply problems. Contracts for December delivery were up 2.15 cents at 92.30 cents a gallon. Home heating oil fell, as traders responded to figures showing an adequate stockpile. December contracts were off .76 cent at 90.37 cents per gallon. On more-distant month contracts, heating oil prices were also lower at the close, while later contracts for gasoline were mixed. Natural gas fell for delivery in the next four months and rose for delivery in later months. The December delivery contract for natural gas was off 1 cent, at $2.35 per 1,000 cubic feet.

DOC.HEAD: Fell Slightly in Latest Week
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Interest rate figures reported by Donoghue's Money Fund Report are for week ended Tuesday. All other figures are for the week ended Wednesday.
DOC.TEXT: Assets of the nation's 525 money market mutual funds fell by $140.4 million in the latest week to $415.39 billion, the Investment Company Institute said Thursday. The decline in the seven-day period ended Wednesday followed a $424.2 million increase in fund assets the previous week to a record $415.53 billion. The institute originally said fund assets decreased by $673.1 million that week to $414.44 billion but revised the figures later to reflect the inclusion of several new funds. It said that in the latest week, assets of 259 general purpose funds rose by $429.7 million to $147.73 billion, assets of 104 broker-dealer funds fell by $475.9 million to $164.72 billion, and assets of 162 institutional funds fell by $94.2 million to $102.94 billion. The seven-day average yield on money market mutual funds fell in the week ended Tuesday to 7.42 percent from 7.45 percent the previous week, said Donoghue's Money Fund Report, a trade journal based in Holliston, Mass. The 30-day average yield fell to 7.45 percent from 7.46 percent, Donoghue's said. The average maturity of the portfolios held by money funds was 47 days, up from 46 days, Donoghue's said. The newsletter Bank Rate Monitor said its survey of 100 leading commercial banks, savings and loan associations and savings banks in the nation's 10 largest markets showed the effective annual yield available on money market accounts fell to 6.02 percent as of Wednesday from 6.03 percent a week earlier. The North Palm Beach, Fla.-based newsletter said the effective annual yield available on special savings accounts, called Super NOW accounts, rose to 5.06 percent from 5.00 percent. Bank Rate Monitor said the effective annual yield was 7.63 percent on six-month certificates of deposit, down from 7.66 percent the previous week. Yields were 7.76 percent on 1-year CDs, down from 7.79 percent; 7.88 percent on 2{-year CDs, down from 7.90 percent; and 8.03 percent on 5-year CDs, down from 8.05 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Silver Futures Rise Sharply, Extending Rebound from 15-Year Low
DOC.TEXT: Silver futures prices rose sharply Thursday on New York's Commodity Exchange, extending a recovery from 15-year lows, in a rally fueled by technical factors and speculation that interest rates may fall soon. On other commodity markets, gold futures rose; platinum futures fell; crude oil futures retreated; grains and soybeans were mostly higher; cattle futures fell and pork futures were mixed. Silver futures settled 7.6 cents to 7.9 cents higher with the contract for delivery in December at $4.256 a troy ounce. Gold ended $1.60 to $2.10 higher on the Commodity Exchange with December at $383.10 a troy ounce; platinum futures were $2.70 to $2.90 lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange with January at $435.70 a troy ounce. Silver prices have risen 5 percent since Monday, when the December contract touched a 15-year low of $4.05 an ounce amid perceptions of slackening demand and rising supplies of the metal. Analysts said much of silver's recovery reflected technical buy signals derived from chart analysis. Thursday's rally also was prompted by expectations that an anticipated decline in payroll employment and an increase in the national unemployment rate will prompt the Federal Reserve Board of take actions to lower lending rates, said Stephen W. Platt, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in Chicago. The Labor Department is scheduled to release the monthly employment data on Friday. Higher stock prices also supported silver Thursday. The metal's price tends to respond to economic indicators because silver has many industrial applications. Trader Tim Evans of Deak International Inc., said the silver market appeared to have established a trading range between $4.25 and $4.35 an ounce. ``I would guess that in the short term, barring any major events, we're going to have a dull trading-range kind of market,'' he said. Crude oil and heating oil futures ended mostly lower and gasoline futures settled mixed in nervous trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange ahead of a presidential news conference. Light sweet crude oil was .33 cent lower to .03 cent higher with December at $35.17 a barrel; heating oil was unchanged to 1.54 cents lower with December at 90.37 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 1.1 cents lower to 2.15 cents higher with December at 92.30 cents a gallon. Grain and soybean futures prices ended mostly higher on the Chicago Board of Trade, boosted by speculation the United States will grant export credits to the Soviet Union before Election Day. The speculative buying was at least partly fueled by ideas the Bush administration will take the long-expected step of declaring the Soviet Union a most-favored trading partner in a id to help Republican candidates from farm states, said Joel Karlin, an analyst with Research Department Inc., a Chicago-based brokers' advisory service. The most-favored trading designation would make the Soviet Union eligible for credit on purchases of agricultural commodities. The Soviets are believed to be seeking export credits to buy U.S. corn and soybean meal. Wheat futures settled \ cent to } cent higher with December at $2.62\ a bushel; corn was \ cent to } cent higher with December at $2.29} a bushel; oats were \ cent to { cent lower with December at $1.21 a bushel; soybeans were \ cent to 4 cents higher with November at $5.96 a bushel. Cattle futures finished mostly lower on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange in a day of profit-taking after Wednesday's moderate gains. Pork bellies and near-term hog futures rose, buoyed by higher cash hog prices and light slaughter levels. The Agriculture Department estimated a hog slaughter of 304,000 head Thursday compared with industry expectations for more than 318,000. Live cattle futures settled .45 cent lower to .08 cent higher with December at 77 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .15 cent to .50 cent lower with November at 87.35 cents a pound; live hogs were .12 cent lower to .45 cent higher with December at 52.22 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .80 cent to 1.2 cents higher with February at 62.45 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Lotus Announces Merger With Atlanta Software Firm
DOC.TEXT: Lotus Development Corp., trying to fill a gap in its product line, announced Thursday it would buy an Atlanta software firm for $65 million. Lotus said it signed a merger agreement with Samna Corp., which makes word processing products. Samna's software operates with the increasingly popular Windows graphical system made by Microsoft Corp., Lotus' main competitor. Windows makes it easier for computer users to operate personal computers made by International Business Machines Corp. and compatible models. If completed, the deal would mark the first acquisition by Lotus since a proposed $1.5 billion merger with Novell Inc., another software maker, fell apart at the last minute in May. Lotus officials said the $18.84 per-share buyout of Samna would represent an important step for the company, which saw earnings plunge by 63 percent in its most recent quarter. Lotus has been known more for its 1-2-3 business spreadsheet program. But Richard Eckel, a company spokesman, said word processing is the leading segment of the software industry, and Lotus has been largely absent from that area. At the same time, customers have been shifting to software that operate with graphics, he said. Buying Samna will allow Lotus to take advantage of both those trends, Eckel said. Samna will become the word processing division of Lotus, operating from Atlanta. Samna had sales of $10.3 million in the first nine months of 1990, compared with $11 million for all of 1989. But the company posted a $1.2 million loss over the first three quarters, largely due to its transition to the graphics-based system. Lotus had sales of $556 million in 1989. The Cambridge company said it would take a one-time charge of $40 million to $50 million against quarterly earnings when the transaction is completed. It hopes to complete the transaction by the end of the year.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Merrill Lynch VP Charged in Kickback Scheme
DOC.TEXT: A former Merrill Lynch & Co. vice president was charged Thursday with soliciting and demanding payoffs from vendors hired to construct the world headquarters of the nation's biggest brokerage firm. A four-count information, filed in U.S. District Court in Manhattan, alleged Merrill Lynch vendors supplied the executive, Albert Young, with a stretch limousine and chauffeur and helped pay for his country home in Hawley, Pa. Young also allegedly received a $2,900 silver fox coat, a corporate credit card, furniture and cash payments, some of which passed hands in a bathroom and stairwell at the company's offices in the gleaming World Financial Center on the tip of southern Manhattan. The complaint claimed Young received at least $350,000 in cash and other benefits from contractors between 1984 and 1987 in return for promises that they would get business with his employer. ``The information alleges that Albert Young made clear to contractors that payments to him or for his benefit would help contractors to obtain and maintain lucrative Merrill Lynch contracts,'' the U.S. attorney's office said in a release announcing the charges. Young, 61, of Manhattan, pleaded innocent to conspiracy, mail fraud and two counts of tax fraud. He was released on a $250,000 bond. Young was a company vice president who directed construction of the headquarters. He resigned from the firm in September 1988. The case was referred to the U.S. attorney's office after an internal investigation revealed irregularities in the way contracts were awarded, said Merrill Lynch vice president Patrick Murphy, who is in charge of the firm's security. ``We started to get complaints from vendors who were trying to do business with us and from Merrill Lynch employees that something was wrong in the way business was being done,'' Murphy said. ``I think that the complaint covers as much as we know about the activities.'' Two other men, including another former Merrill Lynch vice president, also were charged in the scheme.

DOC.HEAD: Wall Street Firm To Trim Investment Banking Unit
With AM-Layoffs Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Morgan Stanley & Co. said Thursday it was laying off about 6 percent of the investment banking division as rumors swirled on Wall Street of major cuts at another big firm. The reductions come during a prolonged downturn in the financial industry that has seen thousands of layoffs, management overhauls and reductions in major business sectors. Morgan Stanley spokeswoman Jean Andrews said the firm, the second most profitable on Wall Street last year with $443 million in earnings, planned to cut 50 professionals from its worldwide investment banking staff of 800 by the end of the year. The division includes mergers and acquisitions, corporate finance, real estate and capital markets - all areas that have been hit hard by the decline in the securities industry since the 1987 stock market crash. Andrews said the cuts would be across the board, including some senior executives. ``It's in response to the current and expected business environment for the industry,'' she said. ``Managing in this environment, you always look at what resources you commit to these businesses.'' Morgan last week reported a 29 percent drop in third-quarter earnings, to $71.9 million from $101 million in the same 1989 period. The firm attributed the decline to a sharp drop in merchant banking and investment banking activity. The announcement of layoffs at Morgan came as rumors circulated widely on Wall Street that First Boston Corp. was planning a major restructuring to include hundreds of layoffs in coming days. Also Thursday, the New York Stock Exchange said it was freezing executive salaries for 1991 and enacting an early retirement plan in an effort to trim about 8 percent of its staff next year. Earlier this week, Merrill Lynch & Co., the nation's biggest securities firm, announced a major restructuring that is expected to result in hundreds of layoffs. ``If people aren't bringing in business, you're running a loss,'' said Perrin Long, an analyst with Lipper Analytical Securities Corp. ``You can't sit back and say, `Times will be get better, we'll just keep the people.''' First Boston workers said talk has focused on staff cuts of up to 10 percent involving investment banking and back-office personnel to be announced early next week. The rumors also were reported in the Wall Street Letter, a weekly trade publication, this week. A First Boston spokesman said the company continuously reviewed its businesses and some staff reductions were expected by the end of 1990. But the spokesman said talk of specific layoffs on a specific date were ``unfounded rumor and speculation.'' ``It looks like there is a consistent overcapacity vis a vis customer and client demand. We'll shrink,'' said the spokesman, who asked not be identified by name. First Boston, a division of CS First Boston Inc., has struggled because of the slump affecting all of Wall Street as well as large junk-bond ``bridge loans'' to cororate clients that could not be refinanced.

DOC.HEAD: Olsen: No Layoffs For Now, but Tough Economy Makes Things Trickier
DOC.TEXT: Digital Equipment Corp., which has slashed its payroll without laying off workers, may find it more difficult in the current economic slump to induce people to leave their jobs, company president Kenneth Olsen said Thursday. But Olsen also said the computer manufacturer should ``do well'' during a recession, and outperform most of its competitors. Olsen gave the assessment to shareholders at the company's annual meeting. The gathering followed a tough year for Digital, the world's second-largest computer company behind International Business Machines Corp. The company posted its first-ever quarterly loss in July and announced plans to cut its work force by more than 5,000 jobs through a costly voluntary severance program. Previously, Digital had cut its payroll by 3,000 positions. Olsen said the company, with sales last year of $13 billion and a worldwide work force of 123,000, hopes to continue avoiding layoffs. But he added: ``We never have said we won't. Never say never about anything.'' When asked if the gloomy economic climate makes it more difficult to get people to give up their jobs, Olsen said, ``Probably. It turns out normal attrition slows down at bad times.'' Company spokesmen said it is too soon to tell how receptive workers have been to the latest round of voluntary cuts. ``You don't stay in business for 33 years without continuously adjusting your staff,'' Olsen said. ``We always make adjustments. We always will. We plan to be in a fast-changing business forever.'' He said, however, ``I feel confident that we will do well in a recession. That does not mean we will live like we do in good times, ... but that we will do better than most of our competition.'' Shareholders at the meeting repeatedly expressed concern about what Digital is doing to improve its profitability. Digital's stock, which approached $200 per share before the October 1987 stock market crash, lately has been worth about one-fourth that amount. On Thursday it closed at $48.62{ a share, up $1.12{. Olsen said despite recent troubles, Digital is in a strong position, having invested $1.5 billion in new products last year and holding $1.6 billion in cash. Part of the company's new strategy is to change its VAX computers so they can run software designed for the popular Unix operating system. That means companies equipped with both VAX and Unix-based computers could run the same software for all, reflecting a trend in the computer industry toward ``open,'' rather than proprietary systems. ``Unix is fun, exciting,'' Olsen said. ``Our strategy is to do it all.'' Analysts say Digital, like some other Massachusetts computer companies, has been hurt by a slump in the market for midsize minicomputers. Their functions have increasingly been swallowed by powerful desktop machines called workstations. But Olsen disputed the notion of a minicomputer slump, claiming workstations fit within that category. Still, he predicted the computer industry will undergo fundamental changes. ``The world needs very few computer manufacturers, just like it needs very few auto manufacturers,'' he said. Olsen, who founded Digital and is now 64 years old, also told shareholders he does not foresee retiring before he has a chance to see current strategies come to fruition. ``I am more enthusiastic than ever,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: RTC Sells $435 Million in Loans
DOC.TEXT: The agency dismantling failed savings institutions said Thursday it sold $435 million of home equity loans once owned by a failed New Jersey S&L. Banc One Corp. of Columbus, Ohio, paid $444 million for the loans - 2.1 percent more than their face value, the Resolution Trust Corp. said. The portfolio consists of 15,700 loans with average outstanding balances of $27,639. The adjustable-rate credit lines have unused credit totaling $430 million. Ninety percent of the homes securing the loans are in New Jersey and 8 percent in Florida. The loans were previously owned by City Federal Savings Bank of Bedminster, N.J. Once the largest S&L in the state, it was seized by the government Dec. 8. Last month, regulators sold City Federal's Florida branches and nine of its 75 New Jersey offices.

DOC.HEAD: Macy Selling Another Equity Stake
DOC.TEXT: R.H. Macy & Co. Inc. took another step toward reducing its debt burden Thursday, saying it was selling up to $150 million in additional equity to current outside shareholders. The retailer said four shareholders - GE Capital Corp., Loews Corp., Mutual Series Fund and Taubman Investment Co. - have made commitments to buy a minimum of $100 million in Macy stock. The company, which is still paying the bills from a 1986 debt-financed management-led buyout, said in a statement it would use proceeds of the sale to purchase some its outstanding bonds. Macy also sold a 1 percent equity stake in August and used the proceeds to retire $50 million in junk bonds. The company told investors last week it planned more sales of stock to reduce liabilities. Macy said it was ``exploring the possibility of selling a more substantial equity interest to a buyer who shares our view of Macy's value and future.'' The sale announced Thursday did not appear to be the transaction Macy said last week it was contemplating. The retailer has been seeking to cut its debt load since a disappointing Christmas 1989 sent its losses soaring and raised questions about Macy's ability to pay its bills. Last month, Macy announced it was selling its credit operations to GE Capital for approximately $100 million. Macy said the move would remove $1.5 billion from its $4.8 billion debt burden. Macy also told investors last week it was prepared for another difficult Christmas. With a flagging economy and unresolved Middle East crisis, consumers have cut their spending back sharply and the entire retail industry is expecting a bleak holiday shopping season. Macy said it has reduced its inventory, cut expenses and planned conservatively going into the Christmas period. The retailer said last week it had lost $215.3 million in the fiscal year ended July 28, compared with a loss of $63 million in fiscal 1989. Sales rose to $7.27 billion from $6.97 billion the previous year. Besides its flagship Macy stores, located mainly in the East and Texas, the company owns I. Magnin and Bullock's stores in California and the West. It also owns specialty stores including Charter Club, Fantasies by Morgan Taylor and Aeropostale, which are stocked with Macy's private label apparel brands.

DOC.HEAD: IBM Agrees To Pay Computer Disk Maker Undisclosed Amount Over Patent Dispute
DOC.TEXT: IBM agreed to pay a Scottish manufacturer of computer memory devices an undisclosed amount to settle a patent infringement suit, the two companies said Thursday. The settlement could result in other payments by computer makers to the company, Rodime PLC, since its patents cover the most widely used type of internal memory device for personal computers, the 3{-inch magnetic hard disc drive. ``In Rodime's opinion, a large number of the 3{-inch disk drives being manufactured do infringe'' on the patents, said John Altmiller, an attorney with Kenyon & Kenyon in Washington, D.C., who represents Rodime. Neither International Business Machines Corp. nor Rodime would disclose the size of the lump-sum payment IBM made. IBM spokesman Brian Doyle did say that it would have no effect on the company's earnings. As part of the settlement, IBM and Rodime also agreed to cross-license each other's patents covering the disk drives, the companies said. ``Is this a win for Rodime and a loss for IBM? No, we don't think so,'' Doyle said. ``We felt both parties would be getting something out of it. It was a negotiated settlement. Each party believed that the other was using its patents.'' James Swent, Rodime's chief financial officer, said Rodime's primary aim was to gain acknowledgment from the world's largest computer company that Rodime's patents were valid. Rodime, based in Glenrothes, Scotland, also has a lawsuit pending against Conner Peripherals Inc. of San Jose, Calif., a major disk drive maker. That suit was stayed pending the outcome of the IBM suit, Swent said. ``Obviously the two companies will be in discussions and we will have to decide whether we continue the stay,'' he said by telephone from Rodime's U.S. headquarters in Boca Raton, Fla. He added that he expected similar discussions would take place with other makers of 3{-inch disk drives. ``We expect to enforce our patents. We would hope that it would not involve litigation,'' he said. Rodime, which makes its disks in Singapore and Scotland, reported a loss of $41.5 million, including a restructuring charge of $12 million, for the fiscal year ended Sept. 30, 1989, Swent said. Revenue totaled $96 million. The 10-year-old company, whose shares are traded as American depositary receipts on the national over-the-counter market, has reported losses the past three years. Fiscal 1990 earnings have not yet been reported.

DOC.HEAD: Money Supply Mixed
DOC.TEXT: One measure of the nation's money supply rose and another fell in the week ended Oct. 22, the Federal Reserve Board reported Thursday. The Fed said the measure known as M2 fell to a seasonally adjusted $3,318.7 billion from $3,323.0 billion the previous week. An even broader measure, M3, rose to a seasonally adjusted $4,091.0 billion from $4,089.4 billion. The narrowest measure of the money supply, M1, fell to a seasonally adjusted $818.8 billion from $819.2 billion. M1 includes cash in circulation, deposits in checking accounts and non-bank travelers checks. M2 is M1 plus accounts like savings deposits and money-market mutual funds. M3 is M2 plus less-liquid accounts, such as certificates of deposit in minimum denominations of $100,000. In judging its monetary policy, the Fed has indicated it is monitoring the value of the dollar, commodity prices and the difference between short- and long-term interest rates. It also has shifted its attention from M1 to the two broader money supply measures. The growth rate in M2 in the last 52 weeks was 4 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 3 percent to 7 percent. The growth rate in M3 over the past year was 1.6 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 1 percent to 5 percent. The Fed has not set a target for M1 growth since early 1987. For the latest 13 weeks, M2 averaged $3,310.3 billion, a 4 percent seasonally adjusted annual rate of gain from the previous 13 weeks. M3 averaged $4,088.7 billion, up 2 percent, while M1 rose 5.5 percent to an average of $818.7 billion. In other reports: -The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported commercial and industrial loans at major New York City banks rose $469 million in the week ended Oct. 24. -The Federal Reserve said bank borrowings from the Federal Reserve System at the discount window, excluding extended credit, averaged $399 million a day in the week ended Wednesday, up from $346 million the previous week. -The Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis reported that the monetary base, the seasonally adjusted total of member bank reserves held at Federal Reserve banks and cash in bank vaults and in circulation, was $318.7 billion in the two-week period ended Wednesday, down from $318.8 billion two weeks earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Publisher Sells Group Insurance Business
DOC.TEXT: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. announced Thursday it has hired Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. to offer ad be considered. ``We will look to Smith Barney for assistance in developing and implementing a program to maximize value for the company's shareholders,'' John S. Herrington, chairman of the board of directors for HBJ, said in a statement. HBJ said Wednesday that it was selling its small group health insurance business to the Bradford National Life and Lamar Life companies. HBJ will retain its large general insurance division, officials said. HBJ began underwriting group life and health insurance two years ago but never earned a profit. The group business had revenue of about $27 million a year, only about 6 percent of HBJ's total insurance revenue of $456.3 million last year. A sale price was not disclosed. Seventy-eight employees in Orlando will be laid off as a result of the sale, Franklin said. HBJ employs about 800 people in its insurance division and 700 in its Orlando publishing division.

DOC.HEAD: Pratt & Whitney Canada to Lay Off up to 1,200
DOC.TEXT: Aircraft-engine maker Pratt & Whitney Canada Inc. Thursday announced plans to lay off between 1,000 and 1,200 workers, about 12 percent of its workforce. The company cited a downturn in demand for small jets in the United States for the cuts. Louise Boutin, company spokeswoman, said a significant number of orders have been cancelled, but she wouldn't specify how many. Pratt & Whitney Canada employs 9,490 in the Montreal area, Toronto and Halifax. Its sister company, Pratt & Whitney, based in East Hartford, Conn., employs about 39,000. Both companies are owned by United Technologies Corp. Pratt supplies engines for corporate jets, regional commuters and other markets. Its major clients include Boeing, de Havilland and Cessna. The company will decide where the cuts are to be made by early December and departments throughout the company will assess their needs in the next month, Boutin said. ``We have to reduce production starting in January 1991,'' she said. Last June, Pratt eliminated 400 jobs because of cancelled orders. Attrition made up most of the cuts with 134 workers laid off, Boutin said.

DOC.HEAD: Ousted Thrift Chairman Fights $30.8 Million Restitution Order
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS second graf to UPDATE with deadline delayed until hearing is held; PICK UP third graf Paul's response ...
DOC.TEXT: Ousted CenTrust Chairman David Paul, whose swank personal life has come to symbolize excesses in the savings & loan crisis, is fighting a $30.8 million restitution order from thrift bailout regulators, accusing them of ``an Alice in Wonderland approach to due process.'' Paul faced a deadline Thursday for submitting securities to cover the claim from the Office of Thrift Supervision, but his attorneys won a delay until a court hearing is held, probably next week. Paul's response doesn't answer specifics of the government complaint, which charges the head of Florida's once-largest savings and loan immersed himself in luxury ranging from $1,100-a-night New York hotel suites to flown-in European chefs, in order ``to satisfy his insatiable vanity and ego.'' Instead, his attorneys challenged the legality of the Oct. 22 order, saying any alleged misconduct occurred before the bailout law was passed last year. Paul, 51, reportedly is the subject of a federal criminal investigation for his CenTrust reign, but no charges have been filed to date. His attorneys charge the government's demand for the $30.8 million ``imposes unprecedented and oppressive conditions ... in that it purports (without legal authority) to seize all the personal assets of Paul and his family.'' The civil proceedings are ``an Alice in Wonderland approach to due process, where execution comes before the trial,'' Paul's attorneys charged. They asked for a speedy hearing, but U.S. District Court Judge Edward Davis hadn't set one by Thursday afternoon. Thrift regulators went after Paul amid congressional pressure to recoup some of the billions of dollars in losses associated with the S&L crisis. The federal takeover of CenTrust last February is costing taxpayers $1.8 billion. A $15 million legal defense fund for CenTrust officers and directors was described by regulators as a ``slush fund'' that included CenTrust's most marketable securities, leaving the S&L with poorer quality securities. U.S. District Judge Federico Moreno on Wednesday upheld the government's seizure of the fund. Paul's lavish ways have long been a subject of public scrutiny. Regulators already have sold or put up for auction $29 million in paintings, a $233,000 sailboat, Limoges china and Baccarat crystal allegedly bought by CenTrust primarily for Paul's use and comfort. Court papers filed by thrift-bailout attorneys, disclosed for the first time with Paul's filing, document some of the suspect purchases, Paul's use of them and limited regulatory efforts to keep his assets separate from CenTrust funds. For example, in December 1988, CenTrust spent $122,726 to bring six European chefs to Paul's Miami Beach home for a Great Chef's Dinner attended by 56 guests. Another $6,300 was spent for a CenTrust employee's trip to Paris for planning. Paul reimbursed the thrift for the dinner after the Federal Home Loan Bank Board questioned the expense, but the employee's trip wasn't covered. Even with the reimbursement, OTS charged CenTrust's payment ``would at the very least have constituted an unrecorded, unapproved and unsecured illegal loan.'' In another example, in August 1988, CenTrust spent $15,000 on an insurance policy in case one-tenth of an inch of rain fell on a clambake at Paul's Connecticut residence, capping a three-day meeting of CenTrust executives. A $50,000 payout on the policy was to be split by CenTrust and Paul. The thrift paid $53,000 for an executive suite at Joe Robbie Stadium, home of the Miami Dolphins, in April 1989 after CenTrust reported a net operating loss of $19 million in the previous quarter, regulators said. CenTrust's 47-story office tower, a stunning addition to Miami's skyline, featured 24-karat golf leaf ceilings above a $1 million marble staircase, they said. Regulators counted $26,000 in CenTrust spending in December 1985 for Paul's leased Mercedes-Benz limousine in Miami, $40,000 for the June 1987 purchase of a Lincoln-Continental limousine for Paul's use in New York City, plus $7,000 for additional limousine services in 1987. Paul's lodging at the New York's Stanhope Hotel in 1988 generated $45,000 in expenses that pushed the nightly room expense to $1,186. Paul reimbursed CenTrust $97 for $35,000 worth of Tiffany stationery, engraved cards, matches, cocktail napkins and other items used by the chairman or bought as gifts for non-employees.

DOC.HEAD: Cigna's Earnings Drop 92 percent
DOC.TEXT: Cigna Corp. on Thursday reported a 92 percent drop in third-quarter earnings, partly blaming losses in the insurance company's property and casualty division and a reorganization. Earnings totaled $11 million, or 15 cents a share, on revenues of $4.69 billion. That compares with $146 million, or $1.81 a share, on revenues of $4 billion for the same three-month period in 1989. Cigna attributed part of the decline to after-tax charges of $98 million. Consolidating field offices for the property and casualty operations cost $59 million; withdrawing from the car insurance market in Massachusetts cost $22 million; and costs related to the integration of Equicor, which Cigna acquired March 29, totaled $17 million. ``Overall results were unsatisfactory for the third quarter,'' said Wilson H. Taylor, Cigna chairman and chief executive officer. ``Our employee benefits, pension and individual life businesses all were strong contributors to earnings. Property and casualty results, however, continue to reflect inadequate industry price levels,'' he said. The property and casualty division showed a $79 million loss, compared with a $54 million loss in the 1989 third quarter. For the first nine months of 1990, Cigna reported earnings of $211 million, or $2.74 a share, compared with $378 million, or $4.64 a share, in 1989. Revenues for the nine-month period were $13.4 billion in 1990, compared to $11.5 billion in 1989.
